This can be a fun game. It can also be a rage inducing one due to its many, many, quirks. I've played computer wargames since the late 1980s, so trust me when I tell you this game is a mixed bag.

Overall: I've had some fun with this game (763 hours at the time of this writing). I'll keep coming back to it. That said, if you get it, understand its challenges and issues - of which there are many. Having also bought the other games in the series (UA both types), you'll find many of the same issues. If you can work around them, great, but know what you're getting. Finally, there is a substantial body of knowledge on the web about this game in particular. Want to know how to beat a particular mission? There's a how to out there.

Pros: 
1) moving your units around the battlefield is a lot of fun and the units typically are more responsive than what you might see in the TW series.
2) The army management system is interesting and fun, if perhaps unrealistic. In reality, the difference between an 1855 and a 1863 musket was pretty negligible, but hey, whatever. It gives you something to spend the money on.
3) Good tactics are generally rewarded - which I appreciate.

Cons:
1) the LOS system in this game is one of the worst I've seen in decades of playing wargames. I can't tell you how many times I've suffered under artillery fire from batteries that I just somehow can't see. Considering most of these are LOS weapons, that's simply ridiculous. While I get it that terrain plays a role in seeing things, with direct fire systems, if the enemy is shooting at you, you should have a very good chance at seeing them - particularly a big honking cannon belching smoke. 

2) Speaking of LOS, the terrain that would obscure or enable LOS is not intuitive. There are the occasional eyespot points, but mostly not at all. A LOS analysis tool would be useful, but this is a finished game, so that's not going to happen. Mostly, just detach skirmishers (who seem to have better eyes for some reason) and stumble forward until you see something.

3) The opening unit placement in this game is simply horrible and completely arbitrary. Sometimes you have multiple set up boxes and the ability to very carefully place your units, other times, your units are just scattered around the battlefield, many times not even with unit integrity. There is also no rhyme or reason to this. I can detail out the starting locations of union forces at the opening of Stones River, which is ostensibly a Confederate surprise attack, but not the union forces at the beginning of the Mule Shoe, which is a deliberate (planned) assault on a fixed position. Oftentimes, this reaches the level of the absurd, such as at Fredericksburg for the Confederates, where you get a set up box with one brigade, and box is barely larger than that brigade, but the computer gets to determine the locations for all of your units in the following deliberate defenses.

4) The battles are very stilted and do not allow for variations when the player changes history. Hold the line at Seminary Ridge at Gettysburg, completely smashing both Hill's and Ewell's corps? That's ok, you're thrown back on Cemetery Ridge the next day without even the option to stay. Also, see above about unit placement. This happens repeatedly in essentially every major battle, on both sides.

5) On the topic of battles, the timers and flags makes things absolutely silly. 

First, the timers. Sometimes you get extra time, sometimes you don't. Some might argue this shows real uncertainty. Not really. Trust, me I've done this for real, this is not how it works. What this means is that people have to search wikis to see if they need to make the timeline or not, and then adjust accordingly - uncertainty gone. Also, having been in real fights, the absurdity of battles abruptly ending mid volley with brigades in each other's faces is simply ridiculous. 

Now the flags - While I get the point of objectives and key terrain, the way they are implemented is silly. For instance, at Shiloh, the Union can slaughter the Confederate army by the bushel, holding its ground, but let a small cav brigade get around your flank and sit on Pittsburgh landing, you've lost the battle - even if the rest of the Confederate Army is dead.

First, I am a big Civil War guy. I love to read about the time period and events on and off the battlefield. If you share this interest, you, like I, are probably aware of how few games tackle this period and that none of them have ever been great. I would rank UGCW as the best I have played, but it is still a relatively limited game with some unfortunate mechanical flaws. There is no grand strategy, you raise/tweak your army before each battle and then have it out. Your performance in battle makes minimal difference on subsequent battles. Winning the Peninsula Campaign doesnt end the war in 1862 or even change where the next battle happens. You dont need to big brain any battles to be successful, but a basic understanding of the mechanics doesnt hurt. In general you just want to outflank the enemy and rout their units so you attain concentrated fire. Topography does play a role but concentration of fire and getting your artillery in close will nearly always win out. What the game excels at is allowing you to control your units very easily, letting you use units commanded by your favorite generals to lick some rebel/northern scum, and letting you play out all the big battles. Union and Confederate campaigns are 90% the same battles. The game also has some bsic rpg elements for army composition, letting you lel up and select upgrades for your units and comanders. Overall, 78/100 but scratches the Civil War game itch better than anything else. If you area Civil War buff, highly reccommend. If you like strategy games, I think its a fun and polished game but it wont take you down the rabbit hole if you like that complexity.

At first, the game didn't look appealing to me, and I didn't even bother to look at it. But a friend of mine suggested the game to me after I told him that I like games where casualties sustained are carried over like in Homeworld series, Ogre Battle and Fire Emblem. I was still skeptical, but here is my review:

Game-play loop: 9/10
In the campaign, your manage your army and go from battle to battle, managing each brigade up to multiple Corps. You have to manage your officers, Soldiers and their experiences, which are tied to each individual. The battles take between 20-80 minutes. The tactics rely more on positioning rather than the arcade style of Total War. If two units are in perfect cover, they can spend the entire battle firing at each other and barely lose 20% of their Soldiers.

Sound/Music: 5/10
Functional, music is alright, I don't really listen to it. Gun sounds are representative.

Story/Narrative: 8/10
Follows history, but allows tactical freedom and the ability to change history, such as CSA victory at Gettysburg. Or Union victory at Gaines Mill. As a general you are immersed in that you feel your loses, the restriction of funds and the lack of equipment that you may face during the Civil War.

Graphics: 4/10
Functional, nothing special to talk about. Sometimes the units have the wrong animation. Terrain height can also be a bit confusing at times.

Final Remarks: This game is definitely carried by the battles. Its a great feeling when you enter battle with 9,000 Soldiers against the enemy's 17,000 and you end up losing 500 Soldiers while the enemy loses 12,000. All because you use your skirmishers, cavalry and artillery properly. Or when your mission is to assault a location like Malvern Hills, Deploying about 25k against 34k and end up losing nearly half of your army, yet still taking the hill, which is historically inaccurate. It goes to show that positional advantage plays a huge role.

I don't find myself nearly as frustrated with how my units are maneuvering after receiving orders (barring dragoons/mounted rifleman, I wish you could toggle their skirmishing off) as I do with something like Warhammer 3.

This is a RTS civil war game spanning the entire war in campaign mode. There are some glaring problems that dampen the fun however. The worst problem is the AI. Completely horrendous. For example, it overuses the charge action to absolutely ridiculous degrees, even when it would not be a good tactical move. It makes absolutely no difference. A enemy unit being flanked by a few hundred skirmishers will turn their flank to the 1500 men they are fighting on the battle line. Really? This was on normal difficulty, and I have decades of experience with RTS, particularly civil war era games. The sound effects are not where they should be in relation to the men yelling, since the South had its infamous "rebel yell", although it is missing in this game. The two sides sound identical. Shame. I would only pick this up if you are a hardcore civil war buff, but even then you will quickly begin to see what I am describing here. Casual players will likely be disappointed in the poor AI decision making. The game is missing the option for some kind of music during the battles as well, which they put in age of sail, and it was quite good in that game. It is like they didn't even try to make the scenarios playable, and focused too much on trying to be historically accurate. Bottom line: The maps get too "busy" with units to manage if you're not into that kind of fast paced complexity. I enjoyed Sid Meir's Gettysburg so many years ago. That was a far better game IMO, even with less impressive graphics. As well as ultimate general Gettysburg for IOS. There is no random scenario generator to encourage replay in this game, which was a huge disappointment. I stopped playing the campaign after experiencing game breaking balancing and playability issues at Gaines Mill. Enough was finally enough. Age of sail is much better in my opinion. If you are a casual player and do not enjoy a very large amount of units to manage, this might not be a good fit.

[h1] This game has a lot of little features that Total War has failed to implement despite its long list of games that make this really fun despite its simpler graphics.

• Semi-autonomous units. Unit officers will adjust and engage threats on the march and in the field on their own and are not completely brain-dead like Total War units who will just walk into danger without question (don't get me wrong though they still sometimes need help). You can also delegate instructions to division-level officers and they will do their best to complete your orders. The drag-a-path movement feature allows you to create more complex maneuver orders when you want.

• The battles can be really dynamic sometimes. Instead of simply eliminating the enemy or holding a bunch of static objectives the battles often change or develop in real-time. Suddenly, you might find yourself performing a fighting retreat or a glorious assault on newly decided objectives. Reinforcements or ambushes can really shake up the battle. The AI in this game is also fairly aggressive and competent and will attempt to envelop you when possible so you need to always be paying attention to your flanks and for spooky business.

• The campaign-specific features like your career points and unit progression are really cool. I can level up my stats that benefits my army in different ways. You can also equip your units with different weapons between battles. It's pretty cool that I can give my battle-hardened 1st and 2nd Infantry brigades lever-action goodies and watch them go crazy. You can also spend reputation points from winning battles on getting other bonuses but if you spend too much your public support becomes weak.

• Supply wagon system for logistics (ammunition). You need to make sure you not only bring enough supplies for the battle but also know how to position your supplies and when to bring them to your depleted units. In longer battles the need to properly manage your logistics becomes really important.

• The line-of-sight and terrain system is pretty good. Heavier terrain slows you down, provides more cover, and makes you more sneaky. Open terrain lets you move faster and fire more effectively but you are very vulnerable.

Ultimate General: Civil War really makes you feel like a general fighting a war of attrition. Losses endured in one battle will result in your forces being weaker in another battle, as unlike in other strategy games, namely Total Wars, you are not simply engaging in a single battle comprised of several stacks of troops which determine the outcome of the entire war, after which you have the luxury of waiting many turns for your troops to convalesce. The battles come right after one another and you have a limited amount of resources to replenish your army, which means you have to make decisions regarding which units to heal, what weapons to bring onto the field, and even to replenish your units with veterans or rookies, with the latter negatively affecting the efficiency of the unit.

Aside from some AI pathing issues (especially with skirmishers), UGCW is a great game and definitely worth the money.

I like that it challenges the hegemony of the Total War series.   
I like that it's a different arena - the Civil War.   
I like how much content it has, tons of engagements, from skirmishes to battles.   
I like that you can build your divisions and corps and see them expand over time.   
I like that you can outfit units with different weapons, including cavalry and artillery units.  

But there also some things that fall flat:  
It doesn't tell you about many important features, and you suffer unless you explore and find them.
It doesn't tell you, clearly, what many things do. Does "condition" affect accuracy, or morale? I don't know.  
It doesn't give examples of what different weapons or artillery do, or how they will benefit you.
In many cases you have to tinker with things, but your decisions are very expensive, and permanent.

Skirmishers are probably the most powerful unit. Because the dominant tactic is always surround a unit and break their morale. But I didn't realize I could separate skirmishers from units until a few battles in.

So, many battles, you're just lining up and taking it in the teeth - often struggling because your, initially, green units are getting mauled by veteran Confederate units.

Once you start detaching skirmishers and circling around, it's easy to consistently break enemy units, capture and kill artillery, and capture supply wagons.

Because of this, many of the battles start to feel 'samey'.  
Each is challenging enough, and different enough, to draw you in.
However, you will (a) detach skirmishers, (b) race to surround and break your enemy, (c) win, go to camp, replenish your units, (d) do it again. 

I stopped even buying artillery or cavalry units and just massed infantry. I tried various artillery such as howitzers and long guns, and it wasn't clear if they were more useful or not. I bombarded enemy units, not in cover, with 2 howitzer groups, and they took little damage. But then Confederate artillery of unknown guns just nailed my own artillery across the map with pinpoint accuracy.

Massed cavalry is amazing, but expensive, and dies quickly. So again, it tends to be a bad investment.

Somehow, the developers managed to make a game, that is almost perfect.
You have you army, that starts from a small force, to vast multi core army, with brigades, regiments, artillery, cavalry, infantry.
Its amazing, how this game manages to give player so many options to customize and develop his forces, while still remain interesting, engaging and fairly "Balanced" all the way throughout entire campaign.
The battles are pretty realistic in terms of line warfare and fire superiority, your forces "Push" the enemy and gain ground by using an overwhelming firepower, flanking and a bayonet charge. 
Unlike many other wargames, you don't actually have to kill every enemy soldier for a change...

It seems like the game has a lot of respect for all these soldiers and Officers, who fought and died in an American Civil war, and tries to depict history through a series of battles.
As a player, you also have a chance to learn the logistical part of that war.
As the war progresses, you get a chance to learn more about the firearms and artillery pieces. 
All these Springfields, Ordnance cannons, Napoleon cannons, Cavalry carbines...
If you play as a north, you will get a lot of high-end weapons and the amount of recruits will be almost endless
But the South have more skilled and resilient soldiers on their side.
What will prevail?
Industry might of the north or a desperate bayonet charge of the south?

First, a disclaimer: I don't consider myself an expert on the military or battle sims.  I adored Sid Meier's Gettysburg for PC, though, which is one of the first things I ever bought with my own money when I was 14.  I found it incredibly thrilling.  I was going to enjoy this game no matter what for that reason as long as it more or less resembled SMG in the way it played, and it does.  I have lots of small gripes not worth getting into, but by far the biggest problem with this game is that for a "dynamic" campaign it is more or less on rails.  I have only spent significant time on the North campaign and it's incredibly frustrating because I find it very easy all the way until Fredericksburg and after that the game just sabotages you in order to force Gettysburg into being a more or less even fight, and by the time Gettysburg is over you have a tiny army and every battle after that is needlessly difficult.  Overall there isn't really anything dynamic about the way the campaign goes along.  The south was up against it from the outset and many scholars believe that it was Mclellan's unwillingness to take risks and take advantage of the materiel advantage early on that allowed the war to drag on until finally Grant forced the issue and made it a war of attrition.  Obviously it's much more difficult to make a campaign truly dynamic and ahistorical, but I think it could have been done much, much better.  My second biggest issue is the lack of immersive flourishes.  For instance, Sid Meier's Gettysburg had cinematic introductions to each phase of the battle with generals discussing strategy in period language and accents.  I loved that to death and I still remember bits and pieces of it from 30 years ago.  "We lack only for shoes, suh."  I realize that this is a small studio and it's better to do it not at all than poorly, but I would love that kind of thing to be added, even if it's just lo-fi graphics and text like an SNES RPG.  Another great memory I have from SMG is that when you won a battle, they played a yell of your troops and a band would play Dixie if you were the south or the battle hymn of the republic if you were the North.  I still remember what a rush it was and how emotional it was hearing those tunes.  Something like that would be great.  I hope they're working on a dramatically improved sequel.  That said, I greatly enjoy playing this and I wish there were many more like this one.  I would love a modern version of Napoleon's campaigns as well with just the battles, none of the other crap they have in games like total war.

The game is often good, but it has major flaws that deeply hold it back.

One of the biggest flaws is the agonizingly slow pacing of the game. Some might enjoy that, but many of us want to enjoy playtime rather than wait for units to slowly crawl across the field. Another is poor AI, and very inconsistent ability to command the AI - there is a menu that allows you to give AI controls, but you will rarely encounter it because it's only available for certain selections. And, there are no commands that are actually useful - such as for skirmishers to stay in skirmish range and to retreat when approached by infantry. There is also no ability or tendency for units to take cover or to stay in cover. This means you will do a lot of micromanagement, which is neither historically accurate (as a general had little ability to get new information or to send new commands during a battle), nor is it fun. 

Also, some of the defaults in the game are completely mindless, and should have been fixed long ago in alpha and playtesting. One of the biggest is the tiny default size of supply wagons - 2,000, when they can be increased to 20,000. This should have been 10,000 by default; and if you forget to set it when creating a new army, that army is doomed in its first battle. 

Perhaps the biggest flaw is the inability to merge units in the management screen. This means that veteran and elite units will inevitably shrink in size, or will need to be constantly replenished with rookie troops that will lower their skills, or with extremely expensive troops that drain your funds. And, as you get good at the game, the opponent's army size will increase - so you'll have units of 600 infantry up against enemy units of 2,000+.


It is little things like this, which should be easily possible for the developers to improve, which make the game deeply frustrating rather than enjoyable. Do not expect the developers to improve this - they have not done so in the 6 years since the game was released.

This game feels how 19th century battle maps look.

[h3] Perfection In Simplicity [/h3]
There are only four unit types; infantry, skirmishers, artillery, cavalry. Many unit behaviors we are used to micromanaging are automatic; infantry fire and reload on the move when an enemy is in range while they are carrying out a move order, skirmishers hold fire while undetected, skirmishers and cavalry fall back to reload after firing, [b] artillery switch between shot types [/b] and (un)limber, all units turn to face the nearest enemy.

[h3] Tactics and Maneuver [/h3]
Units do not rock-paper-scissors each other. Prevailing in an engagement comes from terrain, flanking, concentrated fire and equipment usage. You do not send unit A to hard counter unit B. [b] 200-500 skirmishers can engage, survive, flank, and delay a 2500 strong infantry battalion. [/b] Rookies in favorable terrain with close artillery support, and flanking skirmishers or infantry can handily beat back hardened veterans. Maps and armies are large enough, upwards of 120,000 soldiers, to allow large maneuvers. Identify the weak flank and send half or more of your army to roll up their sides and rear - if you have time before nightfall. Just like Chancellorsville but this time it's your idea :) Forests, rivers, fields, towns; attack the weakest areas - or send your men to the meat grinder of breastworks, I'm not your dad.

[h3] Your Army - Your Way [/h3]
Control over all levels; battalion, division, corps, army. The units you bring into battles are all your own. How many of each type, how many men in each battalion, how many guns in each battery. Artillery battery with 24-pounder howitzers (shotgun kings) or 20-pounder Parrots (counter battery scythes)? 250 skirmishers armed with long range Whitworths or short range repeating rifles? 1500 veterans or 2500 rookies? Spend your budget on the troops you want... [b] and to replace your egregious casualties [/b] :(

IMO one of the best Civil War games ever made. Played the hell out of Edward Grabowski's The Blue & The Gray when it came out and hadn't played a CW game since. (Missed out on Sid Meier's Gettysburg)

The Good:
The Army Organization choices and Unit/Officer progression are my favorite parts of the game. These aspects allow you to shape the army to realize your vision. Do I want large infantry brigades of mostly green soldiers or should I focus on smaller brigades of battle hardened veterans? You can determine the characteristics of a unit as it ranks up. One infantry brigade can be strong in stamina and melee while another is more efficient and better with their weapons.
On the tactical side the AI is NOT 100% scripted.  When AI units initially deploy to the map  they are static. The opposing force adapts to your choices over the course of the fight, hence "no plan survives contact with the enemy". Battlefield tactics and use of terrain are in full play and work well.

The Bad:
I'm a big fan of sandbox play so...
My least favorite part of the game is when it feels scripted. On the strategic side you have to fight battles in a specific order with a set start/finish date of the war, hence the "historical" feel to the game. A game, if possible, should not only offer the historical battles and an historical campaign, but also sandbox play. Basically you make the strategic choices, i.e. where battles would be fought, whether to be offensive/defensive, do I fight a war of attrition.
Units cannot mix weapons. Not a game breaker, just FYI. An infantry brigade of 1500 soldiers has the same weapon so if your short on a rare weapon your brigade size can only grow as large as the availability of that weapon. Units in the CW sometimes had a mix of weapons i.e. 33% Harpers Ferry M1855, 33% Springfield M1855, 33% Springfield 1861.

And The Ugly:
Scaling.

Enjoy.

The product is a very good mix of playability and the challenges of civil war tactics at the brigade level.  The best thing it does is provide an entertaining and challenging set of battles at the division and corps/multi-corps level, where you control each Brigade.  It is unrealistic in many ways, but this is a sacrifice necessary to provide good and quick entertainment that allows the player to jump right into the tactical fight.  It is really quite fun and can be very challenging as well.  The biggest drawbacks are the lack of realism (if you're looking for that, this game isn't it) and the 100% lack of any strategy in the game.  This is a purely tactical level game that decides what fights you're going to have and just gives them to you.  The player has no say in any kind of operational or strategic decision making.   As long as you understand that this is a purely tactical game, and that it is lacking virtually all level of realism in terms of logistics and management, you can appreciate the relaxing quality of not worrying about anything else as it throws you into the next exciting and challenging tactical battle.  The game is not educational - it's just a lot of fun, so enjoy!

I finally finished both campaigns on Legendary difficulty and seeing I’ve put in over 1200 hours I thought I’d leave my two cents here. As someone who is a huge fan of the American Civil War and grew up playing Civil War Generals 2 and Sid Meier's Gettysburg, this title fulfilled my need for a contemporary Civil War game. There just aren't a lot of titles to choose from and the ones that I have played were lackluster or just mods for existing games such as Empire Total War.  This game combines the best of Civil War Generals 2 and Sid Meier's Gettysburg as well as having that Total War franchise feel to it - but without the bugs (mostly). I can tell that the producer was a fan of both of the aforementioned titles, especially Civil War Generals 2. 

The game starts in 1861 near the beginning of the War and allows you to command a small force to either capture a fort (South) or a small city (North). Depending on difficulty, this is either a trivial first mission (colonel difficulty) or nigh-impossible (Legendary difficulty). You have time frame to capture and hold the objective points. After the first battle you are brought to an army camp screen where you train new brigades and equip them with weapons based on how many you captured from the enemy in the last battle(s) and how many you can afford since you are awarded supplies/cash after every victory. Once you equip your small army, you move onto another small battle and then to the first Battle of Bull Run. In this “Major” battle your recently raised troops form a portion of the army and the rest of the troops are historical units that actually fought in the battle. On legendary difficulty, this battle is far easier than the previous smaller battles. For some reason, there is an extremely long time limit on this battle. Since I had almost infinite time, on both my playthroughs I hunted down and wiped out the entirety of both armies to get as many captured weapons as possible. I more or less followed this strategy until the late-game battles where it was either too costly or not enough time is available. I think there are rough 15-20 major battles that get progressively more challenging, especially as the south. Finally, the last major battle is fought at either Richmond or Washington where you face a horde of enemy troops desperate to defend their capitol.

The Union Legendary campaign, while challenging, was far easier that the southern campaign. As the South, after Antietam you really start to have difficulty in replenishing your troops as you face better equipped and increasingly large union armies. You really have to start playing cautiously and smart as the South as taking too many casualties will be a catastrophic mistake which will snowball and lose you the game. The first playthrough I made it all the way to Cold Harbor but I had to restart because I simply didn’t have enough troops to hold back the union onslaught. The second time around I played conservatively through every single battle and even kept a detailed excel grid of how many losses I suffered and how many casualties I inflicted. I managed to grind my way through the last few battles and made it to Washington with an army of over 100,000 troops which I was ecstatic about. However, even though I managed to capture the city I didn’t realize that I then needed to HOLD the city including all the forts in which I just captured. I ended up quitting and I almost quit and uninstalled the game because my troops had taken horrendous casualties taking these forts and I now had to face an army of OVER 200,000 union troops! I was outnumbered 4 to 1!! Finally (yesterday) I managed to calm down and ended up saving the game six separate times during the battle to minimize casualties to I could then be prepared to fight the endless waves of Union troops. After several restarts and over ten hours of grinding and min-maxing, I barely held on the city and finally won the south campaign. What a ride! I will say that I got so frustrated so many times that I had to quit for weeks or months at a time. I almost gave up on winning as the South on Legendary because it was just too hard to replenish causalities, especially in my veteran brigades. In hindsight I would say that this is a very necessary problem for the south based on history and adds a great deal of immersion. 

The Union Campaign is difficult early on as you struggle to take positions that are heavily entrenched. Oddly enough though, I think the hardest battle on the Union side was Malvern Hill where you face a horde of Confederate soldiers who rush and quickly overwhelm you. Only timely reinforcements kept me from losing this battle as I clung on for dear life. The latter battles become easier as you slowly but surely amass greater number and superior firepower. The union artillery is especially effective and as you gunners gain experience they can tip battles in your favor with a few rounds of deadly canister shot. By the time the last battle at Richmond came I had a massive army of almost 200,000 troops and I simply grinded down my foe whom I outnumbered by almost 50,000. General Grant would be proud!

With all of that said, this is a great game. I think this is probably on of only five games that I’ve put over 1000 hours on in my life. I found brigadier General difficulty to be too trivial and Legendary difficulty to be too challenging at first, so I decided to “get good” and figure out how to win on Legendary. I would say in terms of challenge this game is S Tier. I had to restart battles and even campaigns several times because I either took to many casualties, got overwhelmed, or lost valuable units that got stranded and either shattered or surrendered. 

The game is not free of bugs, there is this super-annoying one where enemy cavalry will become un-targetable and just run through your lines and end up reforming in your rear and start wreaking havoc. There is another one where feeling troops will get stuck in rivers and sit there taking shots until they shatter. The AI itself is fairly competent and will attack weak points but is prone to over-committing and doing these “highland charges” where entire divisions will just run at you en-masse and take massive casualties if you know how to counter it. Another “bug” is where if you scale your troops down to smaller brigade sizes the enemy armies won’t be as large. Personally, I tried to exploit this at first but then thought it was too much cheese. It also lowered the enjoyment factor as I like to fight massive armies and capture lots of weapons. The AI units also tend to stand out in the open and take fire instead of seeking cover.

Overall, this is a solid game that has kept me entertained for the last five years. I would recommend it to anyone who is either a fan of the civil war or a fan of the horse and musket time period. It’s FAR superior to Empire Total war as the units don’t bug out on terrain and fire when you tell them too (for the most part). The Legendary difficulty is no joke and was one of the most challenging RTS experiences I’ve ever had. It was extremely fun and rewarding although it was also very frustrating at times. I’d give this game a 4.5/5 and would highly recommend it. Be warned though, it’s addictive and might keep you up late at night!

The Civil War was fought in 10,000 places, from Valverde, New Mexico, and Tullahoma, Tennessee, to St. Albans, Vermont, and Fernandina on the Florida coast. More than 3 million Americans fought in it, and over 600,000 men, 2 percent of the population, died in it.
American homes became headquarters, American churches and schoolhouses sheltered the dying, and huge foraging armies swept across American farms and burned American towns. Americans slaughtered one another wholesale, right here in America in their own cornfields and peach orchards, along familiar roads and by waters with old American names.
In two days at Shiloh, on the banks of the Tennessee River, more American men fell than in all the previous American wars combined. At Cold Harbor, some 7,000 Americans fell in twenty minutes. Men who had never strayed twenty miles from their own front doors now found themselves soldiers in great armies, fighting epic battles hundreds of miles from home. They knew they were making history, and it was the greatest adventure of their lives.
The Civil War has been given many names: the War Between the States, the War Against Northern Aggression, the Second American Revolution, the Lost Cause, the War of the Rebellion, the Brothers' War, the Late Unpleasantness. Walt Whitman called it the War of Attempted Secession. Confederate General Joseph Johnston called it the War Against the States. By whatever name, it was unquestionably the most important event in the life of the nation. It saw the end of slavery and the downfall of the southern planter aristocracy. It was the watershed of a new political and economic order, and the beginning of big industry, big business, big government. It was the first modern war and, for Americans, the costliest, yielding the most American fatalities and the greatest domestic suffering, spiritually and physically. It was the most horrible, necessary, intimate, acrimonious, mean-spirited, and heroic conflict the nation has ever known.

I enjoy war RTS like this; it's simple as you have pretty much just a few units to choose from without a lot of complications.

That said, inside of a campaign or custom battle, you can choose your commanding officer(s), choose the weapon for your particular unit (infantry, cavalry, artillery or skirmishers) and you can "level up" each commander after a certain amount of experience, choosing different perks for each commander.

Being able to re-name the commanding officers helps on a large-scale battle so you can remember which perks you have chosen and utilize to your best strategy/tactics.

This is a major step from the previous version of this game.

Drawbacks:

- It needs more maps.  like, a LOT more maps.
- For "custom" battles, I wish I could save my set of units for future use instead of having to slowly (re)create each one
- Having an "auto-balance on/auto-balance off" feature would be nice so you can match armies versus 3:1 or 4:1 odds
- Flanking/rear - as another user posted, if YOU are flanked/rear attacked, this matters ONLY for YOUR units.  If you do this to the computer, this doesn't seem to do much.  I found I can gang-up on one enemy unit straight-on and get better results than attempting to sneak a few units around the rear; getting the enemy in a cross-fire doesn't do a thing.
- I've noticed that friendly fire doesn't seem to be much of a thing in this game; I had six artillery units pounding a few enemy units . I charged in, my units barely took a scratch while the enemy was being slammed with artillery shells.  I would think that, in the real world, such would not be possible, let alone a simulation.  

Overall, however, I've put in a lot of hours in this game in the past two weeks alone.  As stated, I like having simple units sometimes: guns and big guns.  No snipers, no tanks, no space lasers, etc.  This is simple ground warfare with human units versus armor/remote missile strikes/special attacks.  This requires you to use strategy to plan your attack and tactics to adjust on the battlefield.  The campaign allows for growth and development.  Learning curve is low, will keep you busy for a long time.  

Replay value?  Hard to say over time.  If I can find downloadable maps/DLC, that might make the game higher on the food chain for replyability.

I first played this game a few years ago and honestly didn't like it. It just did not seem to portray Civil War battles well. So I picked this up again last week and have had a hard time to stop playing, I'd play the night through if I could.

To play this game well you have to learn to use combined arms (mostly infantry, skirmishers and artillery) tactics. You need to know the strength of your units and their weaknesses. The same applies to weapons, some older muskets are quite unreliable for firing, but useful in melee, but you might want to give your veterans rifled muskets instead for longer range fire. The same for artillery, use your old brass 6 pounders at point blank range, but keep your 3 inch ordnance rifles further back, maybe try and knock out enemy artillery. In addition to knowing your own units and equipment you also have to be aware of terrain and the aims of the battle you are fighting, not to mention enemy forces. It won't do to just launch a series of frontal attacks against a well defended enemy. Use cover, draw enemy fire on your skirmishers while you pound the enemy line with artillery. Once they are softened up move the regular infantry in to see what you can do. Well, that is assuming a relatively simple enemy defence. If they are really fortified it might be better to try and flank them. And of course you will not always be attacking, there will be meeting engagements where you have to rush your forces to get to better ground, but rush too much and they may gee exhausted and be unable to hold against a determined enemy. Other times you will be defending. Really lots of variations but a good tactician should be able to master most though sometimes it might be better to fight a draw rather than take too many casualties.

There are also some downsides to this game. While the game basics fit the period well there are a number of un-historic elements. For instance the size of brigades, the organisation of divisions and corps. In the end, even if you are playing as the Union you will probably be organising your forces along lines used by the Confederates, just because they are most efficient in game. Command structure could also be better reflected in the game as division leaders are highly abstracted and corps commanders' don't seem to have any real skills like brigade leaders. I've mostly played the two campaigns so far and one thing that I find to be badly designed are names for non historic battles (the small engagements with specific missions in between the large historic ones. Yes, raiding a convoy is a mission, but don't call the battle Convoy Raid, that just takes part of the immersion. Also the intelligence reports are badly written, not at all like actual correspondence of the time. 

This is a rather simple game that most anyone can play, but to play it well you have to learn tactics as commanders at the time did. This is also, at least usually, a fast game, some of the campaign battles only taking half an hour, while larger ones might take two or even more.

I am a bit sceptic for the next iteration of the series portraying the American War of Independence, mostly the new strategic play. A game on the Napoleonic Wars, or maybe the Seven Years Wars in Europe in this system would be interesting as well.

Beautiful, fun and time consuming. This game is great for history buffs or people who just enjoy strategy games. Personally I do have a lot of fun playing this game but I will say it is flawed. The game mechanics and how the game functions during campaign are some of the larger issues I found personally. 

     For instance, flanking is huge in this game like in many other strategy games but the area in which a unit gets flanked is huge. On many occasions I have had units rout from "flanking" when they are only being hit from the front (usually when the unit is being attacked by cavalry). 

     In addition to this skirmishing lines will refuse orders. In almost all my battles I will make large lines of skirmishing units in order to attack or hold a position in order to slow the enemy advance but when order to engage a unit my skirmishers will fallback to reload. This gets to be very annoying especially when I don't want to put them in the "hold" mode so they can rotate and engage another unit. 

     Other flaws within the game mechanics is how  on harder modes if the AI has a number advantage they will just constantly charge your units until they take the objective. In campaigns for the South you are almost always at a disadvantage and to be constantly charge with no regard for true strategic maneuvers is just tedious, repetitive and discouraging. 

     Now, some of these problems would be easier to dismiss if I could deploy my army exactly how I wanted. I appreciate being able to choose a few units at the start of a mission but then to just throw the rest of my army into over stretched or not so favorable positions gets to be upsetting. I believe if in a campaign mission the player should be allowed access to the full map, deploy their army as they so desire and time their attacks as they see fit. The player shouldn't be restricted to such small squares just for the map to open and leave gaps in the line or for the mission to continue into another day and bring you into a disorganized mess of what was your army. These simple flaws within the game play really take a toll on how you can play. These issues often prevent me from being able to try new armies or replay a campaign altogether. 

     If you seek a semi-historical game with an almost Napoleonic style of strategy then by all means I encourage you try this game. This game is unique and offers more detail than many others and is still undoubtedly one of the best strategy games out there.  However, I must emphasize and warn how the AI and in game mechanics may foil your plans or discourage you from continuing.

In some ways it's one of the greatest RTS games I can remember. Very satisfying (caveat below!). It's not the execution, but the idea that makes it great. Scale is perfect, building your army makes each campaign different. But that's when the game works. But even with years of updates and many more years of extensive modding, the AI, and the event triggers, etc. are still often times broken or buggy, seemingly hardcoded to maximize misery.

Example 1: Don't save your game during battle! It "resets" the AI when you load it, meaning they might throw away their entire army on a mass charge up a fortified ridge, turning an interesting battle into a boring cleanup on aisle 5, or magically get their morale and stamina reset, allowing them go from helplessly routing off the map, to taking on multiple brigades of your at once single-handedly, as they turn and face their demons and win the war, all in the blink of an eye. This doesn't happen normally when playing a battle... except for phase changes in battles and after loading a save, which unfortunately, happens a lot.

Example 2: You've taken the final victory point! The enemy is 95% destroyed and you're breaking out your victory cigar. Except you needed to take the victory point  1 hour before the battle ends, and you took it 56 minutes before it ends. So, actually, you lose and you have to re-fight the entire battle if you don't want to mess up your entire campaign. Or not! Maybe you take the victory point and the battle is half over, with tons of time left on the clock, except you win this time! A solid NO for me. The game has been out for years. I played it when it first came out and could not believe how bare bones it is compared to a full-fledged A-list title. Sure, this is not an A-list title, but let me give you my reasoning. 

I am in my 50's. I've played strategy games for 40 years, including the 1/2 inch counter boring old board games like Squad Leader, PC games like Total War (all iterations). I would consider myself a grognard of strategy games. I also have some minimal standards. 

Put all this into perspective when I give you ONE game breaking flaw in the game. In the first scenario, you are to take a town. You order a unit of men into some buildings which supposedly give 200% cover. Moments later you see them dropping like flies because half of them are not in the building and are getting shot to pieces. The flaw in the game is you cannot change the unit formation. A unit of soldiers is a rectangle and the building is square, so some of the men don't fit. Wow that is just absolutely stupid and alone breaks the game for me. I cannot use any actual strategy. 

There are historical attempts at naming units, commanders, weapons, and so forth. But that's where the realism stops. Nothing in the game is realistic and it is all prescripted so the time is always rushing you into positions you have not pre-memorized. It's total nonsense from a tactical standpoint. I cannot scout with cavalry for even two minutes without wasting half the scenario's time limit. I.e. the developers want you to rush forward and not think about it too much.

Growing up, I played a lot of Sid Meier's Civil War Collection (Gettysburg, Antietam, and South Mountain).  I was disappointed to not find in on Steam and gave this a try.  The game has a similar feel while being unique in its own right.  Organizing your forces down to the type of firearms and artillery pieces, assigning corps to different areas on the battlefield, and the map variety make it a breath of fresh air with plenty of replay value.  The only complaint that I have is that victory or defeat in certain battles in the campaign only shape the number of friendly and enemy forces that participate in the final battle.  It is not nearly as dynamic or plays off of the fun "what ifs" as Sid Meier's Gettysburg did (what if the Confederates took Cemetery and Culp's Hills on the first day of the battle?  What if the Confederates attacked the Round Tops on the third day?).  Regardless, there is enough tactical depth to satisfy the nostalgic craving from my childhood, and I recommend this game for those wanting a break from other real-time strategy games.

Don't get if you like history. I want to point out if you are wanting a History game to play battles in this is not one of them. The first Union battle, Battle of Philippi, put you up against 3.5k Confederates while you have 2.5k. Historically Battle of Philippi the Union had 3k and the Confederates had 800. Potomac Fort as far as I could find did not have a battle outside of the naval engagement and it ended indecisively. So the game saying "Experience the bloodiest period of U.S. history" is really pushing what it means to experience history. Yeah its no fun having 2 minor engagements to start the game where its basically a cake walk.

AI is also pretty bad. You know I can take my time engage in an artillery Exchange. Then enemy will shell me with 1 or 2 artillery in which my men are in 100% cover and all together lose about 100 men, The enemy with me shelling 3+ in no cover will lose 80 men across the same number of regiments that I have.  I think the most annoying about the AI, on normal where no buffs exist, the Enemy will not break. I will have superior numbers, have my flanks cover and do a general charge, and all of my forces get routed. I can even take out the general there seems to be no penalty on the enemy. I would expect that if nothing else the enemy would suffer like a organization penalty like maybe their units move more sporadically or are less effective chasing your men down.

I think my last complaint is the controls. I try to box select and I end up moving my unit. Or I will just be unable to select units at times that aren't retreating or fleeing. I also can't form "solid" defensive lines. What I mean by that is for the most part is you can tell your units where to go but its really difficult to move 1 unit. So I end up moving two or three just because its less tedious. If I want to move Williams I should not have to do that annoying left click drag movement, That is what I select my units with why would I do it. I am ngl I did a test on Picket Charge custom battle as both Union and Confederate, Put all my units on AI and just sate back and watched the battle. I watched several instances where the AI inflict a Flank from Artillery bombing. I have also witnessed how the AI will turn to intentionally inflict a flank and then go back to who ever they were shooting. I am not even talking about a turn flank I mean we will have to lines shooting at each other the AI slightly turns inflicts a flank and turns back, but the unit turning doesn't receive any flanking. in these same scenarios I have also seen a regiment of 2100 will lose 800 men in 76% cover (in a defensive position you put your unit into) and gets routed from a charge, but the enemy with 1 artillery and and a force 1600, will lose 400 men in 50% cover (on a open piece of field with either end of the regiment dipping into wood areas) and would not only route the initial Regiment charge but would route a force 1000 coming to help the initial regiment with 1 volley from the infantry.

As awful as this is to say, I believe the best way to play this is with a mod or the Trainer and yes there are other games Like Hearts of Iron that really are better with mods, but those games have a solid foundation to build off of. This seems like it was almost made to be played with a mod in mind and it baffles me there isn't even a workshop for it.

I will say the game is not bad, just never play off of casual and don't get your hopes up on playing relatively historically accurate engagements. If you are wanting fun line battles and very slow movement being careful of everything you do well this is the game for you, but just realize AI is given some extra benefits and some benefits of the doubt you do not get on normal and that controls might actually fight you at times. So I can't recommend but I can't not recommend. 

It is really up to you, I have played more broken games like the Tom Clancy Endwar but I had/have more fun in those than playing this since the AI doesn't feel like its cheating.

Edit: I feel like it would be good if I added, I have fond memories of a strategy game based on the civil war when you still for the most part bought these type of games in a box and had to install with a disk, and I was hoping this would live up to that.

Ultimate General Civil War has some neat ideas, it fits into a space between games like Warcraft 3 where each mission is entirely or almost entirely self contained from the rest and you start with preset stuff every time, and games like Total War, where the perspective is so zoomed out you're basically god micromanaging every aspect of an entire country. Here you command and manage an army and all the ins and outs of it, but that's it. You don't move a chess piece around the map deciding which particular part of the south you feel like burning down that day, you're given a set of missions that you can choose which order you do them, usually with a larger battle meant to cap off that part of the campaign, and then you're given another set. Instead all of the big long term strategic decision making is focused on how you organize your soldiers.

You have control over how large you want your regiments to be, whether or not they're regular infantry, skirmishers, cavalry, or artillery, what specific weapon they use, who commands the regiment, what perks they get, whether or not you want to staff the unit with expensive veterans or cheap rookies that lower its stats, even what the unit is named when you move it around the battlefield. Your army and what you do with it is persistent, and only rarely do units that aren't yours show up for you to control. This leads to fun moments during missions when reinforcements show up, and its YOUR guys who arrive, not some nobodies spawned just for that mission who will never be seen again. Similarly, for the larger battles that take place over multiple days, the opposing side's regiments will persist as well, and if beaten to the point of being ineffective or outright annihilated, will not be replaced.

Battles can end in draws, or defeat, and the game keeps going, because the long term campaign is about managing the war instead of winning every single battle (though you can do that). How well you do effects your reputation, which can give your soldiers a morale boost or penalty depending on how low or high it is, and can let you commission more gear from the government without paying cash for it. The game is less about "WE NEED TO WIN THE WAR TO SAVE/DESTROY AMERICA" and more about "Man, I gotta do good or I'll lose my job!".

Theres some clunky parts as well however. Sometimes when my soldiers were routing they froze in the worst possible place instead of running and got shredded. I would see regiments ready to fire instead be stuck in an infinite reload while getting shot. Cavalry is effective when you could micromanage it but somewhat frustrating to use as it would move without being ordered. You can't swap weapons between units, so unless you have enough guns or cash to completely replace the weapon for every single soldier in that unit you're out of luck.

I give it a tentative recommendation: I liked it once I got used to it, but it might not be what others are looking for.

I like this game but several of its systems make it a slog. 

Firstly the morale system is 100% broken. You get flanked and lose 40 soldiers and your men flee. You flank the enemy on two sides, killing 200 in a single volley and the enemy stands and gives you a volley where your men then flee. Its infuriating. You try and  use tactics to win the battle but the broken system means the ONLY way to win is to have numerical superiority at EVERY point to kill more enemy then you lose, and then pray even then your men dont flee. I have had battles where I have killed 3 enemies for every one of mine and yet still almost lost because of the morale system (This was when playing as the Union too so it makes even less sense for the confederates to take that kind of casualties and still almost won). If there is a 1 vs 1 you WILL lose because your men will break and flee. I have seen a troop of 200 skirmishers in the open rout a brigade of 2000 infantry that were in cover. Thats insane. 

Second big issue is the invisible enemy troops. You will take long range artillery fire, sometimes at the start of the battle, even though you cant see the enemy. Massive units of thousands will come out of the woods out of nowhere, just meters in front of your men. Add to that the broken morale system and you get a surprise melee charge that routs your superior force. You cant plan a battle, you just react to the battle. Which I guess is somewhat accurate to real life, but this isnt a realistic battle simulator. There has to be the ability to see the enemy before they are literally on top of you. As shown by the fact the enemy can see you at the start of the game, clearly the AI has the advantage there. 

This game is so close to being awesome. But the totally broken morale system alone makes some battles essentially unwinable. If I wanted to lose battles my side actually lost in real life I would join a reenactor troop. If I lose because of bad strategy fine. Its when I lose only because of a broken core gameplay mechanic that it becomes an issue.

This is one of the great strategy games I've played ever. It actually allows you to use army-level tactics unlike most real-time game. It's a bit tough to get started because the roles are not clearly explained but just remember:
- Use large infantry formations as your main element for holding positions or pushing back the enemy. Don't make them walk about too much, just use [spacebar] to hold position so they can reload and let the opponent have it.
- Use skirmishers in forest cover to snipe at the enemy formations and generally increase their level of friction.
- Use cavalry in open terrain to chase down the enemy and inflict heavy casualties once they start routing.
- Keep your cannons well back and bombard the large enemy formations continuously.
- Keep a supply wagon moving between the lines to reload ammo.
- Don't bother chasing down the enemy general - it accomplishes nothing much.
- And above all, draw the enemy formations into traps by letting them move into a river, say, and then shoot the hell out of them while they're stuck and floundering down there.

Hope that helps! Now go win that war!

Yo! Not doing some super comprehensive appraisal of this game here, I’ve just realized how this game is the PERFECT game for a very particular kind of situation. 

If you are for some reason on the road and stuck with some garbage laptop that you use for work or something, and if you’re a hardcore RTS gamer, THIS GAME IS PERFECT! 

Even on some 2018 windows workbook with like 2 gb RAM, integrated graphics, and an i5, you can run this game at max settings. On top of that, the graphics are delectable. They’re like one of those old civil war paintings. The musket fire plumes look delicious and all the little hills and trees are so impressionistic. You can just pause sometimes and marvel in awe at all the battlefield chaos, cannons cannons lobbing ordinance atop a ridge line from 400 yards out, then the loaders getting around the front and stuffing the barrel, infantry caught up having formed some jagged frontline after they’ve responded to and attempted flanks on flanks, some bayonet brawl between thousands of troops in the center of the map as they’re clawing their way out of a valley that’s turned into a kill hole… spectacular. 

The sound really cranks things up, the rifles, cannons, and muffled shouting of troops all harmonizing in a quite morbidly comforting wash of Civil War ASMR. The music is sort of just stereotypical Civil War violins and stuff, so it suffices. 

The reason I said it’s for hardcore RTS players or Grand Strat players is because this game is deep af. I still haven’t figured it all out. Infantry do the vast majority of the work, with their main purpose being to establish the line of engagement with the enemy. You clash as far up against the opponent as you can get, then reninforce those flanks until you’re strung out. Then you identify bottlenecks and choke points, prodding at where the enemy is weak or routing, and reinforcing lines of yours that are getting pressured . It’s a thrilling push and pull. 

Artillery can seem lackluster, but you gotta get close with it. Cavalry are much more realistic in their utility when comparing their role in, say, the total war games. A cavalry unit committing to the wrong charge at the wrong time will disappear in seconds. A cavalry unit executing the perfect charge at the perfect time will take care of most problems within the blink of an eye. 

The scale of combat is unique, with you commanding over vast ranges on multiple fronts, often with little sense of battlefield control or cohesion. A division may be combatting enemy presence that is far west of the main opposing force, approaching eastbound, meaning that you’re commanding troops moving in the opposite direction of the main enemy far behind their lines. Kinda weird but also fun.

This is a great army and tactics management game, you can align your troop makeups to match your personal style, though I would always recommend bringing infantry with artillery, and then you can equip those units with different firearms, and decide whether or not to bring supply wagons to sustain ammo reserves mid battle. 

It's a difficult, if ultimately enjoyable game, and the company seems focused on their ultimate admiral series, which I have to assume is also good, but I'd like them to take this concept and bring other conflicts like the crimean war, the franco-prussian war, and even the napoleonic conflicts into this type of game experience, and honestly I wouldn't mind them meshing it with ultimate admiral to bring it all together.

This game however remains a fantastic way to re-enact the civil war, you can either try to repeat or, improve, the twists of history as the Union, or you can challenge yourself to a test of survival as the rebels, both offer challenging gameplay scenarios, with a compelling level of personalisation for your army corps.

[b]Easily my favorite Civil War game and will always be one of my all-time favorite games.  Despite its age, it still is a lot of fun to play.[/b]

Fairly straight-forward point, click and/or drag interface for units with basic commands for each individual unit.  It can be kind of difficult at the Major General level for most players but Colonel level will provide a challenge for most beginners while not being overwhelming.  It is probably easier to play the Union side since they generally have more access to troops, weapons and gold.  The Confederate side has better generals and more experienced units to make up the difference but you need to preserve your army during the course of the game to have much chance near the end - sometimes a draw is okay (in the campaign) if it means preserving your army for another battle.  Just don't lose too many battles or you will lose your command and end the campaign.

I also enjoy the control and flexibility in how you get to put together and equip your army between battles.  There are already some excellent resources out there so I won't discuss them here.

[u]Here are a few tips:[/u]
-- [b]Don't let your units take fire from their rear or flanks[/b] - it doesn't take much to rout troops that are being flanked especially if they lack experience (which usually means lower morale and endurance).  Conversely, [b]hit your enemy's flanks hard as much as you can and try to roll up their line.[/b] 
-- [b]Use your skirmishers often [/b]- They have many uses:  better visibility of enemy movements, can slow down a much larger enemy force especially in difficult terrain which can buy you time or help protect your flanks, as a meat shield when charging enemy positions (I lead with the skirmishers and let them soak up the bullets with the full brigade right behind them).
-- [b]Artillery can be devastating or ineffective depending on what you use and how you use it[/b] - howitzers and Napoleans are very effective at short range against targets in the open but much less against units at a distance or in cover; parrot guns are great a longer ranges against enemy artillery but don't do much against troops at close range.  Artillery uses ammo fast so be sure to only fire when effective.
-- [b]For campaigns, preserving your army for the long haul is key. [/b] Don't waste troops if you already meet the victory conditions. 
-- [b]Veteran troops are expensive to replace so know when and how to use them.[/b]

I could go on and on but these few points are something to keep in mind from the start.

Have fun!

This game feels like what the combat from the Total War series ought to be.

Your task in each battle is to capture or defend key positions within a time limit. This shapes where the action is concentrated and forces one side onto the offensive. Terrain features like forests, farmhouses, and river crossings affect how the units move and fight. You will usually have to plan your assault or defense around local strong points, like a hill dominating a stream crossing or a forest's edge overlooking open fields. This type of 'battle planning' feels more fun and realistic than the typical TW (total war) battle.

In battle, you have full control of each deployed brigade in your army, except when they are wavering/routing. Brigades that do rout will always eventually recover (no shattered retreat status) unless they get totally destroyed or captured. Your brigades are mostly infantry, but you will also have brigades of artillery, cavalry, and skirmishers/snipers. You usually choose a few brigades to begin the battle with, and receive more of the army later as reinforcements. Like in TW, you give commands to each unit (go here, attack these guys, face that way), and they will follow your commands as long as they are able. You actually get a few more commands than TW gives you, and they are really good additions. First, you can draw a specific path for a unit to take from A to B just by dragging the mouse. This lets you avoid hazards or execute flawless flanking maneuvers. Second, you can fall back by pressing a button. This has your unit retreat a short distance while still facing the same direction - returning to safety while avoiding the massive morale impact of an attack in the rear. Third, you can detach skirmishers from infantry brigades. This creates a brand new, fully controllable small unit that is perfect for scouting and harassing the enemy, at the cost of weakening the original brigade. 

The addition of these new commands gives a lot of depth to gameplay. For example, you might detach skirmishers and send them across a river to the edge of a forest to scout for enemies. When the enemy is spotted, you can begin to concentrate your brigades to defend the area where the enemy will be, before you are already under fire. You have your skirmishers fire a volley at the advancing enemy, then fall back into the dense forest before they are hit with return fire. Keeping your skirmishers at the flanks of your main force, you screen against possible flank attacks as you move your cavalry into position to flank the enemy or go behind their mainline in pursuit of undefended artillery. In the middle of your line, the enemy has concentrated their force and a charge has broken your line. They rush to exploit the opening, and you must decide whether to pull the entire force back to a new defensive position or attempt a counterattack to plug the gap. 

My only real gripe is that in career mode you are restricted to the real historical battles of the civil war - so after 2nd Bull Run, the next battle will always be Antietam regardless of who won. The developers have painstakingly modelled every major battle after the real terrain and features of the historical battlefields, so I get why they couldn't do this for imaginary battles too.

Pros:
+ Really fun tactical battles, finds a good balance between challenging enough and  allowing success. 
(I played my first playthrough on "Easy" and am playing the normal difficulty campaign right now - am not a hardcore gamer)
+ Good Level design with goals and strategical points to fight for. I especially like that you can draw battles, when both sides reached part of their goals.
+ Historically accurate for a computer game, contains the original generals who fought the war and recreates the battles of the civil war,  the weapons used are accurate as far as I can tell. Learned a lot about it during my playthrough
+ Good amount of content for the money. There are enough campaign battles, some lasting several days and vast maps, some small skirmishes. Bought it for about 14,- € on sale and its worth it easily
+ No major bugs or crashes 
+ Good campaign where your army grows and battles effect the strength further down the road 
+ Good audio (fitting music, voicing of orders accepted and such, creates good atmosphere)

Cons: 
- Sometimes unit management can be annoying (when they block each others lines, fall back into the wrong direction...). But those are minor issues. Game mechanics work well overall
- It is not a sandbox game. The battles are mostly scripted and a timer limits the possibilities of creativly finding ways to solve a problem - sometimes you just have to stick to the plan.
- Relativly few embellishments, straightforward (like a startup or winning video, reactions of poltics and society to the outcome of your battle, not real tutorial)

All in all, a game which made me feel the devs really liked their project and put a lot of thought and effort in it. Well done.

From what I've seen from play throughs and heard from other players, the enemy team generally matches your force no matter what.

For example, if I'm the South and I bring 10,000 troops, the North will bring 30,000 troops. If I were to bring 50,000 troops on the same battle, the North will bring 150,000 troops. (Generally speaking).  This punishes the player for managing their Army well, good tactics, and negates progress.
It also doesn't allow for too much historical manipulation. When I play a game like this, I want to determine the entire outcome myself. As an example of what I mean by this, Total War Rome II will allow you to play as a nation like Carthage and not only erase Rome from the earth (Not Historical), but allows you to conquer it as them... I've had them engaged head on with a rifle squad, and the cavalry DIRECTLY behind a squad all on it's own. The squad turned, wiped out my cav, and then turned to engage my troops again. It seems like a really fun game, but it will require a lot of time just to learn simple things, and the game doesn't do a good job teaching you them without having to rely on steam guides.

Ultimate General: Civil War is a decent game that scratches that Civil War commander itch that's somewhat of a rarity in gaming. I grew up playing two Gettysburg games in the 1990s, one simply titled "Gettysburg" that had movie footage from Gettysburg mixed in with its 2D pixel troops and aerial view of the battlefield. I also played "Sid Meier's Gettysberg!", which had an isometric view of the battlefield with the battle of Gettysburg split up into smaller battles over the three days. I later got the "Ultimate General: Gettysburg" and played it a little bit before getting frustrated with the dodgy controls, poor AI, and horrendous pathfiding.

Ultimate General: Civil War allows for you to become an officer at the start of the Civil War. With limited troops at your command you go through the great engagements of the Civil War and several smaller skirmishes building up your reputation as a commander and potentially altering the course of the war. As you complete battles you get experience which allows you to expand your capacity to command more troops and have access to cheaper arms and more manpower to fill your depleted ranks. This part of the game is fairly well done and shows the pressure a commander can be under when dealing with limited resources. It's once you get to the battlefield where the glaring problems with the game exist.

I have several issues with the AI, pathfinding, UI, and line-of-sight in the game. The topography of the maps is not always clear and sometimes when you have troops cresting a hill and looking down into the area below, somehow the game says they can't see down the hill. You have to physically start moving down the hill to see down the hill. Sometimes you are on what appears to be flat ground in open fields, but for some reason the ground in front of you is shrouded in the fog of war and troops that seem like they would be easily visible suddenly pop out as if they were invisible and ambush your unit. Vision being broken by forest is sometimes odd as a unit that would still be visible as it enters the forest suddenly goes invisible and breaks line-of-sight and you have to physically go into the forest to see the unit you were attacking again. When moving units as a division, the units behave erratically when moving into position. Skirmishers, for instance, will run and completely ignore units in front of them until they get to their designated position or until they are engaged in melee combat with another unit. If you control the skirmishers on their own, they walk until someone is in range of their arms (usually the extreme range) and will shoot at anything and not focus targets, swing around, firing at any unit that gets anywhere close in range. You have to force them to not fire to move into a more advantageous position. There needs to be a middle ground somewhere to give more options for unit behavior, like when to engage, what range to engage. Cavalry with carbines and sabers also seem to not want to use their firearms and will only use them randomly. I try to move the cavalry into position to fire, but they just stand there and do nothing. I try to move them closer, they just stand there and do nothing, or retreat if someone looks at them. There's no way to select what weapon to prefer when attacking, at least not one that is readily visible or available. It pretty much makes your cavalry a melee only or ranged only unit. The AI also sometimes makes some very strange decisions. On one map, I was defending a hill next to a river with several units and the AI kept hitting the same spot over and over again without any success. The AI seems to laser focus on a single position and will attempt to move units out of that position without regard to any other option, regardless of loss.

The campaign also has some issues with regard to alternate history. It's not advanced enough to take into consideration battles won versus lost and how that could impact the outcome of the war. Also generals cannot be "killed" on the battlefield, even if you do manage to remove them from the map. Officers dying on the battlefield was not uncommon and it should have been factored into the game. The game should have also factored in the outcome of battles and created alternate scenarios to fight in to either accelerate or lengthen the end of the war. The Historical Battles option in the game could be used for players who want to reenact their favorite moments from the historical war. If they make a sequel, I hope they can make a more expansive campaign.

For an indie title, it is not bad. It can provide a lot of fun and can scratch that itch if you are in that Civil War mood. I cannot recommend it to people who are not Civil War buffs or who are strategy fans in general. I think it is made for a niche audience and it does an adequate job. With a few improvements, it could be a truly outstanding game that I could recommend to anyone.
