It's been said many times. There needs to be a neutral or a scoring system for Steam reviews. I have mixed feelings about this game. A couple of things it does well:

The battles are meaty and feel great. Most of the American Civil War games out there do the scale of battles correctly, but without the oomph of musket fire and cannons. This game does that part very well. Battles feel visceral. You can almost feel the cannons shredding through lines of troops, you get a twinge in your stomach while feeding your men into the meat grinder on an assault. You can feel them get cut down by volleys of musket fire but you press them on because you must take that hill dammit. 

The AI is also fun to fight. They will try to flank, they will exploit weak spots in your line, and in general give you a run for your money. If you are like me you'll find yourself often beating the enemy by small margins. Every victory feels well earned, which in turn makes the few times I've dominated the enemy or pulled off an encirclement or heroic flank all the more rewarding. 

Civil War battles were a bloody, grinding mess. It was volunteer army against volunteer army, and everyone who paid attention in history class knows that the tactics had not yet caught up with the technology (for the most part). The game gets the feel of Civil War battles so, so right.

My one gripe with the historical accuracy of the game is that it does not really simulate actual Civil War command structure. It would have been cool to have Sherman for instance as a Brigadier General commanding a division, with Colonels under him commanding brigades, and regiments under those brigades. It's a minor gripe, but I'm a Civil War nerd and I love those details. That being said I found myself easily overlooking that abstraction because the battles felt. so. good. Seriously I have played all the Civil War games and the way the battles feel in this one just can't be matched.

Here's the bad. The campaign missions are highly scripted and make what should be more of a simulator game feel very gamey. The first campaign I ran as the Union I beat the Confederates pretty well at Bull Run, won the side mission battles, and was feeling good about myself. I ended up losing badly at Shiloh not because I did anything tactically wrong, but because I underestimated the size of the units the Confederates would have at that stage of the war. My men were just outnumbered. This didn't bother me. I love hard games. I love learning from my mistakes. So I took the lesson that you should build brigades deep and not wide and loaded up a second campaign. 

Everything was going great the second time around. I beefed up my units. We encircled the Confederates at Bull Run and I ended up capturing the entire Stonewall brigade. I went into the Battle of Shiloh with 1200 men to an Infantry unit at minimum.

This time around Shiloh was a tough fight, but we held the Confederate advance so well that when the scenario suggested we fall back to the Hornet's Nest, I didn't feel the need. I was holding the line. My men were tired but the secesh were too, and they were taking many more casualties than me. I ignored the game telling me to pull back. After all I hadn't even lost the first few objectives. I was still holding them. Why would I pull my lines back?

At the very end of the scenario ONE FREAKING CONFEDERATE CAVALRY UNIT managed to squeeze past my lines and capture Pittsburg Landing. This led to me to ultimately lose the battle, because in the game's eyes I didn't control the most important objective. On no planet whatsoever would one cavalry unit of 300 men completely cut off an army of that size. By every measurable metric I had one that battle. But because I didn't play the way the game wanted me to and take the carefully choreographed historical steps it wanted me to I lost. The game literally wanted me to make the same mistakes the Union made. Let me re-fight the Battle of Shiloh and win the damn thing. 

I realize that The Battle of Shiloh was a fighting retreat for the Union. I have no problem with games recreating actual historical battles and giving you historical situations to see how you would handle them. But there was no need for me to actually engage in a fighting retreat! I had won! I had mounted a successful defense! 

I'm sad to say it sort of ruined the rest of the game for me. I'm not sure why the developers decided to make the campaign missions quite as scripted as they are. They have a solid battle engine and really fantastic AI. They could have made the campaign battles much less scripted and more sandbox style and this game would have been a masterpiece.

I give the game 6/10 stars. It does a lot of things right. But let me be an actual Civil War general. Not just a puppet going through the same historical dance moves that the real life generals did.

8.5/10 - A solid addition to any armchair general's library. 

THE GOOD
- Campaign battles scale well. You start with smaller groups of units and maps. The game progressively builds up complexity as you advance through the campaign. 
- Tactics and coordination. Either coordinate your attacks or suffer the consequences. Getting flanked is brutal. Use your skirmishers and charge artillery if close. Pause the game. Play the tactics game or suffer the consequences. 
- The way you control your units is intuitive. Moving and positioning your units is a huge part of this game. Pay attention to terrain and use the "Double Time" command to make sure you move units quickly. Timing is everything and units move more slowly through wooded areas than roads or open fields- this makes all the difference in flanking the enemy or being flanked. 
- Pay attention to your supply lines and each unit's details. Units that run out of ammo will not retreat (they will shout for "Ammo!", and instead will take casualties. Establish supply lines and protect them. Keeping a tab on whether your unit's captain is down, morale is low or condition is low is something you must do to be successful, especially once the enemies start using cover and trenches. 

THE BAD
- The historical accuracy leaves a lot to be desired. if you aren't familiar with the Civil War, or are just here for a light theme, this won't be a problem for you. The battles you've heard of will appear (Gettsyburg, 1st/2nd Bull Run , Antietam) BUT If you are more than a casual historian you'll start to notice the details are off. Where reinforcements arrive from, how objectives shift across the map, the overwhelming number of enemy units that continue to appear regardless of how many casualties you inflict. 
- The campaign is too scripted. Even if you win every single battle you'll still end up fighting through 1865. This is where the replay value breaks down unfortunately. It's fun the first time, although it doesn't provide the entertaining "what if" scenarios you would assume you are influencing. 
- Cavalry units don't need to be used at all to beat the game. This is unfortunate. You've got one of the game's units (1 of your 4 options) that are unnecessary to use- this feels like a design oversight. Artillery and Infantry are enough to beat the game, and often will give you more utility than Cavalry since being coordinated and keeping your army together is the best way to avoid a tragedy. 
- AI charges are devastating, which is unrealistic and frustrating. They'll have more success than the user with this mechanic. To counter this, every time you hear the "charge" trumpet pause the battle, find out which of your units is getting charged and fallback (if possible). Charges weren't used much in the civil war because they were wildly unsuccessful given how devastating the weapons were from a range. Spare me your Little Round Top story here as well- charges were rare, but they are constant in this game. 
- Some battles have entire parts that are inconsequential to the outcome. For example, Chickamauga's start for the Union is entirely historical units (cool, right!). However, regardless of whether you tell these troops to retreat, march them straight into the enemy, or try to hold the line it doesn't have any bearing on the outcome of the battle. Your own army troops show up and are next to the objective to keep the battle going. This all creates a question- why are the devs including entire gameplay segments that are fillers? 

OVERALL
Do you like tactical games? How about constantly pausing the game, micromanaging units and adapting your strategy? If the answer is "yes", than this is for you. History buffs won't be blown away, especially the longer you play, but it's a solid strategy game that does what it does well- tactical battles. Don't expect anything ground breaking from the campaign or army management and you'll be satisfied. I thoroughly enjoyed this game- no regrets in my time investment, but given the lack of depth in the campaign and the inconsequential battle segments I can't justify pouring more time into this. I experienced a good game and leave with nothing left to gain on this battlefield.

This is a good game that stops itself from being great. 

The small skirmish battles where you only command 1-2 corps are fantastic, challenging and packed with fun strategy. 

The large campaign battles are where this game really struggles. The top negative review doesn't make sense unless you've played the game "How do X amount of troops suddenly go missing?" The game will randomly decide to redeploy your troops elsewhere, whenever it needs to. I just barely drew the battle of Fredericksburg to a draw in my last battle, and it's because the game decided to spawn only a quarter of my forces elsewhere, and worse yet, it chose to spawn only 2 unit of infantry, and 5 of  cannons... with low ammo, because they were low ammo when I had them fighting earlier, however a supply wagon was on it's way to resupply them, before they respawned on the other side of the map, and the map completely cut them off from the rest of my forces. 

my above example isn't the first time this re-spawn my forces elsewhere thing has happened, it was just the most recent, and the first battle that made me Tie with the enemy rather than my deserved Victory.

The game will pretend that 3 different battles are happening at once, cutting off each section of map to a smaller map, and then decide to join all 3 subsections towards the end. which in infuriating because you never know when its going to happen. When I first looked at the pregame battle map I already had a plan, rush one flank, and then spread while the rest of my army simply holds the damned line. Then I got to the battle portion, and suddenly each portion of my army was cut off from the other two thirds, and unable to rally at the flank I knew I was going to rush. 

So all in all this game is fun, it is challenging, it is good, but I have no idea why the large battles where you can finally bring your full force to bear are so poorly designed,  Clearly the game can handle big battle simulations, why detract from those epic moments by cutting them into smaller battles?

[b]Ultimate General Civil War[/b]

30 Jun 22

[h1]The Game[/h1]

Ultimate General Civil War is an American Civil War RTS battle simulator with campaign mechanics.
-Play as the Union or the CSA
-Campaign, Custom Game or Historical Battle - No Multiplayer in Base Game
-Economy, Manpower and Armament Constraints in Campaign
-Multiple Difficulty Levels
-Major Battles of Civil War plus 48 Smaller Skirmishes which affect the Major Battles in the Campaign (i.e If you win the skirmish of Seven Pines the AI will have a manpower penalty for the major battle of 2nd Manasses)

[b]Pros[/b]
-Absolutely no bugs in the 60 or so hours I have played
-The game looks pretty good for being almost 5 years old
-Managing which units get what resources can be fun (i.e. Which units get the modern(1861) rifles and veteran replacements and which units get the raw recruits)
-You lose enough battles/skirmishes you get fired
-There is a time limit which can force you and the AI to do things that are unexpected

[b]Cons[/b]
-The tutorial is laughable. It is not really a tutorial, it is simply the first skirmish in the campaign, and the game drops you in the deep end. Here are some units, that is the objective... you figure it out. Along the way, you may get one or two messages about how your general has a radius that affects unit morale. 
-No matter what, you always feel unfairly “behind” the AI in the campaign. On normal difficulty as the Union, I beat the AI in every battle and skirmish (except Seven Pines) and I am constantly facing a CSA army that has more troops which are all Vets - For me, the cost of vet troops is simply prohibitaivly expensive. When I play as the CSA the reverse is true. I can only conclude it is a coding decision to shore up a bad AI.
-When you find a leader in the game with your last name, but on the wrong side of your belief





[h2]The Short Review[/h2]
I wanna say this game is an oldie and goodie, but it is a lot more complicated than that. 

In short, the game can be fun, but more often than not the game is frustrating. The frustration is not due to having a great AI and being beat fairly - it is because of decisions the coding team made to give the AI a leg up. One could say the game is cheating. 

I am not a Civil War historian, but I know the US South suffered from equipment and manpower issues throughout the entire war and acted accordingly. Instead of figuring out a way to simulate that in the game the designers simply give the south more manpower, better manpower, and money than the north if you play as the Union. If you play as the CSA it does the same by giving the Union more manpower and money, but that is more realistic so more acceptable - I guess.

With that in mind, the game can be very frustrating at times, but at least for me, I have gotten hours of mostly fun gameplay and will continue to play it while I try to figure out how to get around the unfair advantage the AI has. For that reason, and the limited number of games in this genre I would recommend it. It really is the best of the worst in the genre of American Civil War strategy games(RTS or otherwise).

HUGE EDIT: After playing this game for about 16 more hours, I can assure you that anyone who says this game is great is simply incorrect.

The AI is retarded. Even when I issue them a Hold command the units will end up turning or chasing in just a way to allow one volley from even 30 skirmishers to flank them. Meanwhile, I can surround an enemy unit on 3 sides with full infantry units and it still takes forever to flank them. Even when I do flank an enemy unit, they retreat behind my lines instead of towards theirs, causing me to have numerous skirmishes across the field to avoid my main line from being flanked by 20-150 troops.

More often than not you can loose an engagement simply because a unit turned itself 5 degrees to the left without your command and got itself flanked. I even had a 2500 strong infantry unit get routed by a tiny skirmisher and a 300 strong infantry force because it barely turned itself. Here I am making beautiful tactical moves, enveloping the entire enemy force, guarding my actual flanks, while the AI routes my units because of tiny 5-10 degree turns it does itself. Expect to spend most of your time micro managing tiny adjustments to facing  (which has cumbersome controls btw) and doing your best to force your units to hold those positions. Only, on the 3rd and final day of battle, after holding all my positions, the Union attacks my left flank, and the game decides I only deployed 2 infantry brigades to defend the left flank, instead of 7. Thus, my cannons are defenseless against 20,000 Union troops. How does it make any sense, when the game doesn't even let you deploy your troops as you like?!

I initially was very excited by this game - BUT DON'T BUY IT. 

But the Scaling of armies in this game, the biggest let down. It's atrocious and for that reason alone, DO NOT Each new battle phase has to be fought with similar historic numbers, so if you lose badly or win by annihilating the opposing army, each new battle you are numerically set back to square one. 

Scaling makes the game almost unplayable - DON'T BUY!

Yes, you will have some 'white stars' grading units as superior, you'll get better weaponry. But, it is a bit like 'Ground hog day', you start each new battle pretty much as is and was, pointless from a strategic point of view. Scaling essentially takes this game to ruin.

Now, the American Civil War is a period in history both romantic and brutal. The in battle mechanics are okay; it can be difficult to keep track of your units and you will randomly forgot about this or that 1,000 men here and there, such is the fog of war, I'm okay with that. But, one aspect I am not okay with, is phantom units at the rear.

So you will 'rout' an enemy unit, they'll disperse in horror, sometimes they'll run right past your lines. You can't pursue them, they just flee in terror and 'good riddance' you think. Your army is in position.

The enemy is dumbfounded, they've been put to 'rout' and they politely skip past your lines and you can't stop them! So, what to do, well you fight on, being a super wizard general, then suddenly...your cannons and baggage trains will come under attack at the REAR! 

You guessed it, the unit you smashed earlier, those men that your own army just let run right past and through them, the enemy unit you couldn't stop from screaming past your lines. Well, they've only re-organised, had a chat and decided rather cunningly to attack you from the rear. 

So the best tactic in this game, is to have ALL YOUR men scream 'surrender' and crash to 'rout' they'll be allowed to walk unmolested through the enemy lines. Then at some later point you can simply magically re-organise your men and attack the unsuspecting enemy from the rear - absolute rubbish game, makes no sense and did I mention the scaling is atrocious.

Ultimate General carries obvious influences from my favorite earlier Civil War games (Civil War Generals 2 [CWG2] and Sid Meier’s Gettysburg! [SMG!]), improving in some aspects while regressing in others. I’ve played through both campaigns multiple times on Brigadier-General and Major-General and despite the scenario repetitiveness, I always learn new tricks that keep combat and army management interesting. I’d love a sequel that addresses the game’s shortcomings. 

Pros: Fun, easy to learn while difficult to master, pleasant maps, and, most of all, organizing your army is very addictive. 

Cons: The AI is unimaginative and difficulty is increased by AI cheating and player penalizing. The campaign is very linear and once you learn the scenarios, there are lots of cheap hacks. There are numerous mechanic problems that coalesce to make winning battles more about accruing ridiculous KDA ratios than using Civil War tactics and strategy.

Recommendations for an Ultimate General: Civil War II

1) Units recover fighting capacity way too quickly. The morale penalty for high casualties is welcome but insufficient. Since the AI doesn’t care about taking ninety percent casualties, this leads to tedious attrition firefights. 

You can inflict over twenty-five damage on an AI brigade only to face it on the to the frontlines within a few minutes. Since replacing your own losses is costly, you can wipe out ninety percent of the enemy army and win with a 5:1 casualty ratio yet be unable to replace your losses. A much slower recovery rate would also challenge players to manage brigades more carefully. In short battles, you might only get one engagement out of a green unit. 

2) An “effective strength” metric (like CWG2 had) would alleviate this problem. As units maneuver and fight, soldiers flee and formations get tangled. Effective strength would be dependent on morale, condition, and a new sliding scale—organization (another metric from CWG2). 

3) A clumping penalty. The AI loves clumping (I’ve never played a Civil War video game where the AI didn’t). First, impose organization/efficiency penalties that lower effective strength. Second, the “blocking” mechanic needs to be more stringently implemented. It’s way too easy to have your units in a tangle all somehow firing at the same enemy while exhibiting remarkable firing vectors. 

4) Replace the “unit breaking” mechanic with routing, like CWG2 and SMG! Routed units take extra casualties, are more likely to surrender, and will flee off the field if not rallied but are not removed from your army in a campaign. 

5) Movement/UI/Unit Commands
Add a “use roads” command to have units prioritize road pathing, a “stay in column/limbered'' command, and 
division formation commands. 

6) Infantry
Program the AI to detach/reattach skirmishers. Detaching skirmishers is one of the game’s strongest mechanics but the AI doesn’t use it and instead gets bonus skirmishers (the generically labeled skirmishers aren’t from historical orders of battle). 

7) Artillery
a) Add a line of fire for topography and terrain. It’s currently a cheap and effective tactic to clump tons of artillery behind your infantry. It would be more rewarding to utilize lines of fire to deploy and counter artillery.  
Note: I’m okay with artillery being able to fire through units. Since the game is brigade level, there’s a degree of abstraction as each brigade has four to six regiments spaced out in battle lines. 

b) Increase artillery range to historical effective ranges. 

c) Long range artillery fire (even if negligible damage) should disrupt a unit’s organization, leading to decreased effective strength (a mechanic present but a bit overpowered in CWG2). 

d) Make counter-battery fire more effective. First, add a command for artillery to focus other artillery. Second, artillery needs to incur heavier penalties from incoming artillery fire. As is, the AI will keep artillery units on the firing line until they’re destroyed. Historically, accurate counter-battery fire could force a battery to withdraw due to damage to guns, caissons, horses, ect. 

e) Make artillery units partially visible when firing. Blackpowder cannons give away their position from firing and even if enemy artillery can’t directly see the guns, they can return fire. 

f) Add horse artillery, siege guns, and siege mortars either as new units or artillery variants (like CWG2 had). 

8) Skirmishers
Refine the skirmish “running back and forth while fighting”automation; it creates more micro-management problems than it solves. This also applies to detached skirmishers, dismounted cavalry, and especially mounted cavalry. 

9) Cavalry
Cavalry is a mess. Granted, I’ve never played a Civil War video game that does cavalry justice. AI and allied cavalry are frequently represented as skirmishers or infantry because of the inherent flaws in cavalry mechanics (ex: Wilder’s Lightning Brigade and Forrest’s cavalry corps at Chickamauga). 

a) Eliminate the 750-man size limit, refine the maneuvering, efficiency, and firing mechanics, and decrease cavalry cost (possibly adding a horse resource pool that’d also be used for artillery and supplies). As currently designed, a large cavalry brigade is unwieldy if not inoperable. That’s a huge part of the problem. I typically run 4-5 brigades of 400-500 troopers. By comparison, the Army of the Potomac’s cavalry corps at Gettysburg was over 10,000 men divided into seven brigades. 

b) Get rid of saber cavalry and create slots for primary and secondary weapons. European-style heavy cavalry wasn’t a thing in the Civil War. Troopers typically carried a carbine, multiple pistols, and a saber (if available).

c) Add an infantry battle line formation with talent skills to specialize between mounted, dismounted skirmishers, and dismounted infantry. When dismounted, cavalry lose ¼ of their effective strength, as those folks tend to the horses. 

10) Corps Commanders
Add a “rally” command (like SMG!) to use on routed brigades.

11) Fortifications
a) The fortification mechanics need a complete overhaul. Many are death traps, and they wreak havoc on firing arcs, flanks, and perceived visual location. Lastly, the AI is obsessed with manning some of them. While most aspects of the game work (just not always in a historically fun way), these often don’t.

b) Add a “dig in” mechanic (again like CWG2 and SMG!) as a toggle on/off command where brigades automatically entrench if stationary and unengaged. There can be two levels of entrenchment: level one provides modest protection and is destroyed when the unit moves (with some leeway for wheeling) and level two gives substantial protection and becomes a permanent map fixture (like the Cold Harbor breastworks). 

c) Add a skill statistic for entrenching. Increased skill level decreases entrenching time, increasing the protection provided, and decreases condition lost. 

13) Officers/Generals
This aspect is frankly a bit lazy and one of the worst aspects of the game. 

a) Create multi-dimensional leader statistics. Instead of one trait (command that only affects efficiency), have multiple traits (like CWG2) that affect a variety of unit stats (example: charisma increases morale and melee). These traits increase (or decrease) based on the unit’s performance. 

b) Eliminate the rank-based experience and make ranks work like actual ranks (i.e. officers hold a rank commensurate with their command regardless of competency). Officers still get promoted based on tenure, but it’s not always correlated to skill level, and there’s no major-generals commanding 200-man skirmish battalions. 

c) Bad generals can’t be demoted but can be relieved at a reputation cost.

This game is a must if you are interested in Civil War history. The campaigns and battles are very interesting and the AI is excellent. I like the realistic weapons modelling, and the way battles play out very much, you can really feel a sense of urgency and emotion with each confrontation.  
.
What's special about this game, is the ways you build your army up : using the resources at hand, purchasing the right type of rifles and cannon, appointing the right leaders, developing your veteran units, then assigning your brigades into the right corps and divisions, then replenish your units after a hard fought battle.. The flexibility in organising your force is immense, and in itself makes for a different playthrough each and every time. It is the feature I like the most.   
.
Having said that, the one thing that put players off is the linear campaign, and the fact that all battles are on rails. Given -this makes for excellent historic play, and I guess that different army builds and force layouts might shake things up a bit in each playthrough. However, the fact remains that once you know the way each battle develops - after several playthroughs - it feels like being able to see the future, and you can easily beat the game at any difficulty. You know what forces you will face, where charges will come from, where to defend fiercely, and where you can even avoid battle in order to place your force in a better position to rush an objective. It is at that point the game loses a lot of its punch, and leaves a tiny bit of a bitter aftertaste.  
.
I can imagine that if the developers ever decided to work on an open campaign map (even a hex style, wouldn't have to be Total War), further developed the economy and political system,  and therefore encouraged some sort of randomization in each battle, this could become one of the best wargaming platforms ever. This is where the game is flling short, and it's a real pity we're not there yet.

This is easily one of the best RTS games I have ever played. The graphic style is beautiful and vibrant and appears hand drawn/painted. The game play is intricate and immersive. Not only do you command units on the field, you are also responsible for requisitioning men, equipment, and officers; all of which are dependent upon your battlefield performance, commander attributes, and historical availability (ie: weapons made in the Confederate States are not available to the Union and vice versa unless captured on the battlefield). The AI is cunning and will punish you for mistakes while also keeping you on your toes as you look for an opportunity to break through or repel an assault. Combing large scale unit control/deployment, tough but enjoyable campaign, unique art style, and a technical and brilliant unit creation/recourse management system I can not recommend this game enough!

1/21/22 (Edit#2)- (BTW, I think you will find the end point most interesting) Though I've given UG:CW a thumbs down for not being as good as I remember 1996's Sid Meier's Gettysburg, I have since played it more, as I love pushing armies around and to give it more of a chance. I'd give the game a 6.3 our of 10 at this point, mostly because it's okay, but far from perfect. Play conservatively on the hardest setting and you will still win 94(?)% of the time, if not always, once you understand unit behaviors and reactions better. That easy to beat on a hard setting is not good, but I will admit over 30 hours of play will refine your skills for Big Picture Strats, as well. I love the graphics and pace, which you can make faster if desired, but the following are the game's downfalls:

1) The landmarks not being named is just laziness and a time waster. 2) Multi-day historical scenarios should not be interrupted and reset to predetermined points, but rather should be allowed as a continuous scenario. Getting set back when you've amassed great gains is annoying and developers should have adjusted slightly for this or left it alone per my suggestion.  3) The Fallback order is messed up and shows troops reversing direction when in fact it should be more of a controlled backwards, shooting walk facing the enemy. Getting flanked is detrimental; you back to the enemy is unit suicide. 4) Many scenarios depict positional defenses when all that was there or required was the actual busy terrain per the actual battle. Too many of the battles incorporate dug in defenses, whereas battlefield positing is more interesting and what being a general is about. 5) Still don't dig the micro management of budgeting and outfitting units in the Campaign mode. Enough micro management is put into this rather slow and thoughtful form of combat to begin with. 

Upsides? - A great substitute in lieu of a better game for the genre. Nice graphics. One can pause for setting unit orders. Multiple play speeds (bet be a master on higher settings, although playing a few fast... think speed chess... may reveal a few fundamentals faster.. or hide them... IDK) One can create a skirmisher unit from any brigade, and (too) small units may be combined with others, as well.

End Point: In defensive scenarios, such as Gaines' Mill and Malvern Hill, there will be a time limit to which you must hold a position, often before you are told to defend the next backward position. It is very suspect that the PC player makes it's hard move just as this time limit approaches. There you are, holding against great odds for 2 hours, and i the last minute you are overcome. This is fine for historical accuracy, I suppose, but what it means is the AI is leading you on to achieve that timely simulation moment. You are not getting by your hard fought tenacity, but rather the AI holding back. It takes the wind out of my sails for the game, and means the AI may be programmed to behave this way even for scenarios with no clutch points accept the end (lone time limit as oppose to multiple planned resets within the same scenario). That said, if the game is worth playing at all, it is in the single time limit scenarios... you get the idea, but once I noticed the AI defeat when it had to for historical accuracy, or the entire scenario resets all surviving units to next-step positions, it was less fun than my rating. Therefore, as of now, I'm done with the game. This alone makes Sid Meier's Gettyburg (supposedly abandonware, now) a superior game, from 1996. No kidding.

However the campaign mechanics are abysmal. You often have options to place multiple armies at multiple "engagements" of a multi-part battle, but there's absolutely zero information on whether your other armies are going to be included when you fight that phase of the battle. Sometimes they are! Sometimes they aren't! How am I supposed to know?

You also randomly get borrowed units from other armies that don't level up alongside your units, but there's never any indication on when this is, or why.

Nope. suddenly in this phase of the battle, even though it's literally played on the exact same map, my first day army is vanished and only my secondary army is on the field. I got this on sale on Jan 3rd, I'd been eyeing it for a while, I thought it looked interesting but nothing to shake a stick at. BOY WAS I WRONG
So far I have clocked in just over 25 hours. I am addicted and here's why.

1. The game is hand drawn, down to the figures and portraits. making the game experience not only INSANELY pretty but also completely new for any strategy game that I have ever played.

2.The maps are 100% Accurate, again also hand drawn, they are accurate maps of the battlefields that these battles were fought on + some surrounding areas. Making it so that you're not confined to repeat the battle tactics of the time, it gives you the freedom to be your own tactician.

3. The Audio is superb, I could listen to musket volleys and cannon fire all day. In addition you can also hear the faint marching and drumbeats of your enemy through the fog of war, giving you an idea of where they might be

4. The Armies are absolutely massive, yet well organized and very easy to control. I just finished the Battle of Fredericksburg with an army of 80,000, and the game is like, "Yeah but the rebels have 60,000 and are dug in, so maybe take 40,000 more." And I am like holy shit okay. But the Army is very organized into Corps, divisions, and then your individual brigades that you can control. I really appreciate this structure because it is easy to understand and my ADD doesn't go crazy like it does for other strategy games.

5. I lost 57,849 men at the battle of Fredericksburg, It was not an enjoyable experience. You get an after action report between battles and even between battle phases, You are awarded Manpower and money after each battle, the income of which is decided on whether it was a Defeat, Draw, or victory. However, you also are awarded Political points,or you lose political points if you suffer a defeat. which can be used to purchase generals, equipment, money, or manpower. 
6. Equipment is probably my fav aspect of the game, it gives you like 50 options of various era appropriate rifles, percussion muskets, flintlock muskets, revolver rifles, carbines, cannon, howitzers etc to equip your units with varying degrees of availability. Wanna equip your new brigade with 2500 Henry rifles? Guess what, there are only 4 on the market rn bitch, better stockpile that. Want some Texas carbines? Guess what, you’re the north bitch, better hope your enemy has some that you can capture in battle. AND EVEN if you do have 4000 British produced enfield muskets, do you have enough men to give them to? 

7. The last thing I wanna talk about is the AI and the Time progression. The AI is insanely smart for any strategy game that I have played. Yes, it does get a kick in the pants to help it against a human player, but not enough to make it seem ahistorical or overwhelming. However it is mean. It will attempt to flank you, charge you if it has numbers to do so, It will keep reserves that you will curse. And when the enemy brigades charging you have the names of Jackson, Bragg, Lee and Stuart, you can’t help but worry for your lines.

Lastly, and the biggest thing that I can’t decide if I like or dislike. UGCW is a real time strategy, and I mean REAL time. The dev team went back, checked out how long each combat phase of each battle took, and they gave you that time. For example, Lee took Gaines Mill in 2 hours. Congratulations, you now have 2 hours to take Gaines Mill. and That is the MINIMUM amount of time that they give you. Your 2 hours are up but you are almost there? Sure, finish the fight. Granted there is a speed bar and taking an objective early in an assault mission will end the fight early. (If you survive the AI’s counter attack) 

Overall, I just spent 3 hours watching 57,849 of my men try to take a hill again and again and again, And I was invested in every single second of my crushing defeat. I am a very big fan, If you are a fan of the total war games but they just dont have the right Umph, give this one a try

I like strategy games, and I like the civil war, so this really should have been a no-brainer to develop a game that I thoroughly enjoyed based on both. This game ultimately wasn't satisfying, and was only sometimes enjoyable. 4/10

History - some of the history stuff was cool and since I knew the battlefield layouts it was pretty neat seeing how they translated it into their games visual assets. But there were some heinous errors, oversights, and missed opportunities. The game feels like you're only being shown "some" of the battles -- yes gettysburg, no vicksburg. Only maybe a third of the major conflicts are shown (which, tbh because of other issues with the game that I'll address later, probably was for the best. The game would have gotten extremely tedious.)  Final map is "The battle for Richmond" which in the civil war was inconsequential, and not the Appamatox campaign where Lee actually surrendered. Seemed like they couldn't find a way to show the Siege of Petersburg either (and wave away in the game text by saying "We decided we didn't have time for a siege" - what a distortion of the real story!) and had to do something else.

Gameplay - It's almost hard to say that the game has gameplay. You don't actually do that much, aside from positioning units which is generally unresponsive. By the end game, unit counts are too high to micro and attacks degenerate quickly into selecting large groups of units and having them rush isolated gaps. AI is sketchy at best, especially cavalry. Coding seems lazy and overly simplistic, similar to clash of clans style games rather than a RTS combat sim. Although to be fair, it's not entirely unenjoyable, and kept my attention for a few hours. 

Campaign - by far the worst aspect of the game. Totally lazy design, even though its the games main feature. Each planning round you get a set amount of pre-determined cash and recruits, a set amount of of battles and side missions that you need to do, and a new talent point which gives small flat-rate enhancements to the handful of things the game is tracking (unit replenishment, recruit percentage) or allows spying / larger units. There is no variation from this formula, and the focus on tedium like micromanaging your unit replenishment really drags the pacing of the campaign down.  It really doesn't take much effort to come up with an idea for a totally different way of handling the campaign mode which would have made it much more enjoyable -- replayable seed-generated side missions, a map and choices instead of a list of battles in a set order, a larger variety of maps and battles, avoiding the simplistic focus on "cash and recruits" mission rewards and giving a UI which allows the player to make choices that influence the evolution of story and the ability to outfit your team. XCOM's campaign UI isn't even very good but at least they tried -- that's not what this developer did though, c'est la vie.  Very bad, boring, monotonous and lazy.

Replayability - None. Once you play through the campaign, you can play through it the exact same way a second time. There are no meaningful choices that will affect your gameplay experience. Which honestly, is just fine -- since the game wasn't that fun to play, and the campaign mode was tedious and uninspired, I don't even really want to play it again. But you'd think that the developer would care about it, right? They did add in a "custom game" where you can select one of the scenarios you already did. But there's no actual "custom game" like most other RTS style games, and there's also no "build breastwork" gameplay feature, so there would also be no point in a real "custom game" because you couldn't ultimately really customize a map full of cool defensive features and then assault it, which you'd expect from an RTS game but somehow this game doesn't need to actually do any of the cool stuff people like, since by the time you figure out that it doesn't, you've already spent the three hours of your steam refund window on the slow and tedious campaign menus to get a refund. 

TL;DR - It's not very good

This is an easy recommend for me despite apparently so few hours of play because it has done exactly what I was looking for in this kind of wargaming.

You're not going to get realism with RTS, ever, so forget about that, I look for fun and downtime from actual strategic wargaming with these kind of RTS titles, personally, although this game does have some depth, it does not kid itself or you with realism for good gameplay. I also want that genuine Civil War wargaming feel with the aspects unique to that or early industrialised warfare.

This is massed ranks of regiments going at it, toe to toe, across open ground, then charging, breaking, doing it again. This happens. Exhaustion is also a variant and factor, which I approve of and want, because it forces me and the AI to go into the "Dance of death" where we have to cycle units into and out of the line, rest, do it all again. Exhausted units, even if superior will break and run against fresh troops. The Dance of Death is a term from that time, it is accurate gameplay.

The terror of seeing huge formations on the other side moving into the line, usually the bluebellies. All of these things I got to see in another old game once, Robert E. Lee: Civil War General by Sierra. It was also a light game but very popular, it had all of those aspects in it, plus you'd lose men to desertion as the battle progressed, that was also very good and true to the time. It was why armies wore bright colours in Europe, not just because it looked nice, but because it would be impossible to "turn your coat" inside out and fight for the other side, often under duress.

So it's a shame that UG:Civil war does not have this, but it has everything else to give me what I personally am looking for in RTS US Civil Wargaming.

There is also a nice aspect between the battles of raising and equipping, refreshing your regiments that is quite fleshed out and gives you a sense of investment in the game and campaign. All the names and regiments are accurate after watching through my civil war documentaries and watching videos about the battles again.

There is also supply, which I personally like. I am not balancing well enough between re-manning and raising new regiments with chunking out my supply wagons enough with hard cash. My cannon keep running out about a Third into the battle and about Three Quarters we get low on musket-balls, I rely too much on capturing enemy supply wagons with my cavalry, but really should balance unit formation and resupply with adequate supply funds between the battles, and this is also good, tough but fair, giving a sense of realism.

This is again a good sign of a game for me personally, when it makes me look back through my own resources and references about these battles with renewed interest, like with Shiloh after fighting through it the first time last night and seeing what a bloody battle so early on it was. Sometimes you just sit there, paralysed and aghast watching the shambles play out across the map. Which sadly happened in real life, but today is a new day and I know to pull straight back to Pittsburgh Landing now, unlike the Union generals at the time.

The other thing is that wargaming these battles properly goes against my personal playstyle, but in this case I don't mind. I do mind when it's the devs making play like how they want me to, but this is also accurate to the the time (so it's not devs being lazy, as can happen in other games). When I went up to Fort Sumter, I knew I had to rush it, storm it. I don't like that, I am very loss conscious and love economy of force, it's more satisfying. But I know this era and style and it worked better to storm it messily.

Every time I try to play my style, be really slow, take hours, lose tens of men only a time while annihilating the enemy, usually indirectly or from good cover just is not the mode here, that is how you lose battles. You have to push the enemy relentlessly, just keep throwing more men and materiel in there, because he's dong the same and it's desperate stuff.

So I bought this game on not much discount and despite some bad reviews because I wanted something like the Sierra Game, or Sid Meyer's Gettysburg, Ultimate General: Civil War for me personally delivers that "pick up and play" wargaming action I look for when not poring over hex maps doing painstaking moves with more serious turn based games.

The maps look really nice with again the sort of "arcadey" look like in those older titles or in Sudden Strike, which again, I'm personally looking for and appreciate in this kind of experience.

I can understand why it might not be some people's cup of tea, but for me and given that I get a full game and campaign with force-building and supply aspects makes it more game and the full game in one price instead of all those dlc like Sudden Strike's strategy, and your troops in that don't even get experience, like in Ultimate General: Civil War. So there is also the Human Resources aspect also to the game, where, apart from the men getting more experienced, it's also good to hire and fire competent and officers to lead your units, as well as use any political influence points you might garner to get named famous officers assigned to your officer pool, or get more troops, money via those political points (you also get to improve yourself, which buffs your army stats, like improvements to your officers do).

All in all a pretty good offer from these devs, but again from my point of view. I had it wishlisted for about a year while I thought about it, because of the price and the fact that it was nearly never on sale, plus some of the negative reviews, also the sort of gamers that were reviewing it on Youtube. They were not really gamers like me and more the sort of "play it by the numbers" instant gratification gamers who never have any real understanding of the era or gameplay, even the expert ones.

But in the end I'm personally glad I took the plunge for those reasons.

The older games I mentioned, I've personally enjoyed, but I can't, won't play them again. I'd want at least a similar experience again for my money, plus some more bits and this game does that while still being fairly original in combining and compiling those with being up to date.

Mission accomplished.

The Good: The best part about this game is the battlefield combat.  The terrain looks wonderful and watching firefights play out is great.  Controlling your units, directing them into line position, and setting up fields of fire are all simple and work very well.  The campaign has you in charge of either the north or south, managing squads, leaders, weapons, and finances.  Beyond the regular campaign, you can setup scenarios as well as adjust some combat/battle options to create your own battles.

The Bad: In the beginning, I was having a lot of fun playing through the campaign.  But at some point, it felt like the difficulty spiked.  After reading information about the game, it turns out that the opponent’s army size scales so that it always has higher troop levels than yours.  This made it so it didn’t matter what decisions I made organizing my army, the enemy would always overwhelm me.  After having this happen and most of my army getting wiped, time after time, I decided to move on.  It also seems there are still several features missing and bugs left that require mods for the issues to be addressed.

Overall:  I would only recommend this game to someone who really likes the civil war.  It contains lots of detail and does a pretty good job simulating the battles.  Anyone else just looking for a new RTS might wait till this one goes on sale.

Ultimate General: Civil War is an in-depth strategy game which requires quick responses to developing situations as well thinking ahead. The tutorial is very well done. The tool tips are brief and condensed into pop-up squares which you can then click the x to get rid of. Everything is simple to understand, but difficult to master. 
The graphics are awesome, at least in terms of terrain and whatnot. Unit graphics do match the game, but aren't that great. However, it is important to note that "units" are NOT the main feature of this game. The thing that stands out the most, for me, is the A.I. The developers did an incredible job with it. Do not make the mistake of thinking this will be like Total War where the computer player stupidly charges your front line without even a thought given to tactics, or strategy. Uh-uh. I am currently playing on the easiest setting, and the A.I. has very nearly, many times, routed my armies (with ease). I have sat here and watched as the computer player forms it's own front line, performs complex flanking maneuvers, prepares for assaults, effectively coordinates its own units. These are things you will NEVER see in the Total War games or any others like them. Honestly, my mind was blown. If you consider yourself to be good at strategic/tactical games, and you want an ACTUAL FACTUAL challenge for once, buy Ultimate General: Civil War. You will definitely not be disappointed.

Too bad, suddenly your guys are somewhere else, the enemy has shuffled stronger units around so that the ones that were in front of you ten second ago are gone and a horde of fresh troops has appeared out of the blue. Oh and morale? I've never seen a game where a group of 200 men (mauled down from over 2000) will charge 1500 soldiers on high ground.

If you like the American Civil War era or just the war its self interests you and you like strategy games, if this is a game you're just finding its worth its weight in gaben dollars. Honestly a hidden gem of a game. I just finished my first full campaign after many restarts and retries as the union and have to highly recommend this game. I'm personally a fan of the kind of challenge type missions spanning real battles of the time this game has to offer. The games artwork is beautifully done, the audio is amazing, the game play is pretty solid and the fact your generals and officers gain experience over the course of the war and the fact you have full customizeable control over your army that you use throughout the war is a great addition.

It does have its draw backs though that may be off putting to some. Most missions are timed, some being unclear as to how said mission times work. Which to me was kind of frustrating. A lot of the battles can feel scripted, meaning they feel like the game pushes you to place units in specific places and do specific things with those units rather than full strategical freedom. There are some missions where your forces will be split up and the game wont tell you before hand. So you'll have to reload from the start just to find out how to get a good split of units. And one thing i thought that was terribly annoying is the fact that your units will always auto fire at the closest enemy line or unit. So if you have a line of infantry you want shooting at some guys in the east, but also have dudes north that are closer to your dudes, your dudes will auto turn to face the guys north instead giving the enemies in the east flanking shots on your guys. Not sure why this was decided to be a thing in the game. I wish it wasn't as i've accidentally lost plenty of good men at very inopportune times to this function.

Other than that even with its shortcomings the game in my opinion has more positives and is just a fun time. You'll get oodles and oodles of hours playing this game. Even if you beat both campaigns you'll probably just want to do them over again to try new strategies. And even if you one and done both sides you'll still get your monies worth and you'll enjoy every minute of it. Had to leave a good word for this game. Its a solid one.

There is definitely a learning curve to this, but once you get the idea about how to build up your army, manage your resources and fight through the battles, this is an intense game that you won't want to miss.

There have been battles where I felt every loss and where the numbers of men that have been killed or wounded makes you shudder to think about the heavy price of life that was seen on both sides of the conflict back then, the BIG battles especially really capture a bit of what a day or days of battle may have felt like.

Sometimes the battles can be frustrating and very hard to manage, other times you are angry with the A.I. Generals who are basically forcing you to sacrifice your men and units in order to achieve victory.

Balancing out the money, weapons and manpower while trying to ensure that your units are supplied well also gives you a taste of how much of a nightmare logistics might have been back in the 1800's.

It's not a perfect game and there are times where you feel that the numbers of men being sent by the opposing army seem a bit ridiculous, but overall I have had a blast creating my armies, customizing the unit names and finding the best unit set up that works for each situation. I'm still playing through it the first time as the Union, but it's been great learning and playing through Ultimate General: Civil War.

Kudos to the developers and game designers, I hope there's more to come.

I really had fun with this game. I love how the units work - the terrain and the maps look really cool. But after 30 hours of playing, thinking, composing armies I am done. Why thumbs down you may ask? Well there is the answer.

Main critique points:
- bad AI
- no unit formation control
- Menu-UI is convoluted, some things unnecessary, important things not prominent enough...
- translation into german was probably done with google translator
- different difficulties give you a numeric handicap, do not (really) change the AI's behaviour. 

Audio: 
- bad soldier voices when reporting in (sounds like 64kbits mp3 quality)
- recycled soundscapes in camp menu which cycle through and through. (why not use the music of the main menu?)

The game gives you the illusion of a challenge. You got some things to choose from - like perks, army composition, weapons with different ranges and firerates. Skilling units with experience. But in the end it never really mattered. 
I expected it to scale and get harder and scale up with time - but it does not. 

I played US Campain on normal difficulty for like 20 Matches I didnt loose one of them. I wouldnt consider myself to be an RTS-God, sometimes I had to reload and think, but after you figured it out the game is far too easy. All I did was trying to have more than 110% of the enemies corp size (men) and I used every weapon I got dropped. And I won. Easily. Altering the difficulty gives you a massive handicap on the other hand, making winning almost impossible. I just did the first intro-mission and my forces got absolutely crushed - there was absolutely nothing I could do about it. But the AI didn't behave differently. It just had the numbers and the effectiveness.

The praised A.I. of the trailers does nothing really great. It reacts if you misplaced your units - punishes you for your mistakes, yes. But it is not pro-active. It does not force you to make mistakes - maybe only in scripted events. 
The last game I won was "hold position x - wait". I hid in the woods near the mission point, pushed enemies away and stood there. For three in-game hours. They charged me several times, promts appearing calling "confederate units are approaching from the west!" - but after the AI didnt find a way to get around me, it just did nothing. The units tried to stay out of range and that's it. When they charge, they immediatly stop if you deploy skirmishers from the infantry unit making two units out of one. 
It also suffers from more major flaws but explaning them all here would overload this comment. 


Conclusion: 
The game looks unfinished. A bit like nobody did an play-test. There is much potential for telling stories of the american civil war which had been spared. That is totally ok for a small studio. But there is so much more what this game could be and is not. Just Imagine what Multiplayer support would change. The AI wouldnt be a thing anyone would talk about anymore.

Great stuff. If you enjoyed the Total War series, the unit control and multi-unit battles are very similar...morale plays an important role in a units ability to fight. But, comparing this to Shogun: Total War, there are more options and buffs/debuffs available on the battlefield due to the various historic weapons. You can choose to stay in cover and fire volley after volley, if you have adequate supply nearby. You can run up on the enemy and then charge, which can rout that unit entirely. But you can only charge for a short time before the men are exhausted. In between battles, you can manage the army structure and weapon loadouts. For example, buying the rifles with a longer effective range can give you the edge in a shootout against a tenacious foe while you are both in cover...but would it be more effective to use that money to raise new regiments of rookies who can charge the enemy? You can also choose to specialize a unit for endurance and speed, or fire accuracy, or for reloading rates. The opportunities for tactics are endless.  Your officers level up and gain perks that benefit all troops under their command. You can hire new officers from the academy. You can also spend your reputation points (earned by victories on the battlefield) to compel the government to send you more men, or better cannons, or special officers. Your general(s) inspire morale in their troops on the battlefield but cannot do any combat and will run from all enemies that attack him. Artillery cuts lanes in the battlefield. If you enjoy battlefield tactics, this game (really more than a game- it's an historic US civil war simulator) is well worth your time.  The ability to assign the army organization really makes this game shine. The terrain and unit tactics are superbly implemented. High recommend.

I would really like to recommend this game as it is very fun. The battle mechanics all make sense and the game flow is great. But their are some glaring issues with not only the campaign and the ai that accompanies it. 

This game's campaigns is very stale for one, same set of battles each time with these smaller set up battles in between. This could have been an interesting premise but your performance in the major battles does not affect the war in any meaningful sense. One extremely noticeable battle is the 1st battle of bull run, now had the Union secured a decisive victory as I did during my go of the battle, then the civil war would have been very different. An early victory here would have emboldened the Union to be more aggressive and it would have broken cohesion of the rebels. Now would that make for a fun campaign, probably not but it would add much more replay ability to the game. 

Now for the worst part of the campaign, the difficulty level. This game suffers from one of the worst difficulty heights I have seen in a while. So much so that playing on normal is so easy that i have never even scored a draw in my 15 hours of playing. While hard if so difficult that I have to try every mission at least 4 times before I get the hang of it. Now this fucking sucks for a lot of reason. One while for some people this level of play is fun, and i understand why it is this is something that would often fall under a very hard or legendary difficulty kind of deal. For those who play a lot and like to try try try again until they succeed. For this game I am not interested enough to play each level 4 times before I can move on. A good amount of the fun in this game is playing a battle for the first time and not knowing what the enemy is gonna do, having to react in real time. That is fun and is why total war battles have found their way too many hearts.  In this game however the ai will spawn in the exact same spot everytime and will move to the same spot every time. It will act in a way that is historical. While that is great and all, game play wise its dog shit. If you were Napoleon or Grant or Lee or Alexander or fucking anyone and you could just rewind the clock on the battle you would be the greatest general to ever exist. Knowing exactly where the enemy is and what its going to ruins all of the fun, especially when you have to inorder to beat the damn mission. 

Now I am in my final year of university for a bachelors in history and will be moving on to a masters program so I do enjoy history quite a lot. I however firmly believe that games are about changing history and understanding how just one small movement of the pieces can change everything.

The ai is lackluster to say the least, the Union will rarely ever dedicate its whole force at one time and instead will attack one by one. The rebels do not hold position and instead when its a defensive battle for them they will charge you. Now maybe due to incompetency this did happen quite a lot in the civil war I know of an instance at gettysburg where a Union commander almost lost the battle because he was way out of position. 

Overall this game has all the mechanics of a good game but the campaign is so frustratingly difficult or boring easy. The campaign is the game in a sense, if it does not work the game does not work. I would instead hold out for the Armchair historians new game that is coming later this year. It is set in the same period, but it is a different take on the genre.

The strongest positive I can give to Ultimate General: Civil War is its attention to detail. If you're at all passionate about the battles of the American Civil War, you'll find it hard not to be engrossed in the dedication taken to each and every motion the game places you in: moving from day-to-day, attack to counter-attack and so on. It's a unique kind of RTS in that you'll come to know its own system of morale, ammo and structure. It's a line battle game and the tactics you'll be employing are built deeply around that, meaning while it's relatively straight forward, complicated manoeuvres can be difficult to pull off successfully. The fun lies in making it work or hanging on against all odds, but the occasional jankiness of UG:CW can make it an infuriating situation (I'm looking at you "FLANKED!" notification when it's the tiniest of angles I'm moving parallel to an enemy division).

It's fun, but hard work, with long missions making this a surprisingly heavy time sink. The downside comes in the lack of dynamism in the main campaign. While I can fight optional missions that affect the morale/number/intelligence of the enemies I'm fighting in the big battles, it's a dumb, mystifying let down to receive captured enemy intelligence reports thereafter. Why bother telling me about the absolutely crushing defeat I've inflicted on them if they somehow always manage to muster up a fuckton of new recruits to fight me at the next battle? I get the point isn't to snowball, but god it would be fun to and arguably would have made these experiences more dynamic at the cost of their historical qualities, but better as a personalised experience.

Anyway, I wouldn't pay full price for this, but it's an easy buy during a sale. Just know you're going to have to learn a fair bit about how this works and adapt accordingly, it's a tough game but immersive if you're at all interested in the US Civil War. I'd love to see a future rendition of this with 3D models and a better representation of the carnage the battles meagerly represent. Still, nothing like standing atop a pile of confederate corpses.

I hate this game, I hate it so much. 

I will use the Battle of Chickamauga scenario playing as confederates as an example for why this is, as everything wrong with this game is present in microcosm. To start off, you are always outnumbered, even if you have crushed the Union army 20 different times up to this point. Furthermore, the enemy will always have better weapons than you, again even if you've badly beaten them repeatedly before. You have to hold out against overwhelming union forces who will charge without the slightest concern for casualties, inflicting horrific casualties on your own forces as you struggle to hold on to arbitrary Victory Points that will determine whether or not you win the battle. And if you lose, not only do you not get the vital manpower and money you need to rebuild your army, but you will instantly lose the entire game and be booted back to the menu. 

But you win the battle, against all odds and suffering unsustainable casualties. You barely have enough manpower and money left to refill your nearly destroyed units. And then you play the very next battle, and you realize that all of that was for nothing and the Union has magically refilled its ranks and is using the same tactics and you are even more outnumbered than you were before.

This game is the embodiment of trying to hold sand in your fingers, and if you're like me and are so OCD you have to complete everything then this it will probably give you a stroke. The only way to win this game is to cheese every battle and simultaneously get very lucky. Its the same for both sides, just a bit easier as Union.

Summary:
- No victory matters
- Battles are incredibly scripted around certain Victory Points
- The enemy AI is dumb as rocks
- Losing a single battle late game will cause you to lose
- You will bang your head on a table

This game is rich in cool details and gives you the feel of building an army from scratch.  The bad side is you will have to learn the hard way.  I had to restart the campaign many times because I just didn't understand how certain choices can dead end your campaign in a hurry.  That being said it is the details that make this game so sweet and you just have to learn that way.  Equipping your veteran brigades with awesome rifles will make them twice as effective.  Use them recklessly in battle and your huge investment goes into the ground with a little white cross. These are the kind of choices really make this game shine.  This game makes you act like a general and treat your units with respect.  Personally, I get off on slaughtering blue bellies who want to oppress the hell out of us with this overbearing federal government that thinks they own everything and even our lives.  Our stupid blue governor made it a crime to go cut grass at property you own during covid lock down.  If only we could line up one more time and take back our freedom or die trying!  This game is a great covid stress release mechanism. I highly recommend this game.

- The Good -

This game is pretty damn addictive just from how fun it is and how much you can do to change what you do in each battle. I was actually able to learn about campaigns during the war and their important battles. There are a shit ton of battles in this game that I have yet to reach all of them just from the sheer amount. While in the beginning of the game it can be a bit of a hassle to actually get through as both Confederate and Union, the rest of the game is still pretty damn fun if you learn how to utilize each type of unit and their weapons, being able to rack up thousands of kills with just a 800 count infantry brigade. As well as just the cheeky feeling know you managed to capture an enemy behind their own lines using cavalry or 2 other infantry brigades. As well as just being able to get them to rout using nothing but skirmishers.

-  The Bad -

Though I do have some other gripes such as how larger units actually take more damage than they do and are just very difficult to command due to how slow they are in terms of movement, even if that does make sense. There's also how you can't really choose what parts to attack on your own since parts of the map are just completely restricted to you unless you wait out the timer which sucks a lot like in the Fredericksburg battle. It's better to skip trying attack at the 2nd phase due to the lack of cover and sheer amount of artillery so I just always have to wait it out in order to actually do some damage, but even then I have to move all of my units down into the forest in order to actually be effective. It'd be better if you could actually decide where your units go besides these decided spot on the map or at least allow to skip the timer. But those are just a few issues with the game that I have with it.

- Conclusion -

Even with those issues in the game, the ups of it just completely overpower it just from how fun it is to try and command an army and kick the enemy's ass. It's especially fun if you find new ways to lead your army by small parts in the map where you can cross a river or get behind the enemy and try and get them to rout. Not to mention the fact that you can always get better in each battle by trying out new things. I managed to destroy almost the entire enemy army at Malvern Hill just by having less men in each brigade. It's super fuckin' fun and I would totally recommend it to anyone. Interest in history or not this is a solid strategy game. I would like to hear what other people have to say about this game in terms of bad and good things, as there may be some things I missed out on or some thing that people may have to add on to.

This game has an awesome premise. Manage and Army in the Civil War in an XCOM-like format and fight across major battles throughout the American Civil War. The issue is that it is executed so poorly that I cannot in any capacity recommend this game.

After trying the first couple of battles, I was extremely unimpressed. The A.I. is terrible and cheats to try and beat you. Vastly larger soldier counts (even on Brigadier general with max Army Organization), blindly charging a single position, being heavily resistant to flanking and killing their general does nothing to their morale. The battles and overall campaigns are extremely heavy scripted which disincentivizes any form of strategy in favor of min/maxing. No matter what you do, the enemy will not lose sufficient reinforcements for what you accomplish, which realistically doesn't make any sense. If the Union won both the 1st Battle of Bull Run, the Second and Fredericksburg, the CSA would have crumbled. The only thing keeping them in the war was the crazy victories Jackson and Lee were able to inflict on the Union. Because of this, it feels a lot less like a war and more like a movie you are watching.

If you are someone that like RTS's such as Age of Empires, Company of Heroes, Command and Conquer or Total War, stay away from this game. It is not worth any amount of money due to just how frustrating the mechanics are. The combat is the worst I have ever seen in a game like this. Cannons are useless unless you are shot gunning them in the face, cannons can fire through trees and soldier right in front of them. This really is not a strategy game and is not fun. I wish I could defeat the ZERG Confederates in the game by doing the last thing I can think of, refunding the game, but unfortunately I cannot. So, I will hide the game and forget it even exists in two weeks.

Thank the lord for this little game, I've yearned for an American Civil War RTS for the longest time.

UGCW has filled a gap for me, a gap that Total War has yet to try and fill, and probably never will. It's historically accurate to the period, with two long campaigns and several playable historical battles, like Gettysburg or Shiloh, Chickamagua and Chancellorsville etc. It has an AI that's brutally efficient, pressing the attack and attempting to outmaneuver the player. The music is somber but highlights the glory of the era. The sounds are amazing, you can hear roar of cannon and the pop of musketry as infantry go on the attack, screaming as they charge with bayonets and swords.

The campaign is fairly in depth. It's a linear experience mostly, but you can customize your army as you see fit. You can adjust weapons and supplies, size of brigades, corps, and divisions. Officers and their units gain experience as they fight on, making them more efficient on the battlefield.

As for things I don't like? I think the enemy AI and the scaling can be a little unfair at some points. Sure, some of that could be my awful RTS skills, I won't deny. But the fact I can decimate several enemy divisions in several battles and they still have massive resources in 1863 is a little absurd. 

Overall, it's a delightful RTS, and has a fair amount of replayability. Definitely pick up if you're a history nerd like me.

A quite enjoyable simulation of the Civil War.  It provides one the chance to really excel at shaping battles in advantageous ways to attain victory for one's side in this titanic conflict.  The animation style though relatively simplistic is still visually pleasing.  The various mechanics of customizing your army with specific types of training and weaponry is much appreciated, and these historical battlefields are truly lovingly rendered.

I do however do have a handful of complaints where the game falls short:
- I wish there was more unique descriptions of what happens to your character depending upon specific victories or failings after the war in either victory or defeat.  Perhaps one's pre-chosen career path before the game and/or the stats you focused could affect this.  Like if you focused hard on the Political Stat you would have a political ending.  Whereas in a recent playthrough I put only a moderate amount of points into finance and yet became a Banker after the war. Despite maxing out other skills like Politics, Military Organization, etc.
- I also wish there were some more potentially intriguing political choices in the game and consequences for victories and defeats.  Like, if you lose the Battle of Gettysburg as the Union, Lincoln is not reelected and your Commander in Chief for the remainder of the war is McClellan.  Or if you lose at Antietam, Lincoln does not release the Emancipation Proclamation.
- There are also a few major battles I think the game sorely misses out on.  In particular post 1862.  For example Vicksburg is not a Siege Battle we can engage in.  And the March to the Sea is not focused on as strongly as it could have been.
- I also wish there were more unique Historical units.  We receive the Iron Brigade as the Union, and the Cavalry under Forrest for the Confederacy.  But what about the Irish Brigade amongst many other unique and famous units?  I think the exclusion of such units, as well as famous black units for the Union, is a major missed opportunity.

Aside from these minor complaints however it is still a quite excellent game and I heartily recommend it for any history buffs out there.  Especially if you can pick it up when its on sale at some point.
