I really want to recommend this game but I can't. I'm a huge fan of Ultimate General: Gettysburg and highly recommend that game but not this one. Anybody complaining about graphics obviously never played Gettysburg and doesn't care about strategy and overall game play, their probably just someone who wants every game in 4K with 120fps! Who cares! The graphics of your game can be amazing but if the game play sucks then why bother!? This game is all about strategy and tactics not graphics. That being said I am very disappointed in the strategy and tactics of this game.

For starters Artillery is absolutely useless in this game. The artillery doesn't break up enemy formations or charges. It inflicts very little casualties until point blank range with canister fire.

I also find fortifications to be completely useless. For instance if enemy forces come at your fortifications from a slight angle your troops will completely ignore them until in melee mode. The casualty rate is also not effected at all by fortifications. My units will suffer loses at the same rate whether their in fortifications or not.

The AI is also horrible it lacks any strategy at all. Rather than attempting to outflank your positions or pound you with artillery to weaken you, the AI will just send everything it has at you in a frontal assault over and over again. The worst part about this is that the AI will always be better than you at a frontal assault. It doesn't matter how much your front ranks outnumber the enemy they always push you back and route your units!

The lack of strategy is also effected by the timers and limits you to trying to push the enemy off the field as quickly as possible before the end of the day/timer. In real life some battles would last for days with one army just trying to maneuver around a hill and take it. In this game your limited to just a few hours. As the Union you should be able to mass produce artillery and just pound rebel positions into submission just like real life, however the balancing aspect of the game doesn't allow this. It doesn't matter how much you spend on weapons or making your army bigger they always match you. It is very frustrating when playing as the Union and being matched in manpower, artillery, and equipment in every battle. In reality the rebels largest factory in Richmond produced only 30000 rifles over the entire civil war Springfield Armory produced 15-20000 a month. The rebels should be outnumbered and outgunned in every battle that's reality! The most frustrating part of all that though is the Artillery being completely ineffective. Even if you make over half your army artillery and buy as many cannon as you can you'll be overrun in a matter of seconds because they don't stop, slow down, or inflict any real damage upon the enemy.

The final frustrating point is the campaign. My problem with it is that there is no way to fight a different battle. Your always fighting the same battles over and over again and it doesn't matter if you win battles you should've lost. For instance if you win First Bull Run as the Union you continue the campaign as if you lost it. The reality is that if the Union won First Bull Run then the Union would very quickly have been knocking on the door of Richmond early in 1861. If your the Union and win Second Bull Run Lee still invades the North. The reality is that Lee would not have invaded the North if he lost Second Bull Run. 

So overall this game needs a lot of improvement before I can recommend it and it's disappointing because I really want to!

For some Historical reference check out this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lrXxz4iniRs 
If you don't understand the strategy of the civil war you will after watching. You'll understand why Robert E. Lee was so aggressive despite being outnumbered and outgunned all the time!

I also have more hours in the game than Steam is recording because I'm not always online. Something Steam needs to fix!

UPDATE: May 2021

With the release of Grand Tactician: The Civil War I've been playing Ultimate General Civil War again for comparison. Unfortunately this game still has a negative review from me. Despite improvements made to the game over the years the overall game play is still lacking. This game lacks and campaign strategy it remains just a Civil War arcade battles game. If that's what your looking for then this game is for you. However that is not what this game was marketed as. When i purchased the game I was expecting what eventually became Grand Tactician: The Civil War. In that game i can move armies all over the place. In that game there is a campaign strategy I can take Richmond early in 1861 as the Union and continue marching the AoP further South all while having trouble containing the rebels in Missouri! 

While the artillery in UG:CW is improved not so heavily nerfed as it was a few years ago my original points about the type of weaponry being useless still stands.It doesn't matter how well armed my Union army is the rebels always match it. the Rebel army always rivals my size so raising huge vast army is useless. Better to keep it small and rely on the other armies in the big battles and preserve your army for the battles in between.

Because of the style of the campaign your still dragging this one army all over the South and fighting in every major battle which also takes away from the realism. Fighting the Battle of Shiloh on April 6-7, 1862 and then fighting the Battle of Cross Keys on June 8, 1862 with the exact same army completely takes away from the idea of a true campaign. The logistics of such a movement of a massive army would not allow for such a marvel in 1862 for either side.

In the battles themselves my original complaints also stand there is no ability to change the strategy of any battles the way UG: Gettysburg mastered. It doesn't matter how many times you fight the battle of Shiloh once you figure out a winning strategy you will play the battle the same way every time. Also the way it breaks up a battle map into sections and makes you fight the battle in sections also takes away any true strategy the game COULD allow. This is something GT:TCW masters actually and gives you the map for a large area and allows you to fight anywhere on the map and approach a battle differently than they were fought IRL. For instance Chancellorsville is always fought the way Hooker and Lee fought it IRL in UG:CW. In GT:TCW i can be more aggressive as AoP and not halt at Chancellorsville and actually push Lee.

In the end this game is nothing more than a Civil War Battles Arcade game, and unfortunately that's all it will ever be for me. If you want a true Civil War strategy game along with being able to fight the battles my ultimate recommendation is Grand Tactician: The Civil War!

You lose. Reload and try again three more times." Literally many of the battles I'm supposed to attack the AI will actually attack me because it's so stacked against me.

I played through three campaigns. A lot of stuff in the campaigns doesn't make sense at all. There are little-to-no ahistorical scenarios even within the battles themselves. The game obviously wasn't playtested thoroughly or the developers had zero respect for their customers. For example as Shiloh for the CSA - if you manage to take Pittsburgh landing, it makes zero difference. It still advances to the next day and now you don't have Pittsburgh landing. The flag will even show as CSA but the Union will have all the fortifications you already won. Apparently the designer considered this feat impossible

The conditions and the timer will work against you when you're "supposed" to lose or be pushed back even if you totally disagree with the way the game will change objectives and force you to fall back when you might be crushing the enemy or you might lose a battle or end up with a draw in a scenario due to a technicality. It gets old and invites the reload-and-fix mentaity in spades because it's so dumb. I kick the AI's ass and very often when it's a good fight it will be cut short by a scenario end or a change in objectives. 

It pains to me to think what could have been. My first campaign I assumed that there was multiplayer. I was like "oh well, that was kind of an anti-climactic end to my months-long campaign playing time, at least there's multiplayer." And then there isn't.

I played both side's grand campaigns . You begin gradually buidling your own Corps (up to five of them) with a set number of divisions and brigades you can have depending on your stats. You get "Career points" over the course of the campaign that you can expend to pad your stats in a number of areas such as organization (size of units), medical (recovering casualties), training (recruiting veteran troops), ammunition starts, recon (seeing what the AI army will have beforehand) and a bunch of other things. Additionally you create and equip all the units you field with what you are given. As the war goes on other weapons become available in larger numbers and you can replace the old ones or re-equip units however you see fit with what weapons you captured or bought or were given.

For the most part you fight with all the forces you made. On occasion you will have other garrison units or especially cavalry outfits for specific battles which are not part of your command but still your's to control for that battle. Those are usually trap scenarios. You don't have to play every mission available to you. Look at the dates of the battle so that you don't skip any that you don't want to skip. Generally they are an opportunity to get more money, manpower, and career points. You can lose battles and you should understand the victory conditions before you plan. Some battles do not make it all that clear that you will get more time and continue to extend based on circumstances (which were pre-planned by the mapper).

Combat is better than in Ultimate General Gettysburg. You are no longer 100% reliable on the Corps commanders for helping your units' morale recover, they'll recover on their own. Effectiveness, reload time, range, and deadliness is all effected by what muskets, cannons, carbines, or repeating weapons  (whcih are way too watered down) that you give your guys. You can take any given brigade and deploy a battalion of skirmishers which is very useful for scouting and working against artillery or side threats. Your units' various veterancies come with perks you can pick. You can recruit replacements between battles. Artillery is not quite as overpowered while still remaining potent with proper support. Long range artillery (solid shot in this game) is almost useless (24 guns inflicting at most ~5 casualties a volley) for their ammunition expense, except for targeting precious enemy artillery to support your infantry. A "target artillery" button would be very helpful for the guns that occasionally will lose sight of their target and then turn to the nearest infantry. You also can no longer select your ammunition type, like you could in Gettysburg.

There are some other small quirks. I don't quite understand why you have a Lutheran seminary model in Ultimate General Gettysburg but other random structures that don't resemble it on the battlefield in this version's Gettysburg. Unless I'm missing something, there's a lack of labeling on the map. The intro may refer to specific spots on the field but without knowledge of the battle you won't know where / what they are. Fortifications are a big problem at times. It's often sadly true that putting your men in designated places for defense is more detrimental than it is helpful. Sometimes it will subject my guys to a "flanking fire" regardless of where the fire is coming from and they will quickly rout. Very often my units will not fire with all their might when in a defensive structure -- putting them in a losing fight despite the protection afforded. I don't quite understand the conditions causing units to surrender. Sometimes when they are overran, exhausted, and routed, they will surrender quickly. Other times they won't ever until they lose enough men to simply vanish into a placeholder mob of men which freely leaves the battlefield unharassed (desertion?). 

You can't rotate the map around. Even Sid Meier's Gettysburg! (1997ish) allowed this so it's kind of a surprise that they designed it so you can't. The field is only visible from two angles, straight from above and a little cocked to the side. The end of the campaigns is a little rushed, it basically goes from Cold Harbor to your last battles. The Western theater is forgivably mostly ignored other than some major battles (no Atlanta campaign). Also, as many have pointed out, the default speed of gameplay is quite fast and I'll generally play on the slower setting. 

The AI is challenging at times but once you become used to the basics it will cease being a major challenge. UNTIL YOU TRY the higher difficulty levels where it's just stupid. The AI gets elite troops every scenario and always have better weaponry. Many battles (Union and Confederate) I obliterate the opposing army on the 'normal' modes. During my campaigns I inflicted twice or more of my number of casualties which I took during the campaign. The AI reacts poorly to breakthroughs. If you smash through one area the defenders will often stay in their fortifications or trenches allowing you to come up behind and shoot them. Sometimes they'll try to march right by your men to get back to those defensive positions. The AI is also a poor attacker, you can only really be overwhelmed when in a poor spot or at very bad odds. I am an old-school gamer. I always complete Singleplayer before multiplayer. That's what I did over months. So I was a little sad that when I took D.C. and I took Richmond after all that hard work that I can't compete against other humans. I was really looking forward to doing that in a way I fought against humans in Gettysburg! and other Civil War games.

Overall, the campaigns are entertaining and a little challenging. The replayability comes in the units you build and how you fight the battles. Bring your full complement of troops, you'll need them. I just wish I could fight other humans.

THE GOOD, THE BAD, AND THE UGLY: 

THE BAD: It's a historically interesting game that is well designed, but it's stupid hard after a certain point and just becomes ridiculous. In campaign mode, after the battle of Gettysburg it is just dumb. Playing as the CSA is actually easier than being the Union, which doesn't make any sense, and there is no way to win without conquering a battle royale style final battle with all of the CSA heavy hitters present, of course a final showdown between your general and the man himself, Robert E. Lee. During the final battle campaigns, the only way to win is to send thousands of soldiers up hills and against impenetrable walls; victory is only attained through sheer brute force. For this reason, the game becomes really silly. 

THE GOOD: Amazing game play on the historical battles and for the first half of campaign mode. Building armies is a lot of fun and challenging and there is a lot of rich historical information. Optional battles in campaign mode offers a lot of flexibility and brings a strategic influence to the game. Having your line spanning the battle field and cutting down the enemy as they attack is quite a fulfilling experience, and really brighten your day. Up until Gettysburg (and during), this game is just incredible. Historical Battles are all also quite interesting and challenging to play. 

THE UGLY: After a certain point and on the higher difficulty levels, the AI just starts throwing itself at your lines in a desperate attempt to break them. In the worst scenario, I inflicted 58,000 casualties on the CSA at the battle of Cold Harbor, a horrific event that would have not only ended the Civil War, but likely would have ended the south and anything to do with the Confederate cause forever. Also, reorganization of the army in camp can be very clumsy and frustrating. No way to combine brigades or divisions, no way to swap, (unless there is free space) and career points are needed to increase the size of the army, which makes choosing skills obvious and silly (you have to choose the one that increases your army size). Also ugly is that Brigade and Division leaders are often killed or wounded rather randomly, which effectively removes them from the game, however, Corp Commanders are never lost, even if they are destroyed on the battle field. Also, soldiers behave like mindless zombies who relentlessly throw themselves into suicide situations, thus resulting in highly unrealistic maneuvering and tactics that just would never be seen on a real battlefield. Finally, and worst of all, the game doesn't let you setup the battlefield, and is instead highly inflexible in who and where your troops deploy, usually resulting in very awkward starting positions that would never occur in the real world. This makes for a frustrating experience when you can't execute the tactical plan you had because the game restricts you from doing so for no reason other than apparently making it harder to win. In one example, I had all of my artillery deployed on the other side of the field from my infantry, and enemy Cavalry just attacked them and routed half of my brigades. It was just stupid. 

OVERALL: Worth it, but don't plan on finishing it on campaign mode unless you have a lot of time on your hands. I won as the CSA and that was exciting, but playing as the Union is frustrating because they actually won the war, and yet it's not possible to win the game as them without sacrificing about 60,000 Federal soldiers in a ridiculously futile battle for the city of Richmond, that takes literally three hours or more to complete.

Ultimate General: Civil War is a fun and challenging game that does a good job at representing the events of real civil war battles. However, the game has some problems with balancing, exploits, glitches, and difficulty scaling.  

Ultimate General: Civil War is a great single player strategy game and much of this comes from the way the campaigns are structured. Battles are scripted to represent historical strategic realities, and brigades carry over from battle to battle with an upgrades and equipment system. The scripting system allows for multi-stage/multi-day battles, large battles with multiple fronts, piecemeal reinforcements, and the changing of objectives mid battle. The campaign initially gives the player only a few divisions to control, and most of the early battles are fought by units that do not carry over from battle to battle. As the campaign continues a larger percentage of the army is paid for by the player and by the battle of Second Bull Run the entire army is managed by the player. This game has hand crafted scripted historical battles that have the player using armies they designed over course of a war and it works very well.  

This game is balanced to be reflective of historical realities, but this makes one campaign nearly impossible on higher difficulties. The Union has access to more money, soldiers, and better weapons, but are more often expected to storm defensive trenches. More standardized production, rising conscription, and new innovations make the Union army more powerful over the course of the game. The Confederates get less of everything, but more often get easier defensive missions until the late game and are awarded legendary generals earlier into the game. During the late game the Confederates are expected to go on the offensive for battles like Gettysburg and even storm well defended fortresses while outnumbered. This can easily drain the player of resources. The customization options are not just a way for the player to customize their armies, but also a way for the developers to force the player to consider the bigger picture while playing the game. Even with intensive micromanagement, long-term planning and rampant exploit abuse the Confederate campaign is nigh impossible on the hardest settings, but this makes sense.  

There is a large number of exploits, glitches and issues with balancing that can ruin the game for new players. [spoiler]Detaching skirmishers will trick the AI into changing targets, halting all firing and even abandoning their defenses to make a suicidal charge.  Most defensive positions greatly reduce firepower and are broken in a way that leads to brigades being fired on from behind by units they are facing from the front.  With some defenses firing on a brigade from the front from the right angle can instantly route a unit. Later Union trench battles can be cheesed by using snipers to shoot at a trench from the right angle to force a cheap instant route. Forests are incredibly overpowered as they allow units to maintain a high firing rate and take little damage. For the Confederate version of the battle of Second Bull Run the optimal strategy is to start the battle by abandoning the walls, trenches, and houses for a forest that should be the final line of defense.[/spoiler] This game has many issues and players would be wise to keep themselves ignorant of them. 

Ultimate General: Civil War has clearly had a lot of effort put into it, but more advanced play devolves into exploiting the game. Some levels on higher difficultys feel as though they were designed around being cheesed and exploited and that’s just not fun. However, the game at its core respects the history and provides a fair challenge. This game is 100% worth a few normal playthroughs, but please the challenge of the hardest settings is just tedium.

I haven't played this game too much, but the time I have played I do enjoy it but there's some things I think someone getting this game should be aware of.

 First, the battles are a bit slower paced. Not like a simulation, but not quite like a Total War game either. This means there's more emphasis on predicting how a battle will go prior to placing troops. Also you can't rely on troops to sprint from place to place so committing troops in one place or another can alter how the battle goes if your people are out of position. Units who are flanked, even by a little bit can quickly break and soon your whole line is breaking apart if you're not careful.

 This leads to another point. AI is smart enough to generally go toe to toe with you. They make good use of their units and can exploit weaknesses if they arise. However, I think a big portion for why they are so effective is because EVERY battle seems to have the enemy outnumber you in nearly every way. Their units are larger, i.e. more troops per unit, and they have more units. This is mostly in the campaign where apparently the enemy portions change specifically to outnumber your army.

 Despite that, this game is good fun and I recommend it to anyone who likes the history around the American Civil War, or just wants a tougher challenge when playing Total War or a game similar.

I was skeptical about this game at first - I've played a LOT of strategy games, and this one didn't really seem very flashy or polished compared to say, Company of Heroes or XCOM 2. 

I have been blown away. The more I play this game, the more I come to appreciate how fluid, balanced, and tactical it is. I love that there's just 5 kinds of units, enabling you to manage massive armies without getting overwhelmed. I love micro-ing my units, I love naming my units stuff like "The Scooby Doos" or "Blue Man Group" (Because the Union wears - nevermind, you get it). I love customizing weapons and officers before battles. I love telling my infantry to charge an artillery battery and hearing their battlecry. There are like 1000 little things in here that don't sound amazing on paper, but in the aggregate, those little details are what makes a great game great. 

One thing that I wanted to draw attention to is the fog of war. This game was one of the most opaque fogs of war (fog of wars?) I've ever played, and I LOVE IT. When you have no idea where your enemy is, it adds so much strategic depth to the game and also creates some hair-raising experiences (like when you hear a rebel battle cry coming at you from the forest, but you have no idea where it's coming from. Absolutely terrifying). 

Anyway, I cannot recommend this game enough. My only complaint is that the first mission is garbage, so just try to power through it, and watch Youtube videos if you need help.

Boy, I'm torn. Most positive reviews here lack any mention of some serious deficiencies in command, mechanics, and the campaign, and from the small number of negative reviews it seems that only a small number of players ran into the same issues I did. I LOVE aspects of this game (particularly unit and army customisation), but since "The Good" has been covered by so many people, I'm going to focus primarily on the negative, but even with the positive, I would not recommend this game for a very important reason I will get to.

So as much as this is a standalone game, it should be remembered that the designer started his career in game design as a game modder- going on to create a comprehensive set of balance patches for Total War games that focused on a more flexible morale system and realism. The changes that his mods made in those games generally have now become the "default" for this game. Morale is more of a give and take, and rather than simply "routing" your units can leave and return to combat several times during the duration of a mission. Lots of casualties taken at once also are now more critical to your units morale, and flanking is even more important than in Total War games.

With that comparison out of the way, it's very obvious that despite learning what changes in mechanics from the Total War series were beneficial, Ultimate General is still one of his "early" games. Some quality of life improvements are missing (such as stances or formations that would be useful- as it is now you have no ability to quickly form up your units and must resort to slowly lining up units one by one before "locking" them into a stiff formation that cannot shift it's arcs of fire effectively), and the "drag to" command style, while sounding good hypothetically, is at best unneccessary 90% of the time, and at worst will actually draw BEHIND your unit if it's moving and cause them to about-face mid battle, often routing them immediately. These facing issues continue when your units "fall back" or rather, "fall beside", through their own right flank, again exposing themselves to enemy fire. When choosing a target, your unit may select an enemy group further away than others, again exposing their flank causing a rout.

"Innovative command system: You decide which level of control you want. Command every unit individually or just give them a main goal with one button click and watch if they can take that hill."

No. This is a dreamy wish. Your friendly AI is lobotomised (think total war AI controlled army) and your individual units are incapable of handling themselves without constant micromanagement. Weirdly enough, the enemy AI seems competant, but that could be because they had a 5-15% advantage in numbers over me most of the campaign. I understand that people complained about this in the first game as well, but it doesn't seem to be quite capable yet. Additionally in a campaign where you're TOLD ("sometimes, foreshadowing can be relatively obvious") that you will get better rewards if you take more objectives, you will NEVER cede control over to an AI if you can help it. 

I guess I should get to the anecdote that brought me to put the game down, saying "Ah, I'll pick it up again a little later." I have yet to pick it up again even though I enjoy the game immensely.

When you begin a mission, generally you have no idea what to expect. You will get basic information, like the number of armies you can field, and the aproximate composition of the enemy force, but your particular objectives or what they might CHANGE TO throughout the mission are absent. You do not get to see the number of days a mission can go for.

One major problem with this:

When you are composing your army, questions such as "Should I recruit more men, or should I get the ones I have better rifles?" arise. Often times it's best to go with a balance of both, but in certain situations a large force of moderately equipped troops WILL BE REQUIRED to smash through the often superior numbers of the enemy, and in others the exact inverse. On missions that last more than one day (of which there are a few), larger numbers of troops generally are needed to absorb the casualties of large fights. However since there is no way to know before the mission starts how many different stages of objectives it will have, or how many days it will go on, designing your army is a completely crap shoot the first time around.

Suddenly the mission you had properly provisioned for when you thought you only had one objective to capture/defend now goes on for another set of objectives or god forbid another day, forcing you to desperately push forward to capture it before you're destroyed, or to restart the mission with a different army now that you have the hindsight of save-scumming. You would think that a mission briefing would show you ALL your objectives at once, but no as the General you've decided you don't need to be privy to the exact objectives on the map until you've chosen your army and played through half the mission. What the fuck? I can understand the surprise of a whole other day of combat being REALISTIC but why would you not tell me plan B, and C?

And hell, it's not like YOU (as the general) get to decide if you want to fight another day, or split a small mission into a 2 day cake walk, THE GAME decides that for you, but still doesn't tell you when it has arbitraily decided to have a two-dayer. 

The worst perpetrator of this is a confederate mission that pits (even after acing all previous missions) 45000 Union troops, against (at my best) 37000-40000 troops. After spending the better part of my play time with this game just trying to get past the first sets of objectives with enough men that I didn't have to restart, it told me that if I pushed hard enough, I could take the hill and victory would be mine!

It was such a high, pushing harder than I had every pushed before, using the combined tactics of what remained of my advances rifle squads and my cannon-fodder line-riflemen. Several valiant charges later we broke through the defended position! We captured the objective, with the enemy recapturing it once more- WITHIN THE LAST 5 SECONDS I captured the point and secured it! I jumped out of my chair-

-only to see the game roll me over to the next day, move all of my units BACK to a previously captured objective, spawn a fresh set of union units on the hill (who then recaptured it before I could stop them) and give my entire army ZERO rest of recouperation/reinforcements.

I was heartbroken.

I don't mind buying this game as a thanks for all of the work he's done on the Total War games- as a thanks for the mods- but this game does not have a "Dynamic Campaign" or an "Innovative Command system", and the small quality of life failures (proper missions briefings, fall back, drag-to, moving goal posts) pushed me away from this game. I can't really say if it's really a good game or not- all I can say is I only played 47.7 hours.

Wonderful strategy game, with some issues that may or may not bother you depending on your own preference.

1. Beautiful graphic design, each map is unique and immersive.
2. Good gameplay, units are easy to control and pulling off small and large scale strategy is made easy.
3. AI is decent, however the game features a complex difficulty system which can punish you later on for making the wrong economic/army structure decisions in the first few levels.  This system takes a lot of time to learn and can make getting used to the game's grand strategy a turn-off for new and casual players.
4. Missions being on a timer can result in some strategies not being viable, although this is a deliberate gameplay choice and has it's benefits of keeping the game moving.  
5. No multiplayer is a serious disappointment.

Lacks sufficient tactical depth:

You can have two 'troops' of units both 'clashing' into/thru each other when crossing a narrow bridge. 

The cover that buildings provide shouldn't apply if both divisions of forces are fighting each other in what is equivalently the same building.  

Divisions shouldn't receive a flanking penalty when being given a withdraw command (within reason).  

Divisions should be able to 'about face' to be able to turn around when assailed from the rear (distinct from 'wheeling' your force, I'm aware).  

Excessive casualties on a bridge or similar 'choke-point' should impede the passage of troops.  

Opposing cavalry shouldn't be able to glide through standing divisions of men.  

Responsiveness to commands should be a bit 'tighter' (weird delays when issuing orders).  

Etc. etc. etc.  

Close to a correct formula though.  It's simplicity invites you into the game, but there isn't enough there to keep you engaged IMHO.

This is a fantastic real time tactics game set during the American Civil War (ACW). Not only that, several game mechanics are based on real historical issues, and the entire game balances historical issues and fun exceptionally. 

In this game, you can play the campaign or historical battles. Historical battles place you in command of the army of your choosing during the more well known battles of the ACW. You are given objectives and troops that are similar to that used in real life. The campaign is the real draw here: You create your general and are given command of the army of your choosing. You fight a starter battle, then are given a handful of units, and you are supposed take your army to victory. Doing so requires that you resupply and equip your troops before each fight using resources obtained. You get to choose how large your units are, who commands them, and what they are equipped with. There is no campaign map - it's just a campaign menu, but It's very compelling. You are then asked to take these units into the well-known battles of the ACW and achieve victory. 

Battles play out similarly to Total War battles, if you are familiar with those games. Individual units or groups of units (i.e., brigades in the parlance) can be given commands in real time, and they will follow them to the best of their ability. Moral plays a big role, as brigades rarely fight to the last man. Again, very compelling stuff here. The AI will keep you on your toes in several of the battles.

In the campaign, winning or losing battles results in the gain or loss of political power. You can use political power to buy weapons, generals, recruits, etc. However, if your political power falls too low, you lose the campaign (i.e., the president of either the CSA or USA fires you). Again, it's all compelling - do you spend political power to help your troops, or do you save it in case you start losing battles?

I don't have enough positive things to say about this game. I've played over 150 hours and want to keep coming back to it. For anyone who enjoys the ACW, or fans of the gunpowder Total War games, I'd say this is a must buy.

However, the on-the-field battles are sorely lacking. Skirmishers out-running cavalry on foot, cannons somehow firing while mobbed by thousands of infantry, your units will run the second they make contact with the enemy but the AI can zerg you endlessly with little consequence. It doesn't help that no matter how well you do, the AI will always magically respond with more men by the next battle. I wouldn't argue that this game has a steep learning curve and you shouldn't expect an easy victory, but it really dilutes hard-won victories when they honestly don't matter in the grand scheme of the campaign. Your future battles will not become easier because you wiped out an enemy corp's manpower, because they will simply get a magical new shipment of Irish immigrants in the next day.

I would say buy this game with caution. It honestly may not be for you, but the concept is amazing and I really hope this company makes serious improvements to future installments. They have a really great mold here, I hope they don't waste it.

I've never seen a game achieving it's main purpose so well: If you read the forums, a true 'Civil War' is about to erupt among its community around one specific issue.

Sadly, in this game, your main enemy isn't the Confederate or the Union. It's really: The clock!

Fans of this 'timer' say it keeps the game more challenging. I personally side with the other camp and think that, on a game that is so realistic and slow-paced, this very tight timer set for each battles forces us to neglect the strategic aspects, and way too often just run and charge the enemies like chicken with no heads (or cavalry with no horses I should say!)

It's sad because the solution is very easy: Like the Total War series and so many similar successful games, why not just making it optional?! How can that bother them, or the community in general, if I prefer a slower and more realistic pace with no time limit, when I play offline and all by myself?!!

But outside of this much debated issue, which definitely causes me to play it much less than I normally would, the game is otherwise fantastic! 

It runs well without any issues. Graphics are great. Sounds are very realistic. And trust me, those 'puffs' of smoke coming out of the guns of an entire division when they fire (and the corresponding enemy units falling in front of them) during each salvo....are borderline 'orgasmic'! ;)

A very rare and unique masterpiece, both for the genre and the historical era! And as such, very easy to recommend!

One of the best strategy games I played and I don't even like Civil War period!

The things that are great:
- Persistent army - kinda like in Homeworld series your army remains and get veterancy across the campaign.
- Huge range of historic weapons to choose.
- Logistic and economy of your army.
- AI is very COMPETENT - what I mean? usually game have dumb AI that has 10:1 advantage to have chance with player, or the AI is cheating, all knowing. Here the AI PLAY LIKE HUMAN - play well, try to counter flanking, but also makes some msitake that you can exploit. Simply the AI is fum to play against.
- nice spit between side-battles and major battles.
- multi-phase huge major battles - example: phase 1 - you fight on left flank, phase 2 you fight in the center, phase 3 you fight on right flank, phase 4 you merge all into one huge battle, phase 5 you need to push/retreat to final point.
- "reputation points" which can buy you favors (new equipment, officers, cash, recruits).
- Union campaign is fun and Confederate campaign is a bit more challenge (but still within resonable and fun level).

There are some cons:
- there is almost no "persistent army" on enemy side - you can obliterate entire armies during battle, but enemy will aways get fresh and veteran troops next battle.
- many of weapons are in such small amounts that you barely can equip one brigade with them.
- you don't really know how many phases/days each major battle takes.
- veterans cost waaaaay to much.
- oficers die to easily and it's pure RNG, to the ponint you could easily lack officets to recruit when you have full 5 corps.
- there is no indication that you will loose surplus reputation points when you get above 100.

This game is high drama.  Each battle is a test of your wits.  I suggest reading Napoleon's Maxims of War or Claueswitz's "On War" to help get some perspective on how to manage the tactics and strategies of your army in battle. The game is realistic enough that if you follow principles laid out during that time you will be very successful.  The "camp" section of the game where you gear up for the next battle is exciting, too.  You can upgrade your commanders, add weapons and artillery, and tinker with the compositions of your corps to best suit the mission ahead.  Every resource, including manpower, is precious.  Assembling your force and trying to preserve it while annihilating the enemy is very rewarding when it works. I recommend this game to folks who enjoy FPSs, squad-based games like COH2, or the Age of Empires series.

The short and sweet...this game is awesome for those who love involved battle mechanics in strategy and like civil war history.

Now for the long story:

As a person who loves  intricate, well-designed strategy games and also has a childhood interest in Civil War history, it is incredibly rewarding to find a game which successfully combines those two passions. Typically, most attempts to bring the Civil War into the video game industry always seems difficult, either because the game is developed primarily by historians who are not familiar with game design, or because the Civil War itself is such a niche market, rather than broader stroke themes such as in TW Empire, or EU4, which allow you to play as numerous nations throughout a time perioud spanning centuries.

Luckily Ultimate General, in my opinion, killed it with this title. It has all the Civil War aesthetic to immerse you in the 1860s but also an incredibly intelligent and innovative AI that truly makes defeating your enemy feel like an accomplishment (cavalry dont just conveniently charge straight towards your cannon so you can blast them away with cannister shot like in TW Empire, as fun as that is). In other words, as the title suggests, by the end of each major battle, you feel like an actual general, unleashing your inner bloodthirsty Grant by using your infantry as disposable cannon fodder to overwhelm your enemy, or your inner tactical Lee by setting up clever ambushes on good ground and flanking your enemy at the right time. 

Every terrain in the game makes a difference, from having your regiments hide out in a copse of trees, hunker down behind stone walls, or even just take up position at the crest of a steep hill. Flanking and outmaneuvering your opponent is also more important than in other games. You should always attempt to surround your opponent if possible but need to be cautious not to leave your own flank exposed. Just like many real battles from then, things can quickly to hell because you decide to maybe counter attack a weak enemy only to find out they had more reinforcements hiding out on the other side of the field. 

Outside of combat, the game also presents an engaging army management feature that doesn't break immersion by feeling to game-ish. Rather than unlocking better units or upgrades thru research like Civ or TW, you can to purchase or capture improved weaponry or use your reputation, earned by success in battle, to get better rifles and supplies for your men. Also, instead of "leveling up" your units, you can can choose to assign certain officers who have distinguished themselves on the field to lead various regiments (something that you will find incredibly common in Civil War history and politics). For instance, in real life, Lee was only as successful as he was because he delegated command to men he knew he could give generic orders to, and then they would in turn take care of the minute details on the battlefield. In contrast, the Union struggled through much of the early stages of the war because many of the officers were appointed by political favor, often times being politicians themselves rather than West Point grads, and thus knew nothing about how to handle an army. Every officer is a little different and will improve or degrade your units strengths accordingly. 

There's a lot more I could nitpick, but this is a far too  long review anyway. Again, the main takeaway is that this is not only a good Civil War video game, but an honestly fun and immersive strategy game that feels a tad more mature and realistic than some of the others I've played. I highly recommend, at least when you get tired of the cinematic carnage of Total War of the constant expansion of Civ

I want this review to be VERY CLEAR.  I have owned this game for years now, but only really coming to enjoy it now.  I think that I may have been in the mood for a "quick fix" back when I first picked this up, and never really gave all of the mechanics a chance.  

This game is BRILLIANT.  You will see negative reviews saying, "AI Overpowered", "Veterancy Broken", "Cavalry Useless".  In my opinion, if you take your time with this game, really think about what things would have been like, and play accordingly, this game's mechanics are SPOT ON.  

EXAMPLE: Civil War Cavalry - (taken from wiki) - There were four types of mounted forces prevalent in the Civil War. Cavalry were forces that fought principally on horseback, armed with carbines, pistols, and sabers. ... In the second half of the war, most of the units considered to be cavalry actually fought battles using the tactics of mounted infantry. - The word "vidette", as in Vidette Cavalry, comes from Romance Languge (French/Italian) vedetta which is associated with and outlook or sentinel.  You cannot use all Cavalry as Shock troops.

THAT SAID, you can do things to "SPECIALIZE" your troops. Outfit your 750 man Cavalry Brigade with some Carbines that have a range of 300 or more - NOW YOU HAVE MOUNTED INFANTRY.  Their starting carbines are sort of useless, but HEY, THAT'S HOW THINGS WERE!!!

 - "I'M ALWAYS OUTNUMBERED" - HEY NUMBNUTS, EVER HEARD OF A MILITIA? Ever notice those extra 15 THOUSAND  RE-BORED FARMER RIFLES and your extra 12 THOUSAND MANPOOL? Throw some ROOKIES on the field! THESE ARMIES WERE NOT COMPRISED OF BATTLE-HARDENED TROOPS. Most of them were freshies, conscripts, and green volunteers.  Only later on did you have experienced troops.  I am fielding several "State Militia" units headed by lowly Majors.  They work!!

 - USE ARTILLERY PROPERLY - PAY ATTENTION TO RANGE.  At close range, a howitzers and smoothbore cannons turn into GIANT SHOTGUNS.  Crossing a bridge? BRING A CANNON!!  Assaulting the woods? BRING A CANNON!! Holding a Chokepoint? CHOKE THEM WITH THE CANNON STUFF IT DOWN THEIR THROATS!!! YEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEHAWWWWWWW! You get what I'm saying? Good.

- Keep your boiz in COVER!!!  Don't send them out into the slaughter unless you HAVE TO

- the "F" Key can be used to "FALLBACK" in case a unit is taking heavy fire.  DO NOT MOVE THEM OR TURN THEM to retreat.  PRESS F!!!!! They will back away from the enemy WITHOUT TURNING THEIR BACKS. They will not be "FLANKED", lose morale, and ROUT from the fight.

There are so many little nuances that it's hard to write everything down.  I've been sitting here typing for 10 minutes now, but I'm just hoping that you get the idea, and maybe give UGCW another chance if, by chance, you lost interest.

Ultimate General: Civil War is, I think, my favorite RTS. 

It has an extremely high difficulty curve, but once you pass the first hill, it's smooth sailing. In-battle movement is fun and the pause option gives you a moment to really calculate your options before committing your men. That said, it can be very frustrating when units stop responding or just won't fire their weapons. You can have great positioning, but sometime your people won't fire.

Where Ultimate General: CW goes above and beyond Ultimate General: Gettysburg is in the army management. You create your own corps, regiments, detachments, the works. You choose their weapons, their training, and give them stats that will impact the longterm cost of your war. It's excellent at elevating the core gameplay to the next level, but comes with a big drawback. Mid-way through the campaign, you can find yourself in a hole where you either have the wrong units or not enough money to buy new units. It requires a lot of advanced planning to get your army "just so." 

Ultimate General: Civil War is simple. You line up a colored group of numbers and watch the other numbers go down. But the sound design, especially the power of the cannons, makes it extremely satisfying to trick the 3,000-strong Confederate regiment into the riverbed and then hit them with 50 cannons of canister that knocks them down to 1,300 men in 5 minutes. It's hard to match that excitement because it happens so quickly, and you're watching the numbers tick down like a a debt clock, unlike in something like Total War: Rome where battles are fairly slow.

This is quite a special game. You might be turned off by the graphics, but it more than makes up for it with the scale. Battles in Total War, the closest mainstream alternative, can have fewer men than a single unit in this game, and with it comes some educational merit. "Why didn't they just flank around rather than fight in lines?" some people ask. Well, you can try it here, and you will quickly see it's impossible because the armies are so large.

Replay-ability comes from building your army differently, and seeing how it handles different scenarios. There are multiple viable strategies in army composition that can beat the campaigns. Sadly, this freedom is squashed substantially on the highest difficulty, Legendary, which artificially increases difficulty by giving the AI super soldiers, the best weapons to equip them, and by outnumbering the player on top of that. It basically forces you to go with a quality over quantity build.

Weapon balance is a bit wonky, with muzzle loader rifles being better than even repeaters in infantry, (the most common unit,) despite being far more expensive. Fortifications are weird, as the efficiency hit on fortified Infantry sometimes makes them more effective fighting out of them than in, which is just plain silly. There was more to defense than standing in a treeline, but that seems to be the extent of this game's imagination.

Overall, it's a good game, but switching to the J&P Rebalance Mod is highly advised. At the very least, you should use the UI and AI Customization mod, which serves essentially as an unofficial patch for the base game; making the experience far better.

It's fun, but buyer be warned:
This isn't a total war game. Yes there's a campaign, but it doesn't really matter what you do, you'll always be constrained by the scenario. 
If you assign your first corps to an attack, you MIGHT get to use the entire 1st corps, or you might only get a few divisions, and the game doesn't really tell you this. 
Moreover, if you crush the enemy force in a battle (dealing huge numbers of casualties,) don't expect that to be reflected in the following battles. The enemy will always outnumber you, no matter what you do. 

So, while the gameplay is very fun and I do recommend it, I lost a lot of the potential fun when I realized that I'll never actually get to have a battle where all my preparation and would be size superiority lets me crush my smaller enemy force. 
Late game you are ALWAYS placed against a larger force, no matter what, and often times they're entrenched and you have to attack THEM. 
And that sometimes is more stressful than fun. Especially if you know you would never actually initiate that attack under those circumstances.

Honestly, a solid title that knows what it wants to do and focuses on the RTS Aspects. Every single thing matters and none of your units are going to be the same - and that is absolutely brilliant. You can have a large army helped by organisation or a small single corps that is utterly elite at what they are doing with high grade weapons. 

If you like this kind of era warfare or anything related to it (such as Napoleon or even thirty years war), this game will satisfy an itch you did not know you had. While I cannot vouch for the authenticity of the Battlefields, this game is satisfying when you pull something off. 

AI is also pretty clever at times, almost never massing on you unless they have a clear advantage in doing so. Expect them to soften you up with arty or just send forth units to tie up your units. They will flank with a vengeance as well.

Once you get used to the controls and how to move the armies, it was fun and cool to change battle strategy to see if you can create a different outcome.  The down side is now that I've played enough, they all seem like re-runs.  I know what to do in each battle to win with either side so not much of a challenge anymore.  I still play every day tho!

This is an [i] incredible [/i] strategy game.

With most RTS games I get bogged down in the minutiae of managing 2000+ individuals separated in about 20 units, give or take, but where UG: Civil War really shines is with its easy-to-manage units. The controls are intuitive, allowing for less micromanagement and more time trying to attrit the enemy into suing for peace.

Another laudable feature is the AI, which is more intelligent than many other RTS games and will make you pay a steep price in blood for attacking fortified positions while also (mostly) focusing its attacks on where it deems your defense to be weakest. 

UG: Civil War strikes the perfect balance between too much realism (i.e. having a delay in unit reaction time b/c a system of flags has to signal them or a man on horseback has to deliver their next orders, or having your green units route when adjacent units break) and not enough realism.

I often sit dazed at the human cost after what started as a minor engagement. Other times I am shocked that the AI miscalculated and took such severe losses against an entrenched position. But that was the real Civil War, rife with miscalculation on both sides that resulted in over a million casualties. 

That's a [i] river [/i] of blood.

10/10 would destroy a generation to achieve my war goals again.

The mechanics of the actual battles work very well too- if you flank someone it hurts, if you can an overwhelming attack units can start to panic. Great overall game play.

The Good- The reinforcement and morale points system is a good modifier- you can request additional troops, funds, or equipment, but it comes at a cost of overall reputation and morale, and if that dips too low and you lose a battle- that's the game folks! 

The Opportunities- I want to be careful not to call this "The Bad" because I don't actually think there's anything bad about this game, but there are ways to improve. This is solely a tactical game- you fight from one historical battle to the next until the end of the war- with the exception being the "what if" campaign around storming Washington D.C. if you've made it that far as the Confederates. In an ideal world some strategic component allowing you to redirect away from some historical battles would be excellent. Also in their later games you can take artillery and then use it in the same battle, whereas here you can only take it and set it up in the next battle- would be awesome to turn those Napoleons you just took on the enemy.

For all of that this game comes with a high recommendation from me. The developers are superb and continue to push out great material- but this one will remain my favorite from them. The only potential usurper might be the new Grand Tactician: Civil War game- we'll see how that one comes out. Until then- the Ultimate General really is the ULTIMATE GENERAL!

This is a great game! There is a logistical aspect that really drives the gameplay and brings a greater depth to every mission: 

- Each Regiment/Division is equipped with musketry of your choosing, and offers dynamic bonuses based
on historical data of those particular weapons and their availability during the Civil War. You can also customize these divisions and name them, which makes you feel attached to them. 

- Supplies are necessary. Every battle depends on your ability to bring ammunition to certain parts of the battle. I don't know how many times I have not had adequate munitions, and have been forced to cede a part of the battlefield in the early game.  

- Terrain is key and plays a major role in your ability to advance larger units of troops to certain
areas of the battlefield. Having troops under cover of a wood line, or in a wheat field can have different results in firefights. 

This game truly fills a void that most games do not. It is a little more in depth than most strategy games that are mission based, and it really makes you feel in control of your army. The decisions you make, items you choose to equip your divisions with, the kind of divisions you create, and the battles you win (or lose) have a major impact on the campaign going forward.

I've just really enjoyed playing this game. My only criticism is that it is a little too focused on the war in the East. They do include a few of the major battles in the West, but only a few, and they utterly ignore the Vicksburg Campaign. I wish they had broken it down into two campaigns, an Eastern Campaign and a Western Campaign.

While I set this review to be positive, the truth is that this game's appeal is very dependant on what the buyer wants, with the battles being very fun, and the campaign rather tedious.

To start off with, the tactical combat in this game is pretty good. The units move much more smoothly and reliably than in UG Gettysburg, and I feel the weapons effectiveness of the game strikes a good balance of making assualts difficult and costly, but not impossible, even against superior numbers. There are a few questionable factors; for one, while I understand the necessity of making combined arms defenses possible, allowing artillery to fire cannister shot directly through friendly lines seems rather gamey, and while better than most RTS game AI, the AI in this game is hardly brilliant. Overall, though, the tactical combat is clearly well thought out, and will serve as a good foundation for future Ultimate General games.

The strategic aspects of this game are its main failing. First, though perhaps a minor point, I would like to note that the reinforcement system in the game generally leads players to prioritize rebuilding weakened brigades, rather than forming new ones, as was generally the approach taken during the actual Civil War. The main fundamental flaw, however, is that the campaign is essentially a series of historical scenarios, which, aside from manpower, do not change with respect to prior divergences from the historical sequence of events. If, as the union, you win the first battle of Bull Run, you still have to fight through to 1865 to capture Richmond. The game also fails in historical accuracy and interest by compensating for its insufficient AI by simply giving it three times as many troops after each battle as the player gets. This means that aside from complete encirclements, players' prior victories have a minimal effect on the enemy forces in the next battle.

To summarize, the basic battle system of the game is very good, and the historical battles are quite fun, but the strategic campaign mechanics need to be completely reworked to provide either particularly interesting, or historically accurate gameplay.

I really enjoy this game. After getting interested in the history of warfare I've become more and more dissatisfied by the Total War series. This games and Field of Glory 2 are likely the best relatively accessible games that try to show the reality of battle.

personal Pros: 
- the art style does a good job of giving an idea of the size of a battle and the simple design of terrain and units give you all the information you need at a glance
- the progression of building your army while progressing through your military career is neither too quick or slow. The progression is at a spot where you are not frustrated but truly feel that your more experienced and later veteran units have worth making you feel every casualty taken and really getting you to think about how to use them.

personal negatives:
- due to the battles being set instead of there being a sandbox campaign (like in Total War or Mount and Blade) there is some battles that are overly scripted with what is expected of you and what the enemy throws at you resulting in huge difficulty spikes. I often restarted battles until I was satisfied with my performance. (I have to add that the style the campaign is done with aka you doing historical battles in their historical order, between every large battle you can choose to do a small amount of smaller battles in a non set order, is absolutely not a negative especially considering that the budget of the game would've likely never allowed anything else)
- the game is still a video game and as a result has some odd things in battle, one example is that having two 1000 man units against one 1000 man unit in melee will do more damage than fighting that unit with one 2500 man unit

overall a great game with some faults some of which are ironed out by the J&P Rebalance Mod which I would highly recommend

This game walks a very thin line of a completely scripted railroad and tactical combat simulator. More often than not it falls in the former. The enemy is overwhelmingly numerous. They have weird and inconsistent stats that completely dwarf those of your men. They follow scripted paths and there is no real rhyme or reason to the side missions as they impart literally no benefit to you, besides experience. Units are fickle and will barely listen to you, decide to retreat randomly despite no moral problems and there seem to be multiple issues with cavalry involving them not firing revolvers, taking huge casualties in melee against advantageous targets like artillery. On top of all that, the actual combat mechanics are a bit wonky with the battles lasting so long not a single unit has enough stamina to actually last the entire battle or where you are encouraged to shoot into your own melee for extra devastating kills and magically you miss your own men. Meanwhile the AI seems to just constantly get THOUSANDS of fresh reinforcements all the while your same army corpse is taking constant attrition and not a single inflicted casualty seems to stick on the enemy.

Some battles are so lopsided, to the point of ridiculous parody where the numbers are entirely off from the real battle, As for example the battle of Shiloh where in the campaign the enemy has nearly 20'000 more men than you whilst you are fighting on the union side DESPITE the exact opposite being true about the real battle. It just all feels wrong like there is someone behind the scenes making sure every battle is an utter close call with huge casualties even when it's not required. But then the AI is just utterly helpless when you learn the script and manipulate it into performing the actions you want like charging your infantry line with loaded canon behind it or skipping through parts of a battle by intentionally losing to save on ammo and manpower that you can use in the final stand in a better tactical position.

All in all I just can't recommend it. It seems to have way too many problems for it to be a proper RTS and there just isn't any fun to be had when you constantly have to take a peek behind the curtain just to curtail the constant finger on the scale trying to give you a challenge with battalions TWICE your size. And once you peak behind the curtain the famous charge on the Cemetery ridge at Gettysburg morphs into a pathetic 3 battalion charge because you completely murdered the whole opposing army.

Great game.  Polished, well-executed, and immersive.  Battle controls smooth, mostly intuitive.  Interesting tradeoffs in developing army in between battles.  Pretty good battlefied AI, especially compared with other games I've played in this genre.  Challenging even on easier/mid levels, without feeling "stupid hard" with illogical AI advantages on hardest level. 
 There's ways to beat every battle, at any level, without resorting to gamey exploits...but that doesn't mean it'll be easy or cheap.  As is appropriate to the subject matter.

Worth mentioning:  there is a "campaign" between battles, but that portion of gameplay is confined to building/training/equipping the army in camp.  There is no campaign map with maneuvers carried out on the strategic/operational levels.  The campaign is a fixed series of battles all the way through 1865; winning a crushing, ostensibly war-ending victory at, say, Antietam or Gettysburg doesn't end or otherwise shorten the course of the war (although it can reduce enemy's manpower, resources, and morale in future battles).

Overall, I'd probably give UGCW a 7.5/10 overall, but easily 9/10 in its genre (my primary comparison being the similar Total War titles, specifically Empire & Napoleon...with the aforementioned caveat that the comparison is restricted to battlefield play only, as ETW/NTW have a campaign strategic aspect whereas UGCW does not).

I stopped playing Ultimate General Civil War because of game breaking issues, specifically related to continuation of play, when the battle objectives had been accomplished in the first day. The game has since been updated to address these issues since my initial review and these minor updates have made a difference in the player experience. Civil War history is a fascinating period of time and being able to experience it through games like Civil War Generals (1 & 2) and Ultimate General Civil War, is refreshing. The combination of RPG with RTS is a nice touch from the development team. The RPG mechanic involves the management of your character or your army and allows you to apply bonuses through the Careers tab. Each selection can drastically alter the trajectory of your armies success and can affect the long term outlook for how your army engages the enemy. The battle maps are huge and at first is intimidating but as the campaign progresses you begin to appreciate the scale, especially when making wide flanking maneuvers and having the ability to do so without being restricted to a tiny battle map. Overall, I would say that the game is more enjoyable now than it has ever been in it's current state and recommend it to Civil War historians, RTS gamers and RPG gamers alike.

I can't recommend this more.  Not that it is perfect of course (seriously developer that one voice yelling "sir yes sir" in the camp screen absolutely pierces my eardrums every time), but I absolutely love the concept.  I am a big fan of the total war series (especially empire/napoleon hint hint), and although this is missing the depth of a TW campaign, it has even more customization of your units in many ways.   

You control your units weapons, either purchasing them with money won through battle rewards or scavenging your own fallen soldiers weapons as well as the enemies.  If you do give it a try, don't put it down after losing the first battle once or twice.  I did, thinking it was not for me, and then picked it up a week later and havent put it down since.  

Hint for strategy, flanking is the key to winning (as always in these games).  However this game does routing/broken units a bit different.  When a unit breaks, you can't give orders to it until it recovers, but they will still be fighting and shooting a bit.  They just do not fire a coherent volley or maintain a formation.  There seems to be different levels of routing, where sometimes the unit breaks and scatters away from the enemy, and other times are almost in a formation but each individual is firing at their own pace, albeit much slower than the standard volleys.  They also recover from routing much easier, meaning when your center breaks, you need to have a reserve to plug it, but then you can shift the broken unit into your reserve to plug another hole or to send around for a flank attack.  Units break pretty often, but I pretty much always see what I did wrong to cause it. 

One result of this is that cavalry gets eaten alive pretty often, having them mop up routing units only works if the unit has extremely weak melee, eg cannons, otherwise your cavalry dies too fast to clear a large/full unit that broke from a well timed volley into their rear flank.

In response to the review that mentions the campaign following the pre timed events and ignoring what is going on, I do not see it as actually causing a problem.  Sometime the text that pops up during these does not make sense with the battle, but it does not actually affect the flow of the battle when that happens.   I mean, the battle is affected by reinforcements arriving on both sides at different times, but its not like you have to all of a sudden retreat for no reason if you are winning.  Just destroy the enemy as you see fit as long as you accomplish the mission, and you can ignore the text.

If you remember the classic Sid Meier's Gettysburg, this will bring back all those nostalgic memories. It pretty much plays the same as Gettysburg but with enhanced graphics and customization of your units in the campaign which covers the entire war. Fight large battles consisting of tens of thousands of men, often into the hundred thousand range. Although there is no strategic campaign against the AI, it will fight well during battles and attempt flanking maneuvers or focus its' army on your weakest areas. This game is mostly fun, but you will also come across frequent senseless mechanics that I will address below. 

Graphics: It's a nice looking game that's not going to win any "wow" factors. That doesn't mean it's bad, but it doesn't focus on graphics. The game focuses on actual gameplay, and I have zero complaints about it. You can zoom in fairly close to the combat, but not eye level like Total War games. Ultimately, the game looks nice, but by no means will tax your system.

Sound: Crank the volume and you have a full on war going on. Sounds are crisp and clean, muskets have good cracks and cannons provide a great bass roar. The music is also good. Nothing extensive, but fitting for the game.

Gameplay: Take command of the Northern army or Southern army and fight well known battles and many lesser known battles. As you progress as a general, you'll be able to customize your armies with the number of men you want, the weapons they use, and commander abilities to further enhance the regiments such as improved accuracy or melee ability. Since it's an American Civil War game, most combat will be done at range, but if you time your charges correctly, you can do serious damage. But that's where problems creep in. 

The AI can be wonderful at times, and absolute trash at times. The AI is able to charge its' armies across the entire map without penalty, covering large spaces in a short time. Then they'll hit you in melee and possibly route your armies. Anytime a unit is near a charging army, they will reorient themselves to face the direction, even if they are getting shot by other regiments or multiple units are between them and the charging group. And the melee mechanics are quite wonky.

I've charged 2,500 men into a group of 200 men and I didn't kill them. They routed, but they didn't die. 10:1 odds, and they didn't die. And this will happen frequently. I've charged 1,200 cavalry into a group of skirmishers in the open. Despite being armed with sabers, it took the cavalry more than 30 in-game minutes before the skirmishers were completely routed.

And that's lucky too, because cavalry and skirmishers are some of the most finicky units to try and control. The moment cavalry see enemy units they run the opposite direction. Click to engage and they'll sit there. Double click to charge and they'll move in close and suddenly run away. Skirmishers will act similarly. Instead of skirmishing with the enemy, they'll sit just out of range so they're not firing. Click to engage they move up, fire once, and run away. They refuse to actively engage the enemy. Many times, I can't even get them to fire unless I give them a move order, then they'll fire without issue. Same applies when you recruit actually light infantry with long range weapons. Many times I've had the enemy engage the light infantry and they won't even return fire until I tell them to move, then they start shooting.

The objectives to win/lose a battle are very straight forward. But the objectives you actually need to achieve to win the battle can be hard to decipher. As a defender, did you hold 12 of the 13 objectives? Congrats! You lost. As an attacker, did you capture 1 of the 7 objectives? Congrats! You won! Be prepared to fight 2 hour (real life) battles and then lose because of a single objective despite wiping the board on each other objectives.

If you plated Ultimate General Gettysburg, you'll be more disappointed with the tactical combat of this game. The maps do not have the topography information so you can't actually see elevation bonuses as easily on maps with rolling hills.

Conclusion: Overall, the game is pretty fun and the battles can be quite intense. The AI does a good job probing your weak points and then breaking through. The escalation of battles is very enjoyable as it keeps getting bigger and bigger. But battles can quickly become frustrating because of the aforementioned issues.
