Having played this game in detail, I have give an honest opinion. First off, good game over all. For me it was highly addictive and gave me a great sense of nostalgia playing Sid Meier's: Gettysburg and Antietam and General Lee: Civil War 1 and 2. This game seems to be a hybrid of the two, the real time movement and engagement of troops on the battlefield of the former coupled with the stats and economics of the latter. In fact, some of the weapons mentioned in this game, the Farmers and re-bored Farmers muskets (perhaps 1812 Springfields before and after conversion from flintlocks) brought me back to my General Lee: Civil War days.

Pros: As the game progresses you can expand your army; creating corps, divisions, brigades with infantry, cavalry, artillery and skirmishers that you can name your way, appoint commanders, and outfit with special weapons.

As you win battles you earn points towards your general that you can buff certain stats-earning more money from battles, cheaper and more replacements, more ammunition for your troops in battle, healing wounded so you get men back, and recon that gives enemy stats. I like this last perk. At its max it will tell the exact number of enemy troops I face, though it doesn't give locations. The ratio bar fluctuates when units are lost or reinforcements arrive, thereby warning me a counterattack is coming.

Many smaller or lesser known battles are represented; Philippi, Iuka, the Siege of Suffolk to name a few. My favorite is Fort Stevens. Another plus, the developers did their homework as they marked specific units participating in the battle like regiments of the Veterans Reserve Corps (Invalid Corps). Though the one drawback, the unit sprites don't reflect their special uniforms, sky blue with dark blue trim blouse and dark blue forage caps.

One of my favorite parts of this game, the harvesting of discarded weapons. After each battle you're given a list of items that your men either recovered or captured. During the Siege of Suffolk, I bagged 27 artillery pieces and just less than 3,000 stands of arms. Those weapons are now in my inventory to equip my units. As was the case in Fredericksburg-I captured 2,714 Pattern 1853 Enfield rifled-muskets (cause I wrote it down) that I re-quipped one of my new brigades originally with 1842 Springfield smoothbores. So it makes equipping units somewhat easier, granted you'll have to save your pennies to buy enough repeaters.

Another plus, when you win battles you earn favor points from Richmond/Washington that cap at 100. If you force a draw or loss a battle, you lose favor. If it drops to zero the game ends. You can use those points in exchange for favors, extra cash, replacements, or special weapons like some 20lb Parrott rifles, Sharps rifles, Spencer repeaters, or target rifles-to name a few. The more points you earn also gives a morale buff to your units.

Any prisoners taken in battle are 'exchanged' automatically after each battle and you're given free replacements for this exchange. It's on a 1:1 ratio, but it's capped at 1,000 for you. At Gettysburg I bagged 4,630 prisoners, yet gained only 1,000 replacements.

Another plus, the types of weapons used do make a difference. Again the developers did their homework. Gaines Mill, one of my units was engaging a rebel brigade at distance of 100 or so yards in the open with 1842 Springfields and dropping maybe 3 or so men per volley. To assist, a brigade with 1855 Springfield rifled-muskets moved alongside and fired a single volley at the same distance, dropping 40-50 men at once. When I closed the distance to within 50 or less yards, my smoothbores were dropping men like flies. So, props to the developers for understanding what rifling can do.

Cons. The AI is good, but not perfect. Units normally react on their own if attacked so you don't have babysit every unit. However, there were many instances where the AI behaved strangely or glitched. Chancellorsville, rebel wagons rolled right up to my lines as if teasing me to get them. I ran forward and captured three wagon trains without firing a shot. Rebel cavalry also suicide charge solid lines of infantry, either in the open or behind breastworks and are wiped out in a single volley. Enemy infantry do that as well, repeated attacks fail and units are whittled down to 300 or fewer men, yet they come right back expecting it to change. I've also routed enemy units and they, somehow, thread through my line of troops, sometimes several lines, and reform behind me and continue fighting.

The field captures are not consistent. In many battles I virtually wiped out the enemy, yet the weapons gathered are around 1/3 of the number of enemy units on the field-most times they're 1842 Palmetto/Springfields, not real useful by 1864. Same for artillery.

There are quite a few glitches; I've seen some infantry run faster than horses. Once, rebel cavalry became immortal at Fort Stevens. Sometimes units will just stand there under fire and not react, forcing me to remind them to fire. This doesn't always work as I get a 'Blocked' icon even though there are no obstructions between them and their target. Also, the fortifications are a problem. The enemy has to be in a certain position before your troops will engage. Sometimes the enemy firing on me in the open is cutting down more of my guys behind earthworks.

Another complaint, that appears to be common; the strict script. I would agree, in hindsight, this is a big problem. Regardless of your progress one day, when the time runs out you're going to be moved to a new location against your will. At Stones River, I went off-script and launched a counter attack had the rebels almost completely destroyed when the time ran out. 'We're being overrun!' the game would say and then my entire command would be moved behind fortifications. The rebels were so badly damaged after that attack that they made no effort to attack the next day, but had I not been hindered by the script, I would've ended it right there with a total victory.

My last big complaint; no multiplayer. I would love to play a joint-campaign with my friends or face them.

You get some captured messages where enemy officers complain how your efforts bested them. One even called me their 'nemesis' which made me chuckle. They soon repeat themselves. One officer complained four times that he feared being replaced and asked his friend to pull strings to save his position. You'd think after two failures the answer would be-No.

Many maps are also reused for different battles.

The last real complaint is the ending; there's an epilogue; I became governor of New York and heralded with parades so force, but it's just a card and not some you visualize. There's just a period print from a Harper's Weekly of a guy shaking hands. Nothing overwhelming. It would be nice to have a cut-scene where troops are passing in review as you watch with pride, and there was much rejoicing.

This game can be vastly improved upon; cut-scenes, perhaps showing your opponents angry at you besting them. Your men in camp celebrating, and showing the average life of a soldier. Your staff can be your in-game adviser, show the horrors of the battlefield, visiting hospitals so that it gives emotional weight when using the game sprites.

Also, give more choice and allow your actions in one battle influence another and not be hindered by the script.

Include smaller details; oversee court-martials, prisoners exchanges, send scouts to gather intel, and also show captured enemy flags. I'm always eager to capture an enemy flag. Since we can already create units, why not go one further and allow full customization, get Militia, Zouaves, United States Colored Troops, Invalid Corps, and more! 

All in all, a good game and I'll continue playing it. I hope that the developers heed our word and continue to improve or make a sequel. Here's hoping.

Probably one of my favorite strategy games with the most potential, but some big flaws.

The campaign overhaul is an amazing idea, and I vastly prefer the idea of a dynamic historical campaign then a shallow experience like Total War where a lot of important things are glossed over and you get the same generic map, same generic siege battle, and it feels like a game.

But, UG:CW is different. It feels like you are actually fighting an incredibly tense civil war, and there's some jank, yes, but there is absolutely nothing like the later missions when entire corps of veterans and conscripts are duking it out over important battles with interesting terrain and changing scenarios, where failure doesn't necessarily mean the end of the war.

The potential is amazing and it's great, but it's extremely time consuming for these missions and I have to hype myself up before each campaign, and there's some jank as I've said. Not everything is communicated as clearly as it could be, cannons have a certain field of use (Canister Shot or go home!) and a lot of battles have a strict time limit which can really hurt, especially if your going artillery-heavy Union. The other thing is fortifications, which... Well, some fortifications are better then others and others are just deathtraps where being shot at is considered as being "flanked." and instantly breaks your unit. Then there's the missions where they're incredibly useful and help prevent casualties but lowers your damage. 

But, on the other hand, some basic and amazing ideas are introduced. Detaching skirmishers is such a minor thing, but incredibly useful, Consolidation mid-battle, unique types of cannons to use and figure out, strategies you form, and a strong feeling of solidarity with units who you've turned from tier 0 mooks into tier 3 gigachads that are walking death squads, which Total War completely fails to do.

I compare it heavily to Total War since Darthmod worked on this game, one of my more favorite modders who I've followed since Napoleon Total War and dramas around it, and I honestly support him, this game, and his projects out of a hope that it can do what Total War cannot, and deliver a great campaign and experience.

Although the game has many good and quality moments, over all it's simply an exercise in futility. Sword cavalry charge into the rear flank of skirmish troops and end up losing 150 men in the time the skirmishers lose 15. They always just run off and refuse to fight or even hold high ground to site. Even when not under fire they just jerk off ruining your plans. You progress to a point when maxed out the enemy can deploy larger squads than you still. It has little to do with strategy and more to do with following exactly what the game wants you to do when they want. What started out as a promising game is just trash.

This game is a fantastic,  with some pretty incredible combat and game mechanics that works nearly flawlessly and presents a realistic depiction of Civil War battlefields. That being said, it does have some quirks that I feel detract from the experience.

The game is incredibly linear, with essentially no freedom of strategy. The game will tell you exactly where to defend, exactly where to attack, exactly when to do everything, and exactly what you need to do it. The main parts of the game essentially devolve into resource management, where you have to weigh the difference between the cost of victory and the lives of your men. I feel like this system has some slight bonuses, in that it encourages historical realism in terms of the events of the battles, but it can get pretty derailing or upsetting when scripted events take precedence over real-time tactical analysis. 

An example of this is how your army might consist of large units of elite troops fighting an outnumbered foe, but the mission events and cutscenes will still tell you to retreat because the enemy outnumbers you or is stronger. In the same fashion, you could be outnumbered 4 to 1 and the cutscenes will tell you that the enemy is weakened and that you should push your advantage.

Summary: Excellent base game mechanics, fantastic grand strategy elements, but immersion breaking lineality. This game is probably better viewed as less of an RTS and more as a resource management and Civil War battlefield simulator.

This game does NOT deserve any praise as a good game, for it really is not. The developers need to fix this...to cost 74,000 to replenish 1000 men...Veterans, and that is just the cost for the SOLDIERS!

I already had enough guns in the armory to cover that many.

That royally screws the entire reason to even PLAY this game. There is no point...to play, take a total of 22,000 losses and then...IF IM LUCKY able to only replenish...AT MOST 18,000 men.

I just suffered a loss of 4000.

This game offically sucks...and I'm a long time RTS fan, all the way back to the first Command & Conquer games that put this genre on the map.

So...to ALL people who want a GOOD Civil War Game?

Go online to Amazon, buy a Copy of Sid Meyer's Gettysburg and get the fan patchs to the game and play THAT game instead.

The tactics matter more, enemy will attack correctly and adapt to YOUR battle, not historically.

So, if you've stretched your line thin on one end? They'll hit there...hard.

If you've brought up reserves and are waiting for the enemy to hit...say like Picketts' Charge which Ultimate General really FAILS at reproducing...well. It really isn't a contest...this game isn't even worth the money you pay for it.

I ultimately enjoyed the game but have mixed feelings on some of the mechanics. It seems like shortcuts were made in some areas to either make the game more difficult artificially or to avoid the hassle of creating different scenarios. However, the gameplay itself is enjoyable, and it can be fun to manage one's army when in campaign mode.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
- In-depth campaign with a persistent army you grow and use
- Good AI that will normally make decent decisions
- Scenarios that can be exciting and attempt to recreate the POV of whichever side you are in the battle
- Good controls
- A skill system for players that can help make campaigns unique by having different skills at the start

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Artificial scaling of AI
In the campaign, the amount of enemy units will increase with how many units you have in your army, almost always resulting in inferior numbers in a lot of battles, even if historically you should wipe the floor with the enemy, or be massacred by them. This can have some knock-on effects I'll get into below.
- Scenarios can feel very rigid.
I've made scenarios in games before, and I understand how hard it can be to plan for what players do. Especially with a historical game like this, dynamic scenarios can be difficult. Past the early war, it often felt like the scenarios didn't care what the player did. A couple examples that stand out in my mind includes the Union's side of Chancellorsville. In it, the briefing itself says that you should defend, but it could be rewarding to do a risky play and attack the CSA camp. I did that, and did it fairly well. However, when the next day rolled around, my positions were completely reset, I was forced back into my camp, and the Confederates gained an advantageous positions in a battle I was dominating just because of a day swap. It can often make it feel like it's not worth it to do risky plays.

Truthfully, the game is a good game. It can be a fun RTS on the US Civil War, but between issues of scaling and scenarios feeling rigid, the campaign can be frustrating. It seems as though in an effort to make the game more difficult, the developers ended up making it unfair. It feels worthless to invest in "Recon" outside of max level recon because battles will sometimes lie significantly with intel, since they often depend on how many units the player brings. It makes me wonder why I even invest in making a larger army if the enemy is always going to be one step ahead of me in order to make it difficult. If a Union player can decimate the Confederates throughout the entire early war, the Confederates shouldn't keep growing at an insane rate. I've had battles in the campaign where I've killed double the historical amount, such as Fredericksburg, where the CSA had under 10,000 casualties historically, but in game I dealt them 21,000. Yet, the CSA was fine in the next battle, acting almost as if that battle never happened.

Scaling itself isn't a bad game mechanic, it's the implementation in Ultimate General: Civil War that feels bad. Games such as XCOM are great at scaling since it works on a schedule, which would work even better for a historical game. The opponent doesn't care how much you have because they'll keep growing on a schedule. I feel like an implementation of that sort of scaling would work great in a historical game.

I have enjoyed strategy games for a very long time, and this ranks up there with my all time favorites. It is intuitive enough to jump into, yet even as a veteran player you will find yourself learning new things regularly. The game is not overly complex (battle or camp), but there is something very satisfying in developing and equipping your army for the next battle. You become attached to your officers and units over the course of the campaign, giving each battle a personal element. Similarly on the field, getting your units into position for a well-executed flank attack and seeing a devastating volley delivered is very rewarding. 

Graphically it is simplistic compared to a Total War Game for example, but this is quickly forgotten once you get sucked in. You will even come to admire the small animations of your troops as they reload, charge and fire. 

You will certainly learn about the soldiers and battles of the US Civil War and gain an appreciation for their experience, and this is perhaps the greatest part of the game. While it is not 100% historical, it makes a genuine effort to emphasize the history. 

Well worth your time and money!

Highly recommend for strategy gamers. This game manages to create brilliant atmosphere, realism, while maintaining fun gameplay. 

Pros
-There are features that let you manage your forces at the macro/micro level. Adjusting gamespeed and setting movement paths allow you to think tactically. Hotkeys and unit AI allows you to micro manage units quickly or let them make decisions. 
-Really fun game loop. Your troops, commmanders, and generals gain XP. You can build up your army and rank up your commanders and their skillsets the way you want. You are rewarded for winning battles with money, recruits, captured soldiers, etc to add to your army build
-You get to choose the right unit mix to bring into to battle that suits your style and the objectives

Cons
-SCALING IS THE WORST! If you go into battle with a large army, the enemy automatically scales to a large army as well. You are essentially punished for good management. It would be awesome if the devs allowed an option to start your opponent at historical numbers, say ~32K at Bull Run. This would allow you to build your army and punish the enemy vs the AI basically getting free scale at your expense.  
-Linearity of campaign. The multi-day battles while freaking amazing are semi-scripted. You might win an objective that didn't historically happen, for example pushing and taking the battery on the first day at Shiloh, but it gets reset in the next day. It is very difficult to "re-write" history between scaling and linearity.  
-Minor: Some of the units need a lot of micromanaging. The skirmishers and cavalry make really stupid decisions sometimes. Cavalry's auto-avoidance of enemy troops sometimes puts it into compromising positions. Skirms will often fall-back and keep falling back despite lack of real threat. 

Despite the glaring auto-scaling fault,  the core game is excellent enough to overcome. The ambience and strategy is overwhelmingly fun. Its a game you will think about when not even playing.

Do you want to ever feel as stressed as an armchair general when moving around little tokens with a stick? Maybe pull some hair out due to the excessive frustration in being almost twice outnumbered, only to have your ambush that took 30 minutes in real time soiled in about 2 seconds? Look no further than to UG:CW. This is a beautifully constructed game, with so much tinkering involved you'd really have to understand every single game mechanic to maybe get a decisive victory or two. This then results in a smackdown of epic proportions that makes you feel like there was no other choice than to die at the hands of an army of twenty-thousand troops while you try to frantically assemble a meager counterattack force. If you've played Dark Souls, this is sort of the RTS macro image version of it. Though painfully difficult, it is extremely rewarding to find you and your soldiers victorious at the end of the day, and you feel... accomplished. Satisfied. Relieved. Then you get to looking at the battlemap, realizing only then you've drawn more attention to your armies and will likely get crushed again, only to rise back up and perform even better than before. Unless you're a masochist, you are not meant to win every battle even on the regular difficulty (which requires a general understanding of both the game right off the bat and a couple years study in Civil War history and dated infantry fighting tactics), and this game will reward you but at the same time keep your ego in check. You're not invincible, you are, however the Ultimate General.

This is an amazing game. It's a very unique RTS. You get to control your troops in battle (in a cool way where you draw their paths out on the battlefield) but there isn't any base building. Instead what happens is that after every battle you basically go back to your "camp" and you have to recruit new troops into your army, fill up your current units who suffered losses, buy cannons, guns, generals etc from the money you got from the previous battle (basically the gov providing you with funds). This part of the game actually becomes quite strategic and decisions you make on how much $$ or political power you spent can end up haunting you down the line and even end up costing you the war. You can get a game over from the government basically booting you out of the army lol. (recommendation: save often because I have a few campaigns where I basically got to an impassable wall and had to revert back to previous save and change my decision making). 

Also, playing as union and confederates actually feels decently different because of what is actually available to you as each faction. (some diff guns & CSA start with more experienced troops) If you are into civil war this is a no-brainer must buy probably the best civil war game ever created. If you are into historical RTS this is a must buy as well IMO. 

Another thing to mention is that the game is challenging. Particularly the very first battle for the Union is really tough. On my very first play through I did the middle difficult and could not get passed this battle after a few tries, so I went down to the lowest difficulty and still got a run for my money. There are other battles that are very very difficult as well but it's worth noting for those of you who are just starting out that the first Union battle is pretty tough and not all the battles are going to be like that. 

I'm not a civil war expert at all but they do give you a little block of text before each battle telling you what the situation was. There are grand battles and then minor battles and I think even most of the minor battles  (maybe all?) are based off real life battles or skirmishes that took place. I could be wrong on that though. There is a scaling mechanic in this game so the actual # of units in a battle is not historically accurate but one thing that is pretty close to accurate is if the CSA was out numbered in real life, than they will be outnumbered in the game. There are a few battles where CSA had numerical advantage in troops in real life and the game recongizes that. Pretty cool.  

But yeah, overall this game is a load of fun and I highly recommend it to any history buff or armchair general.

A bit of the natural successor to "Civil War Generals" from the late-ish 90s, only that it is real time as opposed to turn-based. The real time aspect gives it a steeper learning curve.

The Good: once you get the basic mechanics down, it does a pretty solid representation of the time periods combat. There is a strong sense of immersion as well because you build out your own army as you go.

The Bad: Between each battle you get to replenish brigades and upgrade weapons. These decisions will impact you as time goes on, but the game gives you no real direction on what to do in "Camp." So there can be some analysis paralysis as you go.

The Ugly: The maps look beautiful and you can mostly get an idea on terrain height, but there doesnt seem to be a map mode to show you terrain elevation changes. So while you are trying to setup that perfect artillery battery, you dont have a great idea on what truly is the best spot.

This game is the king of real-time strategy games. Not only do you learn a bit of history by playing, but you also strategically manage your army's resources, officers, and units. I wholeheartedly and unequivocally recommend this game to any RTS fans or American Civil War buffs.

I have completed the Campaign back to back as Union and Confederacy. I didn't play any skirmish games OR any multiplayer - so my review doesn't mention those facets.

For me, the most interesting facet of the game was in slowly building up my army, supplying it, equipping it, nurturing it and expanding it as the campaign rolled on. From a starting point of a single Brigade your force rapidly snowballs from something that might be found out West in a backwater to a sizable chunk of the Army of the Potomac or North Virginia.

Each battle consumes carefully hoarded resources, so you can find yourself winning the battles but watching your force wither and die, if you do so wastefully. A single advance can bleed you, if it goes wrong, so you'll need to commit scouts, invest in Artillery and tread the line between taking foolish risks and exploiting opportunities.

The Campaign itself has a momentum of its own that drags you from battle to battle - skirmishes and the great set-piece battles of the Civil War.

There are a laundry list of improvements that should have been first on the list for a 2.0 of this game - for a start the War drags you along for the ride - you can choose to ignore the fringe skirmishes if you wish to forgo the advantages in favour of husbanding your resources, but the set-pieces MUST be addressed to move on. There's no diplomatic angle, no maneuvering your forces between battles or anything similar - but given the parameters of the game design, these decisions are understandable.

The graphics are utilitarian but of a consistent and sufficient quality. Gunsmoke hangs in the air, artillery scars the earth and the units serve their purposes. One might have hoped to see some individualisation in weapon types, veterancy and so forth, however.

In all, a very respectable title and one that I enjoyed playing very much during my 59 hours. I'm revisiting it now, some months after completion, and we'll see if it has any replayability value.

If you enjoyed Sierra Entertainment's "Civil War General" in the 90s, this game is EXACTLY what you'd like. I already owned Ultimate General: Gettysburg by the same developer, and while it was amusing, it was pretty much just a redone Sid Meier's Gettysburg (which isn't a bad thing, just limited in scope). This game is different, as it has a revamped engine and plays slow and methodical. Battles are pure chaos but lines can be held -- it's not like Total War titles where you're clicking to twitch move like a madman. You can hold formations if you can manage your morale. It's amazing.

Probably the biggest addiction this game has is its management system. If you like Team Manager style games, you'll get hooked on this. Keeping your army hierarchy in order between battles after officers get wounded or killed is so challenging, and struggling to keep enough arms and manpower to fill your brigades is the bread and butter of the campaign. It's not just an RTS -- this is a team manager wrapped up with an amazing campaign of battles.

These days finding Civil War games, or games in this style at all, is difficult. I'm so grateful this one exists.

Ultimate General Civil War is a fun single player game, where you are a civil war command fighting for what ever side you choose. Fighting and commanding units at historical battles like Gettysburg and Antietam. Below is what I like and dislike about the game. 

What I like: 
It is not just your units fighting at battles, sometimes (Like First Battle of Bull Run) You get to command AI units, cover is important, if your unit is in forests, or in a crop field, they get some cover, another thing I like about it is that each terrain has there ups and downs. There are a lot, and I mean a lot of different types of weapons. Some are good in melee, some can fire at units from far away (not just artillery), and some that reload in a few real seconds. And the fact that every small or minor battle you win, effects other battles. For example: If you win a battle, in the Major battle the enemy might have decreased moral, or less manpower, or even worse weapons. There is a lot more I can talk about. Now on to the stuff, that I wish was fixed. 
  

What I don't like: 
Retreating units: All units retreat in ever battle and in real life, but what makes me say this is that some times the enemy units will retreat behind your lines. Then your artillery is in danger, or they will flank your units, so they fall back or rout, or even break or surrender. Or even worse, they take your supplies. 

More then 2500 men units: The AI some times have more then 2500 units. But your max for a unit (Infantry) is 2500. So it seems unfair, that they get to have bigger units, even when your the union.  

Time limit: Sometimes the time is your friend (Gaines Mill union) and not (marching threw thick forest at Fredericksburg) The time I think should be extended if there is no other event  and will end based on: If it becomes night, To much men on the other side when attacking   

Other then those,  the rest are very minor, or it's just suggestions. So, if you like single player, massive campaigns? This game is for you!

The historical battles in particular are generally fun.. and it is rewarding to turn small victories into much larger ones.. perhaps you are playing as the Confederates in the battle of Antietam and you are able to slaughter the first couple initial waves of Union troops but as the day wears on you are forced back to the Sunken lane.. well since you were able to inflict heavy casualties early on in the battle the endless tide of blue streaming at you is much more manageable. In my opinion.. this view of the game completely changes after a while.. the charm wears off. There is no dynamic campaign.. which in my opinion this game.. desperately needed to have any long term longevity. Honestly.. the only reason I come back to this game is to attempt the campaigns on the hardest difficulty - which is not fun. This game is like the Total War series in that the AI doesn't actually get smarter on higher difficulties.. it just gets so many troops... elite troops.. that the stupid things that it did before will work out of sheer weight of numbers. The game starts to break down as well.. tactics and strategies that worked on lower difficulties will simply fall apart. As you are trying to min-max and cheese your way through each and every battle now you will start to notice where the game completely fails. Holding a line against the AI? Well just wait until the AI charges your face with superior numbers and more elite troops. Think you are winning that melee battle? Look again.. your troops just received a flanking penalty because the AIs artillery from across the map just landed a couple shots in that general vicinity. Now you have a giant hole in your line as your unit routes.. but as your unit routes that elite infantry brigade that just charged into your lines has engaged another one of your units in melee combat forcing it to turn.. now you have a second unit that will receive a flanking penalty albeit justified this time. Fortunately for you.. your artillery has opened up with canister shot on the intruding elite brigade and sent it packing.. now you can surely plug the hole in your line once your units.. recover? Right? No. Because your units are too busy running the wrong way because instead of just running straight away from the enemy they decided that their best chance of getting away is to run parallel to the enemy lines and continually take fire.

You literally have to save scum before every single battle just to min-max how many troops you are bringing to the field because the amount of troops the AI receives scales to how many men you recruit. Did I mention that the campaign is not dynamic? Completely destroying the enemy in one battle has virtually no impact on the next battle. Think you are a military genius and want to rewrite how some of the major battles of the civil war were fought? Too bad. There is no grand strategic map for you to move corps or divisions around on. So your battle of bull run will play out almost exactly like every single other battle of bull run that anyone who plays this game will have.

Honestly, this game is just such a chore most of the time that it's not even worth listing the pros since they are fairly trivial compared to the cons. So I'm just going to run down the cons. 

- Nonsensical Combat Mechanics
       - 2000 infantry, rank 2, with the highest accuracy rifles equipped. Firing on 200 guys, in an open field. 20 kills
       - 500 cav, equipped with sabers engage 200 man artillery unit from the flank, in melee. Cav is routed
       - 750 infantry charge through open field into 1500 entrenched infantry. 1500 infantry routed
       - 2000 infantry (while engaging another unit) sit in front of a 24 cannon artillery unit. 2000 infantry never route or panic.
       - Units are ordered to charge an enemy unit will randomly stop and not complete the charge (cav are really guilt of this)

- Large Battles
       - Large scale battles are on rails and heavily scripted. You can be easily winning one phase of the battle, only to have the next phase occur and suddenly all of the ground you have won/held will be given up and you'll automatically be placed in a disadvantageous position. Frequently, any advantage you gain for yourself will just automatically be lost because the battle needs to rearrange the map and units in order to continue.
       - Even if you are doing excellent in the campaign, expect to be hamstrung in bigger battles. You can field tens of thousands of troops more than the enemy, and the battle brief will even show that you'll be deploying a full corps, however they will only allow you to start the battle with 5 brigades (units) so that you suffer significantly more loses than if you started the battle with a full corp.

- Illusion of Persistent Armies/War 
        - The game gives a bunch of stats and elements that would lead you to believe that your victories/loses/draws are impacting the direction of the war. However it's all fake. You can absolute destroy the enemy in a battle, and the next battle they will come at you will nothing but veteran units. You can kill generals, win key victories, win major victories (I've defeated the enemy 3 to 1), and it won't impact the enemies forces or ability to field full armies of veteran units or more brigades than you. 

I'm really disappointed because I wanted to enjoy this game, and early on it felt novel and intriguing. However, less than half way through the Union campaign, battles became an obnoxious slog that felt designed to stagnate you rather than challenge you.

Ultimate General: Civil War is very nearly the Civil War game I've been looking for my whole life.

It offers a wide selection of battles, units, weapons, tactics, and strategy.

Your soldiers are persistent, and will increase in skill with every battle. Your army will grow over time, and become more powerful. You can even invest in career skills that will change the way the campaign plays out. You are offered a selection of historical battles, and each one is tied together with some optional smaller battles loosely based on historical events.

The graphics are simple, smooth, and polished. Layered 2D sprites give the feeling of a 3D isometric view, holding over from the days of classic RTS games. The color palette is reminiscent of some old Civil War lithographic paintings, and the presentation itself is the very image of a David Greenspan battle map. The puffs of smoke fill the air, the day slowly turns to night, and as the lighting fades from the scene scores of bodies litter the ground amid the brown scars of artillery impacts.

One is left with a sense of horror at the accomplishment of the day's objective, and all of that comes from a presentation that does not rely on blood or gore to convey it's impact.

The sound is basic, but functional. Your muskets pop, your cannons bang, you hear your men cry out in pain as they get hit.
Then the enemy charge rolls in...
Volleys crash together with frightful rapidity, the enemy cheers as they advance at the run, then the lines come together with a clash and an uproar. Every man screams as loud as he can to ward off cowardice as they hack, cut, thrust, and fire into each other's faces. Finally, one side or the other breaks and streams back to whence they came, and the field grows silent once more.

Words can scarcely convey the feel of this game. It has a singular presence I've not felt since a few epic moments in the Take Command series. You get a clear indication of the titanic struggle you're involved with, and it's all wrapped up in a game that is as easy to play as a game of checkers.

So what's not to like?

Well, there's a few things worth mentioning.

1) You never really get a sense of victory as you progress through the campaign. The difficulty of the game ramps up quite steeply even on the 'Normal' mode. Despite winning almost every battle, I never got the feeling I was actually winning the war. The opposing armies were always larger than mine, and by the end of the war the enemy was just as well equipped as I was. There was no sense of a 'turn of the tide' as I stacked enemy bodies upon the battlefield while inflicting three-to-one casualties in my favor. Even with all of the economic career skills maxed out, I never had enough money to maximize the size of my army, and I never had enough money to field even a basic rifled musket like the Springfield in every unit. The Union was supposed to be an economic powerhouse, yet I found myself selling even the fillings in my teeth to equip my army for battle. By the end of the campaign, the enemy outnumbered me two to one, despite the fact I killed far more of them than they did of me at every single encounter.

2) The weapons never really performed the way I thought they would. For example, a unit of 500 skirmishers equipped with scoped sniping rifles couldn't seem to kill more than it's own number of the enemy before running out of ammo. Especially if the enemy was in some kind of cover. Trying to use range and accuracy to inflict casualties without sacrificing manpower never quite came off the way it should. General Sedgewick is safe as houses in this game. Those snipers really CAN'T hit an elephant at this distance.

3) Artillery doesn't work. Period. Having been witness to live firing demonstrations by a 12-pound Napoleon field piece, I can say with absolute certainty the 'King of Battle' has no place on this field. Artillery is hugely inaccurate, and even when it does hit, it does very little damage. This is the exact opposite of reality. Not only is artillery far too ineffective as modeled, but there is no cumulative morale effect on soldiers when being shelled, and cover does not degrade under heavy shelling. Historically, attacking a gun battery was one of the most foolhardy things you could do. It's the sort of thing you would win medals for doing. A simple fix would be to implement a permanent morale loss while being shelled even if it's just one percent morale per direct hit. Another thing I would do is give occupy-able fortifications a number of hit points that would degrade their effectiveness as their hit points are reduced. This would allow the player to bear the cost and restriction of fielding a grand battery in the first place, instead of swapping out that extra field artillery battery for a regiment of foot.

4) Why are there no stabs of flame from firing guns? It makes the battlefield feel a bit sterile. Even just a couple of pixels of bright orange color at the center of the smoke puff would have made a huge difference. I know the real guns don't exactly belch fire when being fired, but in low-light conditions or night battles, some flashes of light and flame would really liven things up.

5) Where is the Rebel Yell? It is conspicuous in it's absence. I never once felt 'that particular corkscrew sensation going down my spine' when the Confederates charged while yelling some generic yelling sound. It just doesn't feel right.

Other than that, this is a fantastic game, well-polished, challenging, and engaging.

If you are looking for a true top level war management game, Ultimate General: Civil War is the game for you. There are some great aspects to the game. The sound effects make you feel like you are actually in the battle. The fog of war feel as your troops are moving into position only to encounter a well entrenched enemy that you did not expect, as well as the unpredictability of your troops morale, present a challenge even to the best strategists. Being able to select individual battles for a quick game is a nice feature.

  Honestly the only two complaints I have with this game is how quickly you lose track of time playing this game, and also that even though I elect to continue my game past the time given, once it reaches dark, the game is over. I would like for it to continue into the next day so I can completely wipe out the enemy.

It's simple, but allows complex battles. The morale factor is also really good where units will fall back, but regain their morale after a bit, and to totally break you need to fully surround.  My only real gripe is that victory is determined on holding positions, while yes that is the basis for battle, but I almost got a stalemate at the battle of fredericksburg because some broken cav that routed from my encirclement walked over to capture the hill while the rest of their army was getting annihilated. The total casualties for the union was 80,000 while my confederates only took 20000, meaning the army of the Potomac was reduced to less than 20,000 men while the confederates still had 45,000. You're telling me that battle would be a stalemate because I didn't hold a single hill. 


Other than that it's really fun!

A friend best described this game as a historical battle simulator with a campaign bolted on to it. If you want to fight individual battles, you'll have fun and I would recommend this game. If you want to play a campaign, then no. 

No matter how well (or badly) you're doing in a battle, the game will force you to follow what happened historically. On the 2nd day of Gettysburg, I've stopped the Confederate attacks and am in the process of counterattacking and rolling up their flank. My army's beaten up but I've two corps on the field and the CSA probably has two badly beaten up divisions. I'm about to rout the remnants off the field but the game stops me because it has to do Pickett's Charge the following day. So I get to watch about 5-7k troops (depleted from the previous day) charge 30,000 troops, mostly behind stone walls. I didn't even bother controlling that fight, I instead take two divisions and start rolling up the Confederate army from the south, letting them bleed themselves against my centre. And of course as I'm about to destroy the last division on the field the battle stops because it's now time to fight Lee's retreat. 

The adherence to history is incredibly frustrating in a campaign game where you can be more successful, inflict horrendous losses on the enemy but you're straightjacketed into following the scripted historical path. There's no point in wiping out an enemy corps because it'll be rebuilt next battle and filled with veterans because the game needs to keep the CSA going until the final battle in the campaign. Apparently Lee didn't realize he could just use magic to keep respawning 2-3 star brigades right up until the battle for Richmond.

This game can be good but often becomes an exercise in frustration when you're steamrolling the enemy but the game grinds to a halt because it has to go to another prescripted battle which may no longer make any tactical sense (see Pickett's Charge). I wanted to like this game but it's so damn frustrating.

This game is perhaps one of my favorite real-time strategy games. I fully enjoyed its prequel Ultimate General Gettysburg and have owned both games since they were in Early Access. 

First despite how great this game is there are cons to this game. At times it could feel too simplistic something that never really bothered me. However, major battles that span over multiple days can be jarring where you can be very successful the first day just for the second day to revert you to the historical positions even if you far out preformed the real life comparisons. I had hoped like Ultimate General Gettysburg they had kept the dynamic way the battle was handled in that game for all of the major battles in this game. For example I wish for battles like Antietam I had the option to carry on the battle for another day if I chose to do so. The same to be true with historically multi-day battles where I might have been clobbered on the first day and have the option to either hold my positions or withdraw and end the battle. The battles are great regardless of these issues but I do wish there was my dynamic interactions with them then there are.

The game however has far more positives. It has an amazing amount of polish and the battlefields are amazing to marvel at. The AI is capable and for the most part feels like a real player. It responds how you would expect a human would in most cases. If it doesn't feel like it has the strength to overcome your positions it won't really try to and will attempt to be more defensive. It made the game in this regard more dynamic with the same battles being different every time based on the condition of the two armies. The Camp system is amazing and I enjoyed naming my brigades and roleplaying a Union or Confederate commander. Battles matter and you decisions in them matter. A victory with heavy losses can come to bite you later in the campaign where you no longer can recoup your losses and slowly find yourself dismissed from the army or flat out destroyed. 

Overall I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a Total War type game that isn't marred in AI difficulties this is the game for you.

I really badly want to like this game, but I just can't. The balance is all over the place & unit behaviours are extremely erratic.

Let's go through the 4 unit types:

Infantry, get them. Only them. They're cheap, many & powerful. They have no flaws. They shrug off cavalry charges & flat out ignore artillery & skirmisher fire.

Artillery is the most expensive units you can get, yet they do the least amount of damage, even if you get heavy pieces & put them in grape-range. Those are ideal conditions btw, yet they horrifically under-perform despite their high cost. This is made even worse when you take unit fatigue into account, which makes having another cheaper infantry brigade a far better choice. There is also the issue of them having to limber & unlimber, which is even more reason not to use them. Artillery's only good point is that they can fire past friendly units (their range is also insane, but their damage at max range is pitiful), but due to the size of the maps & the limitations put on the units you can deploy being blocked is rarely a problem.

Cavalry is extremely random, but usually very bad. Low size units that cannot do much ranged damage no matter which weapons they deploy, mounted or dismounted. This would be alright, if the melee system in this game wasn't completely broken. The melee system is extremely random, 250 men can overpower 2500, if they're infantry, but if they're cavalry, never. The only thing that matters in melee is whether is it cavalry & what weapon it has. If it's cavalry it's almost guaranteed to take excessive casualties no matter the circumstances. Cavalry units often even lose against artillery pieces with less men, which is downright pathetic, but then again I have also seen infantry which is more than 10x larger lose against artillery units in melee. Melee is simply broken.

Dedicated skirmisher troops are made obsolete by infantry brigade skirmishers. Why have a dedicated unit of a few hundred skirmishers when you can have over a thousand infantry + a few hundred skirmishers? The dedicated ones are slightly better, but at the price of a nearly full infantry unit? NO LOL. Dedicated skirmishers are only ever worth it if you get the sniper weapons.

There are also a few others like ironclads that are stationary on certain missions & ammo carriages, but meh. They do what you'd expect.

Now, what are wrong with the game's systems/design? Oh, a few things:

The melee is broken asf as mentioned in the cavalry section. Generally speaking low fatigue high veterancy units got a slight edge, but only a little edge. Melee is kinda like a way to get people to back off a bit in most scenarios, not much more. I should also mention that melee combat is less deadly than ranged combat, because bayonets aren't dangerous.

Morale is OK in this game. What isn't is what happens when a unit runs out of it. They start running, usually away from the enemy (but not always) & then if left unmolested after having ran quite a bit they will simply stand where they stopped running. Problem is how long they run away for & how easy it is to keep them running indefinitely. They refuse to surrender is majority of circumstances (although some units will surrender very easily on occasion) & simply keep running whilst getting shot at & getting melee'd. Most units prefer running until death over surrender. Although sometimes units may also decide to fight back after having been molested whilst fleeing & then beat back the enemy & do the same to them, completely reversing the situation out of nowhere.

The damage curve for diminishing returns for large units is crazy in this game. It goes over-board so hard that units past a certain size in fact deal less damage than units of a lower size. The more those big units get beat up the better they become.

There is AI scaling in this game, for the campaign. The whole point of the campaign is to let you build up your army & get stronger over time & balancing things out for the long run. This is all made pointless by scaling, as the stronger you get the stronger the enemy get, but also the weaker you get the weaker the enemy get. Intentionally limiting yourself within certain limits actually make the game easier due to how the AI scales & doing things as effectively as possible is counter-productive due to the AI getting more bonuses than you built up your forces.

The missions in the campaign are heavily scripted. It's to the point where forces are frequently teleported to different places, new units get teleported in & out of the fight. There are also constant reinforcements on both sides. There are arbitrary time limits on a lot of things, like a lot of them. The enemy will refuse to surrender unless utterly crushed or if you achieved all of your main objectives, which may include holding a position for many minutes, so if the enemy have a single weak unit left running around the place you just gotta wait, take up good positions & then see as your units get teleported to bad positions & enemies spawn in all over the place. This heavily scripted level design is completely counter-productive to the rest of the game.

Cavalry logic is illogical. They run around the place erratically, got stuck in fights never intended for them & flee (skirmish behaviour, not morale flight) despite being told to shoot a unit. They also sometimes decide to use their ranged weapons & sometimes not if they got sabers, I got no idea how that works.

Units will on occasion fire a full salvo despite being stuck in melee for the past few seconds, which will inevitable kill more enemies than the entire melee fight.

Fatigue kinda matters. It's usually better just to completely ignore it however to maximize movement & fire-solutions instead. The penalties are too mild for exhausted units & since even simply walking drains fatigue & it recovers so slowly it's best to just learn to play with zero fatigue.

Now let's talk about the lack of realism:

Weapon stats simply make no sense. Farmers are old cheap muskets that got poor stats overall, but incredibly high melee. Pretty much everything else however, even if comparable size, got less melee than the farmer, for no apparent reason.

Cavalrymen that carry sabers cannot dismount. No, not saber as main weapon, but saber as in saber + ranged weapon. If they only got said ranged weapon then they can dismount.

There is a lot of weapon overlaps between skirmishers & cavalry, as well as ranged only & saber + ranged. They all count as being unique weapons from each-other & cannot be mixed in any way. This causes some more obscure weapons that aren't actually that obscure in total to be useless, as you can't capture/buy enough of them to equip a unit, despite technically having the stuff.

Ironclads will simply sit idle in one position regardless of what happens, they're completely immobile. When they have been shot enough they will simply stop working, not sink or anything.

There are magical protective shield buttons that make your units go into specific places spread all over the place that give good bonuses. There is already a well working cover system that works better than this thing, yet they co-exist.

Generals are invincible, but still flee far too early & leave your troops alone unless you explicitly tell them to hold position.

There are also some other major issues I have heard from others but haven't tried out myself as I got no interest in cheesing games, but supposedly this game get become very easy with simple things like cancelling orders & putting units at precise unit strenghts & using small ballast units to reinforce later to bypass scaling & whatnot. Just google these things if you are interested.

So what's good? Pretty much everything else. Seriously, this game had a lot of potential, many good ideas married together in a cohesive way that works well with each-other, but that doesn't mean I can ignore the myriad of major issues in this game.

Tips and tricks:

Never get into melee with enemy skirmishers.  Ultimate General fact: Delta Force existed in the Civil War.  They were just called skirmishers.  These guys... 200 skirmishers will destroy a 1200 man brigade.  I should record it next time.  They are INSANE.

ALWAYS deploy skirmishers from EVERY brigade.  Skirmishers are by far your must efficient, effective unit.  In fact, why do we even have brigades?  

Don't win battles.  Every time you win, you just massively increase the size of the enemy Army to a point where winning becomes impossible.  The way I see it, with this games scaling mechanics, you can lose to a point where it becomes easy to win.

The Confederates are a powerhouse of industry with massive population centers.  Ultimate General fact: The south during the 1800s held the largest population centers of the world, unrivaled by anything we have seen in the current times.

The enemy has one strategy, and that is to charge, charge, charge.  Just plan your battle plan around that.  Even when they are in the defense, they will charge.

Never recruit anything higher than a Major.  Officers die faster than enlisted soldiers.  Get yourself a colonel for the cost of a new brigade, watch that colonel die immediately.  This game LOVES killing officers till you run out of replacement options.

ALWAYS watch your brigades CLOSELY as they like to adjust angles of fire, become "blocked" and then walk casually under fire, at which point they are promptly routed until they are well out of the fight.  This happens without warning and is devastating.  

NEVER use the "fallback" command.  SO many times I have used this command, only to watch my brigade "fallback" right into the enemy they were shooting at, start melee, and get destroyed.

As someone who is well read in Civil War history I appreciate the scope of these battlefields and their faithful recreation so as to reflect on their size and dimension. I like to reflect on the time it takes for units to get from one place to another and I am reminded of the drastic death toll on American lives. The gameplay is consistent and organized, it can be tense and rewarding. The Army Camp feature is not too micromanaging, and believably necessary. The game is tough and fascinating.

Was fun for awhile, but some of the restrictions get tiresome. Being forced to assault positions and take a point when outnumbered two-to-one is not enjoyable. The perks for leaders are okay, but since they are all the same it's easy to stop caring about who is in charge. The options to outfit units with different weapons seems interesting at first, until you realize that to use most of the good weapons your unit will be undermanned since there are not enough of them for the full unit and you cannot outfit units with multiple weapon types. The combat feels okay, but it's a bit too finicky in regards to flanking and rear attacks. Frequently I will have units break because they think they are being attacked from the flank or the rear, when it's simply not possible in the position they are in. The enemy also charges way too frequently, which is not very historically accurate. Morale and endurance goes down incredibly quickly, and up incredibly quickly. Battles are often just a series of units ping-ponging, in that they rout and are then back in the fight thirty seconds later. I think this game had potential, but just feels like a mod for total war, and not a particularly good one.

Unique strategy warfare game. The game revolves around equipping your armies, and fighting with them on historical, pre-determined battlefields. Gameplay is relatively slow-burning and played from a higher strategical level than for instance a Total War battlefield. Playing this game will require practice though! The correct relative sizes of corps, divisions and brigades are very important (and differ between the Union and the Confederacy), but you'll have to learn for yourself. The campaign might also create some confusing situation the first time you play it. (1) Some battles are so big, that the map (and your army) gets split in pieces during the course of the game, causing parts of your troops to accidentally end up in theatres they weren't supposed to end up in. (2) The game also might have a bit of an unhealthly obsession with capping-points on the battlemap (checkpoints that might cause you to instantly lose the battle if not occupied by your troops). Some of these checkpoint might be located on positions that might have made historical sense, but don't always make sense in the game itself, and can be rage inducing the first time they troll you. 

Nonetheless, there are no flaws in this game that can't be corrected with practice, and you will easily get dozens of hours of fun for a reasonable price.

This is a great battle strategy game with some "grand strategy" elements of sorts.

You play the role of either a Union or Confederate army commander, starting out with a small command that you can build up over time with additional corps, divisions and brigades. 

The game has light role playing elements to it as well and I did find myself getting attached to my veteran brigades, trying to keep them for when the battle was at it's crucial moments (not wanting to throw away veteran troops on minor engagements).

Between battles you refit your army, you can purchase additional weapons (all with different attributes) so it's up to you to balance things. With finite resources to hand you have to decide whether it would be better to raise new brigades with fresh recruits, or do you spend a lot of money on reinforcing your veteran units with more experienced men? If you add raw recruits to your veteran brigades their stats will suffer. This becomes a big juggling act, especially when you play as the resource strapped Confederates as the war goes on.

I think this is a great game, have played various strategy games for many many years, going back to C64 and Amiga 500 days. I am thoroughly enjoying this game and intend on sinking many more hours into it.

Yes, the graphics aren't the best, but other than that this is a great strategy game that is pretty simple on the face of it but does offer depth and some re-playability.

It's a Goodish game, I like that you can play as the Confederates and command armies during the Civil War.
What I dislike is that I have found that I haven't been able win every battle even in easy mode for the Confederate campaign. I don't expect it to be a walk over but I do expect easy difficulty to be actually easy and it not to get impossible halfway through the Confederate Campaign unless you have disgusting amounts of casualties.
When I have ever started doing well as a Confederate, causing massive casualties on the Union, capturing lots of supplies, weapons and inflicting huge defeats on them, I can usually get to a certain point (the battle of Chattanooga) where every battle is unwinnable or winnable but with huge casualties which totally spoils the game. It just makes me really stressed and angry when the hole point of playing games is to de-stress, not cause more.
The reason for this can't be explained by choosing the Confederacy historically as if the Confederacy had caused lots of casualties and captured lots of weapons etc. from the Union, it would have been a lot easier for the Confederacy later on, not harder and the Union will to fight would have been greatly reduced so more of their units should be more willing to rout easier and Confederate morale with more large victories would be way better, more volunteers would be produced and quality of soldiers should be better. Also the Union would have had less 1851 Pattern Enfields due to the factory in England probably being unwilling to supply more weapons just for them to get destroyed or captured and they would sell them to the Confederacy instead as they were seen as doing better so it would be better to have the Union equipped with more 1955 Springfields instead.
There is a glitch where at the end of a battle, you get the choice to continue fighting battle or finish it, I have found that quite often it will finish the battle without me clicking on the "Finish" button. This is usually just before I have had a chance to finish the battle how I want which can if I have just captured the final objective and have to hold it for a little longer, which causes me to loose the battle. In other cases, I have the choice to totally wipe the enemy army out, capture lots of supplies etc. and am forced to finish the battle, letting enemy troops that I could have defeated or captured get away.
Another point is that if you capture more than 1,000 men you can only exchange them for 1,500 men. I see that this is to replicate what happened in real life, however unlike real life where if say I had 2,000 prisoners and wanted to get back a captured Officer I would exchange them, you just get 1,000 regular troops and never get any captured officers back. You should have a choice on weather you want to get an officer back or an amount of regular soldiers back. Also if you are exchanging regular troops, it should be either man for man (e.g. you capture 3,500 men and get 3,500 back) or if you have more captured NCOs or Officers or just lots of prisoners you should be rewarded by getting more prisoners back from the enemy (you have captured 4,500 prisoners with officers and NCOs amongs them so get 5,400 back) and not have a system where you can only get up to 1,500 prisoners back, no matter how many you have captured and none being returned being officers.
Also you should be able to capture enemy officers and exchange them like in real life. e.g. if you capture Burnside. you could either exchange him for say another General such as Lee if Lee was captured or exchange him for a large amount of regular troops such as 5,000 regular troops.
It would also be nice if you didn't have to micro manage each unit. It is annoying that that these great officers you have such as General Longstreet or Lee or Picket don't manage how they deploy their troops. These men would have and should in the game use their skills to deploy their troops to the best of their skills to defeat the enemy and send you messages if they are being badly damaged for you to come back and fix their problems. You can also get problems such as you form a perfect pocket around some enemy units and you leave it to be destroyed to focus on another more important part of the battlefield, only to go back and find the unit has routed through one of your units which are stuck in one place doing nothing as the enemy unit recovers and attacks.
Another point is that you can have captured an enemy unit and send them off the battle and they can be right next to the edge of the map but instead of leaving by the nearest edge of the map, they run right across into the enemy and be re-armed/freed and fight against you again, there should be the possibility for captured units not to either run into areas where you are fighting and for them to go to the nearest edge of the map to be taken off the map.
Also you can kill lots of enemy troops but the amount of captured weapons you can get off the dead enemy seems to be a lot less than it should be, even if you include the ones destroyed in combat. I've had battles where I've killed over 15,000 Union Infantry and I've only got numbers like 1,000 rubbish Farmer rifles and 400 Harpers Ferry 1855 rifles back when I know for a fact that the enemy had been using Sharps Rifles as they said it on in game text or the rate of damage they had been able to inflict on my units meant they were using more advanced rifles and these units I totally destroyed so should at least get 80% of the Sharps Rifles from these units rather than none.
Another point is the system where you have a large army for a major battle as the Confederacy, the Union will have 3x as many troops as you, even when this can be over the actual amount of troops ever fielded during the Civil War or in the Battle you are fighting.
Another point is that you can equip a unit with Henry Rifles, but even if they are a veteran unit, they are very ineffective, which if it was real, this would be very different and they would overwhelm units armed with single shot percussion rifles or muskets such as shown in the Battle of Koniggratz in 1866, just after the Civil War, in Europe where Prussian soldiers with single shot breach loading rifles destroyed an Austrian force armed with single shot percussion rifles.
Also when you use a unit with Henry Rifles, they only fire 1 volley and don't have a quick rate of fire which they would have had with Henry Rifles unless this has recently been changed.
It is a good game and I do like it, but these negative factors have just made me dislike it and stop playing it often. I know I sound a bit like a History Buff (which I am) and there is the excuse that this is just a game, however it does say it's meant to be historical and playable. I would play it more often if these above factors were fixed.

Command is much better, you can detach skirmishers and more easily manage your units on the field and even draw a line of battle for them. Your brigades also automatically change formation at appropriate times.

The campaign is great, I wasn't expecting it to be as good as it is. Managing your brigades strikes the right detail in terms of balance, and you will have fun spending your points on high tech weaponry and veterans to bolster those important brigades. The progression system is a lot of fun, and you feel the weight of each missions as if your fictional Corps really did take part in these epic battles.

I'm not even a huge fan of the Civil War but I love the black powder era, if that's you too then definitely get this game.

I enjoyed the Ultimate Generals - Gettysburg and got this one as a result, but two things have spoilt it.

1) It is not an open map campaign where you can influence where battles occur and manage strategic resources, instead there are set (historical) battles and you can manage the order of battle and equipped weapons etc. and choose which battle to do first to an extent. I had hoped for some form of TW format, or hex based. This was not game-breaking but 2) below is for me.

2) The other side seems to always have massively more troops than you; I just can't figure it out. Some people blame 'scaling' others say this is now not a thing. I've tried different numbers of troops in brigades, different number of corps but it just makes no sense. Neither does how troops come into a battle, why you can't use others at all sometimes. And why in the last battle was I facing massive brigades of 2500 men against my maximum 1500 AND they had more brigades? Perhaps this is historical? But after trying both sides the feeling was the same for each: pending doom. Even the few battles won were pyrrhic it seems.

The atmosphere is good, the limited campaign offering is nice in what it does, the game runs nicely and I really enjoyed the battles in Gettysburg, so I'm extra disappointed that this just seems crushingly difficult on its normal setting, you shouldn't have to debuff the AI side to get a normal experience.

Not the most in-depth review, I'll keep it simple.
Past: played UG: Gettysburg. Didn't really understand it enough to enjoy it at first, but that's why I played as the Union first: wiggle-room to make mistakes :P. Anyway, one crucial detail, for example, was how the units only regained Morale in the presence of their respective Corps commander. Never explained in the Tutorials, not really implied anywhere, just had to experiment. Problem was, the base game had several issues like this to overall make playing the game...partly satisfying. 

Present: have gotten past Battle of Shiloh (good God I needed a bigger army than I had), but I made it work much better than expected (only lost my skirmishers, but I haven't nailed that down yet and I just needed raw BODIES to slow em down). Why tell you this? Because I felt I had a better degree of control and influence over individual unit performance than in UG: Gettysburg. Controlling the Corps composition itself also helped, as I knew exactly what was in each Corps and I can usually deploy an entire Corps all together, so no worries about missing units or morale (they do allow ANY commander to replace Morale, thank God).

Overall: due to the control you possess over your armies composition, the relative control you have over their deployment (smaller, but better equipped, # of divisions/corps helps with this), and the improved feedback I get during battle, I feel much more in control and capable of responding to various threats and conditions. 

In Short: a better style of play, in my opinion, than UG: Gettysburg will ever be. 

Pro-Tip: hesitate to use provided cover, it's usually a deathtrap. Used in Shiloh only with "free" units (not from my own Corps), or by units with no ammo, since the only real good buff is to melee combat...which ironically enough actually helped, since that particular spot was RIGHT ON TOP OF the control point.

This game is overall entertaining, however there are some super annoying mechanics.

GOOD
- It feels like the civil war and you are pushed most of the time to play the way the war was fought in those times - so it feels realistic, most of the time...

- I like the ability of building my own army, being able to customise it, get different types of equipment and veterancy system etc. 

BAD
- You never know how to distribute your troops pre-battle in order to align with the set up plan, which wastes a lot of my time.
Big battles have few slots where you have to allocate your divisions before the battle begins. The problem is that sometimes I overshoot 1 side and didnt put enough troops into the other slots. The multi-turn (days) battle has to be repeated because near the end you realise that in that slot you actually need many more brigades than you could guess at the beginning. It is most of the time total guess and I was forced to watch YT movies to see where which division will go and will have to do... this is so annoying.

- Weird concept of 2 units fighting in tight melee and guns firing at them cannisters with almost no friendly fire casualties. You just take the cheapest rookie troops, send them to fight in melee or use them as a screen, keep your best shooting units behind and just shoot into them - no friendly fire. 

- After losing LoS your units run ahead blindly and suicide. 
If you command your unit to attack an enemy unit which will later run away and be blocked by an other enemy unit, your guys will run into them blindly. After loosing line of sight they just run forward and you find your best troops in the middle of their trenches alone...

I have only played for an hour but I would say yes to this game if you like RTS games like Total War. The controls are very similiar. They are bit clunky sometimes, especially making them do things, but in time I think I will figure out what I am doing wrong. 
What I noticed off the bat is units. You actually have to care for these units. You can give these units different guns so each one has a purpose. In Total War you just sorta send them to their deaths and win the battle. In this game, you want them to live. You have a person "currency" as well. You only get so many people to use in your army, so you are inclined to keep them alive.

I wanted to like this game.  I love the little things, like picking generals, naming unites etc.  But there is nothing "strategic" about this game.  The game map is linear.  Basically, the computer will give you a choice or two of which battle to fight, then you fight it, and the results take you to the next battle etc.  this is NOT a grand strategy game.  The other issue I found, which confirms some other reviews, is because its so linear, there is a balance issue.  You will have points to buy supplies, guns, arty and more troops.  You will create your Corps and your Army (which is cool actually).  But you have to be very careful about spending on luxuries...like arty and cavalry.  neither seemed to have much of an effect.  The AI just throws hordes of infantry at you, and no matter how bad you beat the AI, it will have full armies and reinforcements in the next battle.  Because I overspent on foolish things like supplies and arty, I was mauled in one battle, and because I couldn't afford more troops, in the following battle I was SEVERELY outnumbered.  Basically enemy divisions were just appearing all over the map.  And I had also mauled the enemy in the previous battle.  Again, arty and cavalry seemed useless.  I wanted to like it, the game looks great but I think I will get Civil War II for the grand strategy aspect.  Might give this one another few hours, but.........

I want to recommend this game, but I can't. It isn't worth the price how it is.

No onto the good and bad.

Pros:
- Awesome Graphics
- Design your own army
- Chose bonuses and traits for your units, officers, and army as a whole
- A ton of battles
- Lots of replay ability
- Realistic casualties depending or distance, weapons, terrain and experience
- Historical units
- Casualties transfer between days in a multiday battle
- Favor points to get extra stuff (weapons, cash, men, generals) that are gained or lost depending if you win or lose a battle

Cons:
- No multiplayer :(
- Once and a while a unit glitches or does something weird (usually cavalry attacking fortified infantry or something similar)
- Not much really

Not really a con to me, but some people complain about regaining loses for the confederates and such as being unrealistic. This is because if you play on a hard difficulty then the AI needs to make up those loses and to make the game challenging. I find nothing wrong with this since if you want the game truly historical and to be able to steamroll the south every battle then you can play on the easiest difficulty. All in all the game has something for every play style of strategy gaming.

I loved this game when it first was released and played the battles relentlessly.  They are always fun to me with the actual generals and units, etc.  I just cannot seem to get very far into the campaign w/o losing interest and for the longest time I couldn't put a finger on the reason.  Then it hit me not too long ago.  This game is not realistic in one key aspect and it ruins the campaign for me.  It has nothing to do with imbalance in army size, overpowered units, or anything like that.  It is the most basic of problems.....the same army (or parts of it) fights every battle.  Zero realism!  Fight the battle at Bull Run and then your army is magically transported to far away Tennessee to fight at Shiloh.  Fight that battle and then your entire army is shipped back east to fight for Richmond in the Seven Days.  Repeat ad nauseum.  I know I could replace commanders and change unit names but I shouldn't have to.  How hard would it have been to program the game to allow you to develop two armies simultaneously and transfer parts as needed as was done historically (Longstreet to the west for Chickamauga)?  It just bums me out some.....such potential for really immersive campaign.  Anyways, my two cents.  I'll still play the game and I'd still recommend it but I'm personally sticking to single battles.  Thanks for the read!

Massive battles with hundreds of thousands of troops rage for hours as you fight for whichever side you choose, Confederate or Union. The battles controls in this game are mostly fluent except the final battle of Richmond, which is ridiculous complex and could be easily turned into a butcher's house.

Some small tips to those who want to try this game:
1 Cavalry units are acting as an auxiliary force at this point of history. So cavalry units should avoid direct engagement with infantry whenever possible, unless the enemy is weakened.
2 In this game, the artillery pieces are not accurate enough at mid or long range, and is devastating at close range.The volleys of artillery at short range can severely damage the enemy's morale.
3 Numerical advantage is crucial. If you are a Northern player, do not try to build an elite army and do not recruit too many veterans at the early stage of the war. On contrast, you should use the recourse to train more units.
