This is a well-balance civil war game. On Colonel (Easiest), you can breeze through the campaign. On Brigadier General, you need much better strategy and tactics to be successful. On Major General, the AI is quite good and you are punished for your mistakes, or for focusing to much on one little part of the battle. On  Major General Legendary, the smallest missed detail can mean the difference between victory and defeat. Legendary is absolutely brutal. The campaign plays much different based on difficulty settings. It is possible to win as either the Confederates or the Union on any of the three(+) levels. I enjoy that the outcomes of the battles affect other battles int he campaign, but the campaign itself somewhat railroads you into playing a specific set of battles in a largely chronological order. The game gives you a general feel of how artillery, infantry, and cavalry matched up in the middle 1800s. I'd love to see an expansion with some of the overlooked portions (in this game) of the Civil War- The Vicksburg Campaign would be a good addition, possibly something from the Trans-Mississippi Theater. Militia and Mounted Raiders would also be an interesting troop type that could be added to provide some diversity to the current triumvirate of unit types.

I desperately want to love this game that's why i am giving it a thumbs up despite its flaws.

For those that are fans of an ancient retro hex turn based game called Civil War Generals, i think you will like this game as it really reminded me of that game despite this game having pausable real time combat.

Before i talk about the flaws, i just want to mention the things i love about the game.

1. A persistent army that follows you throughout the campaign from 1861 - 1864 that you can manage and tweak to your hearts content. Create egiments of infantry, artillery, snipers and cavalry. Buy weapons and equip them with different rifles, cannon etc. Tons of fun! And each regiment will improve their stats based on their actions on the battlefield: accuracy, melee etc.

2. Excellent combat mechanics. Each regiment has Morale and fatigue modeled.Experienced troops fight harder and longer. You need to flank enemies or concentrate artillery fire in order to rout enemies to push them back. Gain defensive bonus fighting from woods or behind walls. And a decently challenging AI keeps you on your toes somewhat.

But unfortunately the game has flaws.
1. The campaign is just a static series of battles. You could slaughter the yanks at Antietem or Gettysburg and nothing changes. You just proceed to the next historical battle. 

2. Each battle is standalone and there is no consequence or link between each. Example: i sent my best troops to raid Harpers Ferry in the Antietem campaign. Historically these troops would not be able to make it back to fight in Antietem until late in the afternoon. In this game, these same troops were fresh and ready to fight in the morning at Antietem and i promptly slaughtered the Union army.

3.The enemy army will just replenish in size and difficulty based on your damage to them each battle. Slaughter 10,000 men. The enemy just replaces them with 15,000 experienced troops. Kill 5,000 of their men, they just replace them with 8,000 new recruits. This is meant to ensure the battles scale in difficulty to your progress, but it just makes my battlefield achievements feel kind of meaningless.

Because of these flaws the campaign can feel kind of boring because there is no sense of consequence to each battle. You just fight the battles over and over again and none of your actions on the battlefield feels like it matters.

In the end i still give this game a thumbs up because i love these sorts of army management game despite its boring and flawed campaign mechanics.

Ultimate General: Civil War aims to sate the strategic and tactical appetites of armchair generals, and although it might be the best all-around option out there right now for Civil War enthusiasts, it’s likely to leave you as the general feeling more “penultimate” than “ultimate”.

The core gameplay combines real time strategy, role playing progressions, resource management, and battle planning. Although predominantly focused on RTS battles, the incorporation of these other elements adds depth and fills out what would otherwise be less-than-fulfilling content. It would by no means be a bad game outright if it was just a series of RTS battles set in the civil war, but these additional elements do add to the replay value and make the player experience feel more directly impactful. At times, I felt like I didn’t just beat the AI by commanding preset units to adhere to a preset strategy and engage with preset tactics; I won by molding the army into my army and I overcame as a direct result of my decisions. Admittedly, though, I grew to feel boxed in by many hidden constraints… but more on that later. 

Some RPG elements are incorporated in your role as commander, as well as each corps, division, and brigade. These elements provide bonuses that are almost entirely statistical, but they do add some flavor. After each battle, you are rewarded with money, troops, and reputation that corresponds with how well you performed. You can then use these to buy munitions, train new units, replenish old ones, and appoint new unit leaders. And like the armchair generals’ real-world counterparts, a lot of care needs to be taken with the between-battle logistics, otherwise you are likely to find yourself outnumbered and outgunned the next time you encounter the enemy. 

The RTS battles really cement this series as the spiritual successor to Sid Meier’s Gettysburg. The battle actions are more intuitive – you can simply move your troops by dragging the route you want them to take without your units tripping all over each other – but there are some downsides. Units lines of sight are denoted only by a nearly imperceptible shadow that is cast over the map when a single unit is selected. Couple that with a lack of clearly defined topographical elevations and it’s impossible to position cannons on cannons on useful hilltops. 

From a grand strategy perspective, winning a battle does impact future battles, although often not by much. For example, after successfully defending a supply depot (and routing the enemy, I might add), my reward was having the enemy army’s size being reduced by a paltry 5% in the next Grand Battle. From a narrative perspective, it seems like it would have been a great opportunity to offer a temporary discount on munitions, which always seem to be in short supply, or increase how many are in stock to purchase – but no, just the static 5% reduction in enemy troops.

In another instance, I barely managed to squeak out a victory when attacking a convoy and was rewarded with a 10% reduction to the enemy’s weapon quality in the next Grand Battle. I then replayed it and crushed the convoy, and received the exact same reward. This lack of impact in a Grand Strategy sense makes victories feel less important. Sure, pre-scripting the impact of one battle on another is easier to balance, but it disincentivizes routing your enemy, favors minimizing your own losses, and ultimately reduces replayability. 

Conversely, the role-playing elements improved the replay value. As a general, you are awarded a Career Point or two after each victorious battle that you can then invest in assorted general-specific proficiencies – Politics, Economy, Medicine, Army Organization, Training, Logistics, and Reconnaissance – all of which improve proportionally with your Career Point investments. These proficiencies feel quite balanced insofar as none are completely over or underpowered and encourage replaying the game to try out new command strategies. 

They can be configured to compliment however you command. For instance, I tended to rely heavily on skirmishers to scout out enemy movements, so points in reconnaissance weren’t nearly as valuable to me – focusing on Politics and Training helped me ensure I could fill out my thinned lines with veteran troops after each battle. 

Your brigades, divisions, and corps can also improve independently, contingent on the experience gained by their respective commanding officers. This aspect is wonderfully unforgiving. If you repeatedly put your high-level officers in do-or-die situations, you’re likely to effectively neuter your army. 

When it comes to resource management, you are tasked with maintaining your army by recruiting troops, adding brigades, divisions, corps; and all the while keeping your financial, personnel, and reputation reserves balanced. If any of these reserves get too low, your army will reflect it in terms of poor quality weapons, poor quality or too few troops, or low morale. That said, usually you can see an imbalance coming a mile away and react before it becomes a serious problem.

Unfortunately, at the battle planning stage of the game, it starts to become clear: All the prep work you’ve done only affords you the illusion of control. The choices you make to customize your army are not fully realized in the battles.

Each battle has a maximum number of corps and brigades that you can field, irrespective of the size of your army. Let’s say you decide to build an army with many troops in an effort to simply overwhelm the enemy with numbers, you will be unable to field your entire army – and what’s more, you won’t be able to even select which troops you want to field! As a result, you’ll end up fielding a random assortment of brigades. This is a jarring disconnect. Why would the game award resources for trouncing the enemy if it’s going to turn right around and hamstring you when you try to make use of them?

Furthermore, the amount of soldiers the enemy fields in each battle is largely unaffected by your actions in prior battles. Again, I can appreciate that each side would reasonably be reinforced between battles, but after sustaining multiple crushing defeats in short succession there would come a point when the enemy wouldn’t be able to field armies as large, or you’d gain some other tactical advantage, such as a terrain or strategic resources. The player is effectively disincentivized from totally crushing the enemy in battle after battle, because they are likely to face a completely reinforced enemy army no matter what. 

And when deploying troops, the game restricts you even more. You are only occasionally permitted to deploy your troops at the onset of battle; and when you are, you’re allotted a very small area compared to the rest of the map. And if a battle takes place over multiple days or phases, it automatically places your troops wherever it sees fit, irrespective of wherever you had left them the previous phase. 

Overall, Ultimate General: Civil War is sleek, but the features don’t coalesce into a satisfying experience. It feels like a stepping stone game that’s just not quite there yet – like Game-Labs wants it be immersive enough to entice a hardcore enthusiast, yet simple enough that a casual player can take to it quickly, too. Unfortunately, their aim is just a little off.

All in all, you’ll likely enjoy this game if you go into it expecting to play a predetermined series of battles without being true to history, and about which you only have the illusion of self-determination. If you’re looking for a game that’s true-to-history or expect the spread of battles to more dynamically change based on your actions, then you will likely be disappointed.

Units: Infantry, Artillery, Cavalry and Skirmish units are possible.  There is a good choice of artillery with both smooth bore and rifled cannon.  Unfortunately smooth bore can fire canister shot through their own side and only kill the enemy.  Major fail.  Same with volley fire when units are in melee.  Equally there seems little area effect against other enemy units.  A canon shot misses... you see it land in another formation but that takes no damage 99% of the time (maybe 100%).  Volley fire either hits the unit aimed at or misses, another unit in the firing line takes no damage.

For each unit there is choice of size, weapons, leader and with experience, their development path.  Skirmishers can basically become snipers or recon.  Artillery can specialize in long range (generally best for top quality rifled) or short range (best for smoothbore).  Cavalry can be shock cavalry with sabres or mounted infantry.  Movement is walk or run.

Battlefield orientation is preset.  Bottom to top or left to right, whichever they have chosen, that is what you get.

Unit formation is fixed by the game.  No squares for cavalry attacks, no stretching your line thin.  Send infantry to march a distance and they go into something like column formation, but you have no control of this.

Cavalry when mounted is just a gaggle with no formation.  Cavalry attacks on artillery are lamentably slow to resolve after the merge.  Not a quick killing spree and certainly no running off with the guns.  

Artillery sprites don't change with the number of artillery pieces in the unit.

As so often one is left feeling that much as this is enjoyable, it had the potential to be more.  I'd rank it in the 3-4 star region.

I recently discovered I'm a Civil War buff, so I picked up this game after Ultimate General: Gettysburg-- in which I usually got about as far as the second day before being completely overrun.

It is impressive for its detail, the level of control you have over the size and equipment of your corps, and so far in my campaign (Chancellorsville) it seems fairly balanced--though the challenge is increasing. I'm playing on a relatively low difficulty to learn the ropes, so it is both satisfying and with a little guilt that I use my campaign loot to outfit and maintain an army that even George McClellan would have taken into combat. 

It is possible to keep your force at/near 100% strength continually--but your defeated enemy doesn't seem to slow down much either.

The AI is pretty solid but occasionally does strange things. It seems to be very important in the game (as in real life) not to allow your forces to be flanked--or they will openly rout. Once in a while an infantry brigades decides to pull out of formation seemingly on its own accord and oblique in the wrong f***ing direction, but I'm usually able to pull it back into line before they rout. Also concealment in forest and wheat fields actually provide cover bonuses.

A few more unit behavior commands would be extremely helpful, but as it exists it is perfectly functional.

I think you have to be a Civil War enthusiast to really enjoy the game; there is no opportunity to deviate from the on-rails historical path in-campaign even if the outcome of a battle would have altered the course of the war, so you are essentially maintaining an army between encounters. But it is well-done and as a tactical/strategy game it is entertaining.

Highly under-rated game.

My original review, however, did note a few problems before I start praising the game, here:

#1 - Steep learning curve. The first couple battles are the hardest in the game, really, and there's no tutorial... create your general, and instantly in a battle. It's very poorly thought-out, as the difficulty is front-loaded and serves to push players away if they aren't patient enough.

#2 - Some quality-of-life issues that will never be fixed it looks like. Enemy cavalry sometimes glitch right through your units without taking damage, and some battles still have an issue where supply wagons disappear from time to time on Day 2.

#3 - The campaign is pretty much just a mission select screen. The only real choice between battles is how to re-equip your troops, which is a ton of fun but means that the battles themselves are quite linear... the only option for battles is if you want to skip minor battles between the big ones.

#4 - CPU never withdraws troops. Ever. So, unlike Total War where a routed unit can leave the field, UG:CW sees units get stuck routing at the map edge, and you can easily exploit this time and again. This is my only major gripe with CPU play, though.


All of that said, the *tactical* part of the game is very good. 

CPU movement and decision making (aside from my #4 complaint above) is really good. If a CPU unit is about to get flanked by a big force, it sometimes will move back to make itself safe again. CPU will send cavalry to capture my supply wagons, and will keep units out of the front line in order to let them recover (if they can) before charging again. And the CPU spreads out to cover the field well... unlike in Total War, where units can really bunch up, the CPU in this game usually spreads out well unless I flank or encircle and push them all into a pocket.

Further, the tactical mechanics are varied and interesting. Old equipment may not fire well at long range, but at short range can still be useful. Cavalry includes a melee option, and skirmishers can be equipped with sniper rifle-muskets, given carbines like the cavalry, or get repeating rifles. 

And the control... the control is very simple, and is the least difficult part of the game to learn. The only thing I find silly with controls is that I can't group units into number-bound groups. You still can use division and corps grouping quite well, but when I need ad-hoc grouping, I do miss being able to make my own groups.



Overall, I really enjoy the game for what it is. Civil War purists, however, are going to maybe scoff at the fact that friendly fire is practically non-existent, and at the inability to really change the campaign in any way (for instance, a Confederate win at Gettysburg still results in fighting at Chickamauga for the next battle... changing the course of history in the biggest battles feels underwhelming the moment you get back to the campaign screen).

Arcade-y though it is, and steep learning curve though it has, I find it one of the best RTS experiences on Steam regarding the CPU play, and that's why I have over 1,000 hrs in game, here.

Ultimate General: Civil War is a pretty good game and offers hours of fun if you like playing through historical battle scenarios with huge amounts of units maneuvering around on huge maps. But if you expect anything more from the game, you might be disappointed.

The game has a campaign, but it's essentially just a string of historical battles where you can carry your units from one battle to the next. It works quite well for this game, but if you expect a Total War or Paradox style world map where you can choose your own encounters and pick your battles, you're going to be disappointed. You move from historical battle to historical battle, with major battles being mandatory and smaller battles being optional. Tackling and winning the optional battles will give you a bonus for the major battles. Let's say you win a minor engagement before Gettysburg, this will lead to the enemy force having 10% fewer men at Gettysburg, simulating the effects of your successful battle.

You carry your units from battle to battle. They gain experience and improve their accuracy, morale, reloading speed, melee charge, etc. You can also upgrade their equipment. Starting out with a rookie regiment armed with old smoothbore muskets and seeing them grow to be an elite regiment equipped with high quality Fayetteville rifles is pretty cool. You can freely design your army corps as you want it, with infantry, cavalry, skirmishers and artillery. Your choice of equipment can determine their combat role: equipping cavalry with sabers and pistols makes them great at melee charges, while equipping them with long range carbines turns them into mounted skirmishers.

This is the extent of continuity in the campaign, though. You carry over your army and it gathers experience, you can influence the next major battle by winning minor battles. But if you inflict 50% losses on the enemy army in a major battle, they'll still be back at full strength in the next one (unless a minor battle before it gave you the "10% less enemy soldiers" bonus). So in that way, the histoical battles are pretty static. You will always fight the same army at Gettysburg, for example, even if you managed to absolutely crush the enemy at Chancellorsville before it.

This is why some people gave this game negative reviews: it feels a little inconsistent that your campaign performance has such a low impact on how the battles play out. But a complex campaign just isn't the point of this game: the campaign is just an excuse to string a couple of historical engagements together and allow the player to train and equip his own custom army corps.

The battles themselves are quite fun to play through. They're essentially Total War battles (no wonder, considering the dev used to make mods for Total War before he went on to make commercial games), except larger, slower, and with a better AI. Battlefields can be huge, and so can be the amount of troops you get to lead. It's not uncommon to have over 20 regiments under your command and fighting at 3 different fronts. The battle objectives are all about taking and/or holding victory points, determined by historical objectives of the army you play as. For example, at Antietam the objective of the Confederates is to hold Dunker Church and Sunken Road, and later Burnside's corps will attack at Burnside Bridge and you'll have to defend that, too.

Often, to make the huge battles more manageable, the battles will happen in stages and the battlefield will expand as the game progresses. At Antietam, you start out only defending Dunker Church, later on the map expands to the south and you also get to defend Sunken Road. And even later, it expands again to include Burnside Bridge. These map expansions usually happen when reinforcements arrive, which are based on the time at which they historically arrived. So if you know how a battle played out historically, you'll know what to expect. This creates interesting situations where you try to desperately hold onto defensive ground against an enemy that outnumbers you, knowing that in half an hour, Stonewall Jackson will arrive with some troops to reinforce you. But the same goes for the enemy. You might be close to taking a victory point, but then enemy reinforcements arrive and push you back. This makes timing rather important.

Speaking of timing, battles also run on a timer. Usually, that timer is pretty generous. Battles can start at 6 in the morning and run until 22 in the evening. Sometimes, goals will shift as the day progresses (for example, you start out defending your position, but once a reinforcing corps arrives to your left, your new goal is to roll up the enemy flank with the reinforcements and take their camp). Most major battles take more than one day. At Chancellorsville as the Confederates, for example, you're supposed to take the Union camp, but during your first assault, Union reinforcements arrive and force you to pull back. If you don't take the objective before time runs out, the battle will end and skip to evening, where Jackson flanks the enemy camp. If you still don't manage to take the objective then, the battle will progress to the third day where you get to drive the demoralized defenders out of their camp (but at the end of the day, they receive further reinforcements).

The battlefield constantly shifts and moves as reinforcements arrive and goals are changed. Due to the size of the battlefields and the amount of units involved, the battles usually don't devolve into Total War's complete routs. You might be routing the left flank of the enemy, but your own troops are retreating from the right flank as they're overpowered by enemy artillery. This turns battles into more than just binary affairs where you either rout the enemy or he routs you. Flanking and outmaneuvering the enemy is important, and the key to victory, but it's not as easy as in Total War either because you don't see the enemy positions unless they're within line of sight of one of your units. So using light cavalry as scouts to spot enemy movements is actually important (as it was historically), ambushes can happen naturally by troops hiding in a heavily forested area and shooting once an enemy comes near, etc. It also makes flanking and maneuvering more risky since you can never be sure if there's not an enemy on that hill over there...

The AI is, overall, decent. It's nowhere near genius level and I managed to consistently beat it in every scenario, but it puts up more of a fight than most Total War games, at least. The AI attempts sensible tactics like concentrating its force to push against one point of your defensive like rather than spreading out, using its cavalry to go behind your lines and harrass your artillery, etc etc. As long as you use cover (forming your battle lines in woodlands rather than open fields) and rotate your troops whenever things get hairy (pull back a demoralized and exhausted regiment and have a fresh regiment take its place), you can easily push back the enemy advances. Assaults are, of course, a bit more difficult than defenses, and will require you to reposition your artillery, attack enemy strong points from multiple directions to get a flanking bonus, etc. Overall the AI offers up a decent challenge, but don't expect it to be a master tactician like Robert E. Lee himself.


Conclusion:

If fighting historical battles from the US Civil War, while commanding huge amounts of units on ever-shifting battlefields and performing grand maneuvers to outwit the enemy sounds appealing to you, you should absolutely get this game. If you want a campaign like in a Total War game, where you pick your own engagements and determine the route of conquest yourself, this isn't the game for you. The campaign is just a loose connection of historical battles, not an open world map where you freely move armies around. The battles, however, are pretty great and absolutely worth it.

Overall a well-made RTS war game, did its best to realistically re-render the bloodiest war in American history. Even playing the easiest difficulty starting as a colonel, you still feel tired after a while into the campaign, because after all, you are fighting and trying to win a war... 

The AI design could be improved, unrealistic "routing" maneuver such as "falling back" in enemy's controlled territory or even falling back through the enemy's line is extremely annoying and unreal in life. However, the game did bring us back to the mid-19th century where machine gun is yet to be invented and trench warfare is just being introduced into the battlefield. The game definitely requires a cunning mind out of the player as a commander of their legion, and it surely trains one to always look at the big picture and respond fast to every move on the battle field. 

The campaign design was pretty good, but it could add in more movements in the western theater for sure. And also, since the player has the power to change the outcome of each historical battle, the game should respond more to turning point battles such as winning as the Confederates at Gettysburg and such. The campaign in general should stray away further from history (or having a choice option leading to different endings as done in Dynasty Warriors 8) since a historical battles mode is already present and independent of the campaign mode. 

Lastly, multiplayer mode? If we could pull up the camera closer to the units fighting with an even better graphics that would be super cool. Great game after all, I hope to some further updates.

The reason I acquired this game was basically based on the positive reviews. Although the game plays (that is) runs well and does not have any "bugs", I find it lacking in depth. It is interesting that many of the reviews here and else where have stated that this is not a "Total War" game.   This is true. However,  this should have sparked my thought process, in that, comparing it to the "Total War Standard",  this game does not have the complexity and variance of a Total War game. This is true of any standard we make,  like saying a certain car is "almost like" a Mercedes. 

So why do I say this? First, there is no real carryover from battle to battle,  sure you get to recruit replacements etc... but any real tactical or strategic advantage that you have gained is lost. For example, Shiloh is a multi-day battle and you may have really kicked butt, either as north or south in the first day, but if you don't close out the battle on day one, you are sent to Pittsburgh Landing  on day 2 . Also, if you win the grand battle, and continue to the next campaign the model just sets up the next historical theater. That is,  say you win Shiloh, you can't exploit that victory by capturing territory in the West, instead you are immediately sent to the Peninsular Campaign.  So there is no real continuity. Yes,  the enemy army is penalized somewhat, but you really can't gain a strategic advantage.  

Second, you really can't pick your own ground, but are limited to historically how the armies were set. Not saying that is always a bad thing, as one may enjoy the challenge. However, I am not sure that being locked into Pickett's Charge is a good thing for your army. 

I think, at this point l will stop with the comparisons of the game to the "Total War Experience". Except to say that the detail (visually) of your troops, as well as, variations in movement and  formation are well below that of  Total War.  Overall, I was disappointed with the game, in that, the continuity and consequences of battle outcome are missing, as well as, the freedom to alter strategic objectives.  One would like to see a Creative Assembly game for this conflict .

The Ultimate General: Civil War computer game, reminds me of the 1997 Sid Meier "Gettysburg" computer game.  Since it has been 21 years since Meier's computer civil war game was introduce to the public. The Ultimate General: Civil War takes some of the ideas of Meier's in regards to troop movement, deployment, combat moral and polishes them up.  Moreover, this civil war game has some improvements over the Meier's series. The game adds, "Supply Wagon's" to keep your amry in the field going. So you have to protect them. If you don't then you may have a reduce fire rate with your troops. Plus, you have many more major and minor engagements against the AI.

Ultimate General: Civil War game rules are very easy to read and understand. In some explainations of the game rules the game providers have photographs, videos, or both so it is easy to understand how to play the game. Even though it is helpful to the beginner I would have been more helpful with a hands learning excersise of a minor battle to learn the basics.  The Ultimate General: Civil War provides the gamer with a array of historical battles from the American Civil War, and of course the player choice of playing the Union or the Confederates. 

Their are three different game levels, from beginer, historical to difficult. These levels provide the gamer a bonus in playing. In the beginer mode the AI has a -25% moral reduction on its troops. Now, even though I played the Union forces at the battle of "Bull's Run" at least three times, it wasn't until the fourth time I defeated the Southern forces.  The AI, is no dummy and will take advantage of your weak points within your battle plan. 

I have played the "Campaign" level.  What I have learned is that you have the ability to build your own army for either the "Union" or "Confederates." When you build the army, you have various choices to choose from regarding the training, equipment, type of officers leading them. You can also replace officers that have been killed, capture enemy supplies, troops, also obtain information from your spies in the field. If you capture the enemy supplies you may gain different rifles to arm your troops or additional ammo for your cannons. You play out the historical battles of the civil war.  Depending on which side you choose, you will be in different situations with your troops, and be in major battles like "Bull Run" or "Franklin".

The game does take so time to handle especially with using a mouse, to direct your troops on the game map board. It may be very fustrating especially during the heat of battle. Some game units are difficult to take orders, especially your mounted troops. When you order 200 mounted men to charge a enemy of 600 infantry, they may stop short of this and retreat. The reason my be the unit morale, leader, and any support to back them up.  It is best to keep your eye on your unit's morale when you do a charge into a major position on the battle field. Mounted troops do better when a enemy formations that are withdrawing or routed. When they charge batteries formations from the side or behind they can force the formation to retreat. 

There are a few downsides to this game, the game audio is very boring. It is of civil war actors saying the same thing in a endless loop before and during battles, the music is very dull also. The second, is that the computer AI isn't very smart at times, during a battle, and it doesn't know when to take advantage against its human player in key battle situations. Sometimes, you are left shorthanded because of limitations regarding troops in a critical battle, and the computer AI sends wave after wave of troops in infantry charges and your left wondering where is my reinforcements arriving?  Depending on the amount of men you throw into a battle, the computer AI will either send in massive amounts of troops nearly two to one in its favor being the Union, or send in elite formations for the south.

In closing if you want to learn how to learn to move and attack the enemy on the field this computer game is good for the begin. Ultimate General, ACW is a stepping stone in learning a computer war game.

Hands down the most engaging and fun Civil War (or 18th, 19th century warfare) RTS out there. Graphics may look simple and clean, but the gameplay is super engaging. I wish DarthMod could work on the Total War games...

Best Features:
 -Battles are truly epic, uses Total War style large unit management, does it better than total war!
 -Army management between battles make campaign cumulative, doing well will allow you to strengthen your force, and do better in later battles
 -Terrain actually impacts battles, significantly. Unit morale, condition, and terrain are essential in your strategy, makes the game feel more realistic, and your strategy and method will grow and improve as you learn
 -Despite advanced, realistic battle conditions, the game is easy to play once you understand it
 -The AI is not susceptible to a single mechanic as in most RTS games, the AI is smart enough to adjust its tactics as the battle progresses and will look for weaknesses or attempt to bait you into mistakes.
 -The battles feel costly, as units clash, your constantly shifting units trying to preserve your force, or reinforce a weakening position
 -Battles are objective based, you cant just mass units, what you bring to the fight is what you have, and you must take, or hold your objectives to take the field, the objectives are also sensible and in most cases historically correct

Worst Features:
 -Battles have time limits which is not bad by itself, but the time limits are sometimes silly, having 4 in game hours to take a position that historically you would have had at least an entire day, or multiple days, sometimes rushes you into attacks you would not have made in the real scenario

 -Large battles are broken into sections, that gradually come back together, this is actually nice as it makes managing the field simpler, however each time the shift happens a VERY jarring freeze to the battle, with a text notification comes up. sometimes its well placed, but some battles its aweful, Shiloh is especially bad.

Overall: 9
 -This is one of the best RTS games I have ever played, it does what total war tried to do in napolean and revolution area, but this game actually succeeds. If you like large scale RTS games, or are just a big musket area warfare fan, you should find this game very enjoyable
I really like it

Ultimate General: Civil War, delivers. It shows where the dev comes from, with it's very Total War-esque tactical gameplay. That's half the appeal, the other half being the ability to gradually build up and customise one's army as new guns are captured or bought in the armory. Officers being wounded or killed, an graduating and bein available in the barracks, make post-battle reorganisation even more critical. The fact that each battle has an impact both in losses of men and materiel but also in units cquiring experience and the player receiving reinforcements accordingly are an additional incentive.

Of course it is not a game without drawbacks. The main one has to do with its scope and its predecessor. It's obvious that, given the change in sheer scale, Civil War cannot afford to go into anywhere as much detail regarding alternative paths as Gettysburg did. The campaigns are rigid and battles are forced to unfold much in the same way as historically through more or less important victory points. A point of great confusion is the presence at the start of major battles of victory points that in later stages disappear, and prove to be completely irrelevant to the success or failure of the battle. 

Such flaws notwithstanding, Civil War is a thoroughly engaging game. Fights, within their bounds, are fairly dynamic. You *can* win Gettysburg on the first day. You can repel the enemy, surround it, and destroy it utterly. There is great pleasure in seeing enemy numbers dwindle as they carry out a futile charge after another into well entrenched and well-supported units. There is even greater pleasure in knowing that it is you who have prepared and disposed your units so. Even more importantly, the organisation phase is a welcome break from so much battling, which if continuous would threaten to become monotonous.

A humble game with great aspirations. 4/5

After completing one entire campaign, I feel I can give an honest review. I'm going to put the TL:DR version at the top here with a brief explanation down below. 

I believe this is a good game with quality play-ability and replay-ability. You can play as both Union and Confederate on multiple different difficulties with many different perks to choose from with dozens of battles to play through. Is it worth $30? Well, I caught it for 65% off, so I can't really say. I probably would pay full price for it now after knowing how much I enjoy it. If you're still borderline after reading reviews, perhaps wait to catch it on sale. 

[b]The Great: [/b]
[list]
[*]The grand scale of the campaign, hours of game-play and replay-ability.
[*]Dynamic "career" perks and options, there are many things to help you in different ways during your time as general.
[*]Mostly** realistic fighting for the period. 
[/list]

[b]The Good: [/b]
[list]
[*]Historical accuracy on weapons and strengths/weaknesses of both armies
[*]Well written campaign text provides immersion for those who enjoy reading it.
[*]Your wins, or losses, affect future battles in a multitude of ways.
[/list]

[b]The Neutral: [/b]
[list]
[*]Graphics. They're good, but they aren't great for an epic campaign game.
[*]The method of recruiting soldiers and how it affects your brigade ranks.
[/list]

[b]The Bad: [/b]
[list]
[*]There doesn't seem to be any form of "friendly fire" in this game.
[*]It can be quite easy to sort of "glitch" routing brigades into a permanent rout until they withdraw.
[/list]

[b]The Awful: [/b]
[list]
[*]The method of flanking units which are behind some sort of entrenchment or cover seems to be quite broken.
[/list]

[b]The Explanation: [/b]
So to expand on a few things above, the career perks and options are fantastic. They allow you to choose between recovering some of your fallen men after battle, cheaper prices on weapons, receiving a higher percentage of gold and manpower for battles played, more organization for bigger unit sizes, getting more ammunition for your units and finally more recon on the enemy army and units. Depending what you pick out of these, and in which order, will largely decide how your army fights, or should fight at the very least. 

The fighting, as stated, is [u]mostly[/u] realistic for the time period. There are a few things which doesn't seem to quite line up however. For one thing, I haven't been able to notice any sort of friendly fire mechanic. Now, for a casual player, this may be fine. For someone who wants to be immersed in the battle, tactics and strategy it is a little disheartening though. I've had artillery crews fire canister shot point blank into the back of their own unit and not do any damage to their own unit, only to have the enemy unit suffer 50+ casualties. I've also seen one or more brigade turn and fire into a friendly brigade being charged by the enemy. Now in these, there are casualties in the friendly unit since they're being charged, but their casualties do not seem to reflect taking any damage from these friendly brigades firing into them. Now don't get me wrong, I'm certainly not saying it isn't possible for some of this to occur with minimal friendly casualties. It just doesn't seem like there's even that, which are two of the three negative things I pointed out above. 

Speaking of immersion though, there is quite good text on the battles that provides some immersion for those who enjoy reading through their games. Further, how your army performs and if they win or lose dramatically affect how you will fight your next battle(s). For example, one particular battle may be extremely easy to win as far as the objectives go, but it comes at the cost of men. If played recklessly, one can win, but they'll find their army under strength for the next battle or two. On the other side of the coin, it can be appealing to attempt to out maneuver and out flank enemy(ies) as well, but if in a grand battle that can take multiple days if objectives aren't taken quickly enough, it may equal more overall casualties than simply using a more brute force method. So taking multiple factors into account is critical, and likely separates those who can complete this game on it's "legendary" setting and those who can't. 

And lastly, the bit I mentioned about sort of "glitching" routing armies into a permanent rout/withdraw is a problem but it isn't a huge issue. Mostly you see this either in battles where you vastly outnumber the enemy forces or where the total forces are small enough to successfully do it. Basically it entails getting a unit to route, then while they're routing and retreating you keep a skirmisher unit or a cavalry unit on them to shoot/melee them and they'll basically never "un-route" and return to battle. In the majority of battles though, this is very difficult to pull off since units will mostly retreat into their own reinforcements making sending skirmishers/cavalry for them either very risky or impossible. 

Overall, those who enjoy strategy, tactics, history and battle/military of that period would enjoy this game. I did not enjoy "Ultimate General: Gettysburg" nearly as much, as it was mostly unrefined and didn't offer as much control as you see in this game. So don't be turned off if you've played but did not care for that.

This game is worth your time and monetary investment. It is reminiscent of the great game Sid Meier's Gettysburg from back in they day, but expands to cover the entire war. My only criticism is that winning battles doesn't really seem to impact the game progression a whole lot. You could flawlessly crush your enemy through several campaigns and they don't grow noticeably weaker. I wish you could combine a game like this with Aegeod's behemoth of a game.

This game isn't perfect. There are oddities with the mechanics that let you perform questionable tactics (like firing grapeshot into a melee of friendly and enemy soldiers and only killing enemies), the AI doesn't really keep up with a more advanced player other than just increasing its numbers, there are some mechanics from the previous game that I miss somewhat (e.g. Gettysburg featured radically different deployment plans and tactical choices that could be made in between phases of the battle, while Civil War railroads you somewhat), and unfortunately there are no plans to create a multiplayer.

However, this game still manages to be incredibly enjoyable. The strategic campaign of the game allows you to slowly build up your force from a single division to a multi-corps army that you are intimately familiar with. You foster elite units that follow you from battle to battle. You watch as commanders you recruited as majors early on become major generals commanding entire divisions later on. You wrestle with equipment and manpower. If you are defeated in battle, you may not be able to replace all of your losses going into the next battle, and veteran units can be prohibitively expensive to maintain at the same experience level after heavy losses. As the Confederacy, you are highly limited in advanced weapons, and often rely on capturing it from defeated Union armies. As the Union, you may be able to completely deplete Confederate manpower by the end of the war with a string of successful battles. As either side, you can leverage your reputation from battle victories for more resources from your respective governments, at risk of being sacked if your reputation falls too low from a string of defeats.

On an operational level, each stage of the game features a major historical battle of the war (1st and 2nd Bull Run, Shiloh, Antietam, Gettysburg, etc. etc.), culminating in a fictional battle of Richmond (for the Union) or Washington (for the Confederacy). And each of these major battles is accompanied by a few minor skirmishes/battles (I don't think all of these are historical battles) that are optional. From these secondary battles, you can gain more resources and reputation to help you for the major battle, but it comes at the risk of depleting your army and reputation if you lose.

Tactically, the game makes use of a number of different features to keep the battles dynamic, that are all distilled into a very intelligible and useful UI. Trees and buildings on the battlefield give bonuses to a unit's cover, preventing many losses when they are shot at by enemy units. On the flipside, units are extremely vulnerable while crossing rivers or marshes due to a lack of cover, slowed movement, and difficulty firing their own weapons. Morale impacts when units end up fleeing and refuse to take your orders. Heavy casualties sharply reduces morale, but so can the psychological effect of being shot at from the flanks or the rear. Units also have a Condition level, which measures how tired they are, and thus impacts their movement and firing speed, requiring you to occasionally cycle out units and make hard choices about whether to get reinforcements to the frontline immediately or keep them as fresh as possible in sacrifice of time. Units lose supply with every shot they fire, causing dangerous situations for an army if their units start running out of bullets, especially if the enemy is harassing your supply wagons. Last but not least, different equipment also plays a major role in battle. Rifled guns are expensive to purchase for your army, but are far more effective than the smoothbores you start with. Different types of cannons specialize in different ranges and accuracy. For a few small units, you may even be able to outfit them with repeating carbines, or scoped rifles towards the later part of the war.

Overall, the synthesis of compelling gameplay at multiple levels of strategy makes me recommend this game despite it having some flaws.

You literally get punished for out thinking your opponent because of how the battles are scripted, it has happened to me in several of the campaign battles in which I'll arbitrarily "lose" or "draw" rather than win because of how the game was "intended" to be played.
1. The game suggests you retreat (because that's what happened historically, or something), but I have enough forces and have so decisively beaten my opponent that it's more disadvantageous for me to do so. Well, that means the "victory" point is several miles from my army -- a single unit, one enemy unit, goes around my entire line and caps that point which means that when the time runs out -- even though I've slaughtered 95% of their army at a cost of 20% of mine I still lose the battle.
2. Or, another battle, I advance and capture two of the control points early in the match, because their listed as "victory" points, and have a wonderful strenuous and desperate defense around them -- the time runs out. And a new timer begins. I'm supposed to hold for another half hour (time works strangely in this game) when before I hadn't even been informed of such. If I had literally not captured those points and let the AI beat themselves against my defenses earlier I could have easily had those points, but noooooooo! 
I out thought and fought the AI and was punished for it. That's not strategic, at least not in my opinion. 
3. Thirdly, there are literally some battles in which the AI wont react beyond the base order that the narrative gives them and as such you can literally ignore the main body of their threat and outflank them with minimum effort.

Also, I read a comment where someone was praising the game because flanking the enemy didn't cause them to "instantly" rout, but I disagree, flanking in this game isn't as important in this game as it is in Total War games, but I wouldn't consider that a bonus to the strategy more of a demonstration of the lack there of.

The importance of "winning" "losing" or "drawing" in a battle is as such; you have five resources to spend between each battle to gradually develop your army, they are; Money, Recruits/Veterans, Weapons, Reputation, and Career Points. The first three come in varying amounts depending on the Win/lose/draw result and you get one Career Point for winning every battle and two from major battles. However, you if you lose or draw most battles you lose reputation, losing enough immediately ends your campaign -- you can get a maximum of 100 -- and you can spend the rest to requisition more for the first three resources from the government. In both my Union campaigns I've either had a deficit of Recruits and Weapons or a deficit of Money and Weapons, and that is with the second one being Victorious in every battle. 

As a result the game comes off as more of a unit management game rather than strategy in which you develop your army and then follow the narrative beats to victory.

I feel like this is one of the most accurate representations of close order formation gunpowder battles you'll find in a game. It doesn't have the budget of a Total War game, but it's a deep and interesting representation of the era. You may be turned off by the 2D graphics, but don't be; the game is easy to follow, the UI is clear and concise.

In the campaign you build your army over time, gaining extra troops, money and captured munitions depending on your successes or failures. My first force was a single corps, 6,000 men, 16 guns. Now I've got 3 corps, 70,000 men, 700 guns. I've named units, they've levelled up as I've played. Now my I corps is my elite fighting force. The officers leading each unit are experienced men that provide bonuses to them.

I've played both Union and Confederate campaigns, both of which are long (I've still not finished either with all my play time).

The way line of sight works, in conjunction with each infantry unit being able to detach a small force of skirmishers, or light company, means you'll have to explore out and probe the enemy. The cover system as well creates safe defensive lines among forests and crops, turning open fields in to killing zones with artillery pummelling units. The morale then comes in to play, with units far more likely to turn and run than stand and be cut down. This encourages aggressive play, a well backed up assault that storms an enemy weak point can overwhelm and break the line. An unsupported or poorly coordinated charge will certainly result in defeat.

There is a prisoner system as well, where routing units are able to be captured and controlled, unable to fight. You can use this to pull enemy units out of the battle, hiding them all at the back. Or you can get your cavalry behind their line and capture their supply wagons, and supplies are important in this game. Units that run out of ammo can still fire, although at a well reduced rate, and captured ammo wagons can supply your troops. If you can steal the enemies wagons you can push hard and overwhelm them with firepower.

A solid, challenging and attention grabbing game. Well worth purchasing for full price, as I did.

TL;DR: Great game, worth buying.

The game has 3 major components: campaign, historical battles, and custom battles. The difficulty has 3 settings: easy (colonel), regular (brig. general), and hard (major general). The difficulty can be set at the start of the campaign and at the start of each historical battle. It took me about 150 hours of actual playtime (my Steam hours is about 200 with idling, game minimized, etc.) to complete both campaigns and all historical battles from both sides. That is a pretty great cost to enjoyment ratio, and I have never played any custom battles yet.

The campaign allows you to play as a General for either side through 11 major offensives, each consisting of 1-3 "minor battles" and 1 "major battle". The same locations will be the site of multiple battles (just as it was in real life) so several of the maps are reused multiple times. That may be viewed negatively by some, but each scenario is very unique. Not only are troop positions different, but the landscape will be somewhat altered over time and the actual playable area is changed frequently. All of these factors combine to keep each mission in the campaign interesting and enjoyable.

During the campaign, you are restricted by two main factors: money and manpower. Each battle will earn or cost you an amount of prestige, money, and manpower based on the outcome (victory, draw, or defeat). Each victory will also earn you "career points" that can be invested in various bonuses such as intel (more information before battle), medicine (restoring some of your men after combat), politics (increasing the resources you get from each battle), economy (reducing the cost of new equipment), and others. Capturing enemy POWs will get you up to 1000 additional recruits each battle, and capturing enemy supply wagons will net you some extra cash (the exact amount will be shown in the after action report). Taking enemy prisoners can also earn you large amounts of captured weapons that you can reequip to your own men or sell for extra money.

The historical battles include all the scenarios that form the "major battles" from the campaign. These situations can vary greatly from your experience of that battle during the campaign (for example, you may have significantly less troops available or a very different unit composition) and are very much worth playing even if you play the campaign.

The gameplay can be viewed as pretty simple, there are only 4 types of unit: infantry, skirmishers, artillery, and cavalry. However, there is a lot of nuance as well. Each unit type has a variety of weapons available to them with different characteristics that can completely change how a unit should be used. For example, cavalry can be equipped with carbines as mounted scout infantry (who may dismount to fight) or with revolving rifles and sabers as proper cavalry (who need to get a lot closer to shoot and can't dismount to fight). Skirmishers might be using sawed-off shotguns for CQC in a forest, or they might be equipped with telescopic sighted rifles and shoot from afar. Artillery can similarly be divided into smoothbore (longer range) and rifled (more direct). Infantry will mostly use muskets but you can create elite units with 15-round magazine rifles or revolvers.

The achievements are rational, reasonable goals. If you play through all content you will 100% this game. There is no hunting required and no DLC.

A nice feature is that your saves are organized into folders based on the game mode so "historical" saves will never get mixed in with "campaign" saves. Additionally, the game allows multiple saves of the same name, so unless you intentionally select a save to be overwritten you won't lose your progress.

Graphically, the game is not impressive but that isn't really expected from an RTS that is trying to show battles that involved 10s of thousands of soldiers. The upside is that you don't need much under the hood to run this game. Even most potato-powered PCs should be able to run Ultimate General with no real issues.

Overall, a great game and very much worth buying, even at the full price of $30.

This is a pretty good real-time tactical wargame set during the American Civil War. You can play individual historical battles or indulge in the game's campaign layer, allowing you to customize your army as you play through an 1861 - 1865 scenario. It is easiest to think of Ultimate General as the ACW Total War game that always should have happened, but never did. The dev behind this studio actually WAS a popular TW modder, which makes the comparison even stronger.

TLDR: Check out John Tiller series (turn-based) or Scourge of War (real-time) if you crave the most realistic wargames currently on the market, however Ultimate General does offer a fun, fast-paced, slightly more straightforward "beer & pretzels" (casual) experience, and even boasts a best-in-class campaign component if that's your thing.

Now, below I'm going to write about this game in much more detail, especially regarding some of the features I find most enjoyable in this genre and how it compares to other popular titles. I think you'll see that UG falls somewhere in the middle of the pack in terms of balancing authenticity and accessibility:

--------------------------------------------------

* AI commanders: This is probably my biggest wargaming pet peeve. With large Corps or Army level engagements, it becomes overwhelming to micro-manage all my forces. This ruins the fun for me in games like Civil War Generals 2 and the Hexwar titles. There's a lot to like with these games, but almost every scenario is tedious and overlong. Unfortunately, UG:CW is also in this vein, as it doesn't have any option to assign certain formations over to an AI general.

* Indirect orders: Despite the above, you do have the ability to issue "extended" orders to a unit, for example a long flanking maneuver where you trace the route of their march with your mouse. They will obey your orders instantly though, while you command with a "God's eye" view of the battlefield. One title very worth comparing here is Scourge of War (Gettysburg, Chancellorsville, Antietam), which allows a "headquarters in the saddle" option where you send couriers to deliver your orders, simulating the slowness of communications in the 1860's.

* Leader units: Leaders with command bonuses can really enhance tactical gameplay, not to mention add a ton of interesting context for further historical research. UG only gives you control of Corps commanders or higher (Lee, Jackson, etc.), which unfortunately ties it with Total War as the most obfuscated command structure of any comparable game. :(

* OOB: Maybe it's just the history nerd in me, but I like to browse the orders of battle, especially during combat. Unfortunately, UG only allows this before and after battle. Additionally, the "opposing forces" are presented in a confusing structure, at least for me, that represents Corps and Divisions for organizational purposes, even when it isn't historically accurate (1st Manassas, for example). There is another series of wargames called John Tiller Software's (JTS) Civil War Battles. They are turn-based and they aren't on Steam, but you can check out his website directly. The OOBs there are clean, historically accurate, and really easy to navigate.

* Detailed mechanics (morale, ammo, supply): Having these kind of mechanics are not necessarily good or bad, but just depend on your preferences. UG has all 3 features, although routed (fleeing) units have a strange tendency to recover too quickly and rejoin the fight unexpectedly. Of the games I've mentioned, JTS has the most in-depth options (and optional rulesets to tweak), whereas Hexwar has none of it at all. So again, UG is a middle-of-the-road option.

* Battles/campaigns: The more the better, of course, and hopefully with historically accurate detail. UG is actually pretty good here, compared to typical wargames which focus on major releases of single battles (more like UG: Gettysburg). This title includes many famous engagments like 1st Manassas, Shiloh, Antietam, Chickamauga, Fredericksburg, Chancellorsville, and Gettysburg. Still, it doesn't get any better than JTS in this regard, with 13 releases covering almost the entire war, including some key items missing from this title such as Jackson’s Valley campaign, Wilderness & Spotsylvania Courthouse (Overland campaign), and the Petersburg campaign. Not to mention John Tiller's scenario designers include painstakingly accurate historical detail in terms of the terrain, objectives, leaders, forces, etc.

* Campaign layer: UG excels in this area. It adds a strategy/campaign layer in which you gain money and skills as you fight your way through the ACW. You will be able to recruit your own officers, organize your brigades, and outfit your soldiers with the latest equipment. UG actually does it better than any other game I've listed so far (for most of the others this functionality is not available at all, although CWG2 does have shorter but comparable campaigns if that kind of gameplay interests you).

--------------------------------------------------

Hope this feedback helps. For my personal enjoyment, I really can't recommend the John Tiller series highly enough. The historical authenticity, flexible AI, numerous optional rulesets, detailed mechanics, and unparalleled number of engagements all combine to make JTS a near perfect option if you're looking for a tactical-level wargame covering the American Civil War.

Ultimate General is a good option too, though, especially for newer players. It's also much more affordable at $30 for the whole thing vs. $40 for *each* John Tiller game! If you're patient, you can even pick up UG on sale for ~ $10 a couple times a year.

Cheers and happy gaming!

As a civil war historian and after logging 300 hours into this game, I have mixed reviews of it. As a strategy game about the Civil War it does an excellent job in the combat system, incorporating Civil War tactics with incredibly detailed maps that accurately depict the game. It also incorporates the ability to aquire historic generals to add to your army to boost its capabilities which is fantastic. Having officers be potienal casualties was a great touch (even if i loose a Major General when the brigade has only had 5 casualites >:(.  ) Those are just a few of the aspects of the game that I love. 

However there are some aspects of the game that are quite frustrating. For instance you quickly learn what units are worth getting and what are not. For instance the skirmishers are useful as scouts and little more late game. Therefore if you put them on the flank in hidden positions they can snipe the enemy but otherwise they are not very effective on the field. Infnatry units can send out their own flankers and skirmishers to scout and more or less can replace the Skirmishers so why get skirmishers? Also the artillery can be effective in supporting your units and will get many kills if you place them in the right position. It is clear that they help your infantry when you combine them and the infantry dont perform as well without them. However if you group up your artillery and barrage a positon I have found that you can rarely break a enemy positon with just artillery. For instance in Gettysburg or Fredricksburg if you fire all your cannon on an enemy positon they will still hold despite casualties. Why arent those barrages more effective? Lastly the way cavalry works in this game is incredibly infuriating. They do not have access to weapons in the game that give them range close to that of infantry so engaging with them is pointless wether your cavalry is mounted or dismounted. They are fast and great for scounting, but I have found they are only good for that and engaging exposed enemy artillery from the flanks or rear. The cavlary were used to great effect by both sides throughout the war but in this game they are pointless. I often only have at most 1 unit per full army corps. With a max size limit at 750 compared to the 2500 for infantry they cant even be used for counter charges to break enemy lines because they are so outnumbered that it is sending them to their death, unless an enmy infantry unit is fleeing and below 1000 strength, then they can be used to harrass or charge them. Unltimately the game tactics favor infantry formations and positions so heavily that it makes using cavalry or skirmisher tactics pointless and not worth the loss of life. Also often times the infantry can be in fortified possitions and flee after minimal casualties. At times the locations of fortified positions intentially put your troops where they will just take heavy losses and not hold the positions with the way the AI attack and it is annoying. You want to take the stronger position but he minute you place troops there they are slaughtered. The Confederate campaign on the highest difficulty is incredilby hard as well. Often times it is easier to play passive or defensive against the AI and take a loss at a battle in order to take fewer casualties and continue to expand the army (in a win I could loose 15k men and only be able to replace 10k while in a loss I could loose 5k and not only replace them but add to the army)

I would like to see this game expanded with more components to it. Make cavalry forces larger and give their weapons more range so they can actually be used. Can officers be promoted from within the unit itself, so if your Colonel dies possibly a young Lt proved himself and is made a captain you can assaign a unit? Or possibly add in other famous generals who started at lower ranks so you can have them throughout the campaign. Also it would be interesting to see these officers die in historically accuarate battles. As much as I love having Stonewall Jackson at Gettysburg, It would be interesting if we lost these generals at certain battles no matter what to spice up the campaign play. Id love an expansion on the economic and political aspects of the game so that you can produce better weapons or aquire allies as your successes continue. Including a way to make your own forticications would be great especially on maps like Fredricksburg where large portions of the line are not fortified and your men just stand in the open taking losses. I would also love an expansion to include a western campaign or splitting the army in two so you control one in the West and one in the East and can transfer troops between each depending on the need.

Ultimately I love the game and have played through many times. I would recommmend it to friends but I want more. While I have many complaints they are things I would love to see improved and released in a second game or expansion to this which I would buy in a heart beat.  It was wonderfully done just could be even better :)

No matter how much my boys outfight them that remorseless blue wave just keeps coming and every able soldier lost cannot be replaced. To slowly realise that it is the Iron brigade heading for my weakened flank. Hard choice after hard choice.

The core element of this game, the tactical battles, are impressive from top to bottom you can practically smell the gunpowder. I only wish the rebels gave their distinct yell on the charge!

This game creates an excellent atmosphere, with some footage from Ken Burns civil war spliced in and a bit more dialogue like at the general creation screen this game could assail even loftier heights. Echoes of the sense of purpose the close combat a bridge too far had could have been achieved.

The strategic layer is clearly the weaker aspect of this game but building and customising your army and units was an essential element of the fun. My army never felt faceless or disposable. Battles fought with my own army scrapped together with whatever was available were always more satisfying to fight with than pre-generated units.

This is a game designed by former Total War modders, which when I was following from afar during the days of the original RTW was generally committed to making the games more strategically complex and historically accurate. The results are pretty much what you would expect and makes for, in my opinion, one of the greatest real time strategy games of the last decade. 

The brilliance of this game and its predecessor, UG:Gettysburg is that it goes to such great lengths to portray the warfare of the period in as plausible a manner as possible. In the Civil War, overall casualties in individual battles were fairly low (the Battle of Stones River, which had the highest proportionate casualties of the war, ended with no more than about 35% dead and wounded) and the ability of mass-produced rifle muskets to repulse massed infantry charges meant that battles were generally fought at a distance, with the decisive infantry charges that were common even 20 years prior in the Mexican-American War almost non-existent. Both sides, moreover, fought the war with massive numbers of inexperienced volunteer regiments, generally led by commanders with little to no battlefield experience who were forced to develop their skills in the field.

In UG:Civil War, in other words, the name of the game is as much outmaneuvering your opponents (made possible by your ability to draw movement commands for selected units on the terrain) as it is inflicting casualties, managing the limited conditioning and morale of your troops, and protecting your experienced units while slowly developing raw recruits into battle-hardened veterans over the course of several campaigns.

The game shines brightest during the battles themselves. The design of the battles are brilliantly detailed and make you feel as though you're looking at the battle unfold as the original commanders might have 150 years ago. The overarching campaign mode is somewhat weaker than the battles themselves, and serves mainly to connect your results in previous battles to the resources available to you in subsequent campaigns. Units are persistent throughout the campaign unless they are destroyed, and it is fun to raise and customize your troops and their equipment, and satisfying to see units which were raw recruits in April 1861 become seasoned veterans by July 1863.

Even still, the consequences of your results in the campaign's battles feel somewhat limited. Even if you are somehow able to rout Lee's Army of Northern Virginia as the Union in the Battles of Gaines Mill and Malvern Hill (the decisive battles which ended the Union's advance on Richmond in the Peninsula Campaign and established Lee as the South's premier general), you somehow still end up on the defensive in the 2nd Battle of Bull Run and Antietam, battles which never would have happened if the Peninsula campaign was successful. The *strategic* implications of your victories are practically nil, represented abstractly only by improved conditioning and access to equipment for your troops and reduced manpower for the enemy in future battles. There is probably nothing that the game's designers could have done to address this without overwhelming the player and making the campaign mode too complex and time-consuming to make, but there is still a bit of an odd disconnect between the historical accuracy of the battles and the more abstract campaign mode in which they are presented to the player.

As varied as the selection of battles is in the game, I also feel as though there were some significant oversights. Sieges such as Vicksburg and Petersburg are not represented in the game (the latter is replaced by a fictionalized decisive assault on Richmond,) and the Battle of Missionary Ridge, arguably the decisive battle of the entire Western Theater, is also absent. The Western Theater of the war in general is somewhat under-represented.

But these are all minor complaints in comparison to everything this game gets right. This game is a real achievement, a much-needed jolt in the arm for a real time strategy genre which has been generally saddled by shallow gameplay and obsolete mechanics developed for the most part in the early 1990s. I can't wait to see what the developers' have in store next.

Pros: 
 - Fun gameplay with solid mechanics. 
 - Easy to learn, hard to master.
 - Great army management system. It's really fun to see your army develop and grow as you try to crush the Rebel scum, or alternatively desperately try to keep a viable fighting force together in the face of Northern aggression.

Cons:
 - There are still a few counterintuitive mechanics regarding optimum unit size, but you can learn to avoid the pitfalls by spending 5 minutes reading up on the forums.
 - Don't expect to avoid micromanagement. Units will suicide if you dont keep an eye on them. Your skirmishers will happily charge the entire enemy army if they  lose their line of fire to the target you gave them, or ignore enemies who are murdering them with flanking fire. 
 - The game suffered from poorly designed campaign balance at launch, but that has been fixed for some time now, so not sure why I wrote that. I guess I wanted three cons as well as three pros.

Final judgement: 
Very entertaining game with lots of replay value. 9/10.
