SUMMARY: Ultimate General: Civil War is a very good historical real-time strategy game that is tactically deep (great pitched battles) and possesses a simple but enjoyable strategy layer (campaign+army management). Be aware: The learning curve is steep and the first few battles are difficult. This game has allowed me to enjoy two very long campaigns (Union and CSA) over many months by fighting small battles and managing the army during the week, and then fighting “grand battles” on weekends. If you enjoyed Napoleon Total War but wanted a larger scale and challenging experience that makes you earn your victory, then you will enjoy this game.

THE BATTLES: 75% of UG:CW is spent in pause-able, scripted, timed battles on a large tactical map with victory point objectives. Many minor battles can be completed in 30-60 minutes, but the grand battles like Gettysburg or Chickamauga can take hours. Planning, positioning, and timing are the keys to victory in this game, not rapid clicking and uncoordinated charges that will only get your men killed. Some of the grand battles, like Shiloh, require you to fight intense delaying actions against superior forces so your main body can fall back and get into defensive positions. In other battles, tactics like strategy of central position and encirclement are very effective and satisfying. Brute force is still an option on lower difficulty levels and is downright necessary to take some positions (Cemetery Hill, Nashville Pike), but the cost in men and equipment will be terrible. Grand battle maps can be huge and you may end up fighting several chaotic engagements simultaneously on different sections of the map (example: Fredericksburg). Use of screening forces for flanking, scouting, and raiding behind enemy lines is also really effective and one of the most enjoyable aspects of these grand battles.

The AI in this game is above average (better than N:TW) and will aggressively attack weak points in your defensive lines, protect its artillery, and can still punch you in the face after 100+ hours in game (example: My 7,500 man assault on the Brotherton Road victory point that was counter-attacked by about 15,000 Union infantry waiting in the tree line… “FALLLBAAAACK!”).

THE CAMPAIGN: The campaign could be described as “lite” and consists of 30+ mostly historical battles on pre-made (but beautiful) maps using your customized army. The campaigns are divided into chapters that include 1-3 minor battles for training up your troops, gaining loot, and inflicting casualties before the grand battle that leads to the next chapter. Some battle outcomes lightly affect AI manpower in later battles, but you are able to skip the small battles and go straight to the big fights if you don’t want to take the casualties and can forego the career points. The real meat of the strategic layer is the army management. 

ARMY MANAGEMENT: Create and rename brigades, reinforce, equip soldiers with bought or captured weapons, and re-assign promoted officers. Each unit gains experience from combat that gradually increases its stats and unlocks perks as they level up (example: 50% more ammo for artillery brigades at 1-star). Army corps generals confer passive perks to all units under their command (example +5% speed), while divisional and brigade commanders affect how the unit performs in combat. All of the battles have caps on the quantity of brigades that can be deployed during combat and many feed reinforcements into battle piecemeal (example: Chickamauga), so your army composition and organization are VERY important for effective combat. Victories also allow leveling up of some strategic “career” perks (example: lower equipment costs) using a point system.

ISSUES: UG:CW is not a perfect game and has some widely discussed issues that you may or may NOT find to be a problem. The most discussed topic is “scaling”of the AI Army: As you grow your brigades from 500 to 2,500 men, the AI will usually (not always) deploy larger brigades, especially on higher difficulty levels. There are ways to mitigate scaling that don’t include cheating, but many people dislike the feature. Other debated issues include the nerfed gun ranges and surrender mechanics, ineffective cavalry, a lack of custom unit groupings (example CTRL+1 for ad hoc divisions), a lack of friendly fire mechanics, and how scripting will roll back your gains in some of the grand battles. In my experience, these haven’t been a problem if I was aware of them in advance (by watching YouTube).

TIPS FOR NEW GENERALS

1)	First Campaign: Choose the Union on Colonel difficulty. This game is hard and the first couple missions are difficult even for a Napoleon: Total War veteran. CSA is more fun.

2)	Career Points: The most important skills are (in order) Politics, Training, Medicine, Economy, Army Organization, Logistics, and then Reconnaissance. 

3)	First Perks for Units: Infantry = Discipline, Artillery = Logistics, Cavalry = Horseback, Skirmishers = Endurance.

4)	Victory Conditions: Check the conditions when the battle starts. “Hold” means you will need to have control of the objective for a “contested” amount of time (45-60 game clock minutes) before it is considered captured. If the battle timer reaches zero but an area is still “contested,” the battle will continue in overtime. “Capture” of an objective means you only have to control the area when the battle timer reaches zero.

5)	Skirmishers: NEVER use dedicated skirmisher brigades and instead use detached skirmishers for scouting, flanking actions, capturing supplies, and especially taking out artillery behind the main enemy line.

6)	Cavalry: Melee Cavalry and Mounted Infantry is situationally effective for raiding behind enemy lines to steal supplies, taking out unsupported artillery and skirmishers in the open, and chasing down isolated routing infantry. Cavalry is fragile and will take huge/expensive casualties if it runs into a full-morale enemy infantry brigade.

7)	Artillery and Tactics: The best artillery pieces are the 12lb. Napoleon’s for close range and the 10lb. Ordnance for medium range. Phase in 24lb. Howitzer’s and 20lb. Parrot’s as they become available. Sell everything else. There is an excellent “Artillerist’s Guide to Ultimate General: Civil War” by user The Soldier on Steam.

8)	Command Skill and Efficiency: A unit’s Efficiency value represents the brigade’s potential reload speed and potential damage per volley. Actual reload speed and damage are also affected by the weapon equipped. However, the efficiency value will be capped by the Command value for the unit, which comes from the brigade commander AND the divisional commander’s rank and experience (but not the Corps commander). This means that your 3-star, 12-gun artillery brigade with a displayed efficiency value of 89, but a command value of 58 from Lt. Colonel N00b, will perform like it has an efficiency value of 58 (much slower reload, less damage per volley). This is why it’s important to assign high-ranking officers to directly command elite brigade.

9)	Optimal Unit Size: Efficiency is also negatively affected by unit size. Keep your infantry brigades at 1,500 men, cavalry and skirmishers at 500 men, and artillery at 12-guns for optimal killing power and to mitigate scaling.

10)	AI Scaling: The game uses your average brigade size to determine an appropriate AI scaled brigade size. Avoid making big 2,500 man 1-star infantry brigades that trigger 3,000 man AI brigades. Use smaller, elite, and better equipped units instead.

11)	Defenses/Cover: Avoid using fixed defensive positions (little shield icons). Instead, keep your brigades in their column formation in trees, fields, and buildings where cover is better. Whenever possible, engage enemy troops while they are moving through an open field while your soldiers have good cover.

Long story short, this game is fantastic.

You may experience some growing pains as you try to learn to particular ins-and-outs of the battle system (if you're used to games like the total war series, you will need to quickly realise that cavalry are not nearly as powerful as they are in those games).

Hands down the best RTS civil war game out there. Think Total War battles but with continuity choices thrown into the mix between battles.

Low Down: You have the main battles which test your tactical prowess but between battles you have to refit and reinforce your army as you see fit, upgrading weapons, promoting commanders and units, and selling captured or outdated munitions.

You can choose "minor" skirmishes between fights to improve your chances in the big battles, and as you progress you earn career points which allow you to fill out the type of army you want to field.

Cons: The only real downside is if you pick up a serious head of steam and start winning some battles early on by a significant margin it will make the final battles easier/too easy, but still, seeing 1,000+ rebs behind a trenchwork is enough to make you think twice!

If you are a civil war fan, and a total war fan, get this game!
The AI manuever, resilience, & battle tactics is adorable & attracted me to play & play again this game. Thanks to the creators.
An awesome game for someone who loves history!

Play this game and then try playing a Total War game afterwards. You will never enjoy combat in a Total War game again. In Ultimate General, units will stay and fight until they're flanked or truly routed. No cheesy tricks needed like in all Total War games where you have to send cavalry all over the map and send half the enemy army on a wild goose chase. No more skirmishers and archers who manage to stay just out of reach for an entire battle.

The combat has real weight to it - you know when you send in your best riflemen, they will inflict damage before giving up, even if outnumbered. You know having your general nearby helps. You can actually see the effect that bringing in artillery or a mobile unit like skirmishers can have on a fight. Whereas in Total War fights just eventually result in a chaotic mess where you just have to throw your hands up and hope for the best, in Ultimate General you actually feel like you've accomplished something in winning a tough fight.

Do I wish they had more of a grand strategy mode with a map that I can conquer? Of course. But remember this is probably a very small team with a very small budget. I think these guys have the talent and game design skills to make a better Total War game, but for now what they've done is make a far superior combat experience than Total War can ever offer you. 

Beware if you're a Total War junkie like I was, you'll never be able to go back.

Honestly, this game can go suck a big fat one. It constantly changes the location of objectives that you have to hold in order to fit with the historical events, rather than what is actually happening on the field. Successfully defend an objective against an onslaught of enemies? Guess what! They weren't meant to be defeated, and you have to fall back from your well-organized defensive perimeter anyway because that's what happened in real life. The objective moves a mile or so  behind your lines and the enemy AI sneaks one cavalry unit to the point and you lose. Basically it's as if you were playing chess, but every 5 or 10 turns, your king swaps places with another piece, causing you to potentially lose the game almost instantly at no fault of your own. It's an awful mechanic that rewards metagaming over tactical skill. Moreover, enemies almost always vastly outnumber your own men and most missions devolve quickly into heroic last stands while you wait for the game to give you the second half of your army. On subsequent playthroughs, most levels are significantly easier, as enemies spawn in the same location and you can arrange your forces to best defend against the enemy's formation that your character has no way of knowing.

The objectives in general are just garbage. If the enemy bum rushes (which they can almost always do, since nearly every scenario presents as hordes of enemies rushing your very limited number of men), they can typically route units you have defending the point, and it can be impossible to take it back with in the arbitrary 10-30 game minute deadline. Pretty much every battle I lost saw my army absolutely dominating the opposition, clearly capable of taking back the objective if given time to whittle down the enemy's suicidal mob, but each time, Abe Lincoln apparently descended down from the skies and told the troops to pack it up and leave because allowing the enemy to hold a random hill for 21 minutes is apparently just unacceptable, and we should have opted to lose 1000 guys in a suicide charge to "take the objective back" for 10 seconds before re-losing it immediately, just for the sake of resetting the timer. 

If there were no timers, the objectives would be a reasonably ok system. For example, yes game, I do agree that I have to hold the landing area to get reinforcements at the Battle of Shiloh. But if the boats aren't arriving for six hours, what difference does it make if an enemy cavalry is standing in the landing zone for 25 minutes somewhere in there? The game constantly justifies its timers using various threats. Like, "take X hill in the next hour, because enemy reinforcements are going to get there and improve their defenses, and then taking it will be really hard!" Ok, sure that makes sense, but why insta-fail the scenario if it's not done in time? Why not just send the reinforcements in and make the objective really difficult to take? Rather than this artificial, immersion-shattering, game-destroying instant failure.
Any timers should be counting down to the AI getting some sort of situationally-relevant tactical advantage (most of which are already stated -but not implemented - in the game!), 

Many times timers are on the player's side as well. Most defensive objectives involve letting the clock tick down a couple hours, at which point you click "Finish" even if the battle would realistically rage on for several more hours. And the enemy just... leaves I guess? Even if they were winning? If you don't like winning the scenarios by virtue of not losing before the timer runs out, you can always decide to keep fighting to see if you end up winning in the end. But the objective can still be taken by the AI during this time and you can still lose. Additionally, damage done to enemies during each battle doesn't affect later battles, while damage your troops take will have to be replaced in your own army, so the mechanics strongly encourage you to end missions as soon as possible even if it makes no sense. God forbid you have the urge to play things out to a conclusive end.

Artillery in this game is horribly unbalanced as well. At the end of a day-long battle, they should have more than 150 kills, regardless of whether I put them at their exact optimal range. Luckily, the AI cannons are also trash. You can safely ignore most any artillery bombardment and only lose a small percentage of your men. Most cannons cost far more than they are worth, while infantry-only armies seem to be a distressingly viable composition. You can do at least as well using only armies composed entirely of 1500 man infantry units and buying better rifles using the money that would have been spent on cannons. While the killing power of artillery used correctly may be larger, infantry are the only units that can stop a determined enemy advance, and hiring as many as you can is the only real way to close the manpower gap against the AI. The only drawback is that their feet start to hurt after maybe a quarter mile of running, so they can't always make it to changing objectives before enemy cavalry. 

The controls are a bit wonky as well. Left click and drag to box select multiple units at once. But be careful, because if you click a unit instead of the ground, it draws a path for that unit to walk down. This is the only movement control bound to left mouse. All others are on the right side. And what's more, right clicking on a unit and dragging doesn't do anything at all! Why not have that to control path drawing?? And you'd better get used to moving the camera using middle mouse, because something about moving the camera with WASD just confuses the hell out of all your units.

Overall, the game is reasonably fun until you realize that it doesn't really want you to play it. It wants you to follow a specific sequence of events and troop movements every single time, and if you deviate from that sequence too much, you're wrong and you lose. You aren't role-playing as a Civil War General in this game. You are role-playing as the choreographer for a group of Civil War reinactors.

Ultimate General: Civil War is an all-around solid title for Strategy game fans and Civil War nerds (better, if both.)

The campaign is the highlight of the game, in which you make a custom general and lead either Union or Confederate forces through a series of historical theaters and battles, from Bull Run to Cold Harbor. Over the course of those battles, the player manages the strategic layer and tactical layers that do a good job of showcasing the American Civil War era.

The strategic layer requires managing manpower, equipment, officers, and the organization of one's army. Overall, this is well done; captured weapons can be assigned to units, and the efficiency of one's units is relative to the officer commanding the unit. Meaningful choices are made over the course of the war, and balancing manpower and money is a constant struggle.

The tactical layer is where the player will see most of the action of the game. The choices made in the strategic layer will be put in to practice as the player manages infantry, cavalary, artillery, and skirmishers. These four unit types all fulfilly unique roles on the battle field; while it may be hard to use some of them effectively, early on, they're all critical to victory.

Graphically, the game is quite beautiful, and evocative. Smoke covers the battlefield, craters leave marks on the ground, and fallen soldiers lay where they were wounded. The environments are really quite beautiful. The sound production is equally evocative, as the opening volleys ring out across the battlefield or in the distance.

The game fails primarily in how battles are scripted; you can utterly dominate enemy forces, but find yourself forced to retreat by the end of the day to a more historically accurate position. It's frustrating to utterly dominate the Battle of Shenandoah as the Union, and then have to fight your way forward from the last line of defense the next day.

All in all, the game is quite fun, and worthwhile; I'll be playing it again!

[h1]Pros [/h1] 
[list]
    [*] I absolutely love the focus on leaders. It is disturbing how many games about war, even those claiming to be “realistic, historically accurate” etc, completely ignore this most crucial and decisive element of warfare – leaders. This game has leaders, mostly based on history, ranked from lowly captains to generals, who are in command of every brigade, division and corps as per their ranks. They can be hired, fired, killed, wounded, replaced. They gain experience over battles, get promoted, and learn skills that improve their commanded units.
   [*] The game has a relatively more realistic order of battle, compared to generic RTS games or the likes of Total War. Your army is made up of corps, which are broken up into divisions, each of which are made up for brigades. As you progress through the campaign, you can create more corps and increase the size of your divisions and brigades.
   [*] Recruiting, organizing and equipping your army is an absolute joy as far as I am concerned. There are plenty of weapon types, broken up into four main categories – infantry, skirmishers, cavalry, canons. Each category has further options, letting you choose weapons that focus on range, or firing rate, or melee. As the campaign progresses, you will get access to more modern weapons. You can also loot weapons from your enemies. 
   [*] The pacing and tactics are a lot more satisfying than Total War. The game encourages you to play methodically as opposed to a mad orgy of clicks like a generic RTS or recent Total War games. You rely on positioning, maneuverers, terrain etc. The style is quite close to tactical wargames such as Command Ops or Scourge of War. I wish they had gone even further in that direction, but I guess that would too much for some of the target audience.
   [*] Army sizes and casualties are realistic.
   [*] The visuals are nice enough, especially given the scale and performance.
   [*] Tactical factors such as cover, terrain, flanking etc. have visible, if sometimes inaccurate, effect on the battles.
   [*] You need to manage your supplies in battles, which is refreshing. You can even capture enemy supplies and divert them your way.
   [*] The brigades become organically more proficient in different aspects of combat through participation. E.g. marching a lot will improve their movement. This is realistic, and rarely seen in games like this. 
   [*] There are quality of life features such as tactical pause, comprehensive save / load system, and difficulty settings etc, which for some strange reason, have become too much to ask for some indie developers these days.
   [*] There is a basic chain of command system, which, again, is a welcome feature in games like this, yet is somehow ignored by most developers. In theory, it should allow you to leave mundane tasks to AI commanders, according to your order of battle, making you free to focus on parts of the battle that interests you. This enables a game to add much larger army organizations without a fear of overwhelming the player. It is also a lot more realistic, as you truly play the role of commander, as opposed to some nonsensical hivemind entity controlling every move of your entire army as seen in Total War or generic RTS games. This game gets points for including this, but the system is not fully realized. More on that later.
[/list]

[h1]Cons (and / or Suggestions for future games) [/h1] 
[list]
    [*] While you can control your Corps commander and move him close to units for bonuses, the division commanders are missing in the field. Instead they are attached to one random regiment under them. You have no control over their fates and positions, and thus fail to make the best use of them.  
    [*] Asking multiple brigades to move often leads to the brigades unnecessarily switching positions and getting flanked.
    [*] The game would sometimes inaccurately calculate flanking and line of fire (e.g. blocking).
    [*] You will experience abrupt unrealistic stoppages due to the timer system as the game will force you to move to the next phase, right in the middle of an ongoing battle, or while you are executing a brilliant tactical manoeuvre. Unit's positions will be reset. I find this to be quite jarring, unnatural, and unsatisfactory. 
    [*] Often times you will have very little strategic control over battles. Your corps and divisions will be taken away for fake challenge. Sometimes the game will randomly assign units from your corps leaving out cavalry, artillery or skirmishers that might have provided more tactical variety. I hope that in future games, the player would be in complete strategic control of the extended battlefield. If some of troops need to be on some hill or guarding a flank to prevent an enemy attack, it should be the player's choice which divisions to put there.
    [*] You also can not reduce the size of brigades for some strange reason. Say your elite brigade as 2500 troops. You just purchased 2000 high-end rifles. Ideally you should be able to reduce the brigade to 2000 and give them those new rifles, but it is not possible here.
    [*] The game lacks realistic tactical commands such as "advance at all costs", "advance until resistance", "recon", "avoid engagement", "tactical retreat" etc from other tactical wargames. It will so happen that your units may keep moving forward like idiots despite discovering overwhelming resistance. Some units like skirmishers have hardcoded behaviour which can play havoc on your tactics as they will run back after a single volley instead of decimating an enemy flank as commanded.
    [*] You can give overall commands to larger organizational groups and let the AI do the micromanaging instead of you. But this AI is very unreliable, and often seems much worse than the enemy AI. The traits or rank of the general you assign these commands to seem to have no effect on its behaviour. You are better off doing everything on your own.
    [*] Commanders are more or less indistinguishable, other than the rank, name and portrait. They have no affinities to certain troop types or unique traits. Look at Romance of the Three Kingdoms or AGEOD for how to properly implement characters.
    [*] Corps and division commanders gain xp in a glacial speed. In my entire campaign, I do not think I ever saw a division commander reach the next rank. 
    [*] Battles often follow a pre-set path no matter how you perform in the early phases. For instance, due to the overwhelming damage I caused to the Confederates in my Gettysburg battle, the great scripted Confederate charge during the final phases only had 4000 men against my 100,000. It makes no sense. Large battles should be more dynamic, with branching paths, so that later phases can correspond to the outcomes of the earlier ones.

Tactically, this game can be interesting and a lot of fun.  The tutorial gets you excited at what the game might have to offer.

Strategically, the game is a complete failure.  It doesn't matter HOW successful you are or aren't, the game proceeds in more or less lockstep fashion. Have I been too tough on Ultimate General: Civil War? In spite of everything I've said, I don't hate Civil War. Rather, I expected too much, hoped for fifteen battles with the scope of Ultimate General: Gettysburg, anticipated improvements. Instead the developers delivered a dull, repetitive, tiresome campaign, when they would have better served their customers by offering another single battle: Chancellorsville, Antietam, or Shiloh, with improvements.

Ultimate General: Civil War is a real time tactical strategy game set in, you guessed it, the American Civil War.  This title builds upon its predecessor, Ultimate General: Gettysburg, and expands its focus from one battle (Gettysburg) to the entire war, featuring many of the most famous battles of the conflict (as well as several other fictional battles and smaller skirmishes).

The principle feature of the game is the campaign.  In the campaign, players will take on the role of a fictional Union or Confederate general, fighting battles and using the spoils to build more elaborate armies to fight battles on a larger and larger scale as the war escalates.  The meta-game of building your army and assigning equipment is reminiscent of the Panzer General/Fantasy General series from the mid 1990's (there was a Civil War General game in the same vein but I don't recall it nearly as well), while the battles themselves are played in a pausable real-time tactical interface that any RTS or Total War player will find instantly familiar.

The battles strike an excellent balance between abstraction and realism:  players must contend with supplies and ammunition, positioning of troops/artillery, morale, maneuvering and scouting with skirmishers/cavalry, and terrain without having to micromanage units' lines of sight or specific behaviors too intensely.  Even large battles are generally managable (though you do have the option of assigning divisions or corps to AI command with general instructions) and satisfying to command.  

The goal of battles is usually to try and hold (or take) specific positions on a battlefield within a certain window of time, but there are a very wide array of tactics that one can use to do this depending on your army composition choices.  For example, if you must take a fortified hill, you could bombard with artillery and overwhelm with waves of infantry.  Or, perhaps you could use skirmishers and sharpshooters to wear down the morale and numbers of the defenders before charging in from an unexpected direction with cavalry.  Or, use your cavalry to steal the enemy's supplies and move in once the enemy have exhauseted their ammunition...or a combination of all three!

The AI is good enough to block flanking maneuvers (as well as attempt some itself) and reactive enough to make a feint tactic worthwhile, but not foolproof.  That said, the AI does tend to emphasize infantry charges a bit more than would likely be efficient (but I guess that's not entirely inaccurate for the Confederacy, anyway).  The tactical battles in this game are quite satisfying, and conducting your maneuvers just right to steal enemy supplies or encircle an enemy infantry unit is a great feeling.

The campaign does a good job of tieing all of the battles together, and inflicting heavy casualties on your enemies/capturing their supplies can greatly help you/harm them in the long run of the war (even though all battles play out in their historical order regardless of what happens in the battles).

Overall, this game offers a great and varied tactical wargaming experience at a very modest price.  I highly recommend it.

Deep, yet readily accessible tactical strategy with probably the best UI I have seen in the genre. 

Gameplay combines corps management and just a bit of rpg progression with real-time (with an option to pause at any time) army-level tactics. Simple, yet beautifully done 2D graphics, solid AI and overall a nice, polished feel. 

Army management and skill choices together with randomized battles lead to interesting replayability potential, since those do matter a lot here.

Campaigns feel great to play, as you proceed through them with the same army you have built and trained from scratch. The fact makes it also feel natural to try and avoid any unneccesary casualties on regiments you gradually start recognizing, remembering each one's strong and weak sides. 

There is a clear feeling that making a costly mistake will make your progress harder in the future. Some historical battles play out a lot differently with shifted balance of forces or a different strategy. Many times I was surprised to see the enemy dropping his (historical) goal very early on after realizing that he stands no chance of succeeding. Then he has tried to either flank / find an opening, or has fallen back on defensive altogether, standing to fight another day.

While it's 2D, and you won't get to zoom in too close, the distinctive, hand-drawn, art style, more than make up for it. It also causes the only real downside - in some cases it can be hard to tell a hill from a flat terrain and you can only guess how good or bad FOV you would get from a certain location before you get there.

All in all though, a solid reccomendation if you play this genre.

Scratches the Sid Meier’s Gettysburg itch just enough but still falls so far short of that game. 

For one thing, command is limited to brigade sized units rather than regiments (and I always wanted a way to split regimental commands down further in Gettysburg so this is very much a move in the wrong direction for me). 

Similarly the brigades do take some smart formations, I guess, but nothing like ordering them into totally different formations as could be done in Gettysburg. Again, I felt the options in that game were too limited so this is a move in the wrong direction. 

It allows you to command an army throughout the entire war but not change anything of importance. As a Union commander I won every battle, but still had to fight all the same battles as the real war, many of which historically only followed directly from losing campaigns/battles. 

For example, the peninsula campaign is doomed no matter what you do. Despite winning the engagements I was offered to command the army retreats in defeat no matter what. 

And I captured the vast majority of the Army of Virginia at Antietam, totally destroyed them, but was only given a small bonus of “-5% enemy strength” for the next battle. Which I believe was the Fredericksburg campaign. 

After either of these me, the competent commander of the army of the Potomac, would have pushed forward, captured Richmond, and ended the war. 

Any Civil War game that doesn’t allow a competent union commander to annihilate the CSA by the fall of 1862 is a failure in my book.  

The core failure here is that the concept of Gettysburg doesn’t work on a longer timeline. If you take total command for three days with all forces starting in accurate July 1 1863 positions, then allow the battle to evolve based on what happens in several stages it makes for a really fun game. If you put me, the player into a few specific scenarios that have no bearing on what happens next then I lose interest. This game does the latter. Why win overwhelmingly at Antietam if I still have to wait around until December and then try to March up the hill at Fredericksburg? 

But the killer flaw of this game is that it is absurdly easy. The first mission or two can be tough but after that you build up an overwhelmingly powerful command and can annihilate your opponents by doing little more than dragging all your units towards the mission objective and letting the clock roll. Part of this Is just history, an aggressive and competent commander of the Army of the Potomac would have wiped the floor with the army of Virginia, but since this game is already an alternate history thing, could you at least make it challenging enough to be fun? (Or alt-history enough to be fun? I wouldn’t complain about how easy it is if I could win the war in 1862, but since that doesn’t seem to be possible then at least make it a challenge.) 

I still don’t understand how hard it is to duplicate what made Sid Meier’s Gettysburg so good. Let me control the battle as granularly as feasible. Give my actions weight both in the course of the battle and in changing history. And make it fun to do so. That’s it!!
By the end of a good play through of Gettysburg I feel like I changed the course of the war. By the time I quit this game after Antietam I felt like I was just watching a bad documentary about it. 

It actually takes special effort in Gettysburg to end up with the Pickett’s charge ending — you have to win and lose just the right missions — but this game would make it the default ending. If that’s the case, why play when I can read a 4th grade history textbook?

The best way I can describe this game is that what you'd get if cross Civilization's art style with XCom's gameplay.  The battle scenarios are all scripted, the enemy is going to have basically what history says they should have, and reinforcements will trickle in at the pace they did in the real battles. 

What throws people about Ultimate General is that generally speaking if you're moving, you're losing.  Units that are holding ground with good cover are not going to panic until they're badly encircled or melee'ed.  But units that are out in the open taking fire while moving, they may break and run before even firing a shot.  

What wins is XCom overwatch tactics... a strategically agressive campaign of tactically defensive battles.  You want the enemy to come to you, unless you absolutely have to take a position.  If you HAVE to take a position, you're better off flanking it if you have the time.  

Also, a word about difficulty.

In this game, you take command of either the Confederate troops, fighting for rights, and slavery, or the Union, fighting for Government power, and Abolition. Complete the first mission (I found this quite difficult, as the Confederacy), and decide what to do next, building your small force up first. A defeat in these battles will harm your reputation, which is used to gain extra supplies, and you lose if it drops too low. A victory will harm the enemy. These small battles build up to a huge, historical battle, such as Gettysburg.  A loss in a major battle would be disasterous to your reputation, and army. I remember one of my favorite games was Civil War Generals... It was a hex/interface game that required a little mental visual imagination... This recreates that game on a format for the newer generation PC... It is entertaining as well as allowing the armchair General to select his/her look at how to win. Either side...

Saying that; Don't look for detailed zoom in or more than a closer look at the little ants... The battle maps are good enough but not overly detailed..

All in all I would say that my biggest problem is with the timer mechanics... IE: I move slow and sure, position my troops with care and minimize losses (just as I would if I cared about my soldiers)... A dead soldier may have taken a required position before his death but with a little more time he could have lived to fight another day for his ideals...

I give you the battle of Shiloh: After fighting the left and right flank actions I remove my weaker (gifted) army (out of ammo by then I must note) to the rear... Positioning my snipers forward to allow for the fallback... Move my personally created army (primary into position for a strong advance... Poof the timer runs out, it's the next day, the union army (destroyed or almost so) is re-enforced, back in a better position, my weaker (gifted army) is moved to the butcher shop... hindering my advance (timer) and leaving me no other choice but to charge for the flag in order to win...

This allows for a great loss of men as well as valuable officers... I win as a matter of need to but am damaged and left to struggle through rebuilding my primary only to have it happen again...

Answer: It is a game... the little people that have a name do not matter... The Win does...

It bothers me greatly since I spent over 20 years in the military (Special Ops, ASA, and the faceless heatless agencies protecting our country for another 20) and the loss of a man is not really an option if you have your shit together... Yet I do enjoy the game... 

Perhaps if the developer wants a following for future endeavors they may want to rethink a little...

I would pay full price or a higher price tag for a more realistic re-enactment... As it is... Buy it cheap... Remember it is just a game, and enjoy it... Doc

I just played the battle of Shiloh as the Confederates, and good lord... I was obliterating the Union forces and then they give me the final objective to take the landing. UG: CW is a wargamer's wet dream, and I have never understood why it hasn't received more fanfare. Its campaign posesses all of the grognardy details associated with molding your army from an understrength brigade of a few hundred men to an army consisting of multiple corps of tens of thousands of infantry, cavalry, and cannon whom are all manually recruited, equipped, and trained. 

Which only sets the scene for the gameplay - which is nothing short of endlessly replayable. The first campaign mission is easily the hardest in the game and must be beaten in order to even start the campaign which, honestly, was a pretty awful design decision but is easily forgotten once you play your first grand battle. The way the game works is you rest and refit between every battle, be they the set number of optional skirmishes between what are essentially the main story missions, the historical grand battles of the American civil war. 

You have four basic types of units: infantry, skirmishers, cavalry, and artillery. However depending upon how you have trained, equipped, and fought with two different units of the same type their strengths and weaknesses may vary wildly. For instance you can equip a full strength infantry unit with outdated flintlocks and tell them to charge despite casualties every mission. Their melee attack, stamina, and morale will skyrocket while they will be useless in a firefight. But when your entire army's advance is halted by a single brigade of infantry hiding in the woodline equipped with springfield rifle muskets shooting twice as fast and twice as accurate as your infantry suddenly that brigade of sluggers is worth its weight in gold.

Niche units such as skirmishers and cavalry can be completely ignored in favor of the brute force of infantry or deployed in specialized formations performing niche battlefield roles. Skirmishers can be armed with anything from rifles with telescopic sites to henry repeating rifles with devastating and rapid short range firepower, just done let anything catch them in hand to hand combat. Cavalry can be equipped to skirmish with musketoons or carbines either from horseback or by dismounting before they engage to make them harder to hit, or armed with sabers and pistols to make their charges and melee attack devastating. I will say however, if you are looking for a total war like wargame where cavalry dominates infantry in melee you will be rudely surprised as cavalry formations realistically are comprised of small fewer numbers than infantry formations and the AI will always have mutual support amongst its own formations. Cannons can either be your counter battery snipe machines or giant metal shotguns killing thousands of men per battle, or any role in between. 

Perhaps my only gripe is the difficulty curve; you simply receive less money, recruits, and access to weapons while the enemy army scales to yours on a magnified slider as the difficulty is increased. However that is something that has only bothered me literally hundreds of hours into playing this game, as I have completed the campaign multiple times on every difficulty with both the union and confederate sides and I am sure I will complete them again utilizing what has become increasingly more bizarre strategies.

Overall this game is one of my top picks of all time. Flawless campaign design which does not bog you down with useless and unecessary details like many strategic war games and gives you total freedom over the composition and deployment of your forces into a beautifully balanced tactical layer against and AI that will surprise you over and over again with its subtle and cerebral play.

Gameplay is excessively scripted and there is always a battle timer. The latter is annoying but can be forgiven, the former is annoying and not so easily forgiven. Even after initial victories as the Union, the enemy outnumbered me 2-1. This despite me spending as much of my winnings as possible. Unrealistic and cheap way to ramp up difficulty. The worst part is when a battle kicks off, scripted dialogue will tell you what to attack/defend. Reinforcements showing up in a scripted fashion is fine, but changing and multiplying objectives during a battle is not cool. For example, at the Battle of Shiloh, I held the right flank, a church versus over three times my number with minimal difficulty due to good use of skirmishers. Then the game said, congrats, but we're under attack in the center and right flank. Same battle, different units, adjacent map - this time against 5 times my number. Defeat was imminent, but I held on till the timer wore down. THEN the game says, "great, but now you have to fall back to this position and THIS position before they overrun you (because it's scripted that way) AND remember that right flank on the adjacent map? Well, the map grew to include them and you have to bring them back as well..." So I obliged, but before I could get any of my units back to the newly revealed objective, a confederate cavalry unit got on top of the objective. Despite the fact there was 3+ hours on the battle timer, the single confed cav unit just sits on the previously unknown objective for a few minutes and a nearly hopeless battle gets ended early. (Outnumbered at least 6-1 at this point)

I love the subject material. The controls and graphics are acceptable, but the battle design simply rubs me the wrong way. Incredibly arbitrary actions and odds really take the fun out of something that could EASILY be a blast to play.

This is a very well crafted game and a pleasure to play.  Both the battlefield tactics and the strategic overview are well developed and interwoven with Civil War battle histories.  This is the best battlefield simulator I've played in a decade.

This is a very solid RTS game, and imo it's got a pretty steep learning curve.  This is NOT the kind of game you beat in a day or two.  Not even on easy mode.  If you ask me, I would almost want to call this a "TRTS": Tactical Real Time Strategey (don't quote me on that one, I may have just invented that term).  If you're an RTS fan, I would bet you'll appreciate this, because it's not all about having the biggest army or the better weapons.  You have to actually think about plans in this one (you must learn how to flank, and guard your own flanks too).  

Another thing I like is the Campaign system.  Let me go ahead and tell you: unless you truly are a tactical genius, you most certainly will not win every single battle (not even on easy mode with North campaign).  You will have draws and you will have losses (I lost the battle of Shiloh on my Southern campaign), and that will impact the game.  For example, since I lost the battle of Shiloh, the North will have better weapons in the Battle of Gaine's Mill.  See what I mean?  It's similar to a real war: wins and losses impact the overall campaign, and also like a real war, you're not going to win every battle.  

If I were to give a tip to new players: save very frequently, because not only can you lose a battle, you can technically lose the war.  If you lose too many battles, you will basically be retired, so unless you want to play the entire campaign again, SAVE OFTEN.  Also, there's no shame in playing on easy mode.  Trust me, you need the experience before you need the challenge on this one.

Oh, and one other minor thing.... don't put a rank/title in your profile name.  If you name your profile "General Smith", the captured missives in between battles will call you "General General Smith".

The main problem I have with this game is the lack of user ability to change the outcome of battles. Depending on who won the battle historically, the game tilts it heavily in that sides favor.  What I mean is that they pre-set the units in specific positions that were based on the battle so you dont have to.  The game eliminates the ability to do that by placing them where they should be based on history. An example would be the battle of Fredricksburg with the Confederates. Everything looks great but the fact the game basically walks you through the battles on its own ruins the experience.

Perhaps I should start by saying that I find the American Civil War fascinating and so the theme of this game adds something special for me.

The learning curve when you first start playing in rather steep. I came to Civil War as a 130+ hours veteran of UG: Gettysburg and while this was a huge help in the tactical part of the game and I did well on the battlefield, managing my own army was something new to me and I lost my first campaign in 1865 only a few battles away from the final assault on the enemy capital.

In the tactical part where you lead your units on the battlefield there is a lot to keep an eye out for. You need to make use of terrain (elevation and cover), watch your brigades’ condition, morale and orientation and keep them supplied with ammunition. In other words, order your best brigade take cover in a tree line on the top of a hill and they will probably be able to hold it against overwhelming odds. Send the same brigade to cross a river and if an enemy opens fire on them from the flank while they’re waist deep in water they will retreat in panic.

There are three types of units in the game - infantry, cavalry and artillery.
Infantry makes up the bulk of your army. They are the most versatile units and under the right conditions the ones capable of taking and dispensing the most damage. 
Cavalry is mostly used for outmaneuvering the enemy and striking their flanks and rear, attacking vulnerable units or unprotected artillery and capturing supply wagons.
Artillery can soften up fortified positions, deal enormous amount of damage in certain situations and your long-range cannons can take out enemy artillery batteries from afar depending on the type of cannon you’re using.
Your generals are also present on the battlefield, raising your units’ morale and once reaching the higher ranks also providing small buffs to speed, cover or damage.

The AI is very capable and if you are making mistakes in positioning of your army it will find them and exploit them. Even now, after 300+ hours I occasionally find myself on the edge of my seat watching the enemy pressing my weakest point. I will never forget how during one of my campaign playthroughs I captured all four objective points in the Chickamauga wilderness. The enemy was pressing me hard in the middle of my line where two of the objectives were located and I gradually moved most of my brigades away from one of the objectives where the units were seeing no action whatsoever. I did manage to hold the line in the middle, but shortly afterwards the enemy repositioned their reserves to attack the weakened objective and I nearly lost the battle because of it. That being said, once you learn to evaluate the battlefield and only use the strongest positions the AI may struggle to penetrate your defenses - as it should considering the advantages such positions provided during the Civil War (Fredericksburg, Gettysburg, Cold Harbor) - and ends up fruitlessly assaulting your near impenetrable position and weakening their army to the point where any hope of their victory would be long gone.

Increasing the difficulty doesn’t make the AI smarter, but gives them more brigades with more men in each and a more experience on top of that. On some occasions while playing the campaign on the highest difficulty I found this to be detrimental to the tactical layer as in some battles there isn’t ‘enough terrain’ for you to position your units (such as Union Malvern Hill) and the enemy can just brute force their way through you without the need to make use of any advantageous positions or maneuvers. I don’t mind losing if the enemy played well and I was outsmarted, but watching your brigades getting obliterated in close combat by brigades twice their size and with double their stats is a bad way to lose a battle. Personally I think there is no need to play on the highest difficulty as even playing on Brigadier General (normal) difficulty provides quite a challenge and the better balance of forces makes the game more enjoyable. 

As I’ve hinted above there is a lot of progression in the campaign. Each brigade has several stats that increase as they fight battles (run around a lot and your stamina increases, shoot a lot and your handling of firearms improves, etc) and even commanding officers gain experience and get promoted when their units do well. Some stats could use a bit more clarification as what exactly it is they do. Years of battling will transform your rookies into tough veterans and as you equip them with the latest weapons they could deal enormous amount of damage. You will find that towards the end of the campaign - as both yours and the enemy units gain more experience and use better rifles and cannon - the days of charging an enemy fortified position by running through open terrain to fight up close will be all but over.

During the campaign you receive funding and recruits after each battle and also improve one of your own stats. You are the commanding general of your nation’s entire army. That doesn’t mean, however, that your position can’t change. Lose too many battles, or lose an important one at a bad time and you will be replaced, as it happened to many a Union general in the first few years of the war. In the game it means your career and most certainly your campaign, is over. If you do well on the battlefield, your government will like you more and apart from receiving more funding you will be able to ask favours to help you and your men fight the war, be it more money, recruits, a shipment of weapons or a transfer of a capable officer. Be careful how much you use this as your standing with the politicians in your capital drops each time you ask for something and if you lose a battle after asking too many favours you may be replaced.

The campaign follows the course of the Civil War battles, with all major ones taking place over historically accurate terrain. There is great variety in the terrain and usually plenty of opportunity to experiment with unit placement. Sometimes it’s even better to ignore some of the pre-built fortifications and place your units elsewhere. The game’s historical accuracy occasionally gets in its own way however. Historically some battles were fought over several days. In some cases that meant one side pushed forward and then retreated, before advancing again and so on. When these battles are recreated as they happened it means the player may lose progress on the battlefield. On several occasions I’ve captured most (but not all) objectives to a significant cost of my forces only to find myself back in my trenches the next day, because that was what happened back in the day when the battle was fought. It would be great to know in advance whether it even makes sense to assault the enemy position in any particular phase of the battle or whether anything short of driving the enemy from the field of battle will result in my forces retreating back to ‘their side’ of the battlefield. Anything less cheapens the effort the players put into capturing those objectives and makes capturing the same ones again the next day (often after the enemy has received reinforcements) a disheartening chore. That being said the whole thing becomes less of a problem once you learn the day-to-day progress of the battles and for me personally only ever became an issue in two of them (Chancellorsville and Cold Harbor).
I should also mention that the campaign can’t be won early no matter how well you do. Unlike what would have happened in history, even if you win every single battle, the war will still last 5 years and the first opportunity to win comes in 1865. While this removes a lot of player agency it is an understandable design decision as doing well should not result in a significantly shorter playthrough where the player never sees most of the content.

Ultimate General summed up in 1 story:

Obituary for Colonel Boyle ( Posthumously promoted to Major General):

In the beginning, Captain Boyle was a veteran of the Mexican American War and numerous other conflicts throughout North America. He was a proud and serving member of his state militia, a rank to retire upon and enjoy his twilight years in the southern sun.

The Civil War broke out and although near retirement he volunteered and was immediately assigned to the 5th Volunteer Georgia Infantry. Early on his regiment sustained heavy losses engaging the Federal Army at:

1st Bull Run
River Crossing
Crossroads
Shiloh
Secure River
Rendezvous
Seven Pines
Gaines' Mill
Malvern Hill
Kettle Run
Thoroughfare Gap
2nd Bull Run
Crampton's Gap 
South Mountain
Antietam
Iuka

Losing 20-60% casualties at nearly every engagement. Somehow, even early on in the war he outlasted and survived his fellow officers and quickly gained the rank of Major. At Shiloh, he was assigned to lead 250 Skirmishers which inflicted 3,500 Union casualties alone at a loss of 120 in his brigade. He was awarded and promoted to Lt. Colonel.

His brigade became the most elite in the entire CSA Arsenal inflicting a 10-20 kill ratio and capable of holding an entire flank independently. He was promoted to Colonel.

After our victory at Antietam, although victorious suffered over 50% casualties and an incredibly high rate of WIA and KIA for our famous CSA officers. 

Decimated and nearly leaderless, Colonel Boyle was reassigned to a newly created Brigade of Georgian Volunteers armed with 1842 rifles and in desperate need of leadership for a routine operation and inevitable fight with the enemy. 

His 1,000 Georgian riflemen held the extreme left flank behind a farmers wall. The Union army was routed except his flank, they were pinned and flanked momentarily. The Colonels brigade broke and ran, the hail of bullets hitting their backs running off the field,  Colonel Boyle was killed instantly trying to rally his newbs. 

Many years later Colonel Boyle was exhumed from a common grave not far from where he fell. He was buried with several dozen of his fellow Georgians soldiers and officers, stripped and looted of anything useful. Many of them mere boys.

This was his last fight before being promoted to Divisional Commander of the 1st Corps under General Lee. Cut down short due to some frosty and jumpy newbs. 

He would have been a famous commander, rivaling Lee himself! A man of no means, a common soldier, who rose through the ranks by his toil and unrelenting service to his nation. Now,  merely a footnote in history, left where he died that die.

RIP Colonel Boyle, you sent over 10,000 bluecoats straight to hell. 

You now take your leave in the Southern Sun.

Excellent Civil War battles, in-depth mechanics, physical battlefields reconstructed using GIS software, and historically accurate guns, generals, units, etc., this game outperforms on every level. The $30 price tag may look steep, but it is well worth it. The game is punishingly difficult at times (especially for the Confederacy), so be aware that even the "Easy" difficulty is not a cake walk, but the challenge is part of the fun. If you are a Civil War buff or enjoy well-fleshed out strategy mechanics, this is the game for you.

Pros:
-Big Battles and Small Battles
-Big Battles Flow into a larger narrative
-Campaign
-Solid AI
-Beautiful Maps and Sprites.  Really pleasent to look at.  
-Highly strategic.  
-Very few bugs or gamebreaking activity for an Early Acess title.  

Cons:
-No Multiplayer: This is dumb.  Many of the problems of the game can be fixed with multiplayer, but there seems to be a refusal to add it to the game.  Honestly, I am surprised I have played this game as much as I have.

Poor game design: Many of the campaign battles feel "cheap".  Most of the time you have such little time to accomplish an object you spend half of the game in melee like this is Rome 2.  When defending, you will have too much time and the AI will have troops than you.  I frequently can only play one battle at a time because it is rage inducing.  

This is not "intellignet AI"; it feels like your being cheated.

Custom Games: They are lame.  Just portions of other battles usually dealing with the same times issue.  Needs several custom maps that are random with randomized objects. These  modes of the game are utterly useless at this point and not finished at all.

After a hundred hours and three playthroughs, here are a few thoughts that would take the game to the next level: 
1. There is a large gap between the game's equivilent of normal and hard difficulty. Normal is easy and hard feels like there is no way to win. 
2. Victory is determined by holding ground, but at least on normal difficulty, the AI does not care very much about these key hold points. The enemy units  orient to where your units are. This becomes very problematic on some battles, like Gettysburg, where if the AI cannot see your units, it doesn't attack or do anything. 
3. The description of weapons in general needs to be clearer. The Parrott rifled gun should be better than the 10' ordinance, but the stats show the ordiance is much more powerful even though the Parrott is farther down in the list and I beleive costs more. Many of the other weapons and guns are in such short availability the entire game that you can only equip one small brigage the entire game. The result is you end up with a lof the same brigade. Yes, weapons like the Spencer Carbine were not plentiful at that time, but could bend a little to enhance the fun. Simply grouping the artillery by smoothbore, howitzer, rifled, and putting them in order of their stats, not cost, might also help. For example, a weapon may have high damage, but what exactly does that mean in a battle?  
4. Difference between captured and rescued goods after a battle is a little unclear. Also unclear is how you capture more goods. Does an enemy unit have to surrender? Is it about the percentage of ground taken? 
5. There seems to be a decreasing efficiency of units, even with high command, that are the maximum size. For example, the maximum efficiency for artillery seems to be 12 even though you can have 24 guns. Not sure why the game would penalize you if you have a commander able enough. This may be incorrect, but I just seemed to get better results with average sized units. 

Again, the game is great, definitley worth purchasing, especially if you are a Civil War buff.

This game is honestly two-sided for me...

On the one hand it's a GREAT strategy game; the fact that you have to consider, ammo, fattigue and men forces you to make smart decisions in where to put your best troops, when to fire, and when not. - The simple graphics do the job well, and the fact that you can play this on a touch device is extremely satisfying (Played it on a my Surface). 

On the other hand, the biggest let down for me, is the "timer". It just ruins the experience for me. I find myself rushing objectives, rather than playing "smart". I've read around a lot when it comes to the timer, and I get why it's there. The immense ammount of irratonal arguments arguing "But I do fine with the timer", is just sad. It's not wether you are able to "handle" the timer or if you're a "better player". It's more about the difference in how you want to experience the game... I'm a supporter of the timer being "optional" (Like in Total War). It would give players the option of having a more relaxed playthrough. 

But then again there are battles where the timer makes sense, and it actually helps you win... So it's truly two sided, but in sum... it's done in a way that has led to more frustration than giving me the satisfaction of "making it in time". 

Even if I've put the game down now, due to the timer ruining it for me, I would still recommend this game. Because it's extremely well fleshed out! - But, if you're not the kind of person that likes to "rush" things, I would recommend you to think twice.

I for myself hope that, either, the devs make the timer optional, or, that someone in due time makes a mod that makes the timer optional.

At the end of the day, I have a love/hate-relationship with this game.

[h1]One of the best and sometimes worst modern wargames[/h1]

At first glance this game has a lot to offer and despite the 2D graphics and easy control doesnt seem to do things much differently than other wargames but this first impression is misleading.
At its core the game is quite different to other wargames in its incentives and execution. The fun here lies solely in the battle system where large infantry armies win by outmaneuvering the enemy and clever micromanagement. This is where the game shines. And here it shines a lot. The AI is clever and you really feel the impact of your decisions and playing scenarios often feels rewarding.
Unit variety is of course very limited and the designers struggled to make cavalry and skirmishers(rather dettach skirmishers from your infantry battalions) really worthwhile but artilley and infantry gameply is really satisfying. 

However, this brings me to the two major flaws of the game: 
The campaign: The economic system, army management and campaign progression are all truly terrible (to my taste) and disregard the wargame genre standards. Economy  and army management are almost useless since the enemy will always scale so that it always outnumbers you. Here the game pretends to have depth that it doesnt.  And the campaign actually doesnt dynamically adjust to your exploits or defeats which means you have no incentive to defeat an enemy army completely and losing just one battle is often game over for your campaign. Panzer General in the early 1990s knew that a good campaign has forks and rewarding players for being good is a great incentive to continue to play the game.

The other flaw for me is "realism": I like wargames with a historic feeling and the more accurate it is the better. Here the game went with a more arcade feeling of all battles ending in a bloodbath with casualties even exceeding the bloodiest days of WW1. Furthermore, campaign progression also is a letdown in this regards since battles just get progressively more difficult so Gettysburg is actually way easier than Chickamauga for the CSA just as an example. Adding to this the fact that the AI always gets more troops than you have it (well there are rare exceptions) every battle is just more difficult for the side you are playing. I would have wished for a mix of easier and harder battles depending on the historical context.

I really want to enjoy this game. Unfortunately, there are too many negatives for this to be a recommended game.

Pros:
- Civil war history game with some fairly comlex and rewarding strategies
- Enemy AI is good in parts. Generally, quite clever with it's strategies
- Nice mix of troop types with some basic customisation
- Get to refight certain historical battles either in the campaign or custom mode
- Friendly fire doesn't exist as far as I can tell which is a positive when you consider the cons list

Cons:
- No tutorial. You're on your own bud

- Controls. There's no need to use the keyword beyond moving around. You can't zoom in or out that far. You can't rotate the cameria. You can re-bind keys but it's pointless when you only need a mouse

- The UI. Small, unclear, no hints or indicators. There's no Total War style spacebar button to show exactly where you've moved your troops to


-AI (too many points, see below)
- It's awful. The way your troops move is as if they're glued together. They all rotate first, then march in a straight line. They also do it at an excruciating pace which means you could end up losing a unit to this. I understand there is some historical reason for this but I'm fairly certain that in the thick of it, they didn't rotate their formation as much as this game
- Some units (especially infanty) will just wander off and move of their own accord. Rotating to meet an enemy, fine. But this isn't that. They will literally just start walking off
- Horses are slower than skirmishers (wtf). Supply wagons get sudden bursts of speed even though there is no run option. 
- Infanty run out of condition (basically stamina) stupidly quickly and with large battlefields it means you waste alot of time waiting for your troops to get into position.
- The run ability. It's broken. 
- Cavalry is generally useless. The combat capabilities are awful since after a couple of missions you'll end facing 1000+ infanty regiments. You mainly end up using it to try and sneak attack their cannon (the computer AI is clever enough to leave infanty near cannon anyway) or just holding points.
-Skrimishers always fallback when the enemy gets too close as does cavalry and there's nothing you can do about it. There's no "stand your ground" button to keep them in place
-Infanty will chase after routing melee units and, again, you can't stop them. This can be fatal if there other enemy units nearby since your infanty will be immediate hit with a "rear penalty" which could cause them to rout
- The penalties in general are awful. Skrimishers can cause thousands of men to retreat from a single volley if you're not careful. You get flanking penalties even if you haven't been flanked
- Some cover won't actually give you benefits it says it will. Due to the shape of some fortifications, your infanty will actually end up with flanking penalties even if they haven't been flanked. This results in constant retreat from some areas
- Infanty won't move if there's other enemy units nearby (this is hit and miss, sometimes they do, most of the time they refuse to move)
- There's a charge timer for some stupid reason which means you have position yourself perfectly if you want to charge because if you haven't reached the target by the timer has expired, you're dead (especially if it's cannon)
- Charging makes your troops move slower not faster
- Cannons are generally useless at killing at range but are OP at destroying morale
- The main thing combining the AI issues is that it's very hit and miss. You can have one game where everything goes to plan in terms of execution (aka your troops don't mess up) but there will be times when you'll need to restart the mission several times due to poor player AI
- Mass charges. The AI loves a good charge and will do it (as far as I can tell) as much as possible even if they have no hope of winning
- Troops can't fire over each other unless one is in a fortification. This forces you to spread out your entire army in one long line.
- Scaling. This was put in place to ensure that the AI can always give you a fight but the problem is that they put it on steroids. You can't destroy enemy units, ever. This means they all end up as veterans very quickly. This doesn't happen to you. Moreover, on multi-day battles it scales massive so you could end up fighting a force 100% bigger than yours by the second day. This takes away any sense of accomplishment

- Custom battles. Think Total War without the fun. You can't adjust the funds you get nor can you change the amount of men you can have. Moreover, everything still costs money, including generals, and the armoury is still there with limited quantities of weapons, which, once you've bought them all, you can't get anymore. This makes the mode boring and unenjoyable and forces you to play the game by it's rules. Poorly thought out game mode just added in

- The Campaign. Battle to battle. There's no "what if". The start and end is always the same regardless of how many battles you win. The developers missed a really good opportunity here to create an exciting campaign.

Summary: Game consists of charging artillery batteries in a frantic rush to beat a timer, and in the next battle charging those same magically reanimated artillery batteries. 

+Maps look nice
+It's a decent dicking around game if you can overlook/tolerate the flaws, and it's better than it's predecessor so hopefully the successor to this one will be worth buying
+Can /slightly/ customize units and modify your army (for the most part, purely useless shit like swapping out commanders who all give the same perks, and renaming brigades, but not your divisions or corps because reasons)
+Has a lot of maps that let you refight many civil war battles
+doesn't crash a lot (the fact I have to put this as a positive to balance the negatives should be telling)
+Unit control is obviously inspired by the Total War franchise, and is less clunky most of the time
+Enemy AI in battle is surprisingly competent at controlling his units (which he will almost always have far more than the player)

-UI, sucks, or is nonexistant for almost everything you actually need to see, and is the single biggest handicapping feature that roadblocks most of the things this series introduces to the genre. In a military firearms-era game the fact you can't have range number for your artillery (crucial because canister, shell, and shot does vastly different damages at different ranges) is a stupid thing to make the player guess at. You'll have dozens of battles you'll have to restart because your units panicked and broke because of the bad AI interacting with the morale system and artillery, and you have no way of knowing they're about to shatter unless you click through every single unit in a battle that can have over 50.  
-The AI gets skirmishers. Now you'd think this wouldn't be a problem, until you realize what this means in most battles there's ten units that run faster than anything you have (including cavalry), are invisible when firing (despite this being the age of black powder), and outperform your own because the AI can micro them faster than you can because A. it's a computer and B. it's a computer. Not that it should matter, because thanks to scaling if you use them the AI will get even more, and better ones. 
-The maps are obviously pretty, however you can't do things that have been in this genre for decades because of it. Want to rotate the map to help you control/see units? Or orient the map in a sensible/reasonable direction like north or towards what you're attacking? Too bad. At least they kept the WSAD navigation but that's the only thing they didn't shortchange, also during the prebattle briefings you're told how the historical battle went, then placed on a cartoony map which makes it hard to recognize those features, labels (like every other game in the genre) would have been nice.
-Unit customization. Or lack thereof. You can swap weapons, you can change names of individual brigades/batteries, and that's it. Of the weapons, there are a half dozen that are mandatory equipment (springfield 1842, enfield, harpers 1855, springfield 1861 for infantry, 10lb ordinance, 24lb howitzer and 24lb parrot for artillery, and the cheapest melee weapons for cavalry), the rest only gets used to sell when you capture it from the AI. 
-Inclusion of almost all of the better weapons (except 24lb artillery which is mandatory) is worse than useless. Repeating rifles rightly cost 10 times more than the cheapest weapons, but the forced volley fire means the higher ROF they had doesn't matter and with the much shorter range and accuracy (as much as half) the elite units will get slaughtered/stunned/routed trying to get close enough to use them. Ditto with specalized weapons like the skirmisher rifles and the counterbattery artillery. AI gets 600 men artillery brigades by the dozen, and the timer will run out before you can kill them, all you can do is ignore them or suicide charge them. 
-A timer. For every single battle. And because of the way the game is designed, almost all the battles revolve around you rushing to beat the clock which forces you to make stupid/suicidal moves and lose men, my favorite being the only way to deal with them is to charge them with infantry or cavalry taking hundreds of losses to canister because you don't have time to kill them with skirmishers or heavy artillery, no matter how many you brought. 
-The reason it looks smoother than the Total War series is because the only orders you can give your units are via mouse buttons. Obviously that's a limiting factor, and combined with the awful AI/UI you'll frequently have to restart battles (I've played some two dozen times before getting them to do as told) to prevent the suicide of your army.
-Unkillable units. The AI levels up units faster than yours, which is fine, it's an AI it needs help. But if you surround a 3 star infantry unit that's been reduced to 300 men with 10k men and 60 guns you'll kill off a few of his men then he'll "shatter" and disappear, and you'll have to fight him again, rearmed and reinforced, the next battle. 
-The campaign game design had no thought given to what it's like to experience. It's supposed to have you refight the Civil War, but we already know how that went. So what happens, is you kill all the bad guys on battle 1. You have to replenish your losses, his army on battle 2 is directly proportional to the size/composition of yours. And AI units are unkillable, no matter how many losses you inflict they'll come back with higher veterancy next time (neat trick, I kill 1800 men of a 2k brigade, those 200 survivors magically transfer all their knowledge to 1800 replacements in a week). What this means is AI losses don't matter, and on harder difficulties or later battles you'll spend two dozen straight battles taking less than 10% losses and inflicting over 70%, and find yourself outnumbered 4:1 and facing human waves of infantry and hundreds of artillery pieces. It's incredibly frustrating because every time you see the numbers it's just reminding you that nothing you do actually matters to the outcome.
