Ultimate General: Civil War is a fun game when you first play it. I've even written a few guides for the game.

It bills itself as an authentic historical game with good AI. At first glance, the game does all of this wonderfully.
Deeper analysis of the game reveals fundamental design problems that only become visible with time.

Many of these problems are known to the developers. However due to the mechanism the devs use to solicit feedback these issues remain unaddressed since early access. Other problems are more fundamental, such as a lack of true player agency (a la Mass Effect 3)

[b]Problems with the AI[/b]
Once you get past being beaten by the AI in the beginning and get used to the quirks of the game then the advertised 'strong' AI vanishes. Each map basically devolves into one of two strategies depending on if you are on offense or defense.

The challenge the AI provides against you is not in the AI being smart. Rather the challenge is in the sheer numbers the AI has versus you.

The problem gets worse if you play on half speed. With careful micromanagement, it's possible to defeat armies with 5x the number of men you have as well as drive back the relentless AI charges (if you aren't playing offensively that is). You can even cancel AI charges if you do things right. The AI pretty much always reacts the same way to you and it is easy to learn how the AI reacts and do the same thing every game. This is a regression from UG:GB where the AI had different personalities and acted differently.

[b]Problems with Game Mechanics[/b]
Some of these problems with AI involve various bugs. These include AI breaking charges if you reposition units, AI favoring charges even if the unit is exhausted (which you can halt the advance by micromanaging artillery). Others are more fundamental. For example, early on in early access the AI had problems defending their artillery. So the game devs, instead of making the AI better at defending their artillery, made artillery invincible to melee.

Similar examples of game mechanic problems exist elsewhere. Melee mechanics were broken since early access. 2 brigades of 200 men in melee will perform 4x casualties as 1 brigade with 400 men in melee. Thus, some players (in a single player game mind you) liked to stack lots of tiny cavalry brigades and abuse the melee mechanic bug to beat battles. This bug was reported and these players complained the game was 'too easy'. Instead of fixing the broken melee system (or *gasp* asking the players to not use such strategies in a single player game), it was decided that 'cavalry was too powerful' (since this was the most commonly abused unit). Thus, cavalry got nerfed to the ground so much that the only way to use them is to abuse the melee bug. A 400 men cavalry brigade can't even chase down 90 skirmishers without getting routed.

[b]Problems with Realism[/b]
These issues of game design, where bugs are not fixed but instead hidden, permeates to the entire game. It results in unrealistic situations that hurts realism of the game. Such as 750 cavalrymen who manage to surprise 200 artillerymen from the rear failing to beat the 200 artilleryman and instead being routed and losing half your men. BUT if those very same 750 cavalrymen were dismounted before engaging the artillery, then the results won't be as disastrous (AI will still not lose men though thanks to invincible AI artillery). It results in the best way of dealing with artillery being shooting them (and eating canisters to the face) rather than charging the cannons. It results in on harder difficulties having to play the game a certain way rather than having true agency.

[b]Problems with Player Agency[/b]
On the topic of player agency, UG:Civil War does a poor job of this. On easier difficulties player agency is somewhat there as the AI is not gifted tons of men to produce artificial difficulty. Thus as the game goes on if you manage to defeat the AI (where the AI loses 3-5x your men) the AI won't be able to reinforce. This creates other problems such as the 2nd half of the campaign being too easy.

Due to this complaint (and also due to complaints from players exploiting game bugs and AI weakness on higher difficulties) combined with the lack of difficulty levels, hard and legendary difficulties are not only incredibly broken but also unfun, a tedious chore, and lack player agency. The AI patently ignores the 'army intelligence' screen where you see how many men it should have and deploys much more men than the number shown. This means you can't play with a small, elite army that's lowered the AI army strength, no, you have to bring as much men as possible.

Since the game ignores the army strength on higher difficulties there's no point to capturing or killing AI at all. Instead it's a matter of force preservation (since you only get limited recruits). As the AI is gifted a new army each time you destroy an army, the facade of player agency collapses completely. It simply does not matter what you do or how many men the AI loses.

Fundamentally these problems are a result of a lack of dynamic campaign. This is compounded by game bugs exploited by players on hard/legendary that were never fixed which makes the game 'too easy' for them. Or the lack of a true dynamic campaign where you can choose to end the war early if you manage to defeat the enemy army.

No, the solution chosen by the devs was to brush the bugs under the rug and just give the AI more men (or men invulnerable to their weakness such as invincible artillery). This doesn't result in a fun game. Rather it results in a game where battles become a CHORE to micromanage and abuse AI weaknesses (not to mention all the small bugs which still have not been fixed). It's not any more challenging or hard in a tactical level.

[b]Problems with Feedback[/b]
One aggravating factor which lead to these decisions has to do with feedback. Due to the many different ways one can play a game, issues which may crop up for some players may not crop up for other players. Similarly, due to the vast difference between normal and hard in difficulty (different AI bouses), playstyles/bugs which may work on normal may not work on hard.

Instead of soliciting feedback from the playerbase as a whole, the general impression I have from watching the game progress since early access is that a small privileged group of testers (who tend to be experts and or play using certain strategies) have their suggestions favored more by the devs. This isn't necessarily the fault of the devs, as these players are simply more active in providing feedback. 

This generally wouldn't be a matter if it wasn't for the fact that some of these more active players have a habit of discounting other player's problems (since it doesn't occur for them with how they play). This leads to issues where unless a problem is faced by a majority of players, problems which only affect some players are routinely ignored or outright dismissed. It also leads to poor balance changes and honestly a terrible experience for new players who are thrown into the game (eg the patches making the first intro/tutorial level harder and harder and harder to the point where new players have to go on the forum and ask for how to beat the FIRST LEVEL).

[b]Hostility to Modding[/b]
Many of these fundamental issues would be solvable if there were modding support by the devs. One would think the modder DarthMod would have supported modding in his/her commercial games, having come from the modding community.

Instead, impediments to modding were added on purpose to reduce the basic modding possible in UG:CW.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
I would honestly prefer to play the first early game access version of the game rather than the current version of the game as it is now. I lack faith the devs will be able to fix fundamental problems based on experiences since early access.

Perhaps the best thing I can say of this game is that it is what you'd get if you put two classic American Civil War strategy games into a blender and mixed; a wonderful mishmash of elements from Robert E. Lee: Civil War General and Sid Meier's Gettysburg/Antietam.  It's got relatively intuitive controls, incredible artwork and landscapes you fight across, an engrossing army management system in the campaign that's slightly reminiscent of  XCOM's base management, requires you to both manage strategy and logistics to succeed, but does so simply enough that you won't be overwhelmed and lost during your first playthrough-la Hearts of Iron, and, well, it's just a dope Civil War strategy game (this last point only will matter if you are of the opinion that dope Civil War strategy games are underappreciated in today's market).  If you've got some serious nostalgia for Sid Meier's Civil War games, this game might just fill that void.


And now, to the list of grievances:
Firstly, if you are expecting the amount of customization of strategy and potential historical revisionism with strategy offered by the preceding Ultimate General: Gettysburg, you will be profoundly disappointed.  With some few exceptions, the player is always stuck fighting historical battles with the same goals set by the historical commanders (Fredericksburg as the Union is a real treat, especially if you've won every battle up to that point.  Nothing better than being forced into an unnecessary head on assault that will annihilate the cream of your army! On the plus side, you get to experience firsthand all of the frustrations of competent officers of the time serving under incompetent politician-generals).  At times, securing the historical objectives ahead of schedule will win you the battle, without regard to subsequent events (most noticeable at Second Bull Run and Chancellorsville).  Other battles (Shiloh, Stones River, Gettysburg) force the defender to retreat to historical lines, regardless of how effective the defense was (i.e., falling back to Cemetery Hill, regardless of whether or not the Confederates actually captured Seminary Ridge).  Thus, if you're looking for that "What if" scenarios that UG: Gettysburg offered, you'll walk away disappointed.


Furthermore, the AI could use some improvements.  The issues are no longer as pronounced and game breaking, but there will still be a few instances of a brigade deciding that the best path of retreat is straight through the enemy lines. This can be frustrating.  The AI is heavily weighted towards victory points, so you'll need to use caution when deviating from the historical lines of battle that the game seems so hellbent on forcing you to follow (and trust me, you'll usually want to deviate from following the path of history).  This can lead to players losing a battle they were handily winning, because the enemy managed to sneak a few hundred cavalrymen around your lines and capture the strategic location; a location you long since abandoned to pursue and destroy the enemy, thus costing you the battle.  It can be frustrating.

Relating to the touted "AI management" that's supposed to help new players learn the game without being overwhelmed in pitched historical battles, all I can say is don't use it.  It's OK defensively, but abysmal on the offense.  AI in general is quite poor at tactics in this game, including the opposing AI.  Gone is the dynamic difficulty system from Ultimate General Gettysburg, where you could choose the tactical ability and aggressiveness of the enemy; difficulty is instead determined by the size of the enemy army and the resources you receive to build up your own.  As a result, once you've learned the tactics of the game, the difficulty instead comes from strategic elements, like deciding on the best composition for your army.  I found this disappointing.

You'll still need to heavily rely on the "hold" order to keep your brigades from doing stupid things, like wheeling about in their heavy cover and instead exposing their flank to the enemy assault, simply because they were targeting an enemy unit that charged a nearby friendly unit.  Happily, however, the hold order seems much improved; units still occasionally will not engage an enemy unit that's within range and firing on them unless you directly order them to, but these instances are now few and far between.

On an incredibly minor and nitpicky note, the developer has chosen to continue the specific insanity of portraying a unit's effective range via a light brown/green conical outline.  This outline remains impossible to see in many, many battles.

More extreme nitpicking that should generally be disregarded: the game doesn't have multiplayer.  It wasn't advertised as having multiplayer, so don't hold it against them.  But this game will probably make you wish it had multiplayer.

The early issues of army scaling have been fixed, however, and players will no longer find themselves going against overwhelming odds in battle after battle.  The enemy army still scales in size based on the size of the player's army (the difficulty settings effect this scaling), but the enemy is now penalized based on the player's performance in prior battles and the minor engagements of the campaign.  Furthermore, minor engagements have been improved; in addition to providing money and recruits, victories in these engagements usually provide a debuff to the enemy army for the large scale historical battle, usually taking the form of a reduced enemy army size (and occasionally penalizing their morale or weapon quality).  This furthers the cost basis analysis the player must perform when deciding whether or not to fight the optional side battles.

The latter stages of the campaign do feel a bit rushed. After Gettysburg, only three historical battles (Chickamauga, Cold Harbor, and Richmond/Washington) remain, with a scattering of side battles representing the major engagements at Atlanta, The Wilderness, Spotsylvania Courthouse, Petersburg, and Nashville.  It may disappoint those particularly well versed in the history of the American Civil War who were looking forward to waging a campaign of tactical finesse during the brutal fighting that characterized the war from 1863-5.
But to end things on a very positive note, in spite of this, the campaign is actually very well balanced in terms of a learning curve; players will spend the early game learning to fight offensively and defensively and utilize the terrain to their advantage with a small, easily manageable army and many "non-player-army" units joining them in the early historical battles (providing a more disposable force that you don't have to worry about reinforcing in the event of massive casualties).  By the late game, players are given the opportunity to demonstrate a mastery of the tactics they've learned, commanding massive armies of their own design at battles like Chickamauga and Cold Harbor, with both Union and Confederate campaigns concluding with an all out assault on the well fortified enemy capital that is ahistorical, but nonetheless incredibly gratifying.

Problems I have with it include:
1. Cavalry is a useless unit that ought not even be there. I have yet to see a game session where the cav was not overtaken from behind and annihilated by guys running on foot. Enemy cav is significantly different in almost every way than yours. Enemy cav at least twice as fast as yours, maybe as much as 4 times faster. Enemy cav can run up to an infantry line, fire then run away with minimal losses evan against your largest unit. They can repeat this dozens of times. If you try that you lose your unit on the first approach. When they run away and you shoot them, you get no rear flank bonus for the shot. When you run away and get shot you get smoked from the rear.

The damage done by cav I deem appropriately balanced. I just wish I had the same capabilities on a fundamental level as the enemy has. Then it iwould be great. Enemy cav devastates your cav irrespective of force siae. I had an enemy force of 50 cav beat up from battle completely wipe out my fresh untouched cav force of 750 in about 20 seconds. I had better guns and charged them from behind while they were fleeing an attack against my infantry unit. It walked away with 42 like it was no big deal. My 750 routed and ran off the map. It happens every time you use them. They don't do what you tell them to do. 90% of the time the game will not even let you select them to assign different orders to them. And they never ever survive a battle ever. Not even in a dream. Unless you leave them somewhere and never use them. Which is arguably the best way to employ them in the end. Cav is absolutely useless.

2. Janky interface. Assign an order to one unit, some other unit on the other side of the map decides to carry out the order instead. Every time you want to change a unit's order, you have to pause the game...then give the order...then make sure the guy you told to do it is the acutal one who has decided to carry it out... and all your other orders for every other unit on the map are all still in place...then you can safely unpause. Makes every game take about 6 time longer than it ought to. It would be better to simply make it a turn based game instead.

3. Units don't move when you tell them to. Imagine that you actually are able to give an order to an unit, and then that unit you told actually decides to be the one who executes the order. Whew what an accomplishment. But then you find he does his own thing. Doesn't do what you told him to do. Go here...he goes there. Stop and shoot....he turns his back on the enemy at point blank range. Charge....won't charge. Stand in this line and don't move and fight....he goes wandering off one minute later. Constant refusal to carry out what you tell them to do like 40%+ of the time. It is awfully difficult to play, let alone win, when your troops disobey your commands 40% of the time and decide to go wandering off somewhere or turn circles so every enemy who wants to gets a great shot from behind or just won't shoot at all.

4. Interface won't let you seelct your units. Often during battle you see a unit disobeying your commands and you are not permitted to select him to tell him to stop that and do something else. They go off on their own for anwhere from about 10 seconds up to as long as several minutes of game play. Rogue units off on their own that you cannot command in any way for half the duration of the battle. Happens all the time. Had one run all the way across the map iuntil it got stuck in the corner. It stayed there unselectable until about halfway through the battle. Came staggering in at the very end, full force strength, never fired a shot, exhaused from all the travelling, and arriving after the action was over. Its commander got promoted after the battle...

5. Battles have no middle ground. Either you annihilate the enemy, or he annihilates you. There is a Win/Lose/Draw mechanic, but I've never seen any draws occur. Not even close.

6. Spent one battle where I set up my defensive line, started the battle, and when the enemy showed up he set up his line way out of range. Never attacked. Hour long battle and the only units who ever fired were the cannons which were ineffective at such long ranges. No unit on either side ever moved an inch from its original position. And I won a victory because the objective was to hold my poisition. Spent the battle watching TV then all of a sudden I just won. So boring I wasn't even paying attention. It was pretty damn silly IMO.

7. Formations are a huge factor during battles. The game's combat code implements this fact very nicely. Yet the game interface provides no means whatsoever to control a unit's formation. Sometimes they choose to column up, sometimes they choose to form a line, and there is no way to know or predict when it will happen, Units in a line with great cover will happily wheel around and expose their flanks and rear to an enemy 30 feet in front of them with annoying regularity. You cannot stop it. Well you can, but you have to micro manage on such a millisecond by millisecond scale that you will spend 99% of your game play experience in pause mode if you expect to succeed with every unit in your army at every given moment of the battle. Eventually you just get sick of it and let the enemy shoot your guys in the back from time to time. It is something you come to expect. Also, only the enemy gets any bonuses for formation type advantage. If they attack you from the side, you get the Flanked penalty. From behind you get Rear Flanked. Never do your forces get these. Enemy infantry 500 strong runs up to your 2000, attacks for awhile, gets whittled down until it breaks, turns and runs away, you get nothing special for 2000 shots up his ass.

On the plus side, the enemy AI is fairly descent most of the time (the example I gave in 6 above is admittedly not normally what you get). If only I was able to tell my units what to do, and then they would do what I tell them, the game seems like it could be challenging. The in-battle interface needs a ton and a half of work. It is extraordinarily janky. Trying to select a unit and give them an order it a tough proposition nearly every time you attempt it.

Overall I give it about a 3/10 for playability. I don't think it comes anywhere near the $30 price tag in value. If you could get it for less than $10 then maybe you'll feel you got your money's worth...depending on how patient a person you happen to be. If you are easily annoyed, this game could be hazardous to your life.
Graphics are acceptable 7/10 for that. It is a top down strategy game after all, so that isn't entirely critical. I wish they had included elevation lines though. It is pretty hard to determine where the high and low ground is, and how steep hillsides are etc. Contour lines would have helped.
Bug free engine operation. 10/10 on that. I never had a crash or graphic glitch or freeze or lag spikes or any of that. All the bugs are in the game play code and particularly the in-battle inteface code.... The menu system interface for when you are not in battle is workable, but a little convoluted and confusing in its organization and functionality. It takes effort and curiosity to learn how to use it. I found it to be vague. So you gotta figure it out by trial and error. One of the main issues is that highlights are sometimes not strong enough to notice. This is true during battles too. For example, there is a button you can press to make a unit run when it moves. Clicking it toggles a "running" state for the unit. It runs until you toggle it off again. But the highlight that lets you know if a unit is running is so similar to is non-running state that you cannot simply look at it and tell if the unit is in running state. There is no color shift in the hightlight, it is simply a very marginally brighter tone....and therefore useless.

Ultimate General: Civil War is best summed up with the following experience as the Confederates:
17 September 1862; Union foces have amassed and prepare an attack on the creek at which my 10,000 soldiers and 60 guns stand, more reinforcements are expected and by mid-day I shall have an army of around 35,000 excluding my 140 guns fully manned and around 2,000 cavalry (these played a key role for me in the battle) however I am still horrified at the odds I face, around 70,000 Union infantry a similar amount of cavalry to me and of course a significant artillery advantage estimated at about 200 guns. My only advantage lies in the creek I have chosen to defend; my men are well covered by the trees and we are prepared to mow down the Unions first wave, my cavalry head north to harass the unions northern flank, little did I know the skill of confederate cavalry (with my awesome leadership).
The first wave is upon me, thousands upon thousands of Union men enter my line of fire, perhaps a little to complacent as some even attempted a bayonet charge as blue bodies began to litter the battlefield, as morning came to an end another Union attack wave reached me as my casualties began to mount, I have no definative number but the casualties are around 2:1 in our favour at this point at the least, my cavalry who up until now have been desperately evading Yankee troops up in the north have been freed by Early and his 900 men sent to deal with the Bluecoats, my cavalry are free and I can unleash my masterplan.
The Union launches a small attack on Sunken (I think thats what it was called, civil war buffs may correct me on that) road and my small but sturdy garrison of a few thousand and a small artillery detachment held for now. By now the battlefield is littered with bodies mainly blue and is disfigured by the unfathomable amount of shells fired. My cavalry have been harassing the Unions right for a while now but I realise that I must tale direct control, I send both cavalry brigades I have in a enveloping movement to behind the main Union lines, meanwhile the Union amasses a massive army in secret to attack my garrison on sunken road, their attack commenses and my garrison can barely hold, thousands of men arrive from the south to reinforce my army and 40 artillery guns, I send them to defend the road and and replenish my thinning lines in the forest to the northwest, things are looking good and the union attacks are failing, though their southern attack on the road is becoming a threat. So I unleashed my masterstroke, my cavalry still supported by Early's brigade were now behind the Unions lines so I ordered them to strike west, simultaneously I bombarded the Unions right flank (north) with artillery and volleys of gunfire. As their line retreating they were mowed down by cavalry gunfire and another bombardment from my artillery the Yankees were reeling, so I put them out of their misery with acavalry charge from the right and a bayonet charge from the left, needless to say it was a massacre!
With the Union right flank completely shattered I turned my entire northern army round and along with an overwhelming artillery bombardment I hammered their line and routed the entire Union army, oh the glory, a blob of confused and disorganised Yanks routing from the battlefield, I turned on steamroll mode and pushed them back around 2 kilometres in a few minutes. I pushed them back into a small wooded area, this is where I decided to stop as I surrounded the woodland on 3 sides, and the troops that would have guarded the 4th side were sent back south to protect against a Union attack at two bridges further south, stony bridge and... Other bridge along... A river. The fighting for these bridges was desperate, truly the definition of a bloodbath, at one point I even lost Stony bridge before some more reinforments from the northern encirclement, not realising what was too come. At this point my casualties are about 10,000 infantry and a few hundred cavalry and a few artillery guns. Union losses are unknown but based on what happened next and what their end of the battle losses were I would say around 40,000. It was a decisive victory, until the final phase. 2 hours of the battle left, I was certain of victory. then I noticed that the battles for the bridges was drying up, since the battle was nigh on a victory I assumed the Union were fleeing or that they had simply been killed. I was wrong...
In the north a collosal Union attack was commenced with 90 minutes (game time) There were 4 strategic points I needed to hold in order to have victory on the day and this huge build up of over 20,000 Union troops completely overwhelmed my dwindling forces at the woodland, I sent thousands of troops and as many guns as I could muster north to fight off this 'Blue Death' but to no avail, almost the entiriety of my northern army was killed, thats around 9,000 men killed in a matter of minutes. I was in shock, but being a professional general I needed to fight on all available troops guns and horses were sent north to fight them off, I formed a defensive line and tried to stand my ground.
Without going into specifics I somehow managed to hold them off.
Total casualties for me in that phase of the battle were over 10,000 infantry 20 guns and around a 1,000 cavalry while the Union maybe lost 5,000. All that in an hour game time. However, I managed to hold onto all strategic locations and the battle was a victory. Over 20,000 Confederate losses were recorded, almost 2/3 men died. Union losses were even more disastrous, a little over 40,000 men out of around 70,000. A dark day for both sides, and a horrifying introduction to modern war.

While it is apparent that most people who play UG:CW enjoy it, I think there is a major misconception about the nature of the game that is the fundamental basis of some of the criticism. UG:CW is not a strategy game, it's a logistics and tactics game. 

Most of the gameplay is focused around leading troops on the battlefield in pre-determined battles and then using rewards from battles to develop your army for the next pre-determined battle. In the battles themselves, the player also has only minimal control of when and where units are deployed. The most strategy that the game implements is having some optional battles in the campaign and choosing which corps will be used in the battle.

The tactical simulation is generally great, though its few flaws do warrant some criticism. The control you have over your units feels both effective and realistic for the time. The Enemy AI is well constructed to make battles feel difficult and to make victory feel earned. The difficulty scaling is also great as the increasing difficulty of battles keeps the player engaged, even at the expense of realism. It is not coincidental that optional battles towards the end of the game are frequently harder than earlier major battles. That said, a lot of the disconnect that is felt comes from this scaling. To make battles at the end of the campaign difficult, the enemy armies generally need to be large and well trained regardless of the realistic capabilities of the Union and Confederacy. The reason enemy casualties seem inconsequential to the overall campaign is that, to keep the whole campaign interesting, the enemy army must always maintain its strength.

If this game was a strategy game focused on winning the Civil War, the criticism of its lack of realism would be very strong. Instead, this game is a tactics and logistics game that uses the Civil War as a skin. The tactics and logistics are generally great and realistic to the time. I too feel the cognitive dissonance that as the Union, I can crush the Confederacy in every battle and still take 5 years to conquer Richmond or that as the Confederacy, wiping out the Union Army at Antietam and Gettysburg doesn’t at least bring foreign intervention if not clear victory but that was not the purpose of the game. Adding real strategy and major impacts to the state of the war to the game would make the finely balanced difficulty curve the developers built irrelevant. It would also force the developers to lose realism in other places. If the game was built around the strategy of the war, the early battles would need to become unrealistically difficult for a long, well balanced game. 

The criticism is generally valid as the game certainly creates a sense of cognitive dissonance between how you annihilate your enemy in battle but then they have more troops in the next battle, but if you are thinking about buying the game, consider that the dissonance is not there by accident but rather is the consequence of creating an engaging difficulty curve. 

TL:DR - The reason the campaign feels weird is that it is about the battles rather than the war. Thus, the design focusses on a good difficulty curve rather than strong strategic realism.

I would recommend this game for any civil war fan.  I have played several other civil war games that I liked alot, but this game adds a whole new dimension.  The individual battles are like other civil war games I have played.  However, the decisions between the battles make a world of difference.  

What is better?  A 2500 man brigade with poor guns or a 1500 man with better equipment.  Is it better to have 2 well equiped corps or 3 larger, poorly equipped corps.  Is it better to focus on politics, so you have more recruits and money.  Or, is it better to focus on medicine, so you save more troops with their hard earned experience.  How important is reconnaise / intelligence.  How much effort do you want to spend training new / replacement troops.  If you are winning handily, is it better to take a few more casualties, and wipe out the opponet, or is better to just win the battle with the fewest casualities.

I haven't played another civil war game where I had to deal with these issues.  Also, you have to decide how to equip each brigade.  To understand my options, I really had to research and understand the difference in the equipment.  Thankfully, other users have done much of this, and have some usefull guides.  I like learning more about the civil war, and this game encourages me to do that.

It takes a while to learn all the little tricks to playing this game.  There is a good tutorial, but there are so many things going on that I missed a few things.  I played half of my first campaign before I realized how to detached skirmishers.  This is critical to several battles, but I didn't know how to do it, and didn't even know that I didn't know it.  Also, that first campaign, I didn't realize that you could change what units start most battles.

There is one thing that can be frustrating, and that is the "scaling" the computer does before a battle.  If you have extra money, and want to bring a bigger army to the battle, the computer will also bring a bigger army.  That is annoying and frustrating at times.  But, if you think about intelligence it sort of makes sense.  If the opponent finds out you are massing troops in an area, they are probably going to move troops to counter your movements. 

If you like a game that has many battles, that makes you decide what to focus on first at the strategic level, that makes you decide how to equip the brigades, and how many and what type of brigades (infantry, cavalry, artillery) in each corp. then this is the game for you.  I definitely recommend it.

This is game is as fun as it is frustrating. It has a fairly solid base and plays very similar to the an earlier game from the same developer, Ultimate General: Gettysburg, but this game not only does not bring anything very new to the original game it also brings in a whole lot more frustrating mechanics and taking out a few key things that would have made it better than the original. Let me list down a few of the issues that really irks me and maybe you can decide whether its worth a whole 30 bucks.

Cons:
- Elevation and Terrain of the map
    " The original game Ultimate General: Gettysburg had a scale on the battlefield map that tells you the elevation of the place your troop would be on, but in this game that feature was taken out completely and replaced with a map viewer that allows you to toggle between a complete top-down view or a wannabe 3D view that tries itself to help you see the elevation. This completely ruins the game from a strategically point of view as it strips the player the ability to tell where your troops is standing in comparison to the AI who would never have this problem. This affects multiple things that forms the basis of the combat in this game from line-of-sight to cover and concealment. Imagine you place multiple artillery on a hill only to find out that it was not elevated and only finding out after you wasted five minutes trying to move your slow as fuck artillery to that location."

- Combat losses and AI Scaling
    " The AI in the camapaign does not take loss. Unless said combat takes place on the day after in the same map and battle the AI will never take any losses. I killed a full 15,000 men on the field in the battle of Gaines's Hill only to found out that the AI completely replenishes its troops even as they were supposedly recovering from the former battle. How does the AI get a complete replenishment of their troops when you as the player have to completely replenish your troops everytime you conclude a battle. This cost money and men where both are in short supply especially on a CSA campaign. And one other thing is that the AI's troop count scales accordingly to your army's troop count. So this not only forces you to make a small army but also forces into a situation where you are always outnumbered 3 to 1."

-Poor description of Concealment and Cover
    " The cover and concealment mechanic is as wonky as ever. This game and its earlier iteration Ultimate General: Gettysburg always had a crazy idea of what is a cover is. You can place your troop completely and I mean completely with no excess sticking out in the woods only to take a shit ton of loss from an enemy artillery firing at your location because they saw your troop moving from god knows where. Your troop can never get into cover a 100% and fortifications that look on the map to be a small wooden fort provides you close to no cover, even still taking damage from flanking!? How do you get flank when you troop is covering every coner of the fort? I don't know, maybe only the developer can answer. Then when your troop is completely in middle of a city (I'm looking at you Winchester) you get completly smashed as an enemy artillery decides to walk a few unit closer and blast you with cannister completely destroying your troops."

- Line Formation only
     " Your troop is always stuck in line formation and there is no way for you to change it from column, square or anything that you would thing that an experience general from the Mexican Civil War would use. You would think the developer would had consider this when making this game instead of having it be completely the same as its predecessors."

- Accuracy
    " Accuracy in this game had always been god awful and I can understand that as in the civil war both sides were made from conscripts and volunteers with informal military training. But when your own Naploeon Artillery is having trouble firing at an enemy from say 4 units size away and they are picking you off from miles away you start to really question whether this game was rigged for the AI who was supposedly better and intuitive from most AIs since it was made by an AI modder from a Total War game. I know that accuracy is affected by both Firearms and Efficiency skill and I had both at 60 and 50 respectively, not the best but decent enough in the early game (At Malvern Hill) but I was having trouble firing at enemy artillery. I even had 3 brigades of Napoleons firing at them from a hill overlooking the battlefield at medium range but alas to no avail."

So I have played 41 hours of this game, and I feel after completing a campaign or two I can give a good review for it.

This game has a little bit of a learning curve, and somethings can surprise you.  If your a history guy (not just I watch movies about the civil war type of person) then this is a faithful repressentation with a lot of character for the war.

What is really cool is that choices you make impact the progression of the war, and how you setup your command really really maters on the field and off.

Things to know for new players to lessen frustration:

1. Cavalry are not knights, not even close.  You need to pay attention to what they are armed with to best use them.  I often dismounted with my cavalry depending upon what they are carrying.  If you want to cavalry charge hit tired units and try to  time it with a volley from a supporting unit if poossible.  They are great for screwing with the AI's manuevers and outright smoking their artillery (If they draw arillery attention up close expect loses to cannister, and it's weird but two batteries wil try to fire cannister into one another if you leave one free to do so).  You can setup cavalry as shock units, but it's situational not a go to tactic.

2. Skirmishers, there is a reason you can detach skirmishers and take entire untis of them.  They provide a "screen" against smaller units and cavalry and good units can really mess up even bigger units with skirmishers.  I used them all the time to flank, and to attack approaching units or sneak behind to kill supply carts and generals.  I often merge them back with their parnet unit if I am expecting a lot of charges to a particualr spot on the line, because bodies is more important for defending when they get close.

3. Union gets better guns, but rebels often dont seem to care.  To clarify that means as a Union commander your going to get better gear more often, but your men wil not be as seasoned or....well nuts.  Brave as badgers rebels are.

4.make sure you upgrade and hire commanders and place them with your units from the barracks.  It greatly improves a units stats, and can mean the difference from a useless artillery battery making a lot of smoke and an artillery battery that can smash other artillery in a duel.

5. DO NOT be fraid to spend influence on requests, and dont forget to sell wargear your not gonna use and upgrade your units gear with stuff you "rescue" from battles.  Also try to be on the look out for decent stocks of better guns (1000 or more for line unit armaments), as you might not be able to get them later on and a uunit can only be as big as the number of said gun you want them to field.

6.EDIT: Do yourself a favor and dont put more than 12 artillery pieces in any one unit, they lose effectiveness quickly past 12 when you can just put the extra into another unit.  Sprea artillery out in brigades etc, so if you have to fight with just one etc you have some (same for skirmishers and cav).

While not a perfect game, this is a great game.  The campaign side is a bit silly, with mostly random general names & allowing your brigades to get bigger & bigger over the course of the war instead of shrinking due to casualties, and troop numbers & the replacements model are just so strangely arbitrary and arcade gamey it can break the immersion of feeling like it's an actual battle and not just a casual iphone game.  And the weapons purchasing system in between battles is aggravating, the most expensive & effective weapons are basically a liability, I don't think real generals ever had to decide "Hmm, should I outfit this brigade with modern Springfields but leave everyone else with farmer muskets so I can use them as cannon fodder?"  Historically the Union had almost all their units equipped with mass produced Springfields & rifled cannons by mid-war, and the Confederates had abundant access to Napoleon cannons and Enfield rifle-muskets.  But I never really feel like I can afford the interesting guns in the game, unless I'm already snowballing to an easy victory.   

BUT ALL THAT SAID the gameplay is truly enjoyable and fun, maybe difficult to grasp at first, but after a few sessions I was able to figure out how to dance around with brigades and skirmishers to get flanking & cover bonuses and avoid trading losses, pretty much I can completely wreck armies twice my size with ease now.  And I will admit that the way the scenarios split bigger battles into well defined "phases" with local objectives, is a really innovative & interesting take on these done-to-death historical battles.  After ~70 hours playing I still find myself coming back and trying it again as the opposite side or on a new difficulty setting, it's pretty highly replayable.

So if you are a fan of civil war games & can get over minor quibbles you might have about realism, or if you enjoy real time tactical/strategy games generally, this is a solid title & I would recommend it even at the full price.

Pros:
- I like the graphics, though could be better.  The last best civil war simulator that I played that was near this level was the American Civil War which came out in 1991, so... yes, it is an improvement.
- Managing your Army.  You can build your army as you see fit, though Cavalry are useful only for feints and chasing Arty, Generals and supplies.  Anything else and you risk losing them as they melee their way to a corner of the map.  
- Managing your Army.  Losses hurt and cost money.  This makes you make tradeoffs in your approach to war.  You also are limited to how many divisions, brigades you can have so you need to put some thought into the army.
- Managing your Armory.  Best weapons cost so don’t give them to your troops who will end up being decimated.  
- Some of the issues noted in early comments have been fixed.  I have not been "teleported" at the end of a phase. 
- (Added 27Feb18) AI seems to be adept at "learning" as now seems to keep at least a 300 man skirmisher or 800 Bde around their supplies and arty.  No more easy Cav runs to take out their supply trains.   

Cons:
- Save your troops and don't risk lives unnecessarily as no matter how much you decimate their army, they always get more. 
- AI appears incompetent, but that is a trick.   The other side can charge and do double quick with no loss in effectiveness.  They can be routed, but they will be back as they regain morale to the point that a 800 brigade is still fighting with 96 men.
- Cavalry will not "break" a line.  However, the AI thinks they can and will wheel entire formations to face the charge, so you are left with using them as a paper tiger. 


One potential pro/con is the fact that the AI makes every battle even.  This is good to keep people interested, but is totally unrealistic.  I want to fight unfair battles, I want to crush their armies to never rise again, I want it to be a walk in the park, but.......once you "win" a game, it becomes boring.     While this is unrealistic, it does mean that you will have challenging battles from 1861 to 1865.

Most people tend to agree the game is pretty and fun, but there's a lot of noise around strategic balance.

When playing as the Union, the game plays in a way that's more or less logical.  If you crush the Confederates, they keep fighting but you develop an overwhelming superiority in numbers and men - more or less what happened after 1863, just slower.  I can easily grind down the Confederacy assuming I get past Fredricksburg more or less OK, even on higher difficulties.    
When playing as the Confederacy, the game feels broken because you can string together a series of astonishing victories and still be at a severe disadvantage in the late game.  To some extent, this is probably accurate, emulating what Shelby Foote described as the Union "taking [its] other hand out from behind its back".  But if you won Antietam and Gettysburg, you almost certainly would have received aid from the British and French.  
Without going too deep into what the game isn't - a grand strategy with domestic and international politics - the game could emulate this by giving the Confederacy access to more and better weapons and/or foreign volunteer regiments with a high enough war score late in the game.
I mean, from a historical plausability perspective, the South would likely have surrendered had they lost Bull Run and the Peninsula campaign badly, and Lincoln almost certainly would have lost the 1864 election had he gone in with a string of losses at Fredricksburg, Chancellorsville, and Gettysburg.  But if you're willing to suspend disbelief that far, the only place that feels strategically "off" to me is post-Gettysburg as the South in a winning campaign.

Cons:

-All of the in-battle commands are complex and tedious to carry out, making it very frustrating to do even the simpliest of tasks (retreat, hold fire, split army, etc.)
-The in-game tutorial is lackluster and fails to teach you many of the basic game functions.

              Now I was playing easy mode because, well, I had just bought the game and I didn't know the mechanics very well. And to be honest - I got bitch slapped by the AI. And it's not because I'm new to these types of games. I literally have almost every Total War Game and I have hundreds of hours on them. 
                Each battle sorta goes like this: "Well, I feel pretty good. The rebs are advancing and I got my arty pounding on em. I think I'll win."
                   "Oh shit. That was close. Just got charged by the rebs but I'm all repgrouped now and I got reinforcements to aid me. I still have a good chance."
                      "MOTHERFUCKER. WhErE TeH fUcK DiD 18,000 MoRe rEbS cOmE fRoM."
And this has been the past 5 battles for me. And I know you can't win all of them, but when you're completely outgunned and outmanned by a 2:1 ratio, it really gets to you. I hope they fix this issue because the ideal strategy game is one where the AI makes you work for your victory and actually requires you use your brain. ---------------

Edit: So it's been more than a year since I wrote my initial review, and I've played this game a lot more since then. Overall, it's a pretty solid game. I love how completely destroying your opponent's army has a lasting effect on them throughout the game in that their numbers are depleted for the next few battles. There are still some things that piss me off, though. Cover is way too over powered, as well as small units for some reason. There is no way a 500 man brigade behind cover can hold of my 2500 man 3 star veteran brigade. Utter bs. Even when I charge, with my melee stat at 100. I also hate the morale system. Units break and flee so often that it's not even fun. You have them march up to a fort, they lose 200 out of their 2500 man unit in one volley so they retreat to halfway across the battlefield. Ridiculous. And keep in mind that they severely outnumber the number of troops within the fort, yet they can get about 20 kills and that's it.

The point is, if you like seeing your army being slaughtered by an outnumbered enemy for no reason other than subpar battle design, then this game is for you.

If I was to write a list of all the issues that Ultimate General: Civil War has, that would be longer than The Lord of the Rings written by John Ronald Reuel Tolkien.

If you are interested in Civil War, and would like to purchase this game to enjoy the campaign, know this, it is scripted, from the very first click you make. You will barely have any freedom. This titule was not meant for you to enjoy it, like the Total War games, it was made to recreate the battles that took part. 

Thats right. You get to experience what happened. Every single mission has a time limit, a very short one, which is forcing you play the game in a specific way. Imagine that you are in the middle of a battle, band bang, boom boom... then suddenly it is all over, because... there is no more time. I mean, seriously, what the fuck? I can not recall how mant times did I find myself in a camp because of the time limit. I want to keep on playing, decimate enemies, leave not even one standing. That unforunately is impossible. I want to use tactics, etc., I can not. You either get to rush forward, or defend. 

The latter the battle, the worst it is. Some are divided into parts. You have couple seconds to charge the left flank, then a magic teleportation to the right flank, and once again, now to the center. I hate it. Campaign has nothing to do with campaign. It is a bunch of missions that you complete exactly in the same order, pretty much the same way. Sure, you have a bit of field to maneuver, but if it takes to long, then prepare for defeat, and restart.

Is that how a game is supposed to look like? No. There are plenty issues, mistakes, just a poorly made game. The idea is okay, but when it comes to execution, it leaves a lot of room for improvements.

Get rid of the fucking time limit! For fuck sake.

[h1]Good skin, bad bones[/h1]
Everyone who has ever read a history of the American Civil War will stop at one point or another and ask themselves how things could have gone differently.

[i]Ultimate General: Civil War[/i] does not answer that question.

In its first few hours, the game is a sure winner. The scenery is gorgeous and well-modeled, the tactics fun, and it's easy to lose track of time as you figure out winning strategies on each battlefield.

The longer you play, the more the game's flaws come out. Eventually, you realize the biggest flaw of all: What you do doesn't really matter.

[i]Ultimate General: Civil War[/i] runs into the walls that most historic games face. By hewing too closely to history, they deny the player his or her agency. Everything is fated.

So what if the Confederates win on the first day of Gettysburg? The Union forces will rebound and the Confederate player finds themselves fighting battles farther and farther south.
Pursue the Army of Northern Virginia to ultimate destruction as a Union player on the third day of Gettysburg? It doesn't matter. The Confederacy will miraculously find tens of thousands more soldiers to fill its ranks.
This game, while beautiful, is a handful of tiny sandboxes with only a limited path between. The player does not get to choose where to fight his or her battles, and his or her successes rarely matter.

A papier-mache fictional final series of battles for the Confederate campaign doesn't do much to fix this problem. By the time you reach that point, you'll have already become frustrated with the structure.

It's enormously disappointing, because it only needs a good campaign layer to fix these problems, then the courage to be willing to end the campaign early. Win Bull Run overwelmingly? You could end the war in 1861. Win Antietam as the Confederacy? The war ends in 1862 after the French and British recognize the Confederacy.

If you enjoy playing the historical battles, you'll likely enjoy this game, but you may be frustrated by a handful of bugs -- regiments that become stuck in rivers or on map borders are the worst of these. The game also fails to correctly model repeating weapons: A regiment armed with Henry or Spencer rifles fires no more quickly than one armed with a Springfield.

If you find yourself satisfied by history, you may find something to enjoy here. If, however, you're looking for the answer to "what if," you won't find it here.

This game has some significant problems. In totality, I'd give it a soft recommend. It's frustrating that it is so close to being a great game.

First, the good. This is the probably the best tactical simulation that I've played. It hands down beats Total War, is intuitive, and is generally a pretty solid game all around.

The bad: I'm going to write a little more here. Firstly, the campaign is in need of rebalancing. It doesn't matter if you completely destroy the opposite army; they'll be back at full strength for the next fight. There were 70,000 Confederate casualties at Chickamauga, versus 20,000 Union, but it doesn't mean anything. Your army will still be shot up for the next battle, while there's will be at full strength.

This is to compensate for poor AI. There is no sense of self-preservation. A real commander will not commit failed attack after failed attack - imagine if Pickett's charge had been repeated a second, and then a third time. This is a problem I've seen time and again from the AI. At Chickamauga, there were only 85,000 Confederates total.

The lack of any multiplayer option is pretty significant as well given the poor AI.

The last criticism is a lack of tooltips, or any other explanation of what various characteristics do. As an example, it's never clearly explained what efficiency of a unit is - does this affect movement speed, reloading times, resistance to morale shocks, or something else entirely? How is this really effected by giving another weapon (which has its own efficicency rating) to a brigage ?

I bought this game on sale. T hought that it is a good game, but that was it. But when i started to play, I was instantly sucked in and within the first three or two battles i knew i love it! Seriously this game is worth the 27,99 € and honestly i think it is worth more than the money that are the developers asking for it. So let me just briefly cover the stuff the game has and does great point by point. So here we go.

1. The Army building.
After the introduction into the game in form of your first battle you find youself on the strategic map of the US east coast and in command of your own army comprised of brigades and htey are organized into divisions, which form the main parts of your army that are sent into battles, the corps.
In order to form your army, you will also have to form seperate brigades and equip each with weapons, men and get a commander to lead it. There are many weapons from smooth muskets to rifled mustets to, long revolvers, sabres (for cavalry only), pistols, scoped rifles and magazined rifles. Each has its pros and conns. For example a domestically produced rifle of texan origin will be very good, but it will be more expensive and  most of the time, there are gonna be only very few on the market, so you wont be able to properly equip your brigades with it, or you will get into a situation when you will be forced to replace the said rifle, becouse there just isnt enough of them to replace the ones lost during the last battle. 
So the army building aspect is very nice and it involves some basic economy (you can sell your suff, or the stuff you captured from the other guys).

2.Battles them self.
Battles take place on very well done and beautiful maps and can be quite challanging and can be also very long with multiple stages and objectives. Also there are many smaller battles that all have some effect on your enemy and especially the big battles can have long-lasting consequences. You will meet well know generals on the field standing against you or you can employ some of them in your onw army. Sometimes you will be able to capture some enemy brigades in battle and exchange them for men after the fight.
So the Fights are great, satisfying and just amazing to watch as well.

3. Politics and personal prestige + expirience.
And now the last part. After winnig battles your renown as a general will raise and this will give you a chance to request additional weapons, expirienced generals (Lee, Grant and others), recruits or money from your goverment. Also as you continue through the game you will be able improve your skills in reconnaisence, army organisation, medidine and so on.

4.Final verdict.

The Setting.
Let me start off by saying I am not an American civil wars buff, which, reading other reviews, is a big reason people like this game scewing the review towards positives. I get it, if you are nuts about that period, this allows you to experience battles and drama that unfolded during those years.

The Campaign. -
You should know going into this that you will not be able to forge your very own path through the civil war like choosing were, when and to a large part how to fight. The campaign is on rails for the most part first you are faced with scenarios A, B and C all of which you must overcome before proceeding onto D, E, and F. I think a free form campaign would be better left to a modded version of Total War Empires focussing solely on this period if you want the battles and if you dont want the battles maybe a modded version of Europa Universalis IV.

The Campaign Battles. +
Honestly, I like the scripted nature of the battles it brings each scenario to life. I do find it a little weird that you get to have your own personal retinue of super soldiers, which gains xp and better rifles. Cool, but in conjunction with the scripted battles it just seems off.

Tactical Game Play -
For a game that has such a high focus on the tactical element of battle it just wasnt compelling enough the battles really dragged out with two sides sitting in decent cover just shooting it out. The AI too poor to use its superior numbers to get a decent flank on and you two low on numbers to risk breaking out of cover. I have had to chase infantry with infantry across entire maps becuase both sides are too exhausted to engage in melee. I cant change the width/depth of my units to that I can fit them into that square corn field or long narrow forrested area. The level of information available also limits the tactical depth of the game, see UI and Tutorial.

Multiplayer. -
Maybe some of the problem with having battles that drag out could be mitigated when fighting other players and clearly established victory conditions (unlike Total War Shogun 2 were there would be no timer even if you were defending a castle...). Unfortunately there is no multiplayer.

Graphics. -
Not great honestly, but decent. It is no Totally Accurate Battle Simulator, but neither is it Total War Warhammer. I have already mentioned that I play EU IV, so no I dont think strategy games need good graphics, but this game would really benifit from better ones especially since it shines on the same tactics level that Total War does.

UI. -
Honestly terrible, well maybe not Surgeon simulator levels of frustration, but again it felt clunky and akward moving your troops about. The tool tips are really small same with the manual. I would have loved to be able to tell what was actually a hill from a conture overlay and see the line of sight for my artillery and other units. How about a map that shows you cover levels and the extend of those regions at a glance, heavily wooded, lightly, fields, towns etc. Do units located in the forest get a penalty shooting out of the forrest? What are the modifiers affecting my units right now and what is their effectiveness in fighting the unit it is currently shooting at. 

Tutorial. -
There simply isnt any. The game is fairly simple, but you kinda have to just learn or potentially read in the manual see UI. For instance, a wavering units cannot be controlled. Moral damage from flank, rear attacks. Capturing supply carts. Units will keep fireing when you tell them to move forward if there are enemies in range only advancing when reloading. Tons of little things. Also it takes such a long time to figure out what this game really is that you cant refund it once you have.

This game is the much more fleshed out sequel of Gettysburg and if you enjoy studying the American Civil War, this game is a gem.

-Battles Mechanics:While there are mulitple strategies to win battles, Terrain/Cover and Flanking are the paramount factors for this game. Try to bum rush a fortified position and you'll know exactly how Burnside felt at Federicksburg. Major Battles can be broken down into several days/phases in respect to historical accuracy, but not always depending on Players' action (ex: I won Cold Harbour on Phase/Day One). Casualties inflicted on enemy Brigades are persistent and can swing the battle in your favour on the following days. (My Pickett's Charge involved one severely undermanned brigade and 1 artillery battery). Though there are flaws to this game that might ruin the experience for players. The Fortification System for AI is completely rigged, they will put out inordinate amount of firepower and can take charges outnumbering them 3 to 1 odds. While when the player gets into fortification, one good charge will see your position overrun. Cavalry are fairly crap if the player don't micro them. THIS IS NOT TOTAL WAR, cav charges are next to useless, use them to flank, dismount and fire into the enemy rear. Late game, players will find increasing difficulty to manage battles as the different corps under your command are pressed into the battlefield. It might be a necessity for those who are new to RTS to use their Corp AI. Unfortunately it is a limited AI, that only have TWO commands (Attack/Defend) and will maul your forces as they blindly charge into entrenched positions without much strategic mindset. Another mechanic that players need to be aware of is the Rout Mechanic. You will never see a routing unit being chased off the field of battle unless it is completely shattered. Chasing these units does nothing but open holes in your lines for the others to take advantage of. Enemy Units are KNOWN to rout and flee past your unit and reform at your rear which it would then decimate your brigade.

-Army Management: War cost Treasure, and Treasure are begotten through Victories (or at least Close Defeats). You will start out small with a handful of poorly armed brigades, levying/begging political favours back home to bolster your army through success! or failure. Each Battle, regardless of outcome will net you some manpower, cash and political clout that will allow you to increase your army size and buy better equipment. In the Late Campaigns, your army  can go up to 5 Corps with 25 individual Brigades each. The player have an incredible amount of freedom when it comes to army composition and quality. From making an elite corp of death dealing firing line that can outshoot any adversary to making a literal human tidal wave of raw recruits that can't even shoot a target 3 feet away from them (but they can sure as hell bludgeon their enemies to death). Depending on difficulty, your opponent's resources might be onesided, and if not decisively crippled in battle will severely hamper your future campaigns. 

Overall gameplay: Despite some of glaring flaws, it is by no means broken. It challenges players to develop new tactics to tackle some of these issues, or at least crack open wikipedia and study the battle they're fighting in detail to figure it out. I would say this is a more of a tactical game. Most of the strategy are usually laid out for you in the Battle Briefs and there is not much leeway when it comes to these victory conditions. Even if you completely shatter your enemy if those objectives are not taken, you will Lose/Draw. For those who likes to pick their battles, this game might not be your cup of tea as both campaigns are quite linear, One Major Battle and several smaller ones. But for the price of 30 dollars, you will get your money's worth of content.

When I picked this game up I did not expect it to have the depth that it has. You can create your army down to the T by choosing their equipment and even what the composition of it is (Skirmishers, Infantry, etc.). This game is quite fun and I expect to play it for a while.

I. Love. This. Game.

This game will let you win (or lose) the Civil War. You can play both sides, in three different difficulties. 

Why do I love it so much? Let me explain:
1. It's the Civil War. If you enjoy learing about the Civil War as much as I do, this game is for you.
2. Large scale RTS game. I've never played anything like it. The largest army I have wielded on the battlefield has been about 80,000 troops. Big numbers. 
3. The management/customization. Watch as your brigades evolve and become more experienced. Manage their weapons, skills, and unit size. Command them across the battlefield, using different strategies and tactics to outwit the enemy. Or crush them with overwhelming manpower. 
4. Basically the freedom the game gives you. Are the battles scripted? Kinda, but aside from assigning objectives and giving hints, you are free to do as you please.

Are there things I don't like? Of course. But they are quite minor.
1. Brigades can only face one way, and are easily flanked. I wish they could oblique, or turn part of the brigade to defend the flank. 
2. I wish we could zoom in more.
3. Division Names???
4. Defensive fortifications only appear in certain parts, and I wish we could make our troops build them, or at least spread out to cover a larger area.
5. Campaign wise, in multi-day battles, unit continuity is nonexistant. Meaning, when the game advances to the next day, it rearranges your units. Pretty minor issue.

It's pretty simple. I recommend this game wholeheartedly. The minor flaws are exactly that: minor. The game is a gem. If you like RTS games or the civil war, this game is for you.

Ultimate General Civil War is by far one of the most in depth Civil War games I have played to date. I have had a lot of fun in the campaigns on both sides North and South. Some times the missions can be tedious but usually they are extremely fun. The way divisions are organized and have to be supplied add the extra amount of depth to the game that make me feel like I truly am a general that needs to supply his troops. The campaign also has an intresting way of developing your character in the beginning by picking your background and increasing traits of you and your officers as you progress through the war. If you want to have an intresting experience I highly suggest giving this game a try and it's precurser title, Ultimate General: Gettysburg, but if you truly want the full campaign and wider scope experience pick this one up first.

I bought this on sale and it's definitely worth $15 for anyone that likes stategy games.

I really enjoyed the game and expect it to be on my computer for a long time.  They've really done a nice job recreating the battlefields.  Honestly, it is good enough that I recommend it for anyone whose about to visit one of the battlefields recreated in the game.  I found myself picturing the battlefields as the game played out and it is certainly better than imagining arrows on a map.

That drive to attain historical accuracy does hinder the campaign game in quite a few ways.  You start with a small group of raw recruits and slowly build them into a group of veterans, adding more divisions and corps as you win battles.  Unfortunately it's easy to game the system once you understand how it works.  Winning a battle gives you money, men, and reputation but some battles are harder than others.  For my first playthough I chose the Union and because I've read the history, I knew the futility of doing things like charging the lines at Fredricksburg.  After one halfhearted attempt I held back and won by focusing my attack somewhere else.  Even people who don't know history will learn that lesson quick which really hurts the game's replayability.

The same thing happens when you fight at Chancellorsville.  Your whole army is spread out and facing east as it did historically.  The game's messages tell you to focus your attack east but anyone that has read about the battle knows Stonewall Jackson is behind your lines.  To make it fairer, I waited for him to show up then moved to troops to intercept.  That was much more fun but I shouldn't have advanced information about the battle.  More variety in battles like this would make repeat playthoughs feel less like a waste of time.

Another issue is the game design puts all the battles on rails and even if you win battles your historical counterpart lost, it really doesn't matter.  You advance to the next battle no matter how many casualties you take or cause.  As your army gets more experience the opposition magically gets even more experienced to account for the difference.  I just finished Gettysburg and by now I'm pretty sure I've killed more men than actually served in the actual Confederacy.  Next battle I'm sure Lee will be back to full strength with veteran leaders and skilled men.  This really lessens my desire to push troops other than to stop at mission goals.  There's no need to anything else because you face the same army either way.  Doing more only weakens you in the future.

This game does comes real close to being strategically great on the battlefield.  I think my favorite so far is 2nd Bull Run where you have to send out skirmishers and cavalry to find an isolated part of the Confederate army.  This mission really reinforces why scouting was so important during the Napoleonic warfare.  Once you find the enemy it's a race to link your army as fast as possible and then hit the isolated army as hard as you can before the rest of Lee's army arrives.

This really pushes the risk vs reward along with uncertainty.  Unfortunately this doesn't happen with most battles.  You are usually put into a situation just before armies meet and it's just a matter of seeing the opponent and deciding whether to defend or attack.  It gets old but I'm sure it is difficult to program a stategically smart AI on a huge map.  If you give the computer too many decisions, most human player usually can beat it with cheap tactics.  This problem is the bane of all wargames so it probably isn't fair to criticize too much for this failing.

Even knowing that, I'd still like more ability to choice where to fight.  What would happen if I let Lee take Gettysburg and fight him closer to Washington?  Why can't we get a game that can similate battles as brigades/divisions/corps move around the map?  Why can't we create generated battles based on a general understanding of the maps of the United States from that era?  Why not allow me to fight where ever I want and adjust things like the overall population / technology to help with the what-ifs?  The Confederacy was always at a huge disadvantage so if the Union generals are competent they are destined to win early.  That's ok in a simulation.  Let us change the game assumptions and restart.  Instead this game resorts to cheap tricks to keep everything stuck on the historical path.  

I know this review sounds negative but even with its flaws it is a huge improvement over most wargames.  Just because Pickett's charge is preprogrammed at Gettysburg does not make that experience any less spine chilling.  Like I said at the beginning, this wargame is a great overview of battles and there's something exhilerating to watch your forces fighting on famous battlegrounds.  It really gives a good overview of the terrain and gives insight into why commanders made certain decisions.  

In the long run I doubt I play the campaign more than a couple of times but I'm sure the historical battles (12 major and 16 minor)  will be a long term part of my wargame rotation for whenever I feel the desire.  This game is a good investment if you are at all interested in the American Civil War or wargaming in general.  

I also can't wait to see what the development team for this game does next.  I'm sure they learned a lot from this experience and hopefully we see more advancements so we eventually can get a game that is a better blend of strategy/tactics.

This game is amazing and is everything I've ever wanted in a Civil War Era strategy game. I was drawn to the title due to my love for Firaxis's Sid Meier's Gettysburg. This game nails the feel of that and just blows its out of the water in every way possible. The longer I play the less I like this game.  Buried beneath some truly punitive design choices lie some of the best battlfield mechanics that have ever been devised, unfortunately this is less of a game and more a guided tour.  While looking at Game-Labs' labor of love is encouraged actually interacting with is not.

Within the first few hours of play it became apparent that my enemy was not the Confederate States of America, or even the supposedly advanced AI, but rather the Clock.  I lost count of the number of times I carefully maneuvered my men into advantageous positions, utilizing the admittedly wonderful route planning features, to set complex assaults in motion; only to meet with failure despite the Rebels fleeing in disarray because the timer ran out.  By the third time you reload to win a battle you had dominated with manuever, tactics and strategy in order to win by weight of numbers alone the game will start to lose it's luster.

Complicating this are some truly glaring mistakes which defy all versimilitude.  Artillery, the King of Battle, for instance becomes useless without time for bombardment to provoke natural evolutions in positioning which can be taken advantage of.  In defensive actions it's maddening to watch as your cannons belch cannister shot directly into the melee without the defenders suffering any collateral damage.  Ditto for the ability to enfilade friendly forces to great effect.
Far from putting positional advantage within reach Cavalry units collapse the moment they enter the range of even the most numerically inferior blocking forces' guns.  Skirmishers, while incredibly useful in early battles suffer from a dearth of supply as the game progresses, ultimately becoming useless since the superior weaponry that they naturally rely on (such as scoped and repeating rifles) never become available in numbers which scale to match the increasing unit sizes.

Perhaps the worst aspect of this experience is that there is no reward for undertaking it.  Completing the Campaign does not unlock anything to incentivize you to play again.

Who This Game Will Appeal To:  Hardcore Civil War Buffs.

Pros:

- Your armies are completely customizable-- you get to pick exactly how many men are in each unit, how many divisions you'll have, what kind of units you'll have, and even what they're named. Cons: 
- Calvary are underpowered in general, but especially ranged calvary. They'll take one shot at the enemy, then immediately turn around and retreat. 
- Charges were a big part of the civil war, and were known for being very effective. In this game, however, the charging unit will almost always rout before whomever they charged at, even under the best conditions. 

Overall, I really liked this game. It's realistic enough to make it challenging without forcing you to micromanage every little thing. It's also really good at surprising you-- just when you think you've outmanuvered your opponent, something will change on the battlefield to make you sweat.
