This is really a fantastic tactical game. The developers have really polished up the game since Early Access and resolved a lot of the concerns people had earlier. The AI has improved by leaps and bounds, making maneuvering your army ever more critical to success. It's painfully rare for realtime strategy games to truly reflect the importance of good terrain, flanking, and morale as this game does. To win decisively you must make bold maneuvers, but at the same time a wrong move can result in tremendous losses. Each move has to be carefully weighed.

The strategic campaign aspect really goes hand in hand with the battles. Replacing your armies is expensive, so those casualties you take really hurt. However the reinforcements of your enemy are limited as well, so if you can inflict enough damage on them, you can save a lot of heartache later on. It's another tradeoff; do you risk taking extra losses to weaken your enemy, or do you focus on preserving your army?

There are dozens of playable battles that rapidly grow in scope as the game progresses. By the end, you engage in massive battles involving several dozen brigades stretched across battlefields large enough that you can't just reinforce from one part of your army to the other. Careful advanced planning is critical for victory. The battles are historically based, but offer just enough leeway that I don't really feel constrained.

This game offers a great balance of old-fashioned wargaming and real-time tactical gameplay. If that sounds up you alley, I'd give it a shot!
This is honestly one of the best RTS games i have ever played.

True confession: I am, and have been my entire life, fascinated by history and particularly by the American Civil War. So, therefore this game stands almost zero chance of getting anything but a great review from me. Now, all that said, when I actually began playing this game, I found it to be as exceptional as I had hoped it would be. This is a kind of grand strategy game (ish) with your management of your Army and skill points outside the battlefield. Decisions have to be made, resources (which can be sort of sparse (particularly Army/unit leadership resources) have to be managed well, etc. And then within that grand strategy is the actual RTS battles themselves. This is where the game really shines (although truth be told, I'm a dork for the management side of my Army -- research to name every brigade after a historical unit, etc). The game, inside the battle itself is unforgiving. Make a mistake and the AI WILL take advantage of it. The higher the difficulty level you play at, the more formidable and punishing your mistakes will be magnified. This game will teach you real fast, the value of maintaining cover at all possible costs, covering your flanks effectively, establishing a good solid battle line, proper deployment of your experienced troops vs your green troops, along with many other things. 

All in all, if you are a American Civil War buff -- get this! If you just like a good challenging game -- get this and set it to the highest difficulty. You will not be disappointed. This is a solid A++ game in my book.

This game has been one of the most enjoyable strategy games that I have played in a long while. While I still remember spending countless hours playing Sierra's Caesar 3 way back in the day, as well as the orginal Rome:Total War, I was encouraged to find that there are still some great quality strategy war games being made. 

While I had never played the first version of Ultimate General, I had stumbled upon this game many months ago during the Beta release. Coordinating your armies can be a daunting task unless you have a good idea of how you want to engage your troops. This game allows you to detach skirmishers from your regiments and re-attach them at your convenience. Soldiers may become fatigued, lose morale, or run out of ammo during battle, but if you are well organized you may position re-inforcements to take their place. One way you can replace tired troops is by selecting the "Fallback" feature which many strategy games lack. Your troops can disengage properly without receiving a devastating volley from the enemy and they cover their retreat in an organized fashion.

I feel that there are many positives to this game, too many to list. 

The only negative, at this time, I can think of would be this; Prior to any battle, the game shows you where your troops and the enemy will be deployed, where re-inforcements will come from, and what locations must be captured or defended. It is very important to remember this information, however, when you are in a large battle and you sometimes don't finish the battle in one sitting, It would be beneficial to be able to have the option to review that information the next time you load your campaign. (Sort of how Age of Empires 3 did)

I highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of AOE, Total War, and the early Sierra games like Pharoah, Zeus, or Caesar. It has nothing to do with city building, but plenty to do with warfare and maintenence.

Overall, great game, good job Darth.

But with that, I have on several occasions made a point to ground the enemy army into a fine digestible pulp, at some extra loss to me of course. I considered that the extra weapons gained and intense enemy losses would offset further engagements to my advantage, therefore the slightly higher casualty rate was justified. I especially targeted 3 star commanders and gun batteries to curb their ability to overwhelm my lines with combined arms.

Now we're at the battle of Antietam and I can pretty safely say that the extra effort has made no difference at all. The Yankee dogs have tons of top of the line generals and high end guns pounding my poor 50,000 troops with a big blue hammer. During the first two days of the battle, the blue coats were rounded up and pincered in ever increasing massive blue mounds of dead. Then the third day comes where the union gets some 20,000 ish reinforcements to push their army to now at least twice the size of my remaining forces where I need to hold out for an additional 4 (in-game) hours.

This review is of the Early Access version 0.94. When I first encountered the game, the first impression was that it's "pretty simple" because it only has Infantry, Skirmisher, Cavalry and Artillery. But as soon as you start playing it, you notice how much depth it has. Especially the part between the battles is pretty important. How do I spend my career points? Politics for more troops/money or shall I invent into medicine, economics? Shall I get 2000 rookie soldiers or invest into fewer, but better veterans? Or some of the expensive cavalry? What weapon will I give them. So managing your army before and after a battle is quite in important task. Also during the battle, it's crucial which troops you send in first. Maybe better send in the cheap, unexperienced guys which are "easy to replace". Once the enemy is already demoralized, bring in your 3 star troops. Having a unit who killed around 3000 enemies with a loss of only around 200 soldiers is just satisfying.

Winning/Losing a battle will affect your image. With image points, you can afford additional troops, money, weapons or generals. But the downside is, that buying those things will lower your image points. And bigger image means better morale for the whole army.

Won battles also have effect on some of the upcoming battles (e.g. 5% less troops for the enemy).

The battles itself are really interesting - and even if you replay the same mission again or a savegame, the battle may lead to a complete different direction.

There are often 2 or 3 small battles before a big one. They're good to improve your troops as long as you do good. It doesn't help your campaign if you win a small battle at all costs when you lose maybe 5000 soldiers but you'll only get 3500 for the victory.

Most important thing in battles are cover, flanking the enemy as well as having better weapons. Having a 1 on 1 straight fight on open landscape infantry vs infantry isn't very good because it will result in big loss on both sides. And with some missions, goals for winning the battle might not just be to hold a hill, but also to e.g. make 10% more damage than the enemy or to not lose more than 50% of your army.

While the small battles may take around 30-45 minutes, the bigger battles often have more stages or days and take a longer.

Personally I really like the graphics as long as you don't zoom in too much. For a closer zoom, the solders could need a higher LOD. However, it's not needed to zoom in at all. Overall, the atmosphere is pretty good - and I never was a "fan" of the civil war period. But this game changed my mind.

Now that I'm really thinking about it, I think this might actually be the first dedicated American Civil War game I've ever played. I've certainly played alot of mods, custom scenarios, and other stuff along those lines, but not a game specifically focused on it...

UG:CW is, obviously, focused on that conflict. You get to either fight individual battles or partake in a quite lengthy campaign as you build/maintain your army and fight numerous battles over the course of the war. To me, this game kinda feels like a Total War game, but lacking the high end graphics, animations, and other technical aspects. Other differences being that there is no terrible diplomacy system, the battles you fight are already set and have specific conditions/goals, and your only real concern is winning battles. I actually like this approach because while the "sandbox history" of games like the Total War series or Paradox Games' (Europa Universalis, Crusader Kings, etc) can be very fun, sometimes... a game that trades that freedom for attention to detail is pretty cool too.

In that regard, my history nerd-side got quite a bit out of this game and gave me some insider knowledge that certainly helped while playing the game. I have this massive "atlas book" focused on the ACW and the maps in there match what I saw in this game, as did the generals involved and the overall course of battles. It is heavily scripted, but there is room for differences should you manage to succeed where history failed. That can be very rewarding, with it often meaning you can win battles before enemies are heavily reinforced. Other knowledge, such as how the minie ball (aka, rifle bullets) was the major killer of the war (after disease) or how artillery was very strong at close ranges but hadn't quite become super-lethal at longer ranges just yet, ended up being invaluable. Lastly, that the battles of the war gradually changed from resembling the Napoleonic era towards resembling WW1, and how that changes how you have to approach the game. In other words, this game is a treat for history nerds like me.

..Which may very well have made the difference between winning and losing, actually. This game can be pretty tough, and I was playing as the USA (the CSA would be harder, and by all accounts is). You often find yourself fighting battles with small forces awaiting reinforcement, forcing you to make do with what you have. These moments generally were the toughest parts of the game, since it often means you are outnumbered or racing against time to take an objective. The steamroller approach can work in bigger battles when you have all your forces, but much of the rest of the time you need skill to win. People complain about this, but I'm ok with it. After all, battles don't always happen when you want them to.

Less good is the "prestige" system in the campaign. Basically, you earn prestige from winning battles, can spend it in order to get more money, weapons, etc, lose some from draws, and lose alot from losing battles. It is this last point that is the real issue, because those prestige losses can be huge, and if you lose more than you have it is game over. So you can't really afford to lose battles. I didn't have this problem since I was playing as the Union and my approach to strategy games is to stack the deck in my favor before ever reaching the battlefield. But I am worried about it when I try to play as the CSA instead, since the real ACW (and the game) was very much a case of the USA tapping into their huge resources while the CSA had to fight with what it could scrape together.

One more point to raise about the campaign is that battles and the overall campaign is influenced by your performance. Specifically, enemy armies continually increase in strength as the war continues, but you can mess this up if you keep inflicting huge costly defeats upon them. I though that this was a pretty cool way to let the player "alter" history to a degree, but it ended up being a little disappointing too. Because if you repeatedly crush the enemy, or inflict massive losses in the early stages of a battle they will have much less later on. 

This was highlighted for me strongest in the Battle of Gettysburg. The first day was an intense defensive battle that had me have to fight hard to not get overrun by the CSA. But because I inflicted such heavy casualties first during Day 1 and then during the Day 2 assault on Little Round Top, the CSA attack on Culp's hill didn't really happen and the infamous Pickett's Charge on Day 3 was so feeble I ended up charging them instead. The game continued to be challenging and interesting throughout, but repeated early success probably ended up ensuring that later battles like Gettysburg and Cold Harbor ended up being much easier than they ought to have been because the enemy had little to fight with. With that said, the later battles like Cold Harbor when it became a proto-WW1 ended up being the most costly battles I fought.

Anyway, that's enough for this review I think. As usual, I'm only stopping now because if I don't I could keep going on and on. I don't want to write that much and chances are you don't want to read it. XD

Is this game fun? Reasonably. Does it immerse you into the ACW while balancing historical accuracy with freedom to change results? Absolutely. Would I recommend it to others? Yes, but with the added point that knowledge of the war helps and a lack of it likely makes it harder. So if you are a history nerd who has even a passing interest in the American Civil War, consider checking this out. It was pretty neat, more than worth the money I paid, and there is still plenty of content left for me to do.

A number of reviewers made the same points, so I will be brief.

The good:

-Looks nice.
-Feels like a great game, especially during the first 5 hours.
-Army customization, upgrades and different weaponry are nice touches.

The bad:

-The AI is broken in various ways. For instance, it often charges irrationally, and seemingly to make up for this the developers gave it some super powers.
-Cavalry is useless, even against lone skirmishers or undefended artillery units. You are always better off investing the money and manpower in an infantry unit.
-Battles are heavily scripted, to the point of having a broken logic. You are supposed to defend a position. You do it and thanks to the AI's suicidal charges, the enemy gets almost completely wiped out or routed. Then the game hits a point in the script and you are prompted "Our position is being overwhelmed! We must fall back to that place!" Then the script magically teleports your whole army to the hill behind the position where you were doing just fine. Then you watch the comedy of the enemy trying to charge your new position with 10% of its starting force because you had killed or routed the rest before your position was "overwhelmed."

The ugly:

-No matter how badly you beat the AI, it keeps making up its losses and more. This renders your actions completely inconsequential. After 50 or so hours, (or sooner if you are smarter than I am) you realize that you are not playing a strategy simulator. You are instead playing one of those clicker flash games in which the numbers keep increasing as you upgrade your skills but nothing else changes because as your income increases so do the cost of future upgrades. 

If that sounds too abstract, here is the same point made in concrete gameplay terms: I first played two campaigns with CSA. The first time when enemy kept making up their losses regardless, I thought "Well, I am a noob. So, I didn't beat them hard enough in the beginning. That's why they recovered." But then I played the same campaign again. Even in the easiest difficulty and right after I consistently mowed down 70% of the Union army battle after battle, the next battle they always had 10k more soldiers than they did before. Then, I said "Well, they are the Union after all. They had a larger population than the rebels" and I tried out the Union campaign. Who knew the South could replace 200k+ losses and keep pressing towards the DC? I didn't. They kept coming, their numbers kept swelling no matter how many I killed.

The Verdict:

I wanted to like this game. And to be honest, I enjoyed it for many hours. But the enjoyment was in part due to the illusion created by the game, the illusion that my actions and decisions mattered. Once the illusion was shattered by the realization that no matter how well I play, the AI will be able to match and raise my hand, the enjoyment was replaced with disappointment and frustration. Overall, I would have to say, the experience ended up being negative.

PS: I aslo want to respond to a common objection to negative reviews with many hours: "You played it for 70 hours, how bad can it be? Grow up and get a life!"

It is possible to enjoy something in the short term although the enjoyment is replaced by discomfort after a while. If you think that this is impossible, try telling that to a heroin addict who wishes that he had never done that first shot.

Having played this game, both as Union and Conferederate, for many months, I find the mechanics of the game to be very addictive. I have found myself playing for hours without even realizing it.

However, I feel the game was rushed into production with the premise.... this is good enough.....

More specifically, the game lacks polish and flexability. 

For instance, the campaign game follows the course of the actual battles during the war, but the army management, where you actually build your army, seems to be designed for PvP play rather then any historical immersion.

The major personalities of the war are present, but they lack, personality...good or bad, commanders are just presented for their historical context, their abilities or limitations in real life not withstanding.

You have the ability to outfit your army and customize their arms, but it seems most of the available muskets,  rifles and cannons are just meant for eye candy, as they never appear in the numbers required to outfit a unit.

Winning or loosing a battle does not seem to affect the course of the game, you are stuck in the same battles as the historical counterparts, no matter how you performed in previous battles. There is also no strategic benefit or consequence for winning a battle, apart from a possible buff for the next battle.
 
And all of the battles devolve into "capture the flag" , where everything revolves around capturing a key terrain feature, rather then focusing on the enemy army. In fact, once the terrain requirements are met, its best to husband your units and ignore the enemy until time runs out.

The custom games are very limited, as you are forced to use one of the premade battle maps and then pay for a limited supply of arms and men. 

The pre-made historical battles are very playable and enjoyable, but from these you can also see how the army management system does not do the game justice.

Overall, Ultimate General seems to have potential, but given its built in limitations becomes rather repetative and dull once you've gone through it a couple of times.

A blown-up sequel to the original Ultimate General: Gettysburg game, which was itself an updated and  more complex version of Sid Meyer's Gettysburg from days past.  In a nutshell - a wargame where you move around units composed of individuals, not square cardboard pieces with numbers on them, and watch them duke it out.  The game is executed well -- it's beautiful to look at, it's relatively easy to understand the controls, and it provides a lot of replay value.  

It's not perfect, mind you.  There are some tactical quirks to the AI, and occasionally some gunk gets in the works and you see tiny, almost-panicked units rout a complete and full-strength enemy unit (or something like that).  The terrain can sometimes be hard to read (there is an option to increase the depth of the terrain on the map; I find that essential, but still occasionally have issues), which is a factor in a game that attempts to realistically model the benefits/costs of fighting uphill vs. downhill.  The campaign model in this one (which is greatly expanded and modified from the relatively basic sequential battle system in Gettysburg) can be a bit complex and challenging.  And the game does not hold your hand at all -- you really do need to know at least some basic military tactics and concepts to function well in the game.  

On the whole, though, it's an excellent wargame, albeit not something with copious depth (like, say, anything by Gary Grigsby).  Great for people of intermediate wargame skill (like me), but I'd think that hardcore grognards may find it too easy or simplistic (or both).  Given that it's a very small development team (who have proven to be quite good at responding to user feedback on both their games), it's an impressive achievement.  I wish I had more time to dive into it....

This is the most accurate ACW game I've played and probably one of the most fun tactical one's. I'll address the elephant in room first. The graphics look like that from a game from 10 years ago. That being said it has to be one of the most comprehensive tactical strategy games I've ever played, taking into acount the reload time of your soldiers, their morale, their condition, the weapons stats, the cover that they are in, etc. The coolest part is there are several differant modifiers available to help you improve these stats through unit veterancy, allocating weapons, assigning commanders, etc. which helps this game stand out from Empire Total War. Customizing your army is one of the best parts of this game. It's a constant balancing act of acuring the best weapons for the cheapest cost for the most soldiers. This balancing is depedent purely on ones gameplay within the campaign. Though even losing battles there are so many ways to play around lack of equipment, lack of man power, or lack of money by tailoring your army to work around it. So though you may lose here and there, the game may punish but it's never unfair with what you can or can't do. The tools to beat the odds are always there. So 36 hrs in, I can say I love this game in every aspect; the accuracy, the gameplay, and the balancing of the game.

The gameplay alone makes up for the lack of those two aspects from ETW. Would buy again.

This game does a great job of providing tactical level command, set in an operational storyline that takes you through the Civil War. The graphics are well done. The AI is fairly good, and challenging.  The options you have in each battle are wide open with the exception of holding victory locations and the dreaded battle timer - however, you can customize your Corps units, weapons, generals, and recruitment. You can also determine where you spend your "capital" points. 

Commanding units and giving orders is relatively easy, the interface is quite user-friendly, and overall - I loved playing this game through and seeing how my different Corps excelled, grew, shrank with losses, and how the weapons developed over the course of the war. The challenges on each side are quite different, I played through both from the time this was a limited release.

The Union - you have the disadvantage of mostly being on the offensive and digging out well-entrenched Rebel forces. You also have to procure your weapons, because the ones you might pick up from the battlefield from the Rebels are horribly outdated and not useful. You will be hard pressed to build a big enough Corps, and equip them, to overcome your casualties and beat the Rebels. Your advantages are plenty of recruits, access to advanced weaponry (if you can afford it), and being on the offensive always gives you the initiative to strike the enemy at their weakest points and control the momentum of the battle.

The Confederacy - you have the disadvantage of numbers, you are always outnumbered. Your weapons are heinously outdated, and you don't have access to the Union's advancement in weaponry so you are forced to find ways to capture Union supplies and weapons. Also, you are often times forced to defend positions based on victory locations and it's not always ideal. However, if you can find ways to make sure you have mobile reserves, cover your flanks as necessary, invest in short-range artillery to decimate Union ranks, and run down retreating Union Forces to capture their supplies, your defenses can become impenetrable.

Overall - 8/10.  I've been in the military for over 20 years, have re-enacted Civil War battles, and have been playing war games both electronic and board for nearly 30 years. This game is fun and addictive, and easy to put away and come back to later as you have time.

A fabulous game that takes you through the whole war from start to finish, as either side. There is an excellent battle engine, which provides the best simulation we have seen so far of the civil war, including scripted elements for each battle. This is paired with an abstracted campaign, where you decide which generals to promote, which troops to reinforce, what weapons to buy, etc. It also allows for your supreme general to develop, and either improve their political situation, or logistics, wealth or organisation. 

For fans of a turn based campaign and a real time tactical battle engine (e.g. total war, etc), this is a great alternative.

This isn't the most accessible game out there (would have really liked to have seen a tutorial), so be warned up front that you'll probably need to read some guides before you really get a handle on this game. I've had many hours of fun with this title, finding it to be a unique and innovative approach to the RTS genre.

The game's campaign takes you chronologically through the major battles of the civil war with a persistent army for you to command during and manage between battles. Having an army that you need to manage and carry from one battle to the next adds a great degree of importance to your tactical choices. Each battle has win/loss/draw victory conditions and rewards and this is one of the few games where it may be beneficial to skip (if a minor battle) or fight for a draw or loss if you think pushing for the victory will cost you too many men. I would recommend saving frequently and maintaining several save files so that you don't have to start completely over if you take horrific losses in a battle and find that you just can't recover two or three major battles down the road.

The gameplay itself is quite fun, with a unique way to control your unit's movements and with a focus on locating and occupying advantageous terrain, flanking, and unit morale. As an added bonus, knowing your history oftentimes can be beneficial (I may have forgotten what Stonewall Jackson was up to during Chancellorsville during my first campaign and received a nasty surprise on day 2).

Pros 
- Ability to create and custom equip army
- Unique art style
- Great sound
- Multi-stage battles

Cons
- Terrain glitches causing units to get "stuck" ( i.e. water crossings )
- Enemy units practically "flying" across great distances
- Enemy cav sometimes glitches through your lines with no collision at all
- Enemy units route through your lines and reform on your flanks
- Units in melee can be fired upon by nearby units with almost 0 fratricides
- Poor continuity in some of the multi-stage battles ( i.e. Unit dispositions )

- Routed enemies tend to build up on edges of map rather than fleeing the field
- AI makes outright silly decisions ... ( Too Many )

But I digress... the game needs some polish but this is obviously a labor of love and a definite upgrade in the series

tldr: The best new game in this genre in a decade.  Civil war improves most aspects of the general simulator genre.   

The battles: fun, easy to get into, difficult to master.  Best interface/userinteractions in a game like this by a wide margin, ever.  The AI isn't great (I'm a big proponent of human opponents), but it's still really fun because...

The armies: Rather than moving units around a campaign map you choose from battles from different years of the campaign.  The army management system has more in common with xcom than it does total war.  At times it can feel a little tedious (I felt the same way about managing 20+ xcom soldiers) but it also adds a lot of depth to the game.   Want to win at Gettysburg as the Confederates.  Be prepared to spend many many lives and still not make your objectives.  30,000 men died fighting me to a draw on normal mode and those lives were simply not replaceable.   You're left locked in the same proposition that the North and South found themselves in during the war - the South needing decisive, efficient victories and the north needing a bloodbath. 

Campaign evolution: Over the course of the campaign new guns come into use, earthworks and trenches proliferate, and the size of your army grows vastly.   The new guns drastically increase the killing power of each brigade, especially defenders, and pose interesting problems and opportunities for each side.  In the first battles you're handling maybe 4-6 brigades and in the final years of the campaign you could have something like 150.  You may need to set aside an afternoon for some of the battles: your left-side flanking maneuver might be made up of 25 units (maybe as many as 40 if you've sent out all your skirmishers).

This is a great game and it will influence many games to come in this genre.

After playing 100+ hours in this game I am disappointed that it suffers from the same issues it predecessor Ultimate General: Gettysburg did. Although some fun improvements have been made, they ultimately don’t make that game worth the time.

The Good
The new army camp screen where the player can build their army is an excellent addition.  Recruiting and leveling new brigades and officers, outfitting them with better weapons, and spending reputation points for more money or better weapons gives the player a real sense of achievement as they progress through the campaign.  Sadly this is the only positive for this game.

The Bad
1:  The balance in this game in non-existent.  2000 men infantry brigades routing to 150 men skirmisher brigades and melee cavalry brigades with 3x the men being unable to rout or even push back lone artillery brigades to name a few examples.  Yes I know I about being flanked, that is not the issue.  The balance is also incredibly inconsistent for player vs the AI.  When the player is on defense with superior cover that AI brigades seem to have a much easier time dislodging and routing them player does in the opposite situation.

2:  Since the battles are recreations of actual events it makes them very scripted which is to be expected, but that takes away a lot of the potential strategy a player could employee to achieve a better victory with less loss of men.  Combine this with a battle that has the player attacking a defending AI and the player is guaranteed to take more losses in men and equipment then with be rewarded for winning the battle.  On several occasions I tried to flank the enemy lines only to have the enemy receive reinforcements from behind me making the flanking maneuver pointless.

3:  Any battle that is more attacking of a defending AI will always result in a net loss for the player-ALWAYS.  Try to be smart and flank the enemy, nope doesn’t work.  Try to do something other than continuously throw brigades against a defending entrenched AI, not gonna work/would take too long for the time provided.  Even if you manage to win a Victory in the battle it will cost you more money to rebuild your army than what is gifted to you for the Victory.

I want to like this game but there are many issues and inconsistencies that make it more aggravating than its worth.  If you can buy it on sale for less than 5 bucks I’d say go for it, but otherwise don’t waste your money.

There is a heavy bias to the selection of battles to the Eastern Theater, the one everyone cares about. Outside of that theater you have a grand total of three battles: Shiloh, Stones River, and Chickamauga. I get that one problem is how heavily involved engineering and naval support was in the Western theater, particularly any battle on the Mississippi River, whereas this is a pretty typical napoleonic infantry-cavalry-artillery game, but that's kind of the point, isn't it?

Even aside from that, there are many important battles in the Western Theater which could probably be accomodated in this game: Vicksburg (post-Grant's landing), Chattanooga, Perryville, Franklin, Nashville, and/or the Battle of Atlanta.

This is also kind of part of a mild pro-Confederate (or at least pro-Virginia) bias in terms of the battles chosen. All of the battles I named above were Union victories, since outside of perhaps Chickamauga the Union consistently won major battles and offensives in the West.

I get it, I'm from Virginia, I love all the Eastern theater battles, but even then most of the battles chosen are from the first two years of the war, and there's only a few that take place after Gettysburg.

The only battles between Lee and Grant are Cold Harbor and Richmond? The Wilderness, Spotsylvania Court House, North Anna, the siege of Petersburg? Nope.

I get that you don't want to have too many Union victories (although as I said you're slightly short now), but from a tactical or even strategic perpective most of the battles of the Overland Campaign were either Confederate victories or inconclusive - not until Petersburg did Lee ultimately break.

So bottom line, the game is absolutely fantastic, but seeing as the devs are so amazing at providing updates, I'd love for the broader story of the war to be covered, rather than just the popular history version which ignores everything west of the Appalachians and anything after Gettysburg.

As an old player of Sid Meier's Gettysburg, I have really enjoyed this game.  It adds the critical element of continuity between battles (you keep your army), which for me, makes a campaign-style game much more engaging.  I usually don't care too much for real time games, but this one is manageable.  The balance between infantry/skirmishers, cavalry, and artillery seems about right and the battles are fun.  On top of all of this, it has caused me to study up on Civil War battles and learn some history.

From a gaming standpoint, the one thing I would like to see is an ahistorical option that reflects pathways in the War that may have occurred particularly when the outcome of a major battle is substantially different that what happened historically.  I also don't fully understand the scaling mechanic of the game.  It might be nice to have a bit more transparancy on this or even better an option to adjust the magnitude of the scaling.

Even after 259 hours (at this time), I'm still improving my technique, and in fact, will be starting a new Confederate Campaign (on normal) because I just lost the last one at the final battle (Washington) basically because I didn't have enough troops in one of my Corps.   

All-in-all, I applaud the designers and hope there is more of this style of game down the road.....perhaps a fantasy setting that allows for more flexibility in battle sequence and overall goals.

(The only con is some historical inaccuracy regarding the suggested cause of the war. Amazing civil war game. With each progress, you learn how to give your troops a fighting chance and come home alive. Use cover, invest in 12lb Napoleons and have them right behind your infantry both in attack and defense. When you meet the enemy, the grapeshots will make short work of them. Kill 'em with artillery, and advance from cover to cover. Your infantry just shields artillery, artillery is what kills just beyond rifle range.
Basically just make people shoot each other.

Pros;

A great focus on strategy where terrain, equipment and morale all play a crucial part.
A large amount of historical battles to choose from allowing you to really feel like you are part of the campaign.
Decent AI that moves to counter you and often takes you by suprise.
Glorious graphics.
A competant learning curve throughout the game.
Historical figures that you can recruit to lead your men.
Lovely music and sound quality during combat (if a little repetative at times).
Honest to goodness had me at the edge of my seat focusing hard at the higher game levels to win battles.
SO MUCH MORE! SOOOOO MUCH!


Cons;

AI scaling is a bit wonky, you often end up being heavily outnumbered leaving some battles impossible to win if you try and increase the size of your army.
Routing AI often flee through your troops when you really can't afford to chase them and they end up coming back in perfect flanking positions. 
Veteran costs are a bit extreme considering battle rewards (even with maxed out politics, economy and training perks).
Leaves you wanting more skirmish battles and minor engagements.
Flanking seems a little random at times, i.e flanking an enemy often does very little compared to what it does to you.
Cavalry vs routing inf brigades needs a buff.
Cavalry AI is often a little unresponsive.


Improvements needed in the future;

Ability to have a multiplayer feature for historical + custom battles would be AMAZING!
Mod capability to customise unit appearance.
A fix for the AI rout system so routing units actively try to get back to the rest of the army rather than going literally anywhere they please and often getting lost and decimated behind enemy lines as a result.
Artillery buffs at long range (round shot) so it actually can damage bunched up units a decent amount rather than killing not even a handful of men per volley even with a direct hit.
An ability to rally wavering/routing men more quickly would be appreciated.
A fix to the AI scaling so you don't have to worry about being vastly outnumbered in every battle once you increase your army organisation.

Hello all! As a student of history, and an avid reader of all things WW2, Civil War, Napoleon, Rome, and others I find this game to have an impressive level of historical research, from the weapons, to the names of the various leaders and generals involved. 

Gameplay is designed to keep you thinking, where the same battle played again may have different results if you attack the left flank,  the AI opponents will react accordingly. 

I personally think that this game shines a light on a often overlooked genre of gaming, It harkens back to the days of "CWG 2" in the early 90's. I give it 5 stars.

If I could ask for more, the only thing I would like is more 'between battle' things to do, such as in "AGEODS American Civil War' allowing you to do various things with your funding. 

Of course naval action would be nice... and so would a longer campaign or eastern / western campaign. perhaps your main army is busy fighting 2nd Bull Run while another army is off in the Tennessee area on a different campaign.

Let me start by saying that I really do like this game. The elements of design are excellent, especially in terms of sound and graphics. Building divisions and brigades, arming them with quintesential weapons of the era, and assigning leadership is engaging and interesting. Getting into a nasty exchange of musketry and cannon fire is a gleeful pleasure to watch and winning said fights is rewarding. But where things begin to fall apart for me is when the game starts to get bigger. 


When I say bigger, I mean that in terms of the size of your army. Very rapidly, you will find yourself on titanically big maps, attempting to control dozens of units in an army that must be well over 70,000 men strong. You will also be forced to control that army in 1500-3000 man clumps, and organize them in a manner which will allow you to carry the day in battle. This is not easy. 

This game is, quite frankly, not meant for people like me who simply do not have the headspace to manage such a colossal endeavor.


The game really shines when you are on the defensive. The nature of commanding such a vast array of troops lends itself to defensive fighting in almost every way. Reaction times are not as readily punished on the defensive, and understanding where the enemy will likely move towards and planning ahead for that assault is incredibly rewarding. Going on offensives, however, is a different animal entirely. 


I truly believe that this game would beneift hugely from the inclusion of a cooperative game mode, wherein a friend could be given command of parts of your army. Being able to split the effort of commanding massive armies over multiple people (just like command structures in real life) would, in my very humble opinion, make this game one of the top 3 in my library today if not the very best.

I say this as a reenactor, a gamer, and a Civil War buff: I cannot recommend this game.

I rarely write game reviews, mostly because they don't usually hold my attention for long & after playing for a while I end up feeling "well that was good but it could have been so much better".  This game, however, I wholeheartedly endorse. 

I own its predecessor (Ultimate General Gettysburg) which, while an enjoyable game, had various shortcomings and a lack of replayability, all of which have been more than addressed in Civil War. There's dozens of different ways to approach the Campaign promising years of enjoyment. Supply lines, skirmishers, cavalry that can dismount - these have been added without increasing the need for micromanaging & turning battles into a chore. Line of sight is easier to understand than the previous game, making artillery much more effective - and it clearly shows when units are blocked, flanked, or simply need a rest from battle.

And then there's the whole economy side of things, with money and reputation earned from success in battle and allowing you to grow & equip the army under your command. In many games this kind of thing can be a confusing chore, but in Civil War its a delight.

If you're a fan of any kind of tabletop war gaming, I think you'll love this game. I know its going to soak up a lot of my limited spare time over the months & years ahead.

Trying to keep them all alive and victorious is fun challange. Super fun RTS game I highly recommend. I would love to see this engine applied to the Mexican American war or the war of 1812.

Don't get me wrong, I'm sure creating a good real time strategy game without cloning Total War, Age of Empires or even Warcraft is incredibly difficult, and I salute the team that made this for the effort, but I found this game nearly unplayable. Ironically, with fewer options to control units than a total war game, I found myself micromanaging everyone on the battlefield, constantly tweaking unit positions and orientations. Add to that the fact that the enemy AI follows the historically script pretty tightly (rather than reacting to player actions), and there's not much room for for actual strategy.

It's a bit different than the usual strategy games where a player strives to "decimate" the enemy. This is about attrition, and logical movements of your army. Top that with some RPG elements and resource management and you got a curry of fun. Takes a bit of time to get used to. Ultimate General: Civil War is a solid indie Civil War game and is well worth checking out for strategy fans and for people interested in the American Civil War. It's not quite the deep, complex, free-form Civil War game that I've been hoping to see from Creative Assembly's Total War series, but I can't really expect it to be. Overall, I recommend the game! It doesn't have the polish of a bigger-budget title, but what it does do well, it does really well, and it provides some deep and compelling strategy gaming.

Those of you who do try it out will find a game that does have some genuine innovations. Strategy game developers like Creative Assembly should definitely look closely at Ultimate General's unit movement commands. Drawing movement paths and including a "fall back" command are things that should probably become standard in real-time strategy games -- especially those with historical or realistic settings.

Super addictive game.  

There are three levels of difficulty, and while that may seem like not a huge deal, it really is.  

The easiest level allows those who like the quick action of moving pieces around the battle field and diving into battle; Quick action, fun action that requires some decision making on your part, without having to really dive into the micro-management aspect that might otherwise turn them off.  

The mid-range difficulty setting will require considerably more attention to detail regarding preparation and in-battle management.  Lots more of hitting the pause button during battle to make sure your units are positioned properly.  Once one of your units gets routed things can snowball quickly, so I find that hitting the pause button frequently, especially for larger battles, is a great benefit.  The downside, especially for those who favor point, click and let 'em fight style of play, is that it can get a little tedious to constantly pause the game.  I enjoy it, as it really lets you put your tactical skills to the test. But I can see how the frequent pausing can annoy some (or if they don't make adjustments, how they'll get frustrated with the AI's very competent moves).

The most challenging level leaves you with less money and manpower, plus the AI is quite challenging.  You really need to make smart decisions in camp, where you decide on the weapons to supply your army, and again, on the battlefield you'll need to really, really pay attention to how the battle is playing out.  Right now I've got my hands full on the regular difficulty level. Those who master this level have my full respect.

This is so much more than just a series of battles though.  As I touched on above, you'll have the option to choose the weapons (at a cost) to supply your infantry, cav, arty, and skirmishers.  And as you earn career points for victories you can use those points to improve things like politics, economy, medicine, etc.  Bottom line, you've got lots of options and how you prepare for upcoming battles does have a large impact on how those battles play out.

I do wish that things were not quite so "scripted" as some others have mentioned.  It would be nice if there was a way to re-write history based on the outcome of the battles, or for us to split our armies up, and navigate in various directions(and have the AI have that same freedom, choosing where we want to attack next, or move to defend.  Also, the constant pausing on the more difficult settings in order to make sure your units are properly positioned may be a grind for some people, though I don't mind personally. Regardless, there is still a lot of replay value, as you learn, tweak your strategy and tactics, move up in difficulty level, or switch sides.

Overall, I find this to be an outstanding, and after a few weeks, still very addictive game.  Highly recommended.

I've been playing this game off-and-on since its release and generally I enjoy it! I think this an all-around great RTS. 

However, I have a bit of a concern about some of the historical battles. They seem to be FAR too scripted based on historical events, leaving little room for real player strategy. For example, in the Stones River battle, as the Union, I managed to to the CSA left flank and ball up his army against the river by the end of the second scenario of the battle (which extends to first scenario). However, by the third scenario, the game basically tossed away all my gains, balled my army up on the road, and left me with CSA troops on three sides (presumably per the history of the battle). It basically made all my efforts futile. 

In a second, more recent example, during the Chancellorsville scenario, I managed to secure both the Plank Road objectives with the Union Army on the second scenario (the Stonewall Jackson flank attack scenario). But, like Stones River, by the third scenario my army was balled into a haphazard perimeter around that farmhouse per history and all my gains were lost. What made it particularly worse was that after I won the third scenario, I had to RETAKE all that ground I had already earned. 

What's the point of fighting these battles if the player is simply locked into script that decides the outcome regardless of how well I do? It's very frustrating. . . .

UPDATE: returning to UGCV months later, I became quite addicted to it. I've had  lots of fun playing it, enough so to change my recommendation.  Learning the game is easy (get in cover, always flank, between battles improve troop quantity and quality) but the subtler aspects of tactics are challenging, esp on hard (baiting the enemy, forcing him to fight out of cover, distracting units, cavalry raiding in the rear). 

That being said the game is still quirky: units doing bizarre things because they lose LOS to their target, entrenchments being often useless. rare weapons being rather ineffective. However, the quirks are minor and the game shines enough overall, to keep you coming back.

The game is not at all difficult to get into, especially if you start on easy but there are times that you need to keep a cool head and think about the bigger strategy and not merely the battles themselves.

This game is exceptionly great. It is a great follow up to Gettysburg. The devs may be russian but they are very transparent with thier work, and they reach out to the community for feedback on new updates and what should be included in the future. Something that most game developers lack these days (And they update frequently). For the game itself there are few drawbacks but we will get back to that. But first the good things about this game.

It greatly protrays the civil war, what happens in the battles in game could've easily happend in real life. And if you know your history you can easily make what happens be some what historical. 

The ai is not perfect, but this is ai were talking about and for the company and the game I think the ai is beautiful. They dont make to to many odd choices. You can find the ai choosing to leave its cannon behind and retreating it's infantry but once again its ai.

The graphics are beautiful, it fits the game perfectly. It's not "ultra realistic" But it doesnt need to be, if it was I feel like the game wouldnt be as good as it is now. 

The mechanics are great, you can do a lot with your soldiers and sometimes if they are too tired or are scared they wont follow orders which is just amazing. The addative to supply makes you have to plan out your battles a lot more indepth as you need to get all your divisions and cannons supply. The ability to create your army is so fun and it makes you feel more attached to your soldiers and leaders, making you question if you should charge that unit with 16 cannons. 

There's a lot more than I will list here but now for the complaints.

The inabiliy to rotate the camera really bums me out but from what the devs say the way they textured the world it sounds like its not textured on the other side.

There are a few bugs still that can be a bit odd such as a unit deciding to have a seziure collectively.

The tutorial is just a bunch of reading, luckily ive played gettysburg so I knew what I was doing but for a new player an interactive tutorial would be quite handy.

The clock can be confusing as non of the speeds actually last one second.

All in All 9.8/10

August the 15th, 2017

Dear Sarah,

The indications are very strong that we shall leave for work soon-- perhaps tomorrow. Lest I should not be able to write you again, I feel impelled to write lines on this masterful strategic simulator that may fall under your eye when I shall be no more.

You may find the complexities of control, slow pace, and lack of text over hard-to-identify unit icons difficult. You may find the lack of a topographical mapmode severely difficult when placing artillery. I know how strongly you reacted to this game's predecessor, UG: Gettysburg. We owe a great a debt to that title that came before this one now. And I am willing—perfectly willing—to accept that this title suffers from the same limitations of Gettysburg—simplistic flanking mechanics, a steamrolling Union campaign—to help support this game, and to pay that debt.

But, my dear wife, when I know that you will experience the new depth that resource management, equipment management, and the political system brings, my own joys lay down nearly all of yours. You will encounter one of the most adapatable and intuititive AIs seen since the golden age of Close Combat games—even better than Gettysburg. You will enjoy the care and depth of each major battle—none repetitive, none ignored nor half-measured—and the pleasure of reading AI news dispatched begging for reinforcements against your victorious march. You will appreciate how the games resourcing forces you to choose between a retreat that preserves your army, or a last-stand to defend a capture point.

Sarah, my love for the maps and unit graphics is deathless, it seems to bind me to each battle with mighty cables that nothing but Omnipotence could break; and yet my love of Country comes over me like a strong wind and bears me irresistibly on with all these chains to the battlefield for I cannot bear to play the Confederates yet.

Forgive this game's few UI faults, and the many pains its drop-prone multiplayer have caused you. How thoughtless and foolish enemy brigades can sometimes be, standing still in open cover and taking 50-60% losses without retreat! How gladly would I wash out with my tears every little spot upon your happiness, and struggle with all the misfortune of this world, to shield you and my children from harm. But I cannot. To enjoy this game is to understand that while no perfect tactical simulation game exists, as far as the Civil War genre goes, Ultimate General: CiviI War is as close to one as exists on Steam.

Sarah, do not mourn me dead; think I am gone and wait for me, for we shall meet again. O Sarah, I wait for you there! Come to me, and lead thither my children.

There's quite a few problems with this game that make it so i can't recommend it in it's current state,

This is sort of a minor issue but in the campaign you get to create a custom general as sort of an avatar, But you don't get to change his appearance so he just uses one of the random portraits.

There's a lot of weapon variety in the campaign, But with a lot of the weapons they never appear in large enough numbers to actually arm units with so for the most part. And there's about 9 minie muskets with seemingly random stats, along with the fact that you have to give a unit a completely uniform armament means that you could have 2,499 lorenz rifles in your armory, But you're going to be stuck equipping your men with 1842 smoothbore muskets because you can't give them a single enfield rifle, It would have been cool to have these rifles with their unique names and descriptions but combine them into a single pool of weapons, Especially considering that confederate made arms are almost exclusively copies of weapons that already exist in the game eg. CS Richmond = Harpers Ferry 1855

The Organization in the game is weird, You have brigades which are your units under divisions which are under corps and you have to have officers as divisional, corps and brigade commanders for your units... But the divisional commanders don't appear in the battle at all, The corps officers operate like the generals in Total War boosting moral and effectiveness of troops within a radius and the brigade officers are commanding the units, But the divisional commanders are seemingly spanking their monkey back at camp.

The campaign is structured poorly, No matter if you win or lose a battle it continues to the next battle in an hisorical timeline, Only to abrupty shift from Cold Harbor to taking either richmond or Washington based on if you're the Union or Confederates. The heavy focus on history is good for single battles like in Gettysburg. But when you have a full campaign you're going to get whiplash from suddenly going from winning the war, to losing the war to suddenly defeating your enemy in a climactic final battle. Like the way the confederate campaign is structured.

And finally the game is objective and time limit focused in a really bad way, turning enemy soldiers into casualties and routing them doesn't help in the slightest since they have infinite amounts of manpower that scales based on the size of your army, The only viable strategy is to put the least amount of effort as you can towards completing your objective. so you can preserve your forces and not get fired, Making the game a whole lot of cheese. that in itself is the biggest reason i'd never recommend this game to anyone in it's current state. I hope we'll get mod support for the game some day so someone can fix these issues.

This is a great game, its built on the success of UG: Gettysburg to make one of the best games based on the American Civil War.

The game itself is divided between the campaign camp where you create/reinforce the units of Infantry/Cavalry/Artillery of your army and the battle map which cover the main engagements of the civil war as well as many minor engagements in-between them. 

The campaign camp is quite simplistic, each part of your army is separated into Corps with several Divisions in each. These Divisions are then made up of infantry brigades (the bulk of any army) skirmishers (fast moving infantry but in small numbers) Cavalry (vulnerable when mounted but either great dismountable skirmishers or melee experts) and artillery of various sizes to give you long ranged firepower or devastating shorter-range canister shots.
 These units are persistent between battles and all can all be reinforced with green recruits or veterans (who cost more) from a manpower pool that increases depending on battle success.  Weapons are either purchased or captured in battle, reflecting the superiority of the Union industry the confederates also have issues with getting access to as many weapons but seem to have better officers. 

Battles are selected from the campaign map; the smaller battles are usually only for a maximum of 1 or 2 corps but grant lower rewards than the main ones. They also have some kind of effect on the main battle, so victory in them will deplete the enemy army or lower their morale for example. 
Controlling an army is simple, you can select units and drag an arrow to select their route or right click on a location so they move directly towards it. Finesse can be applied to rotate units by holding right mouse button, allowing flanking shots which devastate morale. There is a lot more to this game than just the basic parts I have explained here but Steam reviews can get a bit long so will leave it there! 

This game has been an excellent example of early access, the developer released a series of main battles which they then expanded out on a regular basis until its full launch in recent months. There were no real delays and consistent updates and information given to the community. The lack of multiplayer is a shame but since uptake of this feature in Gettysburg was very low it would have delayed the game significantly so I think the developers made the correct decision.

This a difficult review for me to write because I wanted so much to like this game.  I was a huge fan of Ultimate General Gettysburg (UGG) and was really excited that the developers were going to make a sequel but sadly it feels like all the changes they made created an experience that had more breadth than the original but also far less depth with respect to the history and the subject matter involved.  A lot of the mechanics also seemed to have been "dumbed down" for the lack of a better term.

Ultimate General Civil War is nominally a brigade level tactical strategy game with a strategic overlayer set in the American Civil War.  The core game play experience involves maneuvering brigades of troops and batteries of artillery to re-fight battles that occurred during the war.  The game attempts to model factors such as morale or troops, the amount of cover they have to work with in any given terrain they are placed, and overall fighting effectiveness in a stat they call "condition".  Most of the game is played on an overhead view where you direct units into positions on a battle map.  The best comparison would be the Total War series and the control scheme is very similar.  In the campaign mode, this is supplemented by a strategy layer where your success or failure affects your ability to acquire "funds" and a manpower pool from which to improve your army.  You can add new brigades, supply replacements to offset casualties, equip them with better weapons as they become available and assign commanders to each unit.  Losses sustained in the tactical game mode carry over from battle to battle and troops that fight and survive gain veteran bonuses that can scale dramatically so it creates a strong incentive to preserve troops.

On the positive side, the game retains and improves its excellent visuals from its predecessor.  All the maps are beautifully presented and despite the fact the men are abstracted, the game conveys scale very well by showing small images of soldiers marching in formation and loading and firing of their weapons.  The interface is also largely untouched from the previous allowing you the traditional select, click to move for units and also the drawing of movement paths in the shape of arrows to more precisely outline routes.  Additional functionality has been added to be able to deploy multiple brigades into line at a particular location cutting down on the amount of clicking one needs to do.

The game does feature a very large number of maps.  All major battles of the Eastern Theater are in the game as well as several notable battles of the Western Theater.  In addition over 35 smaller battles and skirmishes are in the game in the form of side missions in the campaign that a player can complete to get extra rewards and weaken the computer opponent prior to a major battle.  It is advisable to complete all of them with some exceptions which will be noted below.  Overall the campaign features a good reward system where good performance means a better army with more veteran units which allows you to 'snowball' somewhat.  

The tradeoff for this campaign system and the dilution of focus away from a single battle to covering the entire Civil War though has lead to some serious downsides and is definitely a big minus for the game.  The first major issue is that in covering so many battles, it fails to present choice and consequence within some of the more complex multiday battles that they attempt to model.  In many multiday battles such as Chickamauga and Shiloh, your results do not carry over from day to day.  A typical example would be the Union army managing to fight off the surprise attack and hold onto the perimeter at Shiloh Church.  At the end of the day, the game will disregard whatever territory you held and proceed to start day 2 at its historical jumping off point at Pittsburg Landing carrying over only casualties sustained and inflicted.

This is especially jarring for veteran players of the predecessor UGG which carefully sculpted multiple branching scenarios and offered overall strategy choices for the player and the computer opponent.  If the Union held Seminary ridge on day 1, UGG would offer a spate of scenarios on day 2 which would make fit with your accomplishments on day 1.  In UG Civil War, the game jarringly throws you back onto Cementery Hill and Cementery Ridge regardless of what happened.  The entire experience is railroaded onto historical timelines regardless of whether those strategies executed even make sense given what the player's actions are.   Part of historical war gaming is the "what if" factor, the joy of exploring different outcomes even if it is only within the confines of a game.  Ultimate General Civil War offers none of that.

This is compounded by the fact that since you customize and make your own army during the campaign, the order of battle and rosters of divisions for the battles it models will inevitably be inaccurate.  When you fight Antietam during the campaign, it will not be with Hooker's Corps in the north and Burnside's south at the bridge.  The battles you fight and win have no effect on the campaign.  Did you crush Stonewall Jackson at Second Manassas?  Well despite destroying half of Lee's army Antietam will happen anyways.  Victories and defeats very quickly feels meaningless beyond trying to win in order to earn more money to get better gear for you men and raise more brigades.

The Historical Battles option in the game somewhat alleviate this issue by supplying the player with a historical order of battle for scenarios but they still suffer from the issue of not adjusting to player gains or losses on positions and shoehorning the player to historical outcomes regardless of what happens in game.  As such, a player's ability to explore the alternative histories of any individual battle is severely limited and feels shallow and unsatisfying.

Whats more, weapons are modeled seemingly for the sake of having some sort of selection in the game.  Their statistics are not at all reflective of reality.  Examples include the game offering the player a variety of muskets to outfit each brigade.  You have old smoothbore 1842, Springfield models 1855, 1861, and 1863.  For some bizarre reason, the old smoothbore 1842s have a very high melee rating compared to later rifled muskets.  There is no historical basis for this.  It leads to bizarre player choices like having a dedicated assault brigades armed with old 1842s simply because they do better in melee.  Similarly, Springfield muskets 1855 to 1863 are pretty much identical in terms of battlefield performance, yet the game would have you believe that the 1863 can shoot significantly farther and more accurately than an 1855.  This type of arcade management for the sake of having it is unwelcome from this player's point of view.

Finally the tactical gameplay changes arguably make the game worse by stripping tactical complexity, creating needless micromanagement, and adding absurdly unrealistic tactics which are even more egregious than an arcade style title like the Total War series.  One exceedingly offending example follows.

You have the ability to fire into melee combat with any and all weapons and not result in any friendly losses.  This creates absurd situations where you line up cannon and veteran troops equipped with weapons that have a good ranged shot rating behind poorly eqipped expendable brigades that will shield your troops and cannon from fire and when they engage in melee your good troops and cannon then fire INTO the melee and absolutely massacre the enemy brigades with no ill consequence.  This was a staple tactic on defense I used repeatedly.

Overall this game is a serious downgrade from Ultimate General Gettysburg.  I cannot recommend this game.

Great game, well worth the money. You need to play a year or two of a campaign to get an idea of how the game plays, until you do get that fundamental grasp of the game it is a bit overwhelming. 

The level of detail in how you organise and equip your army is a fantastic feature for the obsessive compulsive minded. I have not seen anything like this in any other tactical wargame. 

Note that this game is all about flanking. Secure your flanks to ensure you don't lose; ensure you are able to roll up the enemy's flank to achieve victory. The casualty rate for flanked units seems artifically high. For artillery one could justify high casualties if round ball bounced along an entire line of infantry, but rifle shot would not affect more soldiers just because you have a side angle. One other annoying feature is that you often don't have much freedom to choose the initial placement of your army, or the time and rate of reinforcements in large battles. Tht is a minor gripe though - overall I am very happy with this game.

I'm currently 25 hours into this game, and I'm giving it a qualified 'Thumbs Up' mainly because I am currently enjoying it and to do otherwise would seem unfair.  If there was a middle option I would probably have gone for that instead.

The issue for me is the sort of 'Rights of Passage' arrangement chosen for the first two missions in each campaign.  Most strategy gamers would expect the early missions in any campaign to be reasonably easy, and merely intended to ease the player into the use of the game system with a minimal  challenge.

Not so, with this game.  So, far I can honestly say that the first two battles in both the USA and CSA campaigns have been the most difficult and frustrating of any that I have fought since.  Apart from the nature of the missions themsevles, which are very challenging for a new player, the game employs a scaling mechanism which if the player is not aware of it can make the second battle in each campaign even harder than it needs to be by artificially boosting the AI's troop numbers.  This despite the claims that that the scaling has been removed.  It hasn't, it has merely been scaled down, and after mission 2 it ceases to have much of an impact, but for new players whose natural instinct is to maximise the size of their army after the first battle it is a major headache adding anything up to 2.000 extra troops to the AI army.

I suspect that like me many new players will struggle to complete the first two battles in each campaign and many probably give up and stop playing the game.  I am lucky in that I kept banging away at these early missions, partly because I was trying to work out how the scaling worked, and having finally got past them I have found the game much more enjoyable.

Not sure what the developers were going for with the decision to make these early battles so hard to complete, but if it was to put players off playing the game I'm sure it has been a stunning success.  If you are thinking of buying this game, or struggling to get past the second battle, you have my sympathy, but keep plugging away.  The game gets much better afterwards.

This game is as good a tactical simulation of the U.S. Civil War as has likely ever existed.  Unlike other tactical battlefield simulations (e.g., Scourge of War), It is surprisingly easy to learn.  Yet it provides incredibly challenging gameplay through a tactically diverse array of scenarios coupled with a clever and unrelenting AI.  

The game offers the ability to play out the major engagements of the war, such as Antietam, Gettysburg, and Cold Harbor, as well as custom battles.  Most impressive, however, is the game's campaign feature, which allows you to create your own general and lead your army through the course of the conflict.  You will develop your general's skill set as you struggle to supply, develop, and organize your forces.  In the end, however, even the best equipped and trained armies can be reduced to a routed mob by poor decisions on the battlefield.  This game will put your abilities as a digital general to the test, time and time again.

I would highly recommend this to anyone interested in the U.S. Civil War, or who enjoys challenging tactical gameplay.  It should be noted that multiplayer is not presently supported—look to its predecessor, Ultimate General:  Gettysburg, if you want that.  But the single player experience is second-to-none.  Queue up a good Civil War soundtrack on YouTube, and settle into your saddle as you try to either preserve the Union, or prevail in the Second War of Independence.

This is a game that I really want to love.  I very much enjoyed UG:Gettysburg and much of what makes that game successful was transferred here.  The strategic layer that was added as the stepping stone between the mostly historical battles in this game is fun and I spent a lot of time tweaking my units.  History buffs may want to suspend disbelief at that camp screen as the base rifle for all units is called "farmer" or "hunter".  Not sure why units couldn't just start out with historical weapons, but oh well.  Also smoothbore muskets are given weaker damage and there seems to be no knowledge on the parts of the developers on the use of "buck and ball" for smoothbores which was devastating for units at close range (Irish Brigade loved their .69 smoothbores).  But that is a minor quible.  The heart of the game is the tactical battles, a la UG:G.  Here is where the real problems occur.  Often times a battle goes really well and occurs in a way that tactically makes sense and is historically accurate, even if you lose you still understand why.  Sometimes, battles turn into situations where AI hordes are charging all over the screen.  When these situations occur you will now find yourself in a battle that seems to resemble the Total War series.  There seems to be little rhyme or reason why one unit breaks or holds fast in these situations.  I've seen vastly outnumber units hold firm against a charge and I've seen three star units of superior strength run for the hills.  Also, surrendering seems to be totally random.  The most frustruating flaw in the tactical battles is the enemy units penchant for routing through your lines, regrouping and then taking rear objectives.  Some of the battles need to have their maps redrawn.  I was able to inflict 3 to 1 casualties on the US AI at Antietam, but could not help getting overrun on Marye's Heights at Fredericksburg.  The scale on the Fredericksburg map seems to be off and results in the Union troops starting really close to the Confederate troops.  Fredericksburg is the site of another frustration, which is that on some maps you get to repair your unit dispositions and other times you don't.  I can't explain why the Confederate commander cannot lay out his troops for Fredericksburg, a battle where the confederates were on the defense and had days to prepare their positions.  Also, the defensive strongpoints on most maps will actually lead a novice player to their doom as the AI rarely attacks those locations front a direction that would be beneficial to those units.  Unlike UG:G, there are no terrain lines and you have really no idea where is best to locate artillery for observation and advantage.  I learned to keep my artillery really close to the front because there seems to be no damage advantage to owning the heigher ground.  It seems to be impossible to kill opposing generals even if they walk into multiple infantry volleys.  Overall, it is a game with a lot of potential and if you don't mind reloading a battle multiple times after the AI routes multiple units into your rear area then you will enjoy it.

This game offers an extraordinarily satisfying and engrossing experience. The AI is among the best I’ve seen in a tactical RTS game. This game is complex and very challenging, but relatively easy to get the hang of after a few hours of play.

The most difficult aspect of the game is simply managing your army between battles, especially early on. It can be quite challenging to know how best to invest your finite money and reputation points ahead of time. In addition, there’s a dizzying variety of period accurate weapons available to equip your army with. Here too is a delicate balancing act that one must perform with limited resources. Most of the best weapons, as one would expect, are extremely scarce and expensive and only gradually become available as the game progresses. If you’re playing as the Confederacy, you’ll find yourself equipping new brigades with mostly captured weapons.

That said, I really like that there’s an added incentive to not just win a battle, but to inflict as many casualties on your enemy as possible. Doing so will directly affect the number of troops your opponent will have available for deployment in the next battle, not to mention adding to your cache of captured weapons. You’ll definitely find yourself on occasion playing long past the allotted time in order to bloody your opponent as much as possible, especially when you have the upper hand in a battle.

Overall, simply a great gaming experience.

[b][i]Ultimate General: Civil War[/i][/b] is a strategy game by Game-Labs that puts you right in the middle of the bloodiest battle America has ever seen, a battle without which the United States might never have become the United States.

You play the role of a commander who's trying to fight your way through the ranks not only to lead your men to victory but also to further your own career and ensure you play a significant role in America's future. Assemble your regiments, arm them and set out to meet the enemy in some of the most famous battles from this iconic confrontation. 

The battlefields are really good looking with lifelike forests and fields of various colors and shapes. After a battle, the field will be strewn with dead bodies and artillery craters which look fantastic.

The audio follows in the footsteps of the visual design in being rather excellent.

The original game was popular and [b][i]Ultimate General: Civil War[/i][/b]  is set to follow in the same footsteps. The scenery is incredibly well designed and creates some spectacular battlefields where you can relive these historic fights.

[b]THE GOOD[/b]
- Detailed armory
- Visually stunning battlefields
- Realistic sound effects

[b]THE BAD[/b]
- Some erratic army behavior

[h1]9/10[/h1]

DISASTER | BAD | MEDIOCRE | OKAY | GOOD | GREAT | [b][u]AMAZING[/u][/b] | MASTERPIECE
